Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Sw1218 my prostate volume is 31mL. this was noted in may of 2017 on my MRI. if 90% of prostate inflammation cases do not involve bacteria and do not respond to antibiotics, then why am i being prescribed with cipro? it seems to be a waste of time to take the drug. it would seem that i am just taking it to have something written on paper. i'm not saying this at you, but that doesn't help my anxiety. Table 1, Category 3 of this Harvard Medical School Article cites the 90 percent statistic. But, as you read the article, you see how complex and varied prostatitis is. Prescription of antibiotics could maybe help in some cases, so they do it. https://www.harvardprostateknowledge...e-for-optimism

Numbers 1, 2, and 5 were negative. Numbers 3,4, and 6 were positive with 5% Gleason(3+3) found. Last one was Precision Point transperineal. PSA 4.4, fPSA 24, PHI 32 Hopefully, I can remain untreated. Posts.Title: My PSA Result is 10

Posts.Content: Fred, In 2015, the World Health Organization adopted new risk classification criteria for prostate cancer, which was developed by Johns Hopkins using decades of data. The primary revision in the new standards is the separation of G 3+4 into a new, "low intermediate" class, and G 4+3 as "high intermediate". So, that doctor's comment seems out of date. As far as the time for a G 3+4 to grow and escape the capsule, there is no certain data. There are G 3+4 men who have been in active surveillance for many years, although they do have a higher risk than the G 3+3 men. Their fifteen year survival rate without treatment is 84 percent in the latest Sunnybrook study. Not great, but worth knowing. Have you had genomic tests done on your biopsy slides? These tests, like OncotypeDX and Prolaris, can help predict the future aggressiveness of the cancer. Mine were a decisive factor in my going on AS. In my limited knowledge, you have a mixed bag of factors that could justify treatment now, or holding off for more testing, consultations, and research. Only one small lesion being seen on an MRI could argue in favor of not rushing to a decision. Will there be a magic vaccine out next year? ...probably not, but you need to be fully comfortable in calculating your decision. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Cipro is a powerful antibiotic, but it often has no effect on prostatitis. I have read that about 90 percent of prostate inflammation cases do not involve bacteria and do not respond to antibiotics. They just come and go on their own, (sitz baths help in some cases). What is your prostate density (PSAD)? Your prostate volume should have been noted on your MRI, and is probably larger now. The PHI, 4K Score, or PCA3 tests could add some more data points to your analysis. Right now, it would appear that you have what was diagnosed in August 2014, and just have to follow your uro's advice. If you are not comfortable doing that, then getting more opinions is always a good choice.

Posts.Content: PNI by itself would not be a game changer for me. Nor would four cores with relatively small involvement. They are all on the same side, which makes them less risky by Johns Hopkins revised AS criteria. But, with a positive DRE, and going from knowing about one core to discovering four, I can appreciate your wanting to take action. My research would lead me to select SBRT/Cyberknife, but others also have valid preferences, and all treatments are likely to give you curative results. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 While I am not a fan of super-star Dr. Samadi, just to throw a little gasoline on the Cyberknife discussion, here are his thoughts on the subject from his website: Q. What are the side effects of Cyber Knife? A. The negative side effects of CyberKnifeÂ® can be expected to mirror those of other targeted radiation therapies. Over the short term, radiation therapy for prostate cancer can cause: Urination problems including burning and blood in the urine Urinary urgency and frequency Weakened urinary stream Incomplete emptying of the bladder Anal and rectal irritation, rectal bleeding, hemorrhoids, and stool problems Fatigue and nausea Long-term CyberKnifeÂ® and prostate cancer radiation side effects may include: Sexual impotence and/or erectile dysfunction for up to 2 years after treatment Delayed orgasm or ejaculation Temporary or permanent reduction in sperm count; fertility should be discussed with your physician prior to CyberKnifeÂ® treatment Impaired bowel function Potential increased risk of bladder or rectal cancer by 5% And post-treatment patient satisfaction surveys repeatedly show Cyberknife as the LEAST popular method of treating prostate cancer, primarily due to radiation burns from the massive doses of radiation versus the decades-old gold standard of 35 - 40 sessions of EBRT. Jim, Samadi is super-arrogant. I saw him on a TV news show a couple of years ago, and he was seriously bad-mouthing Dr. Patrick Walsh and open prostatectomy in general. If you were to take Samadi's advice, every treatment besides RALP is invalid. Well, he is entertaining Michael, I like your humor, but I hope to not have to change my handle anytime soon.

Posts.Title: Are we ready to use hypofractionated instead of conventional RT for PCa? Not yet

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH With four positive cores, Active Surveillance is probably not the best way to proceed. I respectfully disagree with the Cyberknife suggestion for 2 reasons: 1- it is a relatively new treatment technique that probably does not have a lengthy track record yet 2- A biopsy can only sample about 1/100th of the prostate. This is a reason why around 28% of surgery patients end up with a higher Gleason score than detected by the biopsy. In other words, there could be other tumors in there that were missed by the biopsy -- and a focal treatment suck as cyberknife (as far as I know) only hits the known tumors. If there are other tumors in there, they would go untreated. My personal suggestion would be for you to consider external beam radiation, brachytherapy (radioactive seeding) or surgery. Any of these three options would involve the ENTIRE prostate and, thus, any other tumors that might be in there. Fortunately, your low PSA "suggests" that there is probably nothing more than Gleason 3+3 in there, so you should be just fine no matter what treatment you might choose -- as long as there are no higher Gleason tumors in there. Good luck! Chuck Two facts: 1. SBRT/Cyberknife is a whole gland treatment. It uses a precision targeting system to deliver highly focused radiation dosages. It is no more "focal" than a surgical cut, an EBRT beam, or a brachy seed. All whole gland treatments involve a series of local actions. 2. SBRT/Cyberknife is not new. It was FDA approved in 2001, and has treated over 40,000 patients, with the numbers sharply increasing in recent years. http://meetinglibrary.asco.org/record/119573/abstract https://www.sciencedaily.com/release...0418145458.htm

Posts.Content: The Tesla ratings of 1.5 and 3 refer to the power of the machine. "mp" means that the machine's software is set up to record three assays, which greatly increases the value for analyzing prostate cancer. The PIRADS score is generated by those three assays. An endorectal coil or an apron coil can be used with either 1.5 or 3 machines. The ERC was recommended with 1.5, but not required on the 3T. Trust me, you do not want the ERC, as it is extremely uncomfortable. Think of being reamed with a police baton. The apron coil is no problem. Both machines use a contrast dye, which is intravenously injected.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by akhlak Dear Sir, I am 45 years old. On February 2017, I checked my PSA level found 6.83 ng/ml and Gleason’s Grade 3+3=6/10 by biopsy test. On April 2017, my doctor suggested me to take Hormone Therapy (3 Zoladex Injection). Already I have taken two injections. He also suggested me to take Calutide tablets 50mg per day without any surgery. On June 17, 2017, again I have checked my PSA found 1.37 ng/ml. And one month later, on July 20, 2017, I found my PSA Level 0.57 ng/ml. Could you please give me your opinion or advice at my present situation? Kind Regards, M. A Zaman Hi Akhlak, I recall posting a comment on one of your previous posts on some forum. Glad to hear that your psa is now so low, but Those drugs are approved for advanced prostate cancer...and they are being prescribed for you as a first line treatment? Zoladex was approved by the FDA for prostate cancer in 1989, but I never read about anyone taking it. Are you in southeast Asia? Are these drugs considered mainstream treatments in your country? I can appreciate your not wanting surgery, but how effective is this treatment in the long term? Sorry that I don't have an answer for you, but I hope that another member with knowledge of these drugs can comment.

Posts.Content: The most effective RT regimen for high risk PCa is EBRT + BBT ( brachy boost). While the study mentions that some men had BBT, it did not do a comparison of that regimen versus RP. Also, SBRT is now being used in some trials to replace the brachytherapy. While this following study was not age-restricted, it produced quite different conclusions. https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jam...rticle/2673969

Posts.Title: PCa-Specific Mortality with RP versus RT for Localized High Grade PCa in men < 60 yr

Posts.Content: Like the above members, I am puzzled as to why action has not been taken based on that biopsy. Regarding intermediate-risk PCa and Active Surveillance, I just received a publication from my specialist, H. Ballentine Carter, MD, who pioneered AS in the United States. He concluded that men with low-intermediate-risk (G3+4) prostate cancer were 4.5 to 5 times more likely to have aggressive tumors requiring immediate treatment than men in lower-risk groups. Also, that the research did not find any "favorable" sub-group among low-intermediate-risk patients who would benefit from active surveillance. So, yes, the time for inaction is past. You need to research and select a type of treatment.

In my limited knowledge, you have a mixed bag of factors that could justify treatment now, or holding off for more testing, consultations, and research. Only one small lesion being seen on an MRI could argue in favor of not rushing to a decision. Will there be a magic vaccine out next year? ...probably not, but you need to be fully comfortable in calculating your decision. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Am I making the right choice for surgery now.

Posts.Content: Djin, if the efficacy is non-Inferior, as far as has been shown, in multiple studies, why are we even discussing the value of hypofractionation? As I was told face-to-face with the chief RO of a major medical center in my (DC) area, the ROs choice is dictated by the insurance companies reimbursement. He said that he could do SBRT in ONE session, but they would pay him much more for 44 sessions of IMRT. So, well, you see my point.
Posts.Title: Are we ready to use hypofractionated instead of conventional RT for PCa? Not yet

Posts.Content: The most effective RT regimen for high risk PCa is EBRT + BBT ( brachy boost). While the study mentions that some men had BBT, it did not do a comparison of that regimen versus RP. Also, SBRT is now being used in some trials to replace the brachytherapy. While this following study was not age-restricted, it produced quite different conclusions. https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jam...rticle/2673969

I would suggest another blood draw, this time using the PHI test, which is more accurate than psa. (It does also provide psa and free psa numbers). And, no sex of any kind, bike riding or working out for at least 2-3 days before the draw. Good luck.

Posts.Title: SM88 therapeutic treatment for cancer

Posts.Content: Like the above members, I am puzzled as to why action has not been taken based on that biopsy. Regarding intermediate-risk PCa and Active Surveillance, I just received a publication from my specialist, H. Ballentine Carter, MD, who pioneered AS in the United States. He concluded that men with low-intermediate-risk (G3+4) prostate cancer were 4.5 to 5 times more likely to have aggressive tumors requiring immediate treatment than men in lower-risk groups. Also, that the research did not find any "favorable" sub-group among low-intermediate-risk patients who would benefit from active surveillance. So, yes, the time for inaction is past. You need to research and select a type of treatment.

They are all on the same side, which makes them less risky by Johns Hopkins revised AS criteria. But, with a positive DRE, and going from knowing about one core to discovering four, I can appreciate your wanting to take action. My research would lead me to select SBRT/Cyberknife, but others also have valid preferences, and all treatments are likely to give you curative results. Good luck.

What are the side effects of Cyber Knife? A. The negative side effects of CyberKnifeÂ® can be expected to mirror those of other targeted radiation therapies. Over the short term, radiation therapy for prostate cancer can cause: Urination problems including burning and blood in the urine Urinary urgency and frequency Weakened urinary stream Incomplete emptying of the bladder Anal and rectal irritation, rectal bleeding, hemorrhoids, and stool problems Fatigue and nausea Long-term CyberKnifeÂ® and prostate cancer radiation side effects may include: Sexual impotence and/or erectile dysfunction for up to 2 years after treatment Delayed orgasm or ejaculation Temporary or permanent reduction in sperm count; fertility should be discussed with your physician prior to CyberKnifeÂ® treatment Impaired bowel function Potential increased risk of bladder or rectal cancer by 5% And post-treatment patient satisfaction surveys repeatedly show Cyberknife as the LEAST popular method of treating prostate cancer, primarily due to radiation burns from the massive doses of radiation versus the decades-old gold standard of 35 - 40 sessions of EBRT. Jim, Samadi is super-arrogant. I saw him on a TV news show a couple of years ago, and he was seriously bad-mouthing Dr. Patrick Walsh and open prostatectomy in general. If you were to take Samadi's advice, every treatment besides RALP is invalid. Well, he is entertaining Michael, I like your humor, but I hope to not have to change my handle anytime soon.

Posts.Content: N.A.H, I am very surprised at the advice that you received from that radiation oncologist. There are five very different types of primary radiation therapy: IMRT, SBRT, LDR-BT, HDR-BT, and PBT (Proton Beam). What was his specialty? It sounds like he maybe was doing IMRT on salvage patients after RP failed. His reasoning about radiation after surgery is an expected talking point of surgeons, and is highly misleading. There are actually several salvage options should a primary radiation treatment fail. These include HIFU, SBRT, HDR-BT, FLA, and IRE. All have studies proving their efficacy. And, you would do well to compare the recent studies on the failure rate of surgery versus SBRT and HDR-BT. The results may get you thinking twice about consulting with more RO's. Just my input. Take it as you wish. Good luck to you.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH With four positive cores, Active Surveillance is probably not the best way to proceed. I respectfully disagree with the Cyberknife suggestion for 2 reasons: 1- it is a relatively new treatment technique that probably does not have a lengthy track record yet 2- A biopsy can only sample about 1/100th of the prostate. This is a reason why around 28% of surgery patients end up with a higher Gleason score than detected by the biopsy. In other words, there could be other tumors in there that were missed by the biopsy -- and a focal treatment suck as cyberknife (as far as I know) only hits the known tumors. If there are other tumors in there, they would go untreated. My personal suggestion would be for you to consider external beam radiation, brachytherapy (radioactive seeding) or surgery. Any of these three options would involve the ENTIRE prostate and, thus, any other tumors that might be in there. Fortunately, your low PSA "suggests" that there is probably nothing more than Gleason 3+3 in there, so you should be just fine no matter what treatment you might choose -- as long as there are no higher Gleason tumors in there. Good luck! Chuck Two facts: 1. SBRT/Cyberknife is a whole gland treatment. It uses a precision targeting system to deliver highly focused radiation dosages. It is no more "focal" than a surgical cut, an EBRT beam, or a brachy seed. All whole gland treatments involve a series of local actions. 2. SBRT/Cyberknife is not new. It was FDA approved in 2001, and has treated over 40,000 patients, with the numbers sharply increasing in recent years. http://meetinglibrary.asco.org/record/119573/abstract https://www.sciencedaily.com/release...0418145458.htm

Posts.Title: clamps

Posts.Content: There have been recent studies showing no difference in recurrence between high risk men who had immediate surgery, and those who waited for six months. So, dont be panicked into treatment before you have your thoughts clear. You mentioned protons. They have excellent outcomes, with five year recurrence rates of less than ten percent for intermediate risk men like yourself. Cyberknife/SBRT has similar statistics. The recurrence rates for surgery run from 25 to 40 percent, depending on which study. Surgery first, followed by radiation is what many surgeons recommend. But, that subjects you to the side effects of both treatments, and it is radiation that finally stops the cancer. Think that over. And, if there should be a failure of primary radiation, there are several effective non-surgical treatments available to you. Keep asking, and certainly have more consultations. You have to be fully confident with your choice of treatment.

Posts.Title: New diagnosis - High numbers - some pressure to rush treatment from urologist

Posts.Content: Allmo, Thanks for this detailed post. Last year, I attended a support group meeting where a veteran urologist did a slide show presenting the same facts as you did. His conclusion was that PSA testing was only saving one man per one thousand tested.. The men in the room were pretty much in an uproar, as they respected that doctor, but refused to accept the conclusion. It was a quite a meeting. I recall that everyone agreed with testing, and blamed the urologists for being too eager to rush men into surgery. The presenter assured them that AS was on dramatic recent rise, and that more options were being discussed, at least in larger practices.

Posts.Title: 2018 US Preventative Task force recommendation on Psa screening

Posts.Content: All due respect, Djin, but you are repeating the meme that I frequently see on this forum to influence men into having surgery. A better perspective is provided by Dr. Jonathan Epstein, the world's preeminent prostate pathologist. His findings are that about 20 percent of biopsy Gleason scores are upgraded post-RP. That is certainly concerning. But, about 16 percent of the Gleason (3+4) biopsy scores are DOWNGRADED upon post-RP pathology. http://pcri.org/insights-blog/2016/3...ng-pathologist

Posts.Title: Up- and Down-grading of Gleason scores and treatment decisions

Posts.Content: N.A.H, I am very surprised at the advice that you received from that radiation oncologist. There are five very different types of primary radiation therapy: IMRT, SBRT, LDR-BT, HDR-BT, and PBT (Proton Beam). What was his specialty? It sounds like he maybe was doing IMRT on salvage patients after RP failed. His reasoning about radiation after surgery is an expected talking point of surgeons, and is highly misleading. There are actually several salvage options should a primary radiation treatment fail. These include HIFU, SBRT, HDR-BT, FLA, and IRE. All have studies proving their efficacy. And, you would do well to compare the recent studies on the failure rate of surgery versus SBRT and HDR-BT. The results may get you thinking twice about consulting with more RO's. Just my input. Take it as you wish. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: Up- and Down-grading of Gleason scores and treatment decisions

Posts.Content: Fred, In 2015, the World Health Organization adopted new risk classification criteria for prostate cancer, which was developed by Johns Hopkins using decades of data. The primary revision in the new standards is the separation of G 3+4 into a new, "low intermediate" class, and G 4+3 as "high intermediate". So, that doctor's comment seems out of date. As far as the time for a G 3+4 to grow and escape the capsule, there is no certain data. There are G 3+4 men who have been in active surveillance for many years, although they do have a higher risk than the G 3+3 men. Their fifteen year survival rate without treatment is 84 percent in the latest Sunnybrook study. Not great, but worth knowing. Have you had genomic tests done on your biopsy slides? These tests, like OncotypeDX and Prolaris, can help predict the future aggressiveness of the cancer. Mine were a decisive factor in my going on AS. In my limited knowledge, you have a mixed bag of factors that could justify treatment now, or holding off for more testing, consultations, and research. Only one small lesion being seen on an MRI could argue in favor of not rushing to a decision. Will there be a magic vaccine out next year? ...probably not, but you need to be fully comfortable in calculating your decision. Good luck.

Posts.Title: The Book

Posts.Content: Nice to know, but I have to question their data for long-term membership in those AS programs. For example, the article says that they mostly had one core of G6, and the long term results were : "After 5, 10 and 15 years of follow-up, respectively, 58%, 39% and 23% of men were still on AS." But, these are the results from the Sunnybrook AS program, which included more positive cores, and intermediate risk men: "At 5, 10, and 15 years, 75.7%, 63.5%, and 55.0% of patients remained untreated and on surveillance." So, while it's great to have a consolidated database of many AS programs' data, I have to admit that I am confused by what other groups were included, and how they selected their men. Also, why did the men leave the group?

Posts.Content: Wbigs, As Michael F stated, this is a good report for someone already on AS. The report did not say if they were using the PIRADS 2.0 version. One of my lesions was reclassified from 4 to 3 with the newer version, and possibly the same could happen with you. Your doctor is giving you good advice. Maybe do PHI rather then just psa as part of your monitoring. Also, were there genomic tests on your biopsy slides? The OncotypeDX or Prolaris assays can provide more information in predicting the future aggressiveness of the cancer that was found. When you are on AS, you want all the tests that are reasonable to arrange.

Posts.Content: Cipro is a powerful antibiotic, but it often has no effect on prostatitis. I have read that about 90 percent of prostate inflammation cases do not involve bacteria and do not respond to antibiotics. They just come and go on their own, (sitz baths help in some cases). What is your prostate density (PSAD)? Your prostate volume should have been noted on your MRI, and is probably larger now. The PHI, 4K Score, or PCA3 tests could add some more data points to your analysis. Right now, it would appear that you have what was diagnosed in August 2014, and just have to follow your uro's advice. If you are not comfortable doing that, then getting more opinions is always a good choice.

Posts.Title: My PSA Result is 10

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by akhlak Dear Sir, I am 45 years old. On February 2017, I checked my PSA level found 6.83 ng/ml and Gleason’s Grade 3+3=6/10 by biopsy test. On April 2017, my doctor suggested me to take Hormone Therapy (3 Zoladex Injection). Already I have taken two injections. He also suggested me to take Calutide tablets 50mg per day without any surgery. On June 17, 2017, again I have checked my PSA found 1.37 ng/ml. And one month later, on July 20, 2017, I found my PSA Level 0.57 ng/ml. Could you please give me your opinion or advice at my present situation? Kind Regards, M. A Zaman Hi Akhlak, I recall posting a comment on one of your previous posts on some forum. Glad to hear that your psa is now so low, but Those drugs are approved for advanced prostate cancer...and they are being prescribed for you as a first line treatment? Zoladex was approved by the FDA for prostate cancer in 1989, but I never read about anyone taking it. Are you in southeast Asia? Are these drugs considered mainstream treatments in your country? I can appreciate your not wanting surgery, but how effective is this treatment in the long term? Sorry that I don't have an answer for you, but I hope that another member with knowledge of these drugs can comment.

Posts.Title: Calutide tablet has reduced my PSA level dramatically.

Posts.Content: Like the above members, I am puzzled as to why action has not been taken based on that biopsy. Regarding intermediate-risk PCa and Active Surveillance, I just received a publication from my specialist, H. Ballentine Carter, MD, who pioneered AS in the United States. He concluded that men with low-intermediate-risk (G3+4) prostate cancer were 4.5 to 5 times more likely to have aggressive tumors requiring immediate treatment than men in lower-risk groups. Also, that the research did not find any "favorable" sub-group among low-intermediate-risk patients who would benefit from active surveillance. So, yes, the time for inaction is past. You need to research and select a type of treatment.

Posts.Title: Need help understanding my info. Is it time to take action.

Posts.Content: Like the above members, I am puzzled as to why action has not been taken based on that biopsy. Regarding intermediate-risk PCa and Active Surveillance, I just received a publication from my specialist, H. Ballentine Carter, MD, who pioneered AS in the United States. He concluded that men with low-intermediate-risk (G3+4) prostate cancer were 4.5 to 5 times more likely to have aggressive tumors requiring immediate treatment than men in lower-risk groups. Also, that the research did not find any "favorable" sub-group among low-intermediate-risk patients who would benefit from active surveillance. So, yes, the time for inaction is past. You need to research and select a type of treatment.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 While I am not a fan of super-star Dr. Samadi, just to throw a little gasoline on the Cyberknife discussion, here are his thoughts on the subject from his website: Q. What are the side effects of Cyber Knife? A. The negative side effects of CyberKnifeÂ® can be expected to mirror those of other targeted radiation therapies. Over the short term, radiation therapy for prostate cancer can cause: Urination problems including burning and blood in the urine Urinary urgency and frequency Weakened urinary stream Incomplete emptying of the bladder Anal and rectal irritation, rectal bleeding, hemorrhoids, and stool problems Fatigue and nausea Long-term CyberKnifeÂ® and prostate cancer radiation side effects may include: Sexual impotence and/or erectile dysfunction for up to 2 years after treatment Delayed orgasm or ejaculation Temporary or permanent reduction in sperm count; fertility should be discussed with your physician prior to CyberKnifeÂ® treatment Impaired bowel function Potential increased risk of bladder or rectal cancer by 5% And post-treatment patient satisfaction surveys repeatedly show Cyberknife as the LEAST popular method of treating prostate cancer, primarily due to radiation burns from the massive doses of radiation versus the decades-old gold standard of 35 - 40 sessions of EBRT. Jim, Samadi is super-arrogant. I saw him on a TV news show a couple of years ago, and he was seriously bad-mouthing Dr. Patrick Walsh and open prostatectomy in general. If you were to take Samadi's advice, every treatment besides RALP is invalid. Well, he is entertaining Michael, I like your humor, but I hope to not have to change my handle anytime soon.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Interesting -- although two key differences are (1) the first study was limited to men under 60; and (2) the first study looked at Gleason score â‰¥ 8, the second at Gleason score â‰¥ 9. Djin, The 2108 Guidelines for Clinicians published by the AUA/ASTRO/SUO have combined Gleason 8 men into the same "high risk" category as G9-10. Accordingly, they now fall into the same treatment options as G 9-10 cases. There is no "very high risk" classification. High risk now includes "PSA â‰¥20 ng/ml OR Grade Group 4-5 OR clinical stage â‰¥T3". Gleason (4+4) is Grade Group 4.

Posts.Content: Cipro is a powerful antibiotic, but it often has no effect on prostatitis. I have read that about 90 percent of prostate inflammation cases do not involve bacteria and do not respond to antibiotics. They just come and go on their own, (sitz baths help in some cases). What is your prostate density (PSAD)? Your prostate volume should have been noted on your MRI, and is probably larger now. The PHI, 4K Score, or PCA3 tests could add some more data points to your analysis. Right now, it would appear that you have what was diagnosed in August 2014, and just have to follow your uro's advice. If you are not comfortable doing that, then getting more opinions is always a good choice.

Posts.Content: The most effective RT regimen for high risk PCa is EBRT + BBT ( brachy boost). While the study mentions that some men had BBT, it did not do a comparison of that regimen versus RP. Also, SBRT is now being used in some trials to replace the brachytherapy. While this following study was not age-restricted, it produced quite different conclusions. https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jam...rticle/2673969

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Sw1218 my prostate volume is 31mL. this was noted in may of 2017 on my MRI. if 90% of prostate inflammation cases do not involve bacteria and do not respond to antibiotics, then why am i being prescribed with cipro? it seems to be a waste of time to take the drug. it would seem that i am just taking it to have something written on paper. i'm not saying this at you, but that doesn't help my anxiety. Table 1, Category 3 of this Harvard Medical School Article cites the 90 percent statistic. But, as you read the article, you see how complex and varied prostatitis is. Prescription of antibiotics could maybe help in some cases, so they do it. https://www.harvardprostateknowledge...e-for-optimism

Posts.Content: The Tesla ratings of 1.5 and 3 refer to the power of the machine. "mp" means that the machine's software is set up to record three assays, which greatly increases the value for analyzing prostate cancer. The PIRADS score is generated by those three assays. An endorectal coil or an apron coil can be used with either 1.5 or 3 machines. The ERC was recommended with 1.5, but not required on the 3T. Trust me, you do not want the ERC, as it is extremely uncomfortable. Think of being reamed with a police baton. The apron coil is no problem. Both machines use a contrast dye, which is intravenously injected.

Posts.Content: Allmo, Thanks for this detailed post. Last year, I attended a support group meeting where a veteran urologist did a slide show presenting the same facts as you did. His conclusion was that PSA testing was only saving one man per one thousand tested.. The men in the room were pretty much in an uproar, as they respected that doctor, but refused to accept the conclusion. It was a quite a meeting. I recall that everyone agreed with testing, and blamed the urologists for being too eager to rush men into surgery. The presenter assured them that AS was on dramatic recent rise, and that more options were being discussed, at least in larger practices.

Posts.Content: Djin, if the efficacy is non-Inferior, as far as has been shown, in multiple studies, why are we even discussing the value of hypofractionation? As I was told face-to-face with the chief RO of a major medical center in my (DC) area, the ROs choice is dictated by the insurance companies reimbursement. He said that he could do SBRT in ONE session, but they would pay him much more for 44 sessions of IMRT. So, well, you see my point.

Posts.Title: The Book

Posts.Content: Nice to know, but I have to question their data for long-term membership in those AS programs. For example, the article says that they mostly had one core of G6, and the long term results were : "After 5, 10 and 15 years of follow-up, respectively, 58%, 39% and 23% of men were still on AS." But, these are the results from the Sunnybrook AS program, which included more positive cores, and intermediate risk men: "At 5, 10, and 15 years, 75.7%, 63.5%, and 55.0% of patients remained untreated and on surveillance." So, while it's great to have a consolidated database of many AS programs' data, I have to admit that I am confused by what other groups were included, and how they selected their men. Also, why did the men leave the group?

Posts.Title: The GAP3 cohort: A profile of the largest global prostate cancer AS database

Posts.Content: N.A.H, I am very surprised at the advice that you received from that radiation oncologist. There are five very different types of primary radiation therapy: IMRT, SBRT, LDR-BT, HDR-BT, and PBT (Proton Beam). What was his specialty? It sounds like he maybe was doing IMRT on salvage patients after RP failed. His reasoning about radiation after surgery is an expected talking point of surgeons, and is highly misleading. There are actually several salvage options should a primary radiation treatment fail. These include HIFU, SBRT, HDR-BT, FLA, and IRE. All have studies proving their efficacy. And, you would do well to compare the recent studies on the failure rate of surgery versus SBRT and HDR-BT. The results may get you thinking twice about consulting with more RO's. Just my input. Take it as you wish. Good luck to you.

Posts.Content: Allmo, Thanks for this detailed post. Last year, I attended a support group meeting where a veteran urologist did a slide show presenting the same facts as you did. His conclusion was that PSA testing was only saving one man per one thousand tested.. The men in the room were pretty much in an uproar, as they respected that doctor, but refused to accept the conclusion. It was a quite a meeting. I recall that everyone agreed with testing, and blamed the urologists for being too eager to rush men into surgery. The presenter assured them that AS was on dramatic recent rise, and that more options were being discussed, at least in larger practices.

Posts.Title: SM88 therapeutic treatment for cancer

Posts.Content: There have been recent studies showing no difference in recurrence between high risk men who had immediate surgery, and those who waited for six months. So, dont be panicked into treatment before you have your thoughts clear. You mentioned protons. They have excellent outcomes, with five year recurrence rates of less than ten percent for intermediate risk men like yourself. Cyberknife/SBRT has similar statistics. The recurrence rates for surgery run from 25 to 40 percent, depending on which study. Surgery first, followed by radiation is what many surgeons recommend. But, that subjects you to the side effects of both treatments, and it is radiation that finally stops the cancer. Think that over. And, if there should be a failure of primary radiation, there are several effective non-surgical treatments available to you. Keep asking, and certainly have more consultations. You have to be fully confident with your choice of treatment.

Posts.Content: All due respect, Djin, but you are repeating the meme that I frequently see on this forum to influence men into having surgery. A better perspective is provided by Dr. Jonathan Epstein, the world's preeminent prostate pathologist. His findings are that about 20 percent of biopsy Gleason scores are upgraded post-RP. That is certainly concerning. But, about 16 percent of the Gleason (3+4) biopsy scores are DOWNGRADED upon post-RP pathology. http://pcri.org/insights-blog/2016/3...ng-pathologist

Posts.Title: Up- and Down-grading of Gleason scores and treatment decisions

Posts.Content: LakeRat, Having your prostate removed is no guarantee that the cancer is gone. Multiple studies have shown that the recurrence rate after surgery for a Grade Group 3 risk like you is 35 percent. The results are at least as good or better for radiation, especially with a combo that adds brachyterapy boost and/or ADT to the treatment. Please consider your options carefully. The goal is to minimize that chances that the cancer persists after any treatment. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Certainly, having an ejaculation an hour before a biopsy will falsely raise the result. Biopsies are not a day at the beach. Some men (like myself) have had infections and long lingering pain from biopsies. They are required when necessary, but I'm not convinced that you are at that point. I would suggest another blood draw, this time using the PHI test, which is more accurate than psa. (It does also provide psa and free psa numbers). And, no sex of any kind, bike riding or working out for at least 2-3 days before the draw. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by caddy2507 Gentlemen, thanks for all your opinions and advice. I really need "somebody to talk to" about my situation that understands. My friends keep asking me "why aren't you in the hospital yet getting that cut out!". I guess you've all heard that. As far as my family history, my Dad had his PC back in the early 90's and had 30 external radiation treatments. He was then about 70. He lived until he was 94 and died of complications of dementia. His younger brother contracted PC at age 74 and had Brachy therapy and is 82 now, doing fine. His other brother contracted PC when he was about 65 and this was in the early 70's. he wound up dying from it as there was no PSA test then (as I recall) and his PCP didn't recognize the symptoms until it was too late. I'm a bit leery of radiation treatment in any form, since my understanding is once you have that you can no longer have prostate region surgery should you need to. Supposedly, they only option is "salvage" which does not sound too attractive. I don't know if my reasoning makes sense. By the way, my doctor is affiliated with UPMC (University of Pittsburgh) and can refer me to an RO, robotic surgeon (he only does open). if I wish. Anyway, I'll let you know what my plans will be. Thanks again. Why would you need salvage surgery if salvage radiation can do the job, and allow you to avoid the additional side effects of such surgery? It was widely believed that, after primary radiation, that secondary radiation was not appropriate and that salvage surgery would be very difficult. That belief has now been overtaken by the proven efficacy of salvage SBRT radiation. These links will display three recent scholarly articles that show the feasibility and efficacy of salvage SBRT after primary radiation: https://pcnrv.blogspot.com/2016/08/s...nce-after.html https://ro-journal.biomedcentral.com...014-017-0833-9

Posts.Title: Who Are Us?

Posts.Content: mike, IMHO, an excellent post. I have also observed that the posters are predominantly newbie/recurrent guys, and often ask where the treated and satisfied people were? I guess that they just considered themselves cured and move on. Also, many men don't naturally share intimate medical details, so it's not something they feel comfortable hanging around and discussing. The same thing with local support groups, there are new guys, and there are those veteran members who have developed strong opinions and advocacies. There is an advantage to not acting impulsively after diagnosis, or just accepting the advice of that doctor without more consultations and research. Here is a study of men who had RT that shows that an informed selection of treatment results in less regret afterwards. https://pcnrv.blogspot.com/2017/01/l...-sbrt-and.html

They ruled that Pfizer had "gamed" the rules on extending a patent by claiming new formulations. This was interesting, as they ruled that the citizens were harmed by Pfizer intentionally violating the spirit of the law, but not the letter of the law. I thought that was impressive, as they would not let Pfizer profit from a bad faith tactic.

Posts.Content: whigs, from what I've read and been told, you need to avoid sexual activity (intercourse, masturbation) for 48 to 72 hours before a psa blood draw. Some urologists have told me 5 days, and one said 7 days! The same applies to bicycle riding, and possible other saddle-bound activities. I stay off my jet ski, just to be sure. Not really aware of restrictions on running, but maybe some extreme or marathon-level runs might not be advisable. Those are the things that are most mentioned. There may be others.

Posts.Title: PSA and physical activity

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by caddy2507 Gentlemen, thanks for all your opinions and advice. I really need "somebody to talk to" about my situation that understands. My friends keep asking me "why aren't you in the hospital yet getting that cut out!". I guess you've all heard that. As far as my family history, my Dad had his PC back in the early 90's and had 30 external radiation treatments. He was then about 70. He lived until he was 94 and died of complications of dementia. His younger brother contracted PC at age 74 and had Brachy therapy and is 82 now, doing fine. His other brother contracted PC when he was about 65 and this was in the early 70's. he wound up dying from it as there was no PSA test then (as I recall) and his PCP didn't recognize the symptoms until it was too late. I'm a bit leery of radiation treatment in any form, since my understanding is once you have that you can no longer have prostate region surgery should you need to. Supposedly, they only option is "salvage" which does not sound too attractive. I don't know if my reasoning makes sense. By the way, my doctor is affiliated with UPMC (University of Pittsburgh) and can refer me to an RO, robotic surgeon (he only does open). if I wish. Anyway, I'll let you know what my plans will be. Thanks again. Why would you need salvage surgery if salvage radiation can do the job, and allow you to avoid the additional side effects of such surgery? It was widely believed that, after primary radiation, that secondary radiation was not appropriate and that salvage surgery would be very difficult. That belief has now been overtaken by the proven efficacy of salvage SBRT radiation. These links will display three recent scholarly articles that show the feasibility and efficacy of salvage SBRT after primary radiation: https://pcnrv.blogspot.com/2016/08/s...nce-after.html https://ro-journal.biomedcentral.com...014-017-0833-9

Posts.Content: All due respect, Djin, but you are repeating the meme that I frequently see on this forum to influence men into having surgery. A better perspective is provided by Dr. Jonathan Epstein, the world's preeminent prostate pathologist. His findings are that about 20 percent of biopsy Gleason scores are upgraded post-RP. That is certainly concerning. But, about 16 percent of the Gleason (3+4) biopsy scores are DOWNGRADED upon post-RP pathology. http://pcri.org/insights-blog/2016/3...ng-pathologist

Posts.Title: Up- and Down-grading of Gleason scores and treatment decisions

Posts.Content: There have been recent studies showing no difference in recurrence between high risk men who had immediate surgery, and those who waited for six months. So, dont be panicked into treatment before you have your thoughts clear. You mentioned protons. They have excellent outcomes, with five year recurrence rates of less than ten percent for intermediate risk men like yourself. Cyberknife/SBRT has similar statistics. The recurrence rates for surgery run from 25 to 40 percent, depending on which study. Surgery first, followed by radiation is what many surgeons recommend. But, that subjects you to the side effects of both treatments, and it is radiation that finally stops the cancer. Think that over. And, if there should be a failure of primary radiation, there are several effective non-surgical treatments available to you. Keep asking, and certainly have more consultations. You have to be fully confident with your choice of treatment.

Posts.Title: New Finding Regarding PSA Testing

Posts.Content: Caddy, Please take your time. I was diagnosed with Gleason(3+3) eight years ago, and there has been no progression of my cancer, which I hope to die with, not of. However, the five cores is a bit more than mine, and I would think it prudent that you begin to educate yourself on the pros and cons of eventual treatment. The long term studies of the active surveillance groups at Sunnybrook, and at Johns Hopkins, as well as the statistics of the American Cancer Society do not support your doctor's statement that your cancer would be beyond treatment in 10 years. BUT, those are the averages, and you may not want to play the odds when your life is the stake. You can certainly take your time and mull over your options. The cure rates have historically been the same between surgery and radiation, but now the SBRT type of radiation is reporting cure rates and low sides effects that "may" be a game-changer. Others will attest to the efficacy of what treatments they had. There are several similar forums and an infinite amount of data, studies, and opinions out on the internet. Attending some monthly local prostate cancer support groups is another way to learn of experiences and side effects face-to-face. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: Age 68 and recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: jetski, (BTW, I own a Sea-Doo and love riding it!) I am not that informed on the various testing types you mentioned. but I do know that, in addition to staining, that several genomics tests are now in common use for predicting the aggressiveness of the cancer that was found in the core samples. These assays would include OncotypeDX, Prolaris, ConfirmMDX, and Decipher (post biopsy version). Of course, they are only designed to test cores that were judged to be cancerous, and that has not been determined yet in your father's case. Generally, to be extent of my knowledge, the primary determinants of PCa during a biopsy review are microscopic analysis by a pathologist and staining of the cores.

Posts.Title: Question about Father's Biopsy Report

Posts.Content: NadiaB, a few things to keep in mind: 1) about two-thirds of initial prostate biopsies are negative. 2) PIRADS is for suspicious areas, it does not mean that the area has cancer. 3) Prostate cancer is not like other cancers. It is slow growing, and many cases are indolent and will never require treatment. 4. The American Cancer Society estimates that 99+ percent of the men diagnosed with prostate cancer today will not die from prostate cancer over the next ten years. Try to relax, and take the process one step at a time.

Posts.Content: Wbigs, As Michael F stated, this is a good report for someone already on AS. The report did not say if they were using the PIRADS 2.0 version. One of my lesions was reclassified from 4 to 3 with the newer version, and possibly the same could happen with you. Your doctor is giving you good advice. Maybe do PHI rather then just psa as part of your monitoring. Also, were there genomic tests on your biopsy slides? The OncotypeDX or Prolaris assays can provide more information in predicting the future aggressiveness of the cancer that was found. When you are on AS, you want all the tests that are reasonable to arrange.

Posts.Content: PVD, How did you get generic Viagra in the USA? Pfizer's patent has been extended until 2020. What I did was bring my USA prescription to a walk-in clinic while in Canada, and asked them to re-write the rx for their minimum visit fee of $39. Got 30 100mg tablets of generic sidenafil for about $140 at a Costco there. Then use a simple pill splitter to cut them into quarters. I think that it would cost me over $600 to get the same rx here in the states.

Posts.Title: Sex and PC

Posts.Content: I recently had a discussion with an Interventional Radiologist while sharing a dinner table on a cruise ship. He was talking about his profession, and I asked him if he worked on prostate issues. He said that his practice has had great success with prostate artery embolization (PAE), in which needles are used to inject plastic blocking materials into the arteries supplying blood to the prostate gland. They are able to reduce the gland size up to 85 percent with this procedure, which he considered a game-changer for men with enlarged prostates. Here is a typical description of the procedure. Note the impressive before-and-after images. http://www.inova.org/healthcare-serv...paign=prostate My question for the forum: This procedure is designed to relieve the symptoms of benign prostatic hypertrophy (BPH), but can it be used for men with BHP who also have diagnosed prostate cancer? My prostate isn't getting any smaller with age, and this option would be great to have available, if it is not contraindicated. Anyone know the answer?

Posts.Title: Prostate Artery Embolization if cancer is present?

Posts.Content: LakeRat, Having your prostate removed is no guarantee that the cancer is gone. Multiple studies have shown that the recurrence rate after surgery for a Grade Group 3 risk like you is 35 percent. The results are at least as good or better for radiation, especially with a combo that adds brachyterapy boost and/or ADT to the treatment. Please consider your options carefully. The goal is to minimize that chances that the cancer persists after any treatment. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Sex and PC

Posts.Content: Another, I also found that advice article to be disturbing, and I am a big believer that some men are overtreated. IMHO, overtreatment is the result of either the diagnosing urologist pushing his cure, and/or the patient panicking at the thought of cancer in his body. But I see a distinction between diagnostic tools and the decision to (over) treat. When I got "the call" I was told "You can take this biopsy report to any surgeon or radiologist in the country and schedule their services. But, given your age and the small amount of cancer we found, I am going to recommend you for a program we have here at Hopkins." He could have said "I'll schedule surgery for next month"...But, he didn't. If he had, and I had been overtreated it would have been his and my fault, not the psa tests, the MRI, or the biopsy. As Michael F said, we need liquid biopsies and other more perfect diagnostic tools. They are arriving, all the time. Meanwhile, I support psa testing, and also better communications about options from diagnosing urologists.

Posts.Content: Don't know where you live, but Canada is the answer. The Canadian Supreme Court unanimously invalidated Pfizer's Viagra patent a couple of year ago, because of how they cleverly "gamed" their patent application. An Israeli company makes a perfectly good generic version of Viagra. My girlfriend lives in Canada, so I go there frequently. Every couple of years, I have my local, American doctor write me an rx for Viagra. In Canada, I walk into any storefront medic clinic, and show that to them. They dither a bit, and write out the same rx, for about $40. I next drive to Costco, and get it filled for about a quarter of what it would have cost in the states. I always get the 100mg size, and then quarter them with a pill splitter. Perfect!

Posts.Title: Up- and Down-grading of Gleason scores and treatment decisions

Posts.Content: Caddy, Please take your time. I was diagnosed with Gleason(3+3) eight years ago, and there has been no progression of my cancer, which I hope to die with, not of. However, the five cores is a bit more than mine, and I would think it prudent that you begin to educate yourself on the pros and cons of eventual treatment. The long term studies of the active surveillance groups at Sunnybrook, and at Johns Hopkins, as well as the statistics of the American Cancer Society do not support your doctor's statement that your cancer would be beyond treatment in 10 years. BUT, those are the averages, and you may not want to play the odds when your life is the stake. You can certainly take your time and mull over your options. The cure rates have historically been the same between surgery and radiation, but now the SBRT type of radiation is reporting cure rates and low sides effects that "may" be a game-changer. Others will attest to the efficacy of what treatments they had. There are several similar forums and an infinite amount of data, studies, and opinions out on the internet. Attending some monthly local prostate cancer support groups is another way to learn of experiences and side effects face-to-face. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: Age 68 and recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: PVD, How did you get generic Viagra in the USA? Pfizer's patent has been extended until 2020. What I did was bring my USA prescription to a walk-in clinic while in Canada, and asked them to re-write the rx for their minimum visit fee of $39. Got 30 100mg tablets of generic sidenafil for about $140 at a Costco there. Then use a simple pill splitter to cut them into quarters. I think that it would cost me over $600 to get the same rx here in the states.

Posts.Title: New Finding Regarding PSA Testing

Posts.Content: mike, IMHO, an excellent post. I have also observed that the posters are predominantly newbie/recurrent guys, and often ask where the treated and satisfied people were? I guess that they just considered themselves cured and move on. Also, many men don't naturally share intimate medical details, so it's not something they feel comfortable hanging around and discussing. The same thing with local support groups, there are new guys, and there are those veteran members who have developed strong opinions and advocacies. There is an advantage to not acting impulsively after diagnosis, or just accepting the advice of that doctor without more consultations and research. Here is a study of men who had RT that shows that an informed selection of treatment results in less regret afterwards. https://pcnrv.blogspot.com/2017/01/l...-sbrt-and.html

Posts.Title: Generic Viagra only $25 per pill?

Posts.Content: Thought that I would post this link to a new clinical trial. Proton beam therapy for prostate cancer typically requires 44 sessions and is very expensive. This trial intends to mimic SBRT, but using protons, and complete the treatment in only five sessions. This is being done at the Mayo Clinic, but also other institutions. Faster, more powerful, easier ... technology goes racing ahead. And, we won't know for many years what the end results are. Two men that I know from elsewhere have already started in this same trial, but not at Mayo. Pioneers ... hope that it works for them. That's a lot of radiation, but SBRT appears popular and successful, so the proton folks want to attract more patients using a similar offering. https://www.mayo.edu/research/clinic...OqlZy7yF0eMttI

Posts.Title: Who Are Us?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider Proton Therapy has been demonstrated to be very effective with certain tumors particularly in childhood cancer. But the machines are very expensive and they'd like to show that it has advantages in treating other cancers. Prostate cancer is pretty popular- if they can demonstrate the advantage of protons in treating PC, they can get more patients. In this recent study, PBRT had a five year non-recurrence rate of almost 97 percent for intermediate risk men. That result is higher than any other prostate cancer treatment. If they can both produce more studies like this, and also decrease the number of sessions and the cost, protons can become a serious choice for men with PCa. http://ascopubs.org/doi/abs/10.1200/....36.6_suppl.97

Posts.Title: Treatment Technology keeps Racing Ahead

Posts.Content: For its Active Surveillance study group, Johns Hopkins switched to the PHI test several years ago. PHI includes PSA, free PSA, a prostate cancer biomarker, and an algorithm that produces a score on the likelihood of finding aggressive cancer on biopsy. I have heard that it costs about $100, about double that of psa alone, and worth it for its superior accuracy.

Posts.Title: ASCO AS Roundtable Discussion - July 18

Posts.Content: Welcome, OleJoe (well, you're younger than me ) While it's always good to be informed, you are not even diagnosed yet, and, if you have cancer, the pathology can direct the appropriate choice of treatment(s). If a small amount of low risk PCa is found, then active surveillance is what the major urological associations recommend. On the other hand, an advanced cancer may require only certain treatments. The intermediate risk group is where there are several choices that all can cure you. Proton beam therapy is great in theory, and in potential, but studies have yet to show that it produces superior results, while being more expensive. IMRT, IGRT, SBRT, LDR-BT (seeds), and HDR-BT are the radiation offerings, and most radiologists only offer one or two of them, so you have to consult with multiple doctors to learn the full stories. Surgery is also an option, although it is less chosen by men after age 70.

Posts.Title: Travel insurance

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi Dan! Your case must be noted by anyone considering AS. PC can be a wolf in sheep's clothing. Biopsies are not a 100% accurate assessment! Fortunately, you opted for RP and not AS. MF I feel that this is a very unfair and incomplete statement. If Dan had chosen to enter a formal AS program, he would have had additional testing (Imaging, fusion biopsy, genomics tests, PHI/4K) within a few months of his original diagnosis. These would have either found his more advanced cancer, or; reassured him that AS was a proper choice for him. Nobody can know if AS is a correct choice after one biopsy. That is why "active" is the core element of those programs. Properly screened, the enrollees can enjoy their lives without the negative QOL factors of overtreatment.

Posts.Content: Hahaha, I just ordered 32 100 mg splittable Sildenafil (Viagra) tablets for $100. You should only need 50mg per "needed" use. That's a $1.56 per usage. Made by Teva, Israel's largest pharma company, and available worldwide. I get mine from an online Canadian pharmacy. It takes about three weeks, but they always arrive...and work as you want them too. It's OK as Congress has stopped the Customs Service from blocking "personal use" size shipments of imported drugs. Those Canadian pharmacies are the most cost-effective way to buy Viagra (sildenadfil) and other ED meds. Well, at least until 2020, when Pfizer's last USA patent finally expires. The Canadian Supreme Court unanimously invalidated Pfizer's patent in 2010 because of deliberate gaming of their formulary application.

Posts.Content: A PSA that high requires a urologist consultation. You are going for a quick exam and advice. He/She may give you medicine for an infection, or take blood for a PHI or 4K Score test. Later, if the things remain suspicious, they could order an MRI, and possibly a biopsy. I recall reading that a prostate massage or sex before a PSA test will only raise the result by 20 percent or so. IMHO, you need a consult to get a more informed assessment and plan. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Hello from SW Florida

Posts.Content: Jazz, the issue of "needle tract spreading" or "needle tracking" is often discussed on prostate cancer forums. Studies have shown that it is possible, but extremely rare, like one in thousands. The general consensus is that if you need a biopsy, you should not let that remote possibility stop you. As Chuck mentioned, you may want to consider active surveillance. Still, an AS protocol would require another, confirming, biopsy within the next year. Those are usually 12 core, with another 2 to 4 in areas targeted by the MRI.

Posts.Content: Jazz, If you are looking at radiation options, the three types that have the best study results are SBRT, proton beam, and HDR brachytherapy. Cryo has the downside of near-total ED. I had discussed this with the leader of a cryo clinical trial at Johns Hopkins. Not for me, please. Regarding the three forms of radiation that I suggested, please try to consult with a specialist in each one, and not let others describe those they don't perform. There is often a surprising knowledge gap about other specialties.

Posts.Title: 3D Mapping Biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi Dan! Your case must be noted by anyone considering AS. PC can be a wolf in sheep's clothing. Biopsies are not a 100% accurate assessment! Fortunately, you opted for RP and not AS. MF I feel that this is a very unfair and incomplete statement. If Dan had chosen to enter a formal AS program, he would have had additional testing (Imaging, fusion biopsy, genomics tests, PHI/4K) within a few months of his original diagnosis. These would have either found his more advanced cancer, or; reassured him that AS was a proper choice for him. Nobody can know if AS is a correct choice after one biopsy. That is why "active" is the core element of those programs. Properly screened, the enrollees can enjoy their lives without the negative QOL factors of overtreatment.

Made by Teva, Israel's largest pharma company, and available worldwide. I get mine from an online Canadian pharmacy. It takes about three weeks, but they always arrive...and work as you want them too. It's OK as Congress has stopped the Customs Service from blocking "personal use" size shipments of imported drugs. Those Canadian pharmacies are the most cost-effective way to buy Viagra (sildenadfil) and other ED meds. Well, at least until 2020, when Pfizer's last USA patent finally expires. The Canadian Supreme Court unanimously invalidated Pfizer's patent in 2010 because of deliberate gaming of their formulary application.

Posts.Title: Generic Viagra only $25 per pill?

Posts.Content: A PSA that high requires a urologist consultation. You are going for a quick exam and advice. He/She may give you medicine for an infection, or take blood for a PHI or 4K Score test. Later, if the things remain suspicious, they could order an MRI, and possibly a biopsy. I recall reading that a prostate massage or sex before a PSA test will only raise the result by 20 percent or so. IMHO, you need a consult to get a more informed assessment and plan. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Tilly, All of us on this forum have been through your partner's experience. And, yes, the few days that it takes before you hear the test results can seem like years. But, there are many folks here who will be able to relate to you when the pathology report is known. And, you want the actual lab report, in whatever form is available, not just the doctor talking about it. Stay calm, and let us know when you know further results. Good luck to you and your partner.

Posts.Title: Partner being tested for prostate cancer.

Posts.Content: You are being advised to get a biopsy by well-meaning men who have had one or two in their lives. I have had five, and two had long-lasting, painful consequences. Biopsies are NOT a risk-free deal. Many cause trauma and one in 1500 results in fatal sepsis. That said, I am not against biopsies IF they are justified. In your case, I would recommend a PHI blood test, and, if that is high, an mp-MRI to identify any target areas for a biopsy, if such are found.

Posts.Title: Elevated and rising PSA, what should I do?

Posts.Content: It does not matter what treatment you had (AS is also considered a "treatment"), there will never be a time when you will stop having PSA or other tests. Just today. I read posts elsewhere from four men who were dealing with rising PSA's more than 12 years after RP. And, they were all shocked, as we all would be. But, they are moving on to more treatments. My partner had a stage 3 melanoma removed almost 40 years ago. She has mandatory appointments every year to monitor for recurrence. Now, she is a Canadian, and their health care is quite different, but it all shows that once you are diagnosed with a cancer (other than a really indolent skin type), you are NEVER free from being on a surveillance regimen.

Posts.Title: Is PC a chronic illness?

Posts.Content: Steve2015, I believe that you said that you were 65 in another thread. So, with a G3+3 in <5 percent of 1 of 12 cores. you are certainly within the range for AS. A positive DRE puts you in "low risk", rather than "very low risk" classification. But, regardless, you have some time on your side, and doing this type of research can only help you sort through your future options, should you ever need intervention. There are lesser-done therapies such as cryoablation, HIFU, proton, etc., to check out, as well as radical diets and supplements that some people say have helped them. Many folks don't want to lose a day in getting the cancer out, but I think that you are wise in learning what possible alternatives are being tested.

Posts.Title: Elevated and rising PSA, what should I do?

Posts.Content: I would suggest that you request a PHI blood test. It includes psa, free psa, a marker for prostate cancer activity, and a formula to provide a score of the liklihood of a biopsy finding prostate cancer. It is less sensitive to benign prostatitis spikes than just psa. There are some infection risks with biopsies, and a PHI test can help determine if one is really necessary. The blood must be drawn before any rectal exam, and the urologist should know that.

Posts.Title: PSA Questions

Posts.Content: Thank you for this interesting article, They have tried to cover their bases as to why they performed RP on an 80 year old man, But, as one of their major points was to avoid ADT, perhaps they might have investigated using using EBRT + brachy boost instead of the RP. This recent study finds that EBRT + brachy was superior to RP for high-risk men, and even superior to EBRT + ADT. "Adjusted 5-year rates of distant metastasis also favored dose-escalated radiation therapy: 8% for EBRT+BT vs 24% for RP and 24% for EBRT. EBRT+BT was associated with a significant 73% and 70% decreased risk of distant metastasis, respectively, compared with RP and EBRT+ADT." https://www.renalandurologynews.com/prostate-cancer/prostate-cancer-gleason-9-10-ebrt-radiation-brachytherapy-adt-optimal/article/748160/

Posts.Content: The odds are good that this psa rise is just more bph and prostatitis. But, a uro appt is needed to confirm what's going on. You should able to get your psa and other test results from your NP by asking for digital record copies. Many, if not most, practices have online patient portals where you can view and download your medical records. Ask the urologist for a PHI test, as that is more accurate and less affected by benign issues than psa alone.

Posts.Content: The odds are good that this psa rise is just more bph and prostatitis. But, a uro appt is needed to confirm what's going on. You should able to get your psa and other test results from your NP by asking for digital record copies. Many, if not most, practices have online patient portals where you can view and download your medical records. Ask the urologist for a PHI test, as that is more accurate and less affected by benign issues than psa alone.

Posts.Title: Amazing how ones perspective can change!

Posts.Content: It seems that you have already been on AS for the past year. Your steadily rising psa and low free psa are cause for continued close monitoring. If you have HGPIN or ASAP, there is no certainty that they will ever become true cancer, or at least not a significant cancer. Your idea for future testing in the next year makes sense. I would suggest PHI rather than psa/fpsa tests, and also that you track your PHI density, which Johns Hopkins has found to be the most reliable test for future significant PCa.

Posts.Content: There is another, newer treatment for BPH, and that is Prostate Artery Embolization (PAE), which is an outpatient procedure performed by an interventional radiologist. It reduces the prostate size by 85 percent. Hopefully, that will soon spread from a few hospitals that now offer it. Probably every man will have these issues at some age, and better solutions are needed. Glad that your results were good. I trust that you are in a strict regimen of testing, that is critical to AS being successful.

Posts.Title: Elevated and rising PSA, what should I do?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SergeFL Thank you for topic. As I am still in the learning curve SBRT (CyberKnife) is one of the treatments that are on my radar, along with HR BT. The thing that looks interesting about this treatment, that it requires only 5 visits for radiation treatment vs 40-50 treatments for IMRT or PT. My only concern is that I am still unclear if it can treat the entire gland or is it more focal therapy targeting know tumors? SBRT, as a primary treatment, is a whole gland therapy. Also, it has recently been used for salvage therapy after either surgery or primary radiation. I believe that it is used focally in those salvage applications, as it can direct a lot of radiation at known targets, like lymph and bone nodes. The studies for both primary and salvage treatments show impressive results. SBRT was purposely designed to be the external beam equivalent of HDR-BT. I have read that the total dosages are the same. There are others who may know more about that.

I had to have kidney cysts drained years ago, and they do that and many other invasive procedures.

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed husband - ?'s to ask Doc at our first appt?

Posts.Content: To address your question about if Active Surveillance is appropriate for him, I would think that his age of 50 would be outside of any guidelines that I have seen. Usually, even for the lowest-risk patients, which he appears to be, the AS protocols define that choice as best for those 65 and over. That's usually coupled with a life expectancy of 20 years or less, which is statistically correct, even for healthy men. Now, certainly he has time to ask and learn and perhaps gain some additional insights. You have come to a great forum with many fellow patients glad to share their wisdom.

Posts.Title: Vaccine Trials Advance - For Both Low Risk and Recurrence Patients

Posts.Content: I would suggest that you request a PHI blood test. It includes psa, free psa, a marker for prostate cancer activity, and a formula to provide a score of the liklihood of a biopsy finding prostate cancer. It is less sensitive to benign prostatitis spikes than just psa. There are some infection risks with biopsies, and a PHI test can help determine if one is really necessary. The blood must be drawn before any rectal exam, and the urologist should know that.

Posts.Title: First PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by G1enn My free PSA was 10%. It's the only other test I've had. The doctor did a DRE and said it felt normal- but no ultrasound. What complications did you have if you don't mind me asking. I am a little hesitant to wait as I have insurance through the ACA and I'm uncertain if it will be available nest year. My biopsy complications included hemorrhages and other structural damage to the prostate, as well as groin pain and a tripled psa that lasted for six months. Only sitz baths, an ancient remedy, were helpful in healing the damage. A free psa of 10 is not good, but I would still want more testing, especially an mp-MRI, before any biopsy, if I were you.

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed husband - ?'s to ask Doc at our first appt?

Posts.Content: Don't know how I missed this in 2016, but here is an article about the results of both low and medium-risk patients having SBRT radiation treatments at the Swedish Cancer Institute in Seattle. We know that 5-year results with low-risk PCa don't mean much, as other studies have shown no difference in mortality after 10 years, regardless if they did RP, RT, or AS. But, the intermediate-risk patients are what makes this study interesting. Ninety-seven percent were recurrence-free after five years. That, IMHO, is super-impressive, and with few side effects. "For the 137 patients with intermediate risk disease (T1B-T2b, Gleason = 7, and PSA of 10 or less, or Gleason 6 or lower with a PSA between 10 and 20), 97% were recurrence-free at 5 years, a result “that matches the best results in radiotherapy for intermediate-risk patients, and matches the best results for, for example, dose-escalated IMRT [intensity-modulated radiation therapy],” https://www.mdedge.com/oncologypractice/article/114784/genitourinary-cancer/prostate-cancer-recurrence-rates-low-sbrt Now, it's on to the high-risk patients, since SBRT delivers the same total dosage as a HDR brachy boost. Those results, if they pan out, will be a new weapon to fight all localized PCa.

Posts.Title: Encouraging Radiation Study

Posts.Content: I have not read much about this test on patient forums. From a Medscape article: "The ConfirmMDx assay has a negative predictive value of 90%; however, the positive predictive value is only 28%." So, it's having a biopsy in the hope of avoiding more biopsies. If the the biopsy itself is positive, there is no reason to do this test, as the presence of cancer is known. Personally, I have had two awful biopsy experiences, and understand the desire not to have any more unless there are very strong indications for one. Have you have had a PHI test, and/or a PCA3 test? You may want to try these before dealing with another biopsy.
Posts.Signature: DOB: May 1944 In Active Surveillance program at Johns Hopkins Strict protocol of tests, including PHI, DRE, MRI, and biopsy. Six biopsies from 2009 to 2019. Numbers 1, 2, and 5 were negative. Numbers 3,4, and 6 were positive with 5% Gleason(3+3) found. Last one was Precision Point transperineal. PSA 4.4, fPSA 24, PHI 32 Hopefully, I can remain untreated. So far, so good.

Posts.Content: To address your question about if Active Surveillance is appropriate for him, I would think that his age of 50 would be outside of any guidelines that I have seen. Usually, even for the lowest-risk patients, which he appears to be, the AS protocols define that choice as best for those 65 and over. That's usually coupled with a life expectancy of 20 years or less, which is statistically correct, even for healthy men. Now, certainly he has time to ask and learn and perhaps gain some additional insights. You have come to a great forum with many fellow patients glad to share their wisdom.

Posts.Content: A fluctuating psa is indicative of prostatitis, while steadily rising psa is indicative of prostate cancer. Have you had a free psa test? How about PHI, 4K Score, or PCA3 tests? And, have you had an ultrasound that could measure your prostate size? While most prostate biopsies are without complications, that has happened to me, twice. Painful and long lasting damage. From my experience, I would recommend that you insist on having some of the tests mentioned above, before taking the risk of a biopsy.

Posts.Title: Prostate biopsy at 32

Posts.Content: Ready, I'm certainly no expert, but I have had six of these MRI assessments with varying results, so I'll try to make a general guess on this one. Was PIRADS 2.0 used? That is the latest and greatest version of the scoring software, and it would be good if that was used. My index lesion was actually downgraded from 4 to 3 with the latest version. A PIRADS 5 is obviously not good, but it is not absolute. I have seen posts by two or three men recently who had targeted biopsies on PIRADS 5 areas, with negative findings. BUT, that lesion must be biopsied, which apparently you are awaiting the results for. You must be prepared to hear that some form and extent of PCa will be found. And, the biopsy report will contain all the relevant data, and you should post that here when you have it. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by chiguy BMI 22 SBMI 33/70 AUA Score 7 That and the rest gives me a 27% chance of high grade Ca and a 78% 10 year survival rate. I can live with that... Hi ChiGuy, I was reading your signature and my mindwheels were churning. Four low risk biopsies, and yet your psa keeps rising, up and up. Two questions: (1) Imaging. When have you had MRI's? What Telsa strength machines and what PIRADS results? (2) What is your current prostate size/volume? The larger the prostate, the higher a normal psa can be expected. Hopefully, that could be your case. If there has been am ultrasound or an MRI, there should be volume cited on the report.

Posts.Content: Prolaris is an assay similar to OncotypeDX, in that it analyzes cancer cells found on the biopsy to test for aggressive profiles. But, those tests are usually used to determine if a man with Gleason 6 is a good candidate for active surveillance. That is not your circumstance. So, I'm not sure what your doctor is looking for with those assay results. Hopefully, this will soon be explained to you, as well as recommendations for treatment.

Posts.Content: There is another, newer treatment for BPH, and that is Prostate Artery Embolization (PAE), which is an outpatient procedure performed by an interventional radiologist. It reduces the prostate size by 85 percent. Hopefully, that will soon spread from a few hospitals that now offer it. Probably every man will have these issues at some age, and better solutions are needed. Glad that your results were good. I trust that you are in a strict regimen of testing, that is critical to AS being successful.

Posts.Content: AceVA, Since you mentioned focal therapy, this is the latest news on a new product. Dr. Pavlovich of Johns Hopkins is a highly respected DaVinci surgeon. His enthusiasm for this treatment is noteworthy. Regarding focal therapy, it is somewhat predicated on the index lesion theory. That is, you destroy the most serious lesion, and the others are Gleason 6, and not dangerous. This is a disputed theory, but the argument is that the treatment has few side effects and can be repeated if necessary. https://globenewswire.com/news-relea...te-Cancer.html

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by G1enn My free PSA was 10%. It's the only other test I've had. The doctor did a DRE and said it felt normal- but no ultrasound. What complications did you have if you don't mind me asking. I am a little hesitant to wait as I have insurance through the ACA and I'm uncertain if it will be available nest year. My biopsy complications included hemorrhages and other structural damage to the prostate, as well as groin pain and a tripled psa that lasted for six months. Only sitz baths, an ancient remedy, were helpful in healing the damage. A free psa of 10 is not good, but I would still want more testing, especially an mp-MRI, before any biopsy, if I were you.
