Posts.Content: Another retrospective study comparing the outcomes of three types of prostate cancer treatment for intermediate-risk men. This one used data from 2004-2007, so advocates of both RP and RT can claim that this does not represent the latest generation of equipment and techniques. What is interesting is that RP and RT (at that time) had exactly the same recurrence-free outcomes at 58 percent. That's means 42 percent of each group had their cancer return.. Brachytherapy had an 82 percent recurrence-free rate, which would make it clearly superior. The ironic fact is that BT has fallen off in popularity since 2004, and is now used in only about 3 percent of treatments. https://www.urotoday.com/conference-...te-cancer.html

Posts.Content: I would resist having a biopsy at this time, if I were you. They are not risk or pain free, and there really hasn't been any red line crossed that would suggest that one is required. A PSA less than 4 for your age sounds pretty normal. I would suggest that your next blood test be Prostate Health Index (PHI), which includes PSA, Free PSA, and a biomarker for prostate cancer. It is more accurate than PSA alone. Have you had a recent mp-MRI of your prostate? That would be useful in helping determine if there are any suspicious areas that would justify a biopsy.

Posts.Title: New pc diagnosis & new to site

Posts.Content: Don't know how I missed this in 2016, but here is an article about the results of both low and medium-risk patients having SBRT radiation treatments at the Swedish Cancer Institute in Seattle. We know that 5-year results with low-risk PCa don't mean much, as other studies have shown no difference in mortality after 10 years, regardless if they did RP, RT, or AS. But, the intermediate-risk patients are what makes this study interesting. Ninety-seven percent were recurrence-free after five years. That, IMHO, is super-impressive, and with few side effects. "For the 137 patients with intermediate risk disease (T1B-T2b, Gleason = 7, and PSA of 10 or less, or Gleason 6 or lower with a PSA between 10 and 20), 97% were recurrence-free at 5 years, a result “that matches the best results in radiotherapy for intermediate-risk patients, and matches the best results for, for example, dose-escalated IMRT [intensity-modulated radiation therapy],” https://www.mdedge.com/oncologypractice/article/114784/genitourinary-cancer/prostate-cancer-recurrence-rates-low-sbrt Now, it's on to the high-risk patients, since SBRT delivers the same total dosage as a HDR brachy boost. Those results, if they pan out, will be a new weapon to fight all localized PCa.

Posts.Title: New pc diagnosis & new to site

Posts.Content: Chuck, The NCCN guidleines for prostate cancer recommend AS for both very low risk and also low risk patients. Your reference to the "less than fifty percent of a core" is only specified in the very low risk group. But, active surveillance is also the first listed option for the low risk group. NCCN Prostate Cancer guidelines, p.42 and 46. I have no issue with being conservative with advice when people's lives are affected, but, IMHO, only stating the criteria of the very low risk group seems to offer only partial advice.

Posts.Content: I would resist having a biopsy at this time, if I were you. They are not risk or pain free, and there really hasn't been any red line crossed that would suggest that one is required. A PSA less than 4 for your age sounds pretty normal. I would suggest that your next blood test be Prostate Health Index (PHI), which includes PSA, Free PSA, and a biomarker for prostate cancer. It is more accurate than PSA alone. Have you had a recent mp-MRI of your prostate? That would be useful in helping determine if there are any suspicious areas that would justify a biopsy.

Posts.Title: Do I REALLY Need Another Biopsy

Posts.Content: Djin, Good information. But, while BT (both LDR and HDR) has impressive results, their usage has declined sharply over the past dozen years. There was a detailed discussion about this trend on another forum last week. It appears that the use of both types of BT fell between 50 to 70 percent from 2004 to 2014. That would be about the time that RALP skyrocketed into popularity. Why? Especially since RALP has not proven to have better outcomes than BT? Well, it seems that providers can make a lot more money by doing RALP (and IMRT) than either form of BT. At least, that was the opinion of this other forum's posters. In a perfect world, a comparatively good technology would continue to gain market share. That has not been the case with BT, which continues to lose practictioners.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by PDV Sildenfil is the active ingredient in Viagra and it is definitely available as a generic. I've been using it for over a year now and it works great--just ask my wife! Sildenafil is approved for heart failure. It is being prescribed off-label in your case. And, it's dosage is below that of a Viagra pill. Of course, it all works out the same, as we both know. But, technically, there is no generic Viagra by prescription for ED until December.

Posts.Title: Cialis cost confusion?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 Welcome ddvh: On this site, you will find many people who will gladly share their experiences in order to help others and I have no doubt that you will be the beneficiary of some very intelligent and caring feedback. At the same time, many of us continue to learn via this sharing mechanism. With that said, I am floored by the fact that your Dad, at age 50, began to religiously obtain and record his many PSA tests over the next 10 years, BUT apparently took no action relative to his PSA test results. Of the 28 PSA tests listed, every one of the 28 had a reading that should have caused bells to start ringing and red lights flashing to alert him that his PSA results FAR exceeded the norm. Has your Dad declined a biopsy and treatment for the last 10 years? Michael asked: - What did his primary care MD tell your dad about his steadily rising PSA over the past 10 years? Uh-huh!! Patients are free to accept or reject a doctor's recommendation for a prostate biopsy; however, after demonstrating 28 out of 28 times that the patient "could" be suffering from prostate cancer and he rejects same, some doctors would fire the patient. Could you share with us what happened that possibly allowed prostate cancer to spread for 10 years unabated? You wrote: My father(Age 59), has recently been diagnosed with PC on 2/25, we are still trying to soak it all in. That's simply not true as nearly any non-medical professional on this website could have told you the same thing 8 years ago based on his PSA test results. And if your Dad was not the one who declined follow-up, than he almost certainly has a viable malpractice case against the doctor who failed to recommend action. Best of luck, Jim I will echo Jim's reaction, There is a big gap in our making sense of this ten year history. Like many others, when my psa hit 4, my PCP sent me to a urologist who scheduled for a biopsy. A negative DRE and no symptoms made no difference - the psa level of 4 required a biopsy. Period. Maybe today, there would be an additional blood test or two, but certainly not ten years ago. Any other details you can provide us with will help us formulate our best responses to your dad's situation.

Posts.Content: Ready, Prostate coils are usually used with 1.5T MRI's. The 3T (newer) MRI's usually use an apron which contains the necessary circuitry. The newer technique is more accurate, and avoids the pain of the rectal coil. MultiHance is a contrast agent, so that sharpens the images. Now to wait and see what what the biopsy says. Good luck.

Posts.Title: A Little News Today!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by IndyLou If you are in the US, Cialis is still on-patent. No physician should be writing you a prescription for a generic, which is why you should question this claim. Viagra is off-patent in the US, and generic options may be available. Actually, Pfizer's U.S. patent on Viagra is still in force. But, relief is on the way, starting in December. From an AP press release: "Pfizer's patent protecting Viagra from generic competition expires in April 2020, but Teva Pharmaceuticals USA Inc. will be allowed to launch its generic version in the United States on Dec. 11, 2017. Teva Pharmaceuticals USA is a division of Israeli-based Teva Industries Ltd."

Posts.Title: Cialis cost confusion?

Posts.Content: Carmel, Sorry that you are dealing with unwelcome news. We have all been through this, and can relate to your emotions. The more data that we can have, the more informed opinions we can offer you. You should be able to get a copy of the biopsy pathology report. Many medical offices post them online for patient access through a portal. When you have the report, then please create a signature like those of members here, with the relevant Gleason scores, and other data from that report. Prostate cancer has a spectrum of severity, from indolent to life-threatening. But, it is usually slow growing, so there is no necessity for action this month. Please take the time to learn as much as you can, and try to figure out the best course of action. Hopefully, we can help answer some questions for you.

Posts.Title: Elevated PSA at 37 years old

Posts.Content: I live by three mantras: Decision, resolution, closure. You have to make a decision, take action to resolve that decision, and then enjoy the inner peace without looking back.. If you are going to have any satisfaction from AS, then you must not re-examine your decision every waking hour. As my children told me years ago "The only thing that you need to know about prostate cancer is when your next appointment is". I don't know how constant worry stacks up against the known SE's of various treatments, but I would guess that it can be very powerful and distressing. That may be a greater burden for you than having immediate treatment with it's issues.

Posts.Title: Elevated PSA at 37 years old

Posts.Content: Maverick, With only a small amount of G6 cancer found on biopsy, you don't have to rush into treatment, if you don't want to. As Pratoman suggested, a second opinion on your slides and a 3T mpMRI will provide more assurance of the true amount of cancer. Also, there are at least three genomics tests, like Prolaris and OncotypeDX, which help predict the likelihood of the cancer spreading. I had a biopsy result exactly like yours a few years ago, and the advice I received was to go on Active Surveillance. Now, because you are 47 and I was then 68, that probably influenced that decision. There is a lot of information for you and your wife to become aware of and compare. There are also other, newer options in addition to surgery and radiation, although those don't have much long term data yet. Keep asking all the questions you can think of. Ultimately, you have a big choice to make, and any choice, even not treating now, is something that you must be confident is right for you.

Posts.Title: Targeted biopsy question

Posts.Content: As far as the "less than three positive cores" criterion, that is today the official protocol for patients under 65 years of age. There are, however, studies at the NCI and JH using an expanded set of criteria that includes up to four positive cores. While a paper was published recently stating that the pathology results from both set of standards are the same, there apparently needs to be more supporting data before the published protocol is revised. Time will tell, the science is always evolving.

Posts.Title: It's official, it's not cancer!

Posts.Content: Carmel, Sorry that you are dealing with unwelcome news. We have all been through this, and can relate to your emotions. The more data that we can have, the more informed opinions we can offer you. You should be able to get a copy of the biopsy pathology report. Many medical offices post them online for patient access through a portal. When you have the report, then please create a signature like those of members here, with the relevant Gleason scores, and other data from that report. Prostate cancer has a spectrum of severity, from indolent to life-threatening. But, it is usually slow growing, so there is no necessity for action this month. Please take the time to learn as much as you can, and try to figure out the best course of action. Hopefully, we can help answer some questions for you.

Posts.Title: Elevated PSA at 37 years old

Posts.Content: I live by three mantras: Decision, resolution, closure. You have to make a decision, take action to resolve that decision, and then enjoy the inner peace without looking back.. If you are going to have any satisfaction from AS, then you must not re-examine your decision every waking hour. As my children told me years ago "The only thing that you need to know about prostate cancer is when your next appointment is". I don't know how constant worry stacks up against the known SE's of various treatments, but I would guess that it can be very powerful and distressing. That may be a greater burden for you than having immediate treatment with it's issues.

Posts.Title: My husband was diagnosed last night. This doesn't feel real. What should I do?

Posts.Content: Denis has asked an excellent question that it is difficult to find hard numbers for. I recall seeing some stats that were 60 percent surgery, 25 percent radiation, and the other unknown. But, also, I have seen recent stats showing 50 percent of newly diagnosed low risk men are choosing active surveillance, especially those being treated at large institutions. I suspect that the large numbers for surgery are because the diagnosis is always made from a biopsy performed by a urologist, who may be quick to suggest "I can cure you". Who could resist that offer at that moment? The statement about "there is no chance to do surgery after radiation" is mostly true, but a radiation proponent will reply "so what?". Radiation appears to have a lower incidence of BCR than surgery, and cryotherapy, FLA, HIFU, and now SBRT and HDRBT are all being used to do local salvage treatments should primary radiation fail. So, that pro-surgery talking point would be quickly challenged on a pro-radiation forum. My former specialist at Johns Hopkins, who is widely published and considered among the 'best and brightest" in the field of prostate cancer, told another patient that radiation was overtaking surgery in efficacy, and that studies would soon show that. So, past and current statistics, whille interesting, may not be the best guidelines for the future. Hopefully, in the future, immunotherapy will make all these treatments obsolete...hopefully.

Posts.Title: Newbie to the forum

Posts.Content: mikev, Your concerns are normal for men on AS. We are always fearful of our next test, be it PSA, MRI, or biopsy. That's the price we pay for monitoring our cancer, rather than deal with the downsides of possible overtreatment. In your case, a confirmatory follow-up biopsy is required by some AS programs to better assure that the first one did not miss anything more significant. So, that is a prudent test, in any event. As for waiting for test or pathology reports, try to enroll in a patient portal at that practice. I usually get all my results online within three days, usually before the doctors contact me.

Posts.Content: You could consider the PHI test, which is used by Johns Hopkins instead of the 4K Score. The cost is about $110. But, as ejc61 stated, those biomarker tests are designed to see if a biopsy can be avoided, whereas an MRI presents a whole different perspective and data. I've had plenty of both kinds of tests, and believe that the MRI is far more valuable than any biomarker assay.

So, take some deep breaths and wait to see what the biopsy results are. Even if the doctor says "we found some cancer", he may next say "we have a program here that would be a good fit for you". Hopefully, in your case, nothing problematic will be found. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: First Post -- Awaiting 2nd opinion on biopsy and a few questions

Posts.Content: If you are set against surgery, and are looking at new and little-used (so far) treatments, then you should add cryotherapy to your list of options. It can be used on only the one side of your prostate where the cancer was found, and has fewer side effects than surgery, from what I've read. You could also look at HIFU, FLA, TFT, and an alphabet soup of possible other treatments and experimental vaccines and genetic modifications. Still, what Chuck and the others cautioned about is undeniable. It's OK to make your own decisions about your life, just be sure that the option you pick has a good track record of non-recurrence.

It is designed to augment a psa test and provide additional suspicion of cancer. That sounds good to me. The more tests to prove or disprove the likelihood of cancer, the better we all are. Every urologist should know not to perform a DRE before taking a blood sample for psa. I can't understand him doing that. But, apparently, it has no effect on the Apifiny test.

Posts.Title: Astronaut survives prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Joy, Please have you or him, or his brother become his own advocate. Do not let the advice of one specialist make THE decision for his future. At this point, he appears to be a "very low risk" or Group Grade 1 on the WHO ranking. That calls for no radical intervention. None. Just more intensive monitoring. In Sweden, where the the Government decides the health care criteria, active surveillance is advised for patients like him, and 90 percent chose that, with only six percent of the men electing surgery. Here, with our profit motive, only about 45 percent go into AS, and the others are processed into surgery. Not right, in my humble opinion. BTW, people in Sweden live longer than Americans.

Posts.Title: Newbie... Tomorrow my love meets with urologist for treatment options

Posts.Content: After ten years of being on AS and speaking with many other men, I have come to accept that some of them just dont want to deal with having untreated cancer in their bodies. While I can cite them many opinions and studies to support their continuing on AS, they simply arent comfortable, and feel compelled to have treatment. Thats your choice. Regarding reference books, while Dr. Patrick Walsh was the dean of prostate surgeons in the 1980s and 1990s, he did not write the chapters on other treatments in his new edition. They were written by a medical writer. So, I would suggest that you read the following new book before making a decision on which treatment. Dr. Mark Scholz The Key to Prostate Cancer for which he interviewed 30 other prostate cancer experts. Scholz, himself a surgeon, presents a cautionary theme that men need to fully explore ALL their options. Good luck, and keep asking.

Posts.Title: Viadur (leuprolide acetate implant)

Posts.Content: PCASpouse, It sounds like you are planning for a specific treatment without a definite diagnosis of prostate cancer. Keep in mind that about 35-50 percent (depending on which study) of prostate cancers will never need any type of treatment. Even if he is diagnosed with a Gleason 7 or higher grade of PCa, there is usually a pause of six weeks or so before surgery is scheduled, to allow for the biopsy trauma to subside. Meanwhile. that time should be used to consult with various specialists to make sure that whatever treatment is chosen is a choice that he and you are most confident with. You can google "prostate treatment regret" to see what I am referring to. Also, attending local PCa support groups, where you can hear the advice of men who have had different treatments, can be enlightening. Good luck.

Posts.Content: PCASpouse, There is an exciting new solution for BPH issues. It does not require surgery, yet it reduces the prostate size by 85 percent. It's prostate artery embolization (PAE). Two hospitals near me in the D.C. Area were part of a highly successful clinical trial a few years ago, and the procedure is now available to the public. Plastic balls are placed into the arteries supplying the prostate, causing it to dramatically shrink. It is an outpatient procedure performed by a interventional radiologist. I also had a chance meeting with a radiologist with a large practice in Los Angeles, and he said that PAE was revolutionizing prostate therapy. Some more info for you to absorb.

Posts.Title: Biopsy upcoming. Hope I'm doing the right thing.

Posts.Content: Gulf coaster, can you please provide us with some additional data to help us give you the most informed feedback. How old are you? Were the two positive cancer cores on the same side, or bilateral? Were any genomics tests run on those slides? What advice is your urologist giving you. A negative biopsy after a positive one is an indicator of an indolent cancer IF the suspect areas were identified by a 3T MRI, and the last biopsy was fused with those images. What kind of imaging have you had? Have all three biopsies been "blind"? More detail of your psa history for the past five or ten years would also be very helpful in determining doubling time and other trends. Going off of AS and into any type of interventional treatment is a major life decision. To help you make that type of choice, we need all the background info you can provide us. Thanks, and good luck.

Posts.Content: I think that participating in these forums adds to my appreciation of how unpredictable life can be, and to be glad to live every day and enjoy my friends and family to the fullest. We are all only one bad test result (with any disease) away from those who are now in a desperate state. Often, I will mention a post that I have just read to my partner, and she will ask why I relate to others with more serious diagnoses. Well, I have been very, very lucky with health, agility, and life in general, but I realize that is merely the luck of the draw, having lost my father and brother to other cancers at younger ages. Being aware of this, and possibly, once in a while, having something useful to share, is part of my goal to know life as fully as possible.

Posts.Title: do ya ever wonder?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another Your age, PSA history and current PSA velocity call for a biopsy. Avoiding it only avoids dealing with the possibility of cancer. Taking a long path with many tests of varying degrees of usefulness will result in the same event, a biopsy. Deny and delay and you lose any advantage of early detection. You can't outsmart cancer. All paths for you lead to a biopsy. Nothing else moves this process forward faster. You are lucky. You already know your next step. Some never have a chance to see it coming. Don't squander it, too many brothers have suffered building this path for us. The purpose of ExoDx, PHI, 4 K Score, PCA3, and SelectMDX is to help men avoid unnecessary biopsies. The rationale for avoiding biopsies is twofold: (1) they are not without risks, and (2) diagnosis of low risk cancer has led in many cases to overtreatment. Three of one hundred biopsied men require hospitalization for sepsis, which has proven fatal in rare cases. Overtreatment has been discussed in depth, and doesn't need a rehash here. At this time, and from what has been written, keeptrying has one high PSA result. That could be due to any number of benign causes. What is the harm in his waiting to see if the next reading is lower and/or having another of those tests? Yes, only a biopsy can diagnose prostate cancer, and I respect your stance against men's denial when they need to act, but I agree with his urologist that waiting a short time and having more testing is a reasonable course.

I just wish I had the MRI option when I first had my elevated PSA Just asking Because of the fpsa being so low. I usually oppose random biopsies, and have had bad experiences with two of mine. But, there needs to be more done to understand that free psa result. If his psa was above 4, then I would suggest PHI, 4K, and/or PCA3 tests as the next step, but I don't think they are indicated for psa < 4.

Posts.Title: Very nervous

Posts.Content: Rylee, I have been involved with JH Urology for eight years now, and am in their Active Surveillance program. No regrets, thankful every day that they put me under AS from day 1 of suspected PCa. My uro-oncologist is Ashley Ross, and I recommend him as among the "best and brightest" of the younger generation of PCa authorities. Generally, bilateral involvement is now a disqualifier from their AS program. But, that is only for newly-diagnosed. If you have a history of stable AS monitoring, they may recommend that you stay with it. One of my biopsies showed a small amount of bilateral involvement, and my case was sent to a review committee which recommended that I stay in the program. My last biopsy was negative...so, all good. Given all the posts that I have read on various prostate cancer forums about the side effects of some treatments, I believe that a man should stay on AS until (1) he psychologically HAS to try to get rid of the cancer; or (2) he is presented with results that his risk classification has significantly increased. Otherwise, stay the course. Good luck.
Posts.Signature: DOB: May 1944 In Active Surveillance program at Johns Hopkins Strict protocol of tests, including PHI, DRE, MRI, and biopsy. Six biopsies from 2009 to 2019. Numbers 1, 2, and 5 were negative. Numbers 3,4, and 6 were positive with 5% Gleason(3+3) found. Last one was Precision Point transperineal. PSA 4.4, fPSA 24, PHI 32 Hopefully, I can remain untreated. So far, so good.
Posts.Title: Second opinion John's Hopkins

Posts.Content: These statistics from the American Cancer Society should help you calm down. Only 2 percent of the men diagnosed now with prostate cancer will die from prostate cancer within 10 years. Only 5 percent will die from prostate cancer in 15 years. And, treatments are becoming more effective with time. https://www.cancer.org/cancer/prosta...val-rates.html Now, that said, moving ahead with a biopsy and other diagnostic work is essential to know if he has cancer, and to ensure that he has the best odds to beat it.

Posts.Title: Very nervous

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Tybeeman ASAdovocate, Why would you think he needs a biopsy if they did a MRI and found nothing? Those biopsies are hit and miss to start with. I just wish I had the MRI option when I first had my elevated PSA Just asking Because of the fpsa being so low. I usually oppose random biopsies, and have had bad experiences with two of mine. But, there needs to be more done to understand that free psa result. If his psa was above 4, then I would suggest PHI, 4K, and/or PCA3 tests as the next step, but I don't think they are indicated for psa < 4.

Posts.Title: Very nervous

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another Your age, PSA history and current PSA velocity call for a biopsy. Avoiding it only avoids dealing with the possibility of cancer. Taking a long path with many tests of varying degrees of usefulness will result in the same event, a biopsy. Deny and delay and you lose any advantage of early detection. You can't outsmart cancer. All paths for you lead to a biopsy. Nothing else moves this process forward faster. You are lucky. You already know your next step. Some never have a chance to see it coming. Don't squander it, too many brothers have suffered building this path for us. The purpose of ExoDx, PHI, 4 K Score, PCA3, and SelectMDX is to help men avoid unnecessary biopsies. The rationale for avoiding biopsies is twofold: (1) they are not without risks, and (2) diagnosis of low risk cancer has led in many cases to overtreatment. Three of one hundred biopsied men require hospitalization for sepsis, which has proven fatal in rare cases. Overtreatment has been discussed in depth, and doesn't need a rehash here. At this time, and from what has been written, keeptrying has one high PSA result. That could be due to any number of benign causes. What is the harm in his waiting to see if the next reading is lower and/or having another of those tests? Yes, only a biopsy can diagnose prostate cancer, and I respect your stance against men's denial when they need to act, but I agree with his urologist that waiting a short time and having more testing is a reasonable course.

Posts.Title: ExoDx (Ordered by PCP) Encouraging Score, and Urologist Initial Visit

Posts.Content: I think that participating in these forums adds to my appreciation of how unpredictable life can be, and to be glad to live every day and enjoy my friends and family to the fullest. We are all only one bad test result (with any disease) away from those who are now in a desperate state. Often, I will mention a post that I have just read to my partner, and she will ask why I relate to others with more serious diagnoses. Well, I have been very, very lucky with health, agility, and life in general, but I realize that is merely the luck of the draw, having lost my father and brother to other cancers at younger ages. Being aware of this, and possibly, once in a while, having something useful to share, is part of my goal to know life as fully as possible.

Posts.Title: NO surgery?

Posts.Content: Djin, What this trial is doing is testing the use of higher dosages of IMRT in fewer sessions. Like comparing the current 39 sessions to 25 sessions using higher amounts of Gy's. I have seen references to this type of study recently, with positive initial comments. In fact, the chief radiologist at a local hospital told me two years ago that insurance payments were the main reason it was not widely done. As far as your urologist wanting 20 year+ studies on radiation, you should have asked where they are for RALP? Of course, they don't exist. That logic reminds me of an exchange with a surgery advocate who told me a few years ago that SBRT was suspect because it did not have 10 year results. Recently, He made some claim against SBRT, and I replied with some 10 year results, which were impressive. He then responded that only 12 year studies were valid. What a joke! I guess that I should have asked him for the 3,000 year studies on basic surgery

Posts.Content: As Fairwind stated, the first biopsy is usually done with ultrasound guidance. Subsequent biopsies, especially if an MRI has seen suspicious areas, may use those images to target the needles. After a positive diagnosis, or if on Active Surveillance, MRI's are typically used for determining if a biopsy is justified, and where it will be aimed.

Posts.Title: Biopsy questions???

Posts.Content: Results of the biopsy in two weeks? Why not sooner? Ive had five, and always had the results within three working days. Does this practice have a patient portal like MyChart, where you can see your tests online, as soon as available? Two weeks is a long time to be anxious. Call them and ask why the delay.
Posts.Title: First Biopsy completed, waiting for results

Posts.Content: Denis, As you probably read recently on another forum, the use of both LDR and HDR BT have declined 50 percent or more since 2004. Like yourself, the well-informed man who posted those statistics was somewhat puzzled, as the impressive clinical outcomes should have resulted in more popularity. But, the institutions found the shiny new toy of robotic surgery to have a great marketing appeal and profitability. I had a social conversation with a professor of radiology a few months ago, and he he stated that low profitability due to insurance guidelines had caused the decrease of BT usage, and was retarding the popularity of SBRT, which was growing, but more slowly than expected.

Posts.Title: HDR BT literature search all positive

Posts.Content: For its Active Surveillance study group, Johns Hopkins switched to the PHI test several years ago. PHI includes PSA, free PSA, a prostate cancer biomarker, and an algorithm that produces a score on the likelihood of finding aggressive cancer on biopsy. I have heard that it costs about $100, about double that of psa alone, and worth it for its superior accuracy.

Posts.Content: I would guess that his doctors are doing the radiation with a curative intent. Radiation and surgery are equally effective for localized prostate cancer. For locally advanced, as he may be, the radiation beams can hit not only the prostate, but also penetrate the surrounding areas, killing the cancer there. It may be possible to eradicate the cancer, and not have to worry about hormone resistance. There is reason to be hopeful.

Posts.Title: NO surgery?

Posts.Content: Some AS programs use criteria for remaining life expectancy, but I now have seen some that don't. Under the ones that consider life expectancy, age 52 would be too young. If you are going to have an "informal" active surveillance, as opposed to enrolling in a study program, then your urologist will set the intervals for PSA, MRI, and biopsies, probably at the same frequency as in formal programs. He/she will best determine what psa velocity or other test results would trigger an intervention. You've been advised to do AS for now, and that makes sense, as long as you faithfully keep your appointments.

Posts.Title: Club Membership

Posts.Content: Pratoman, About three years ago, when it was likely that I had some PCa, I went deeply into scouring the web for every scintilla of information. At one point, I emailed my two adult children with my "take" on a very clinical study report that I believed augured well for my outcome. I received replies within the hour. Both essentially said: "Dad, the only thing you need to know about prostate cancer is the date of your next appointment." Of course, they were right, and maybe that is the advice that would most benefit you right now. Stop worrying, and see what your next results are.

Posts.Content: For what it's worth, I recently posted a thread entitled "Does radiation treatment for prostate cancer coincidentally alleviate BPH symptoms?" This was on another forum that is known to have RT advocates. Interesting replies. Some said that RT shrunk their prostates by at least half, and improved urine flow. Others did not notice any improvement. So, it appears that RT has some coincidental benefits for some men, but not as dramatic as RP.

Posts.Title: What was your experience with flow rate after RP?

Posts.Content: I have seen this topic of needle tract seeding / needle tracking debated across the Internet forums for years. There are people who believe it with the fervor of cultists convinced that organized medicine is a greedy, evil empire. Forget their conspiracy rants, as Djin has given you the facts. You must have a biopsy to diagnose prostate cancer. Period. And, any chances of spreading the cancer is one in thousands. Your psa warrants a biopsy to determine if cancer is present. Odds are that it is not, but you cant take the chance of not knowing.
Posts.Title: Question about Biopsy

Posts.Content: Gunrun, I'm glad to hear that you changed doctors. Recommending surgery for a one percent G3+4 seems very drastic and unnecessary. However, while the MRI can detect areas of interest for a biopsy, it cannot, at this time, classify the grade of cancer. For example, I have a PIRADS 4 lesion. Sounds serious, right? But, it is almost all HGPIN, with less than 5 percent G3+3 cancer. FIVE biopsies to prove that! So, just keep going slow and accumulate the pathology data and knowledge that you need. You may want to add your birth year to your signature. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Bph

Posts.Content: You should relax and be content that only a very small amount of low-grade cancer was found. That puts you in very low risk classification. The targeted biopsy probably hit all the suspected areas, but found nothing or only HGPIN. HGPIN "looks" like cancer, both on an MRI and under a microscope. Only staining will differentiate it. I've been there, done that, several times. Right now, with those results, you should consider a regimen of Active Surveillance, as the amount of cancer found does not, in my humble opinion, merit any interventional treatment.

Posts.Content: This is a general question, that probably belongs in a Prostatitis Forum. I can't seem to Google the answer. We have seen cases where men with prostate cancer have reported PSA results in the thousands, up to 5200! But, how high can PSA go from other causes like BPH, infection, inflammation, sex, bike riding, biopsy trauma, etc.? My impression, which could be totally incorrect, is that it may not go above 10 or 20. This may be useful to know for understanding questions from new members with very high numbers.

Posts.Title: How high can PSA rise from non-Malignant Causes?

Posts.Content: In addition to Michael F's excellent advice, you would be wise to schedule consultations with one or more radiation oncologists. Either type of treatment can cure his cancer, but surgeons are not always well informed about radiation,so you need to speak with a specialist directly. If you have read Dr. Walsh's book, that is full of valuable information for a patient that has decided on surgery. But I often hear it criticized by advocates of radiation, saying that it is out-of-date regarding the new radiation technologies and improved results. So, be sure to read other sources, as well. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Went For My Annual Check Up!

Posts.Content: From what I've read (and I am one of the least qualified by experience), cases of Gleason 10 are managed rather than assumed "cured". That is because the cancer eventually mutates to defeat the chemical regimen being used. This is not gloom and doom. There are currently several clinical trials, not only of additional chemical regimens that go beyond those now used, but also of genomic and vaccine therapies that might actually kill the cancer cells and be a real "cure". The goal of the game is to keep buying time while progress on various fronts is being made every month. Please try to constantly research what clinical trials are open and where. Last month, I checked the website for Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (MSKCC). and they had 43 open clinical trials for prostate cancer. That's very encouraging.

Posts.Content: Welcome back! You can google "needle tract seeding' or 'needle tracking" to read articles about your concern. Not sure why your doctor did not discuss BPH medicines with you years ago. But, it sounds like you are going to find out more about condition in the near future.

Posts.Title: Cancer Research Institute: Emerging Concepts in Prostate Cancer Immunotherapy

Posts.Content: In addition to Michael F's excellent advice, you would be wise to schedule consultations with one or more radiation oncologists. Either type of treatment can cure his cancer, but surgeons are not always well informed about radiation,so you need to speak with a specialist directly. If you have read Dr. Walsh's book, that is full of valuable information for a patient that has decided on surgery. But I often hear it criticized by advocates of radiation, saying that it is out-of-date regarding the new radiation technologies and improved results. So, be sure to read other sources, as well. Good luck.

Posts.Title: The results are in

Posts.Content: Hi Ray, Sorry that you have to be here. We are the same age, and while I consider myself healthy, active, and agile, I would not consider choosing major surgery at our age, when there is an equally effective alternative. That is because I am always hearing about classmates having surgery for one thing or another, and it seems like they have far more complications and slower recoveries now than when younger. That is a pretty high psa. What does the biopsy pathology report say about the extent of the cancer? How many cores, how much of the prostate affected, and is there PNI or extracapsular extension (EPE)? Radiation can target a wide margin around the prostate if there is a concern of the cancer escaping. This is early in your learning process. There are hundreds of men here who have been through the decisions and the aftermaths, and they will certainly chime in with their great advice. Good luck.

There are other website forums that tilt towards RT, and another that promotes Focal Laser Ablation. All are populated by well meaning folks who were satisfied with their choices. I do know that there is an on-going trial at Johns Hopkins, but I have no idea what they have found out. So, ask your RT guy/gal every smart question you can, and, above all else, be content with whatever treatment and doctor that you eventually choose.

Posts.Title: Bph

Posts.Content: This article contains data comparing the various forms of radiation therapy. One of the charts clearly summarizes the comparison. While this data is for primary, not adjuvant treatment, it may still be useful for you. https://pcnrv.blogspot.ca/2016/08/pr...f-florida.html I have seen recent articles about PBT being used for salvage treatment, and also for SBRT being used instead of IMRT after RP. Don't have links to cite, but I recall that both the articles were to show the non-inferiority of PBT and also SBRT when compared to IMRT in limited patient trials. PBT is certainly more expensive than IMRT, as others have mentioned. An advantage to SBRT would be the far fewer number of sessions. As things stand now, IMRT is the most-used post-RP salvage treatment.

Can you get an OncotypeDX, Prolaris, or ConfirmMDX assay run on your biopsy slides? That may help determine if there is a risk of higher grade cancer. Posts.Title: 3t mri ?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by TN Bigfoot Just found this forum and looking forward to the discussions. Heard all the pro's/cons of biopsy at this stage but for me, knowing if PCa is a reality is better than Being on hold. Is there any value in pushing for another PSA before biopsy? Would be ~3 months since last test. Yes, I would suggest another round of testing before a biopsy (unlike the others, I have suffered the long lasting negative effects of two biopsies). But, not just another psa test, which is the least accurate measure. You should have either PHI or PCA3. Both are more accurate than psa alone, and not as affected by prostatitis. PHI uses a blood draw, and PCA3 uses urine after a vigorous DRE. PHI is used at Johns Hopkins, where it is a mandatory part of my surveillance program. Both tests have cut-off ranges to help in the decision to proceed to biopsy or not. Do you have any free psa results? Those are included as part of a PHI assay.

There must be more serious reservations. LDR BT has been performed for over 25 years, so "long term results" are certainly available. NYC mayor Rudy Giuliani had LDR BT in 2000. I have heard the payments issue from three radiologists. Both types of BT peaked in 2004, and usage and practitioners have decreased since then. The low rates of payment have impacted its availability. Its efficacy has not been an issue, to my knowledge.

Posts.Title: Next procedure scheduled

Posts.Content: Rooster22, Thanks for posting this. I had heard something about the gold nanopartices before, but this is quite informative. Also, this is the third piece of news about focal treatments this week. Dr. Walser at UT is reporting very good results with a small group of FLA patients. And, Dr. Pavlovich at JH is reporting impressive results with TULSA, a new HIFU variant, in a clinical trial. Just when I thought that focal treatments for PCa were being sidelined, it seems that newer, better ones are showing up. As the urologist in this video stated, this type of treatment can address those who are nervous about being on the borderline for AS. Progress.

Posts.Title: New member looking for help in analysing my PSA results

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mamadeesix Hubby's MRI showed several suspicious areas. So on to biopsy on April 20th. So far in this journey, I have been hoping that everything could be explained away with his enlarged prostate. After all, bph can cause increasing and higher psa numbers and even low free percentage numbers, if I understand right. Although the 9.5 free psa was a bit more concerning than the 6.7 psa alone, it could still be affected by bph, I think. Maybe I'm wrong there, or maybe it's just wishful thinking. Anyway..... I am thinking that finding suspicious areas on an MRI cannot be explained away by bph. It seems a bit of a game changer, considering the bph basket I put all our eggs in, so to speak. Any thoughts on this? Anything I should be asking at this point? I know nothing more than the suspicious areas....don't know if the doc. actually said more than that. Hubby is not nearly as obsessive about asking questions and trying to understand things as I am. He just knows he has to have another biopsy and what's more to know at this point. Is there any other reason for suspicious areas on an MRI than cancer? Dee Hubby: 1/2010 2.6 8/2012 3.1 4/2015 7.7 10/2015 6.9 9/2017 6.3 free 10.2 percent 3/2018 6.7 free 9.5 percent biopsy 2015, 12 cores negative MRI April 1, 2018 - several suspicious areas biopsy schedule April 20, 2018 Hemorrhages, scarring, benign lesions, and other structures can be mistaken for prostate cancer. What PIRADS scores were assigned to those areas on the MRI report? Generally, PIRADS scores below 4 cannot be assumed to be cancer. And, I have even seen posts by men with PIRADS 5 lesions that have been sampled by multiple targeted biopsies with no cancer found.

Posts.Title: Need a break

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by TN Bigfoot Just found this forum and looking forward to the discussions. Heard all the pro's/cons of biopsy at this stage but for me, knowing if PCa is a reality is better than Being on hold. Is there any value in pushing for another PSA before biopsy? Would be ~3 months since last test. Yes, I would suggest another round of testing before a biopsy (unlike the others, I have suffered the long lasting negative effects of two biopsies). But, not just another psa test, which is the least accurate measure. You should have either PHI or PCA3. Both are more accurate than psa alone, and not as affected by prostatitis. PHI uses a blood draw, and PCA3 uses urine after a vigorous DRE. PHI is used at Johns Hopkins, where it is a mandatory part of my surveillance program. Both tests have cut-off ranges to help in the decision to proceed to biopsy or not. Do you have any free psa results? Those are included as part of a PHI assay.

Posts.Title: Next procedure scheduled

Posts.Content: Thom, I may have an experience much different than the others that have posted, but I will try to relate it to your case. I have found that a prostate biopsy can TRIPLE your psa, and that the rise can last for six months. This happened to me TWICE! No antibiotics were recommended the second time, and they didn't make any difference the the first time. I found that a week of hot sitz baths returned my psa to normal both times. Again, I don't mean to argue with the above advice, it's just that I have walked down a different path, and want to offer you this input.

Posts.Title: PSA Doubling Time

Posts.Content: Relax...It could upgrade, or, it could not. I would not lose sleep over it, if I were you. Because of modern medicine and technology, you have some advance warning of a possible future cancer threat. My advice is that you consider yourself under active surveillance for a few years into the future, and make all the appointments for tests, MRIs, and biopsies that are recommended. Other than remembring and showing up for those appointments, you should not dwell on your possibly having cancer.

Posts.Title: Focal Therapy - a Top Experts Interview

Posts.Content: While I would normally rate an MRI over an CDUS, Duke Bahn is regarded the wizard of CDUS diagnostics. So, you do need a tie breaker. Can you get an OncotypeDX, Prolaris, or ConfirmMDX assay run on your biopsy slides? That may help determine if there is a risk of higher grade cancer. The next specialist may need to order a targeted biopsy. A PIRADS 5 could be nothing significant. It happens. But, it must be taken very seriously, and more tests are now needed.

Posts.Title: Duke Bahn and yet another opinion in the near future

Posts.Content: With the information that you've provided, I don't believe that you should be assuming that surgery (or other intervention) is inevitable. You are well within the guidelines of AS protocols at this point. Just keep your appointments, get other opinions as you think necessary and keep building your knowledge base. As others have noted, a psa rise can have other causes. Relax, and see what the next test results are. Also, as noted above, the T3 MRI is an excellent pre-biopsy tool.

Posts.Title: MRI results and a ?

Posts.Content: Jack, Did you get a copy of the MRI report? If so, did it state that a lesion was identified? Was a PIRADS score assigned? If so, what was that number? If the suspicious area did not contain a PIRADS lesion rated above 3, then that is a hopeful sign that you may not have a serious cancer. Still, with the positive DRE, the biopsy is probably necessary.

Posts.Title: Need your opinion

Posts.Content: Diesel, You are at the outer edge of risk for AS. Forget the usual program guidelines for this discussion. There are some men with similar profiles who are avoiding treatment, for various reasons. Laurence Klotz has recently described the added risk they have. But, if you defer treatment, you must be aware of that risk, and commit to acting if there is any future progress. With bilateral involvement, and some G4, I would only take the time to find the treatment I was comfortable with, and be ready to embrace it, as some test will be likely be worse, sooner or later. I wish you well.

Posts.Title: Need your opinion

Posts.Content: Hi Al, Welcome and so sorry to read about your scary experience with sepsis from a biopsy. From what I have read, that happens in 1 to 3 cases out of 100, and about 1 out of 1400 biopsy patients die from the procedure. They are not to be taken lightly, and hopefully will be replaced by non-invasive blood or urine assays in the near future. You have already received valuable advice. Chuck is correct that you should demand a copy of your biopsy pathology report NOW. Many practices have an online patient portal where you you can see your test results as soon as they are processed. You should ask if that access is available, In any, case, that office should be able to email you the report today. Many low risk cases of prostate cancer are indolent and will never need treatment, and can be safely monitored, avoiding the side effects. Yours may be one of those cases. Please provide us the data when you get it so that all the options can be discussed. Like the others said, your urologist has not served you well, and you should find another one.

Posts.Title: I just Want To Introduce Myself!

Posts.Content: Thom, I may have an experience much different than the others that have posted, but I will try to relate it to your case. I have found that a prostate biopsy can TRIPLE your psa, and that the rise can last for six months. This happened to me TWICE! No antibiotics were recommended the second time, and they didn't make any difference the the first time. I found that a week of hot sitz baths returned my psa to normal both times. Again, I don't mean to argue with the above advice, it's just that I have walked down a different path, and want to offer you this input.

Posts.Title: Need your opinion

Posts.Content: As the others have stated, there is no certainty that you have prostate cancer. Men can have PSA's in the 30's from BPH and other benign causes. Most initial biopsies do not find prostate cancer, so try to calm down and not get too far ahead of yourself. Seeing a urologist is your next step. He/she will recommend what tests you need. If you don't like or trust that one, go to another one. Regarding MRI vs. color Doppler, I believe that color Doppler is an older technology, as I rarely hear anyone mention it anymore. The 3Telsa MRI's are the standard imaging machines for prostate exams.

Posts.Title: I just Want To Introduce Myself!

Posts.Content: OTS, If you go with RT, the triple play of ADT, EBRT and BBT (brachy boost) appears to have some really good results. Actually, with BBT involved, the ADT may not make a difference. And (damn - more complications ) the boost can come from LDR-BT, HDR-BT, or SBRT. SBRT (Cyberknife or TrueBeam) was designed to supply the same Gy's as HDR-BT, without being invasive. All three of these boost treatments are available, and perhaps you should ask why this RO is preferring one type over the other two.

Most initial biopsies do not find prostate cancer, so try to calm down and not get too far ahead of yourself. Seeing a urologist is your next step. He/she will recommend what tests you need. If you don't like or trust that one, go to another one. Regarding MRI vs. color Doppler, I believe that color Doppler is an older technology, as I rarely hear anyone mention it anymore. The 3Telsa MRI's are the standard imaging machines for prostate exams.
Posts.Signature: DOB: May 1944 In Active Surveillance program at Johns Hopkins Strict protocol of tests, including PHI, DRE, MRI, and biopsy. Six biopsies from 2009 to 2019. Numbers 1, 2, and 5 were negative. Numbers 3,4, and 6 were positive with 5% Gleason(3+3) found. Last one was Precision Point transperineal. PSA 4.4, fPSA 24, PHI 32 Hopefully, I can remain untreated. So far, so good.
Posts.Title: How Bad is a PSA over 9?

Posts.Content: As you can see, that wait is unacceptable. It is your test that you are paying for. Make sure that you can contact the lab within 48 hours, or, find another doctor who has a reasonable schedule.

Posts.Title: PSA result wait time

Posts.Content: Your psa rise could just be a spike. I would recommend that you have a PHI blood test. It includes psa, fpsa, and Propsa, with a formula to determine your likelihood of PCa, which is more accurate than psa or fpsa alone. You would have to have stage IV metastatic prostate cancer to have it affect the joints you cited. Extremely unlikely with your psa.

Posts.Title: Were your PCa treatment results what you expected?

Posts.Content: In addition to the clips that RobLee has cited, there is also a recent intervention procedure known as prostate artery embolization (PAE) that blocks the arteries supplying the prostate, shrinking its size by about 85 percent. Two hospitals near me were part of a clinical trial a few years ago, and now they are advertising it, with very impressive before-and-after images of how much it shrinks the prostate. This procedure is performed by interventional radiologists.

Posts.Title: Some Prostate Drugs May Do Harm

Posts.Content: Thanks, Djin, for this valuable new research. Two other quotes from that link that caught my attention: "Again at 5 years, incidence rates of distant metastasis were 24% for the radical prostatectomy group, 24% for the EBRT plus ADT group, and 8% for the EBRT + BT plus ADT group." And: Kishan summarized: "I would also stress that, should patients move forward with standard radiotherapy, they consider the importance of receiving at least high-dose radiation, along with a long duration of androgen-deprivation therapy, as in this subgroup. Outcomes were better." The only downside that I have heard about this triple whatever of ADT, EBRT, and BT is that the ADT has very serious effects on QOL which may lead the patient to think over the choice, regardless of how effective. Just my not-very-informed opinion.

Posts.Title: Alternative Medicine Claims

Posts.Content: Mark, As Highlander asked, we need to know more of your pathology. If you are Risk Grade 1 or 2 on the new WHO grade scale, then your default action is AS, according to the current NCCN guidelines. Anything else is overtreatment, unless you demand it, But that doesn't change it from being overtreatment. Of course a uro will recommend surgery, that's what they do. There are many outdated myths regarding radiation, and many uro's repeat them. The radiation types receiving the latest good reports are SBRT and HDR brachytherapy. You should be aware of them. Walsh's book is fine for someone planning on surgery. Instead, I would suggest Mark Scholz' "Invasion of the Prostate Snatchers", also written by a prostate surgeon, but warning about unnecessary overtreatment.

Posts.Title: 3+3 = decision time

Posts.Content: Rich, Thanks for your first post here. Sorry that you have to be here. My opinions are my own, and I am sure that others will chime in with theirs. The usual reaction to a 47 yo with 3 or 4 cores of G7 would be "surgery, get it out!". But, that second reading of 3 cores of G 3+3 makes me want to caution you. Yes, you will hear from others that the younger, you are, the better you can recover from surgery. The flip side of that coin is those could also be more years to suffer with an unexpectedly lower quality of life. The percent of core involvement does not matter under the Johns Hopkins AS criteria revised in 2014. They are also working to prove that the number of cores also does not matter. If cancer is found on both sides, that would matter, but does not appear to be your case. I would suggest that you seriously reconsider your decision to rush into surgery. Things will never be the same, and it may not be necessary, at least at this time. If you are adamant that you want surgery, then go for it, and don't look back. But, you've only had a month to reflect on what the future could be for you. I would recommend that you read this recent article. Be sure to consider the "Conclusions" section. https://prostatecancerinfolink.net/2...-surveillance/ Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: New diagnosis, new member & question regarding 2nd opinion

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by TinkerbellRM27 Just wanted to share this link to a formative guide released by John Hopkins. My Dad has found it very helpful to understand more of his options. Wanted to share for others who unfortunately need to join this group too. http://www.cincinnatiprostate.com/up...treat_2011.pdf I am a member of a JH prostate cancer study group, and have been reading these publications for about ten years. This link is for the 2011 publication, which was based on even older studies. I believe that the references to both active surveillance and radiation are now out-of-date, and newer reading material should be consulted. That said, if you are decided on surgery, or recently had surgery, those chapters should be very valuable to you.

Posts.Title: Were your PCa treatment results what you expected?

Posts.Content: I just happened to google "surgery vs radiation prostate cancer forum" and got 684,000 hits! Yes, that's how intense this topic has become. And, it certainly cannot be helpful to newbie's facing life-altering decisions. Of course, that's because there is no definitive cure-all yet, and very few are one hundred percent happy with the solutions today. I spend a lot of time on Facebook, and recently joined two groups there. One is for prostate cancer guys who have chosen surgery. The group rules state that the purpose is to support men who are about to have, or have had RP. No discussion of any other treatments are allowed. Very clear, got it! The second FB group I recently joined is for "non-surgical prostate cancer treatments". Everything about PCa is welcome, except the mention of surgery, which will result in immediate banning. OMG! That division is...what can I say? I participated in political forums, even with dial-up access, for over 30 years (gave it up after the 2016 elections), and am afraid that I am seeing the same tribalism develop with PC advice. I even see this at my local support meetings. Diet vs. surgery vs. radiation. And, on the radiation front, IMRT vs. SBRT vs. BT (two types) vs. PT. Yes, I also see this at face-to-face seminars. Thank you for allowing me to vent. But, we must do better. ALL the above-mentioned treatments have cured and saved innumerable men. But, this "no-mention-of-the-others" rigidity does not serve any of us well.

Posts.Title: Letter to the Editor: PCa Opinions are Becoming as Intense as Politics

Posts.Content: Welcome NJ, In order to provide you with the most accurate advice, we need more information. What has been your PSA history? Did you have a positive DRE, or do you have relatives with prostate cancer? A PSA of 4.4 is fine for me, but you may a lot younger, so your age is important. That 4K score would indicate that a biopsy is advised. If you can arrange to have an MRI before the biopsy, that can make it more accurate. Have you been referred to a urologist? If not, that would be a next step. So, tell us as much as you can about your situation, and the forum members are always willing to share their experiences and advise you.

Posts.Title: Pathologist Report

Posts.Content: Justin, You have received excellent advice from the above posters. The one thing everyone agrees upon is that you should not rush into a treatment. However, With your young age, some G4, and multiple pre-cancerous lesions, you may not have the option of being on AS for a long time, so continue asking and researching your future options. One suggestion I would add is that you have a genomics test, like OncotypeDX, Prolaris, Decipher, etc., done on your biopsy slides. That would add a data point for PCa aggressiveness that can help your decisions.

Posts.Content: Chuck, After seeing your eloquent and admirable reply, I had to look up the dictionary definition of bias, which turned out to have a stronger meaning than I realized. "prejudice in favor of or against one thing, person, or group compared with another, usually in a way considered to be unfair." I had used the word to indicate "preference, or leaning towards". Apparently, my concept of the meaning of "bias" is not correct. I'm sorry for that mistake. No offense intended. Live and learn.

Posts.Title: Were your PCa treatment results what you expected?

Posts.Content: srkohler, You have received excellent advice from the above posters. The only perspective I can add is that this forum includes a bias towards surgery, and another provides a bias towards radiation, and still another is biased towards focal therapies. Focal therapies are not applicable in your case, and it comes to your choosing between surgery, some form of radiation, (or the less-used all-gland cryotherapy). This is further complicated by open and robotic RP, and a three or four radiation techniques, as well as Proton therapy, which is related. So, you have your homework cut out for you. With your pathology, there are several options for a cure and a long life. Read, ask, discuss, and make your choice as fully informed and confident as you can. Good luck.

Posts.Title: new psa results

Posts.Content: Mark, As Highlander asked, we need to know more of your pathology. If you are Risk Grade 1 or 2 on the new WHO grade scale, then your default action is AS, according to the current NCCN guidelines. Anything else is overtreatment, unless you demand it, But that doesn't change it from being overtreatment. Of course a uro will recommend surgery, that's what they do. There are many outdated myths regarding radiation, and many uro's repeat them. The radiation types receiving the latest good reports are SBRT and HDR brachytherapy. You should be aware of them. Walsh's book is fine for someone planning on surgery. Instead, I would suggest Mark Scholz' "Invasion of the Prostate Snatchers", also written by a prostate surgeon, but warning about unnecessary overtreatment.

Posts.Title: 3+3 = decision time

Posts.Content: Thanks, Dijin, that's a scary case study. He appeared to be very low risk, accordingly to two biopsies and the OncotypeDX test. His stats were similar to mine at that point, but, two years later he was actually a G(4+5). This certainly shows the imperfection of genomic testing. But, I noticed one big difference between the NYU AS protocol and Johns Hopkins'. At JH, you must have an mp-MRI and a confirmatory fusion biopsy within six months of the first positive biopsy. That did not happen in his case. And, it was the PIRADS 5 seen on his MRI two years later that signaled his more serious PCa. So, this unfortunate case also demonstrates the value of a very strict AS protocol.

Posts.Title: What to do? Two different Opinions

Posts.Content: Mic, The fpsa is accurate enough to warrant further testing, in your case. I was sent to a urologist about ten years ago, when my psa jumped about three points, to 5.2. The uro did a DRE, which was unremarkable, then took a blood sample for fpsa, and booked an appointment for a biopsy. A few days later, his office called and cancelled the biopsy. My fpsa came back at 25, and he had enough faith in the fpsa result to not see me further. So, just as a high fpsa can often rule out significant PCa, so can a low reading, like yours, demand a next step. Today, there are more comprehensive and accurate blood tests, like PHI and 4K Score, and also a urine test, PCA3. All of them are used to eliminate or justify biopsies. You could ask for one of them. But, probably, there is enough suspicion at this point to justify a biopsy. If you can arrange an MRI first, it can be very helpful in focusing the biopsy needles on any abnormal-appearing areas. Good luck to you.

Some guidelines suggest suspicion if there is a rise of .7 in a year, but that is not cast in concrete. Why don't you order a PHI test the next time? It includes psa and two other factors, and is more accurate than psa alone.

Posts.Title: Advice on PSA results for 49 year old

Posts.Content: To answer two of your specific questions (1) a urinalysis will not rule out a prostate infection, as most prostate inflammation is not caused by bacteria, and simply comes and goes away as it wishes. (2) PSA Velocity has been downgraded as a factor in predicting the likelihood of prostate cancer. https://www.cancer.gov/types/prostat...city-detection

Posts.Title: New beginnings in prostate awareness

Posts.Content: I will echo Pratoman's opinions. I have been on medicare for eight years, and, between that and my supplemental insurance, have not paid a dime of my own pocket. Medicare is a great example of a single-payer system. Canada also passed a Medicare law in 1965, except theirs is for all ages, not just those over 65. I am now in Canada, where I spend much of my time, and I can tell you that Canadians are very pleased with their system. The oft-told myths about coming to the States for treatment and long wait times are mostly false. I have yet to meet a single Canadian who had to go to the States for treatment. On a global scale, EVERY other nation, rich and poor, that you can name, has "socialized medicine". And, the USA is about number 53 in life expectancy. So much for us having a superior medical system.

Posts.Title: Curious About treatment choices for those with socialized medicine

Posts.Content: Dan, Glad to hear that you have a definitive pathology, and that you are totally justified in your decision and action. The best of luck to you in your follow-up testing and recovery. But, as Pratoman noted, the roiling debate concerning overtreatment continues, if not so much on this forum as on others (I participate in four). The problem is that the diagnostic tools are always "just ahead" of what we all need to be confident and comfortable in our decisions. Certainly, had you deferred treatment, and entered a strict AS program, there would have immediately been more intensive imaging, biomarker, genomics, and biopsy confirmations. Maybe in your case, they would have pointed out the greater danger ... or failed. No one knows for certain. Maybe in X years, one simple test will tell us everything with 100 certainty. Maybe, but not today. I hope that your recovery and cure are quick and complete.

Posts.Title: Medicare covers Prolaris Genetic Test for low risk patients.

Posts.Content: I agree with Southsider, that a follow-up "confirmatory" biopsy is mandatory in many AS programs. It is usually done between six months and a year after the first positive biopsy. The purpose is to greatly reduce the chances that a significant cancer was missed. Expect to be asked to do another one. If they don't insist on a biopsy, you should at least ask for an mp-MRI, as you need something more than PSA tests and DRE's to monitor a confirmed case of PCa.

Posts.Content: Mup, I will echo the excellent advice offered above. As Chuck mentioned, the PNI could be a red flag. I have not had to deal with that, and have no advice, so make sure that you become aware of the significance of that finding. After this biopsy, you have a low risk finding, BUT, you will benefit from joining a formal, structured AS program. Families and friends are often simply not aware that prostate cancer has different severities, some of which will never be life threatening. Also there are serious side effects from possibly unnecessary treatment. Read, discuss, join groups, and always keep your own counsel. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by KPINOTT Thanks guys. Much appreciated and puts my mind more at ease. I never considered the PHI as I live in Canada and the doctors here are not well versed in non-standard offerings. I was thinking of this new test from Neogenomics that supposedly has a 96% rate of identifying high risk PC. See this link https://neogenomics.com/diagnostic-s...tive-to-biopsy Have you heard of this ? Its a liquid biospy Thanks again PHI has become quite common in the States, and only costs about $120 USD. Our insurance usually covers it. The NeoLab test is the type of "liquid biopsy" that everyone dreams of, but has not been widely tested or endorsed. Other than their press release, this is the only mention I have heard of it. When you have been on AS for a long time, and know that your psa fluctates for whatever reasons, getting a high number on any one test is not going to keep me up at nights, That's a mental thing that comes with experience and past false alarms.

Posts.Title: new psa results

Posts.Content: Mic, The fpsa is accurate enough to warrant further testing, in your case. I was sent to a urologist about ten years ago, when my psa jumped about three points, to 5.2. The uro did a DRE, which was unremarkable, then took a blood sample for fpsa, and booked an appointment for a biopsy. A few days later, his office called and cancelled the biopsy. My fpsa came back at 25, and he had enough faith in the fpsa result to not see me further. So, just as a high fpsa can often rule out significant PCa, so can a low reading, like yours, demand a next step. Today, there are more comprehensive and accurate blood tests, like PHI and 4K Score, and also a urine test, PCA3. All of them are used to eliminate or justify biopsies. You could ask for one of them. But, probably, there is enough suspicion at this point to justify a biopsy. If you can arrange an MRI first, it can be very helpful in focusing the biopsy needles on any abnormal-appearing areas. Good luck to you.

Posts.Content: To answer two of your specific questions (1) a urinalysis will not rule out a prostate infection, as most prostate inflammation is not caused by bacteria, and simply comes and goes away as it wishes. (2) PSA Velocity has been downgraded as a factor in predicting the likelihood of prostate cancer. https://www.cancer.gov/types/prostat...city-detection

Posts.Content: Sparky, Next time ask for a PHI test. This includes psa, free psa, plus a marker of cancer activity and an algorithm to calculate a score that predicts the likelihood of cancer. As I mentioned in a previous post, the important of psa velocity has been downgraded in determining the presence of prostate cancer.

Posts.Title: New beginnings in prostate awareness

Posts.Content: Mup, I will echo the excellent advice offered above. As Chuck mentioned, the PNI could be a red flag. I have not had to deal with that, and have no advice, so make sure that you become aware of the significance of that finding. After this biopsy, you have a low risk finding, BUT, you will benefit from joining a formal, structured AS program. Families and friends are often simply not aware that prostate cancer has different severities, some of which will never be life threatening. Also there are serious side effects from possibly unnecessary treatment. Read, discuss, join groups, and always keep your own counsel. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Just Received Diagnosis Active Sur Route I Think

Posts.Content: Radiation usually does not make your psa undetectable. You still have a prostate, so some psa is expected. Recurrence is monitored by checking for consecutive rises after your psa hits a nadir, which can take up to three years. I have seen posts from a few radiation advocates stating that their prostate volumes were lower after treatment, but don't know it they are exceptions.

Posts.Title: Now I'm even more nervous

Posts.Content: Dan, Glad to hear that you have a definitive pathology, and that you are totally justified in your decision and action. The best of luck to you in your follow-up testing and recovery. But, as Pratoman noted, the roiling debate concerning overtreatment continues, if not so much on this forum as on others (I participate in four). The problem is that the diagnostic tools are always "just ahead" of what we all need to be confident and comfortable in our decisions. Certainly, had you deferred treatment, and entered a strict AS program, there would have immediately been more intensive imaging, biomarker, genomics, and biopsy confirmations. Maybe in your case, they would have pointed out the greater danger ... or failed. No one knows for certain. Maybe in X years, one simple test will tell us everything with 100 certainty. Maybe, but not today. I hope that your recovery and cure are quick and complete.

Posts.Title: Hello from the Other Side (of Surgery)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another I never understood the overtreatment mantra. I think it is linked to the other myth you will die of something else before you die of PC. As life expectancy increases and the cancer expands to more and younger men and more aggressive forms public perception will change. I think that about 220,000 men are diagnosed with PCa in the USA every year, and about 28,000 will die each year. That would tell me that most do die from something else. A month or two ago, Djin published a new nomogram for PCa survival. I plugged in my data, and it said that my chances of dying from PCa were only 1 percent over the next 10 years. But, it also said that my overall survival was less than 36 percent. And, it assumed otherwise good health. Bummer, ruined my day! But, those numbers would prove that "dying from something else" is not a myth with this disease. I've been betting on that for a long time.

Posts.Title: USPSTF Backtracks, Now Says PSA Test Is 'Individual Decision'

Posts.Content: Searcher, In response to those who may conjure that current forms of RT do not have 25 year histories, I would remind them that robotic surgery had almost NO clinical history when it was approved for general usage in the early 2000's. In fact, neither surgery (2000+ years) nor radiation (since 1895) went through ANY such trials before being widely accepted. Here is a 27 minute video interview with a well-known radio/TV personality who had Gleason 6 PCa and was persuaded to have RP by the best known (most boastful) RALP surgeon in the world. He totally regrets the operation and his quality of life since then. Watch it all. Interestingly, I found this video on a "surgery support" website, which is paid for by the surgeon who is being criticized. I wrote a sincere compliment to the moderator for allowing the post to remain. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_AiZ...&feature=share

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lismil The doctor had said if it rises too high they would do hormone therapy (but that was before we had the 0.1 reading), and that radiation would only be hit or miss. I would suggest another opinion on this point. Salvage radiation is the standard treatment for locally-recurrent prostate cancer. It can be combined with HT for additional effect, if recommended. However, just going to HT is not curative, while RT can possibly cure him. You really need more consultation with other specialists if more treatment is eventually needed.

Check out the chart showing that 1 person out of 1,000 avoids death from PCa by being screened. Also, they make the point that many men are over-treated. Posts.Title: Radiation starting soon, what is best way to protect other parts

Posts.Content: Tim, Welcome, and you are certainly among friends here who are willing to share their experiences and advice with you. I'm surprised that your urologist offered you an option of active surveillance with three cores having some G4. That would be outside even my comfort zone. You mention that you have already selected surgery, but then ask about a second opinion. OK - my advice for a second opinion is that you look into SBRT/Cyberknife radiation treatment. Recent studies have shown it to be producing higher cure rates and fewer side effects than surgery. In this case, your consult should be with a radiation oncologist whose facility offers that treatment. Any event, your stage of cancer should respond well to either radiation or surgery. Good luck to you.

Posts.Content: Newporter, Thank you for posting this. Another thing to be concerned with, but also another piece of critical information. The degree of confidence for who is safe for AS remains a major challenge of responding to this disease. I am sure glad that I am in the Johns Hopkins AS program, and that my specialist talks with Drs. Carter and Epstein as part of his work. I'll stay calm and let them worry about new discoveries that may or may not impact me. So far, so good. For now.

Posts.Title: G6 Prostate Cancer and AS

Posts.Content: Michael F said: "We all look forward to the development of accurate genetic testing that will differentiate "less aggressive" from "highly aggressive" forms of PC from biopsy samples." I don't know... Things are being discovered, and new suggestions/guidelines are evolving weekly. I had the most advanced genomics test the month it was approved two years ago. It basically told me not to worry. But, did it anticipate what has been published since? Of course not, as that was not known then. Will the testing be altered to include those factors? Probably. There is way too much living to enjoy than to spend too much time thinking about what we don't know that may harm us. My doctors tell me that a cellular cure for prostate cancer may be likely within the next 15 years or so. Great...but the confusion before the cure is both exciting and unsettling.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lismil The doctor had said if it rises too high they would do hormone therapy (but that was before we had the 0.1 reading), and that radiation would only be hit or miss. I would suggest another opinion on this point. Salvage radiation is the standard treatment for locally-recurrent prostate cancer. It can be combined with HT for additional effect, if recommended. However, just going to HT is not curative, while RT can possibly cure him. You really need more consultation with other specialists if more treatment is eventually needed.

Numbers 1, 2, and 5 were negative. Numbers 3,4, and 6 were positive with 5% Gleason(3+3) found. Last one was Precision Point transperineal. PSA 4.4, fPSA 24, PHI 32 Hopefully, I can remain untreated. So far, so good.
