Posts.Title: Medicare Refused to Pay for PSA Test

Posts.Content: I was surprised to receive a letter from Medicare stating that they would not pay for a prescribed PSA/Free PSA test that I had done at a local Lab Corp location in April. Their reason was "Medicare does not pay for this item or service". This has never happened in a decade of every-six-months PSA testing ordered by Johns Hopkins. My Blue Cross supplemental plan did pay about $20 towards the $177 total charge. Is this refusal something new? If so, its a really bad policy.

Posts.Title: Radiation starting soon, what is best way to protect other parts

Posts.Content: Tim, Welcome, and you are certainly among friends here who are willing to share their experiences and advice with you. I'm surprised that your urologist offered you an option of active surveillance with three cores having some G4. That would be outside even my comfort zone. You mention that you have already selected surgery, but then ask about a second opinion. OK - my advice for a second opinion is that you look into SBRT/Cyberknife radiation treatment. Recent studies have shown it to be producing higher cure rates and fewer side effects than surgery. In this case, your consult should be with a radiation oncologist whose facility offers that treatment. Any event, your stage of cancer should respond well to either radiation or surgery. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: Newly Diagnossed - questions about choosing a surgeon

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee Probably more a matter of when rather than if. Granted, 7 is borderline intervention stage, but my experience is the Gleason tends to be elevated with time rather than lowered. If there is a tumor it will spread. The question is, when is a good time to stop it in its tracks? It won't get better on its own. We all have different experiences, RobLee, and mine does not align with yours. But, for Winter's choices, the long term outlook is likely that he will need treatment at some time. The PI-RADS 5 lesion score is concerning. How much of the positive core was G4? That is, IMHO, significant as to whether he could consider some time in AS. I think that every day for which radical treatment can be avoided is worth having and enjoying. There are many new technologies and less-invasive treatments in the pipeline. Maybe Winter could qualify for a Prostvac trial or other new possible cure. It's worth taking the time to make sure he won't regret his choice for the rest of his life.

Posts.Title: 2nd Opinion - thoughts on AS

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee You are two months younger than my late older brother. He's been gone six years now. Yes, Life is different for all of us. My older brother died of brain cancer at 67. But, my 80-year-old sister is an active skydiver, and I recently climbed the Great Wall of China. We never know how long we have, just have to live to the max every day. The progression and indolence of our respective cancers is another dimension of this complex disease and all that we have to learn in order to fight it and support others.

Posts.Title: 2nd Opinion - thoughts on AS

Posts.Content: A psa that jumps from 3 to 6 in less than a month is far more indicative of a spike due to prostatitis than from prostate cancer. I would recommend a PHI, 4K Score, or SelectMDx test as your next step. PHI is the least expensive of those, and less affected by prostatitis than just psa. Biopsies have risks, the more punctures you have, the more damage you accumulate. I know, painfully so. You may want to try a few less invasive tests before taking that step.

Posts.Title: Saturated 3D Perineal Mapping Biopsy in SE USA?

Posts.Content: I think that Partin, Allaf, Carter, and Pavlovich at John Hopkins are among the most experienced prostate surgeons in the area, if not the world. Among them, they do both ORP and RALP with the best results possible. Please be aware that every study (even a new one I read today) concludes that there is no significant difference in outcomes between traditional and robotic prostate surgery. The experience of the surgeon is the deciding factor.

Posts.Content: This news just came out. It is sure to keep the debate over PSA screening going at full volume. Check out the chart showing that 1 person out of 1,000 avoids death from PCa by being screened. Also, they make the point that many men are over-treated. My position has always been that screening is valuable, and that over-treatment is the result of incomplete counseling, and consideration of options, after a diagnosis. https://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/896331

Posts.Title: USPSTF Backtracks, Now Says PSA Test Is 'Individual Decision'

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another I never understood the overtreatment mantra. I think it is linked to the other myth you will die of something else before you die of PC. As life expectancy increases and the cancer expands to more and younger men and more aggressive forms public perception will change. I think that about 220,000 men are diagnosed with PCa in the USA every year, and about 28,000 will die each year. That would tell me that most do die from something else. A month or two ago, Djin published a new nomogram for PCa survival. I plugged in my data, and it said that my chances of dying from PCa were only 1 percent over the next 10 years. But, it also said that my overall survival was less than 36 percent. And, it assumed otherwise good health. Bummer, ruined my day! But, those numbers would prove that "dying from something else" is not a myth with this disease. I've been betting on that for a long time.

Posts.Title: 2nd Opinion - thoughts on AS

Posts.Content: Searcher, In response to those who may conjure that current forms of RT do not have 25 year histories, I would remind them that robotic surgery had almost NO clinical history when it was approved for general usage in the early 2000's. In fact, neither surgery (2000+ years) nor radiation (since 1895) went through ANY such trials before being widely accepted. Here is a 27 minute video interview with a well-known radio/TV personality who had Gleason 6 PCa and was persuaded to have RP by the best known (most boastful) RALP surgeon in the world. He totally regrets the operation and his quality of life since then. Watch it all. Interestingly, I found this video on a "surgery support" website, which is paid for by the surgeon who is being criticized. I wrote a sincere compliment to the moderator for allowing the post to remain. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_AiZ...&feature=share

Posts.Title: USPSTF Backtracks, Now Says PSA Test Is 'Individual Decision'

Posts.Content: Michael F said: "We all look forward to the development of accurate genetic testing that will differentiate "less aggressive" from "highly aggressive" forms of PC from biopsy samples." I don't know... Things are being discovered, and new suggestions/guidelines are evolving weekly. I had the most advanced genomics test the month it was approved two years ago. It basically told me not to worry. But, did it anticipate what has been published since? Of course not, as that was not known then. Will the testing be altered to include those factors? Probably. There is way too much living to enjoy than to spend too much time thinking about what we don't know that may harm us. My doctors tell me that a cellular cure for prostate cancer may be likely within the next 15 years or so. Great...but the confusion before the cure is both exciting and unsettling.

Posts.Title: Torn between Brachy or Surgery: Input Requested

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Dogdays I went into this with a GS9 DX. Having heart and COPD problems compounded things. I met with a surgeon and a radiation oncologist at MSKCC. As a GS9, the chances of the cancer escaping the capsule were higher. Even the surgeon at MSK recommended radiation. Their theory was, why go through two teatments (surgery followed by radiation) when one treatment would suffice. I had LDR brachy at MSK in July by Dr. Zelefsky, followed by SHARP (SBRT) in August. I also started ADT hormone treatments in April. Make sure you do yourself a favor and meet with a radiation oncologist at MSK. IMO, you are more a candidate for radiation and ADT treatment. Keep us up to date Hi Dogdays, Glad that you have joined this forum, as you have recent experience with MSK and Dr. Zelefsky, which can be informative for those interested in state-of-the-art radiation techniques. But, let me ask, did you have LDR brachytherapy followed by SHARP? Really? Usually, I have read about HDR brachy being used before external beam radiation (including SBRT/SHARP). So, did you have seeds implanted? I know that Dr. Zelefsky is often trying new techniques, but this combination seems different. Can you give us some more detail on your treatment?

Posts.Title: Choice Of PC Treatments

Posts.Content: Welcome Mark, I fail to see how a biopsy can be justified for PIRADS 2 results. The MRI did not find any lesions, and your psa fell after a course of antibiotics. My experiences with biopsies were far from trauma-free; two of them resulting in pain that lasted for six months. Still, Chuck is correct that biopsy is the only current test for determining the presence and risk grade of any prostate cancer. The key point here is whether the testing done so far justifies the risk inherent in the biopsy procedure. Have you had other blood or urine tests like PHI, 4Kscore, or PCA3? These are more accurate than psa alone, and less affected by infections. Keep asking questions and learning your options. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Medicare Refused to Pay for PSA Test

Posts.Content: Tim, Welcome, and you are certainly among friends here who are willing to share their experiences and advice with you. I'm surprised that your urologist offered you an option of active surveillance with three cores having some G4. That would be outside even my comfort zone. You mention that you have already selected surgery, but then ask about a second opinion. OK - my advice for a second opinion is that you look into SBRT/Cyberknife radiation treatment. Recent studies have shown it to be producing higher cure rates and fewer side effects than surgery. In this case, your consult should be with a radiation oncologist whose facility offers that treatment. Any event, your stage of cancer should respond well to either radiation or surgery. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: 12 years

Posts.Content: This news just came out. It is sure to keep the debate over PSA screening going at full volume. Check out the chart showing that 1 person out of 1,000 avoids death from PCa by being screened. Also, they make the point that many men are over-treated. My position has always been that screening is valuable, and that over-treatment is the result of incomplete counseling, and consideration of options, after a diagnosis. https://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/896331

Posts.Title: USPSTF Backtracks, Now Says PSA Test Is 'Individual Decision'

Posts.Content: I had mixed reactions reading it. The graphics and diagnostic and staging tables were a nice summary of what you need to know, While this web article is brand new, some of the primary source articles are VERY old. The first one was published in 1993, using retrospective studies. That means that it used outcome statistics for men treated in the 1970's and 1980's. Other studies were also outdated. How can you compare treatment outcomes when robotic surgery, laproscopic surgery, image-guided radiation, and hypofractionated radiation were not yet in use? Same for SBRT and HDRBT. One brief mention of seeds, but, as Denis noted, they used different terminology. Some parts of this are good reference, but not the outcomes. There are better, more recent sources for those.

Posts.Title: PDQ Cancer-Treatment Summary, 2018 (NCI)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another I never understood the overtreatment mantra. I think it is linked to the other myth you will die of something else before you die of PC. As life expectancy increases and the cancer expands to more and younger men and more aggressive forms public perception will change. I think that about 220,000 men are diagnosed with PCa in the USA every year, and about 28,000 will die each year. That would tell me that most do die from something else. A month or two ago, Djin published a new nomogram for PCa survival. I plugged in my data, and it said that my chances of dying from PCa were only 1 percent over the next 10 years. But, it also said that my overall survival was less than 36 percent. And, it assumed otherwise good health. Bummer, ruined my day! But, those numbers would prove that "dying from something else" is not a myth with this disease. I've been betting on that for a long time.

Posts.Content: tpjames, Welcome, and I hope that you will not need to be here very long. About 2/3 of first biopsies are negative, and yours may be also. Inflammation is often the cause of psa rises. If any cancer is found, what you decide for treatment should depend on the risk level of the pathology. The cure rates for surgery and radiation are the same, and the percentage of low risk men choosing active surveillance is now approaching 50 percent. That's up from near zero 12 years ago, as more and more men learn that their indolent prostate cancer may never need any treatment. But, here's hoping for a negative pathology in your case. Please let us know your results, if positive, as the men here have many experiences and recommendations to share with you.

Posts.Title: Being Paranoid???

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Dogdays I went into this with a GS9 DX. Having heart and COPD problems compounded things. I met with a surgeon and a radiation oncologist at MSKCC. As a GS9, the chances of the cancer escaping the capsule were higher. Even the surgeon at MSK recommended radiation. Their theory was, why go through two teatments (surgery followed by radiation) when one treatment would suffice. I had LDR brachy at MSK in July by Dr. Zelefsky, followed by SHARP (SBRT) in August. I also started ADT hormone treatments in April. Make sure you do yourself a favor and meet with a radiation oncologist at MSK. IMO, you are more a candidate for radiation and ADT treatment. Keep us up to date Hi Dogdays, Glad that you have joined this forum, as you have recent experience with MSK and Dr. Zelefsky, which can be informative for those interested in state-of-the-art radiation techniques. But, let me ask, did you have LDR brachytherapy followed by SHARP? Really? Usually, I have read about HDR brachy being used before external beam radiation (including SBRT/SHARP). So, did you have seeds implanted? I know that Dr. Zelefsky is often trying new techniques, but this combination seems different. Can you give us some more detail on your treatment?

Posts.Content: I had that same question about losing anonymity when deciding to join some Facebook prostate cancer support groups this year. Of course, FB uses your real name, and people can see your photos and posts. But, you know, you are within a closed group, and your personal FB friends won't see what you post, so it is OK to lose anonymity with people who share your concerns. At least, that is my opinion. I have since recognized and friended someone from this forum. All good.

Posts.Title: A reflection...

Posts.Content: I'm not sure why he would order a 4K test for someone with a normal psa. Did you have a positive DRE? Usually, the sequence of blood testing would be psa, free psa, and then PHI. What is your free psa? Do you know you prostate size and psa density? There was a article just published by US TOO that contrasted the results from PHI and 4K tests, and all that study did was add to the confusion and lessen confidence in such tests. Biopsies are not risk or pain free. Three out of 100 result in hospitalization for sepsis, and one in 1400 is fatal. Two of mine resulted in pain that lasted for six months, while tripling my psa. That said, I am not against biopsies if other tests are ominous for cancer. I would have another one if, lets say, I had a PIRADS 5 lesion on an MRI. Keep asking and questioning. IMHO, there is no immediate need to rush into a biopsy at this time, given what you have told us.

Posts.Content: I agree with Djin. Your age, weight, and other health issues would be factors against surgery. Also, as Djin said, you have high grade cancer with an increased risk of surgery not being able to eradicate it all. The HT and radiation are a good recommendation for someone with your situation. Your family needs to understand that "cutting it out" is not always the best way to stop prostate cancer.

Posts.Title: first biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mitchden Ive been on AS for 2 years - my PSA is stable. My AS protocol is a PSA every 6 months, DRE every year and biopsies every 2-3 years -based on the PSA results. I cant have an MRI because of my defibrillator. I know that MRIs are part of the standard AS protocol. I asked my doctor(s)  local urologist and MSKCC consult about an MRI workaround and I was told there isnt any. My urologist told me that he would take 16 samples during the next biopsy. I was awake for the first 2 biopsies and although it wasnt fun, it wasnt too bad. I already told my doctor that I want to be knocked out for the next biopsy  especially if he is going to take additional samples. Question: Being knocked out; with a TRUS biopsy, will my doctor be able to take samples from areas of the prostate that he wouldnt otherwise reach if I was awake? I really dont want a saturation biopsy or a template mapping biopsy  although I may ask my doctor about them. For low and intermediate grade cancer, I understand that the cure rate for surgery, IMRT and SBRT is the same  around 75%. Therefore, the probability for recurrence would be 25%. Questions: Assuming that HT/SRT is the follow-up treatment for recurrence after surgery, what is the cure rate after HT/SRT? I understand that an MRI is done as part of the simulation for SRT. For men that cant have an MRI, is there a work around? If radiation (IMRT or SBRT) is done as the primary treatment, if there is a recurrence, what is the secondary treatment and what are their respective cure rates? mitchden, I think that the "equivalence" of non-recurrence between various treatments needs to be updated in light of recent studies. The rates for SBRT, HDR-BT, proton beam (PBT) for low and intermediate cases appear to be around 94-99 percent after five years. That is significantly above previous stats on PCa treatments. I say this after a lengthy exchange with some PBT advocates on another forum. They had posted how PBT was superior to any other interventional PCa treatment. I challenged that, and posted a very recent study showing a 97 percent non-recurrence rate after five years for SBRT. They replied with a large PBT study showing 99 percent for low risk, and 94 percent for intermediate risk men. Both the SBRT and PBT studies had urinary and gastro side effects at 3 percent or below. Plus, they personally said that the two of them had had ZERO side effects from PBT. I think (based on a long thread on yet another forum) that we agreed that the recurrence rate was about 35 percent for ALL cases of men having RP. While RP non-recurrence rates for only low and intermediate cases would probably be lower than 35 percent, it would appear that the more recent RT treatments (SBRT and PBT) are now the ones setting the "gold standard". Regarding salvage treatments should there be a failure of primary radaition, there are several available, as described in this article: https://pcnrv.blogspot.com/2017/09/f...for-radio.html

Posts.Title: Biopsy Samples and Secondary Treatment

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by tpjames Results are in. Out of 12, 2 cores are positive, one with Gleason 7 , the other with Gleason 10 . Both reported very small in size ( 10%) . Appointment Monday with the Doc to discuss treatment. It appears to me that being Gleason 10 there really is only one treatment, removal. Removal is not your only option. The newest combinations of RT are showing very impressive results against high risk PCa. https://prostatecancerinfolink.net/2...ostate-cancer/ Also, many cases of high risk PCa require adjuvant or salvage radiation after surgery. Why have the SE's of surgery, if you are going to need radiation anyway to kill the cancer? Perhaps having a second opinion on your biopsy slides from the experts at Johns Hopkins would be wise to confirm that G10? Many men use their service. In any event, good luck, and let us know what are the recommendations from your appointment.

Johns Hopkins has the strictest protocols, and Dr, Carter recently told me that i HAVE to have another (last?) biopsy because its been over four years since my previous one. That's his protocol, and I can do what he says, or leave the program. As much as I hate biopsies, there is no arguing with the success of his 24-year-old program. So, I will do it after another MRI finds any targets. But, even if that MRI shows no targets, he is insistent that "protocol" demands that I have another biopsy. Arrgh!

Posts.Content: The most effective treatment for high risk PCa is that proposed by RO#1. Even the most recent studies have that conclusion, and the outcomes are not close. His lack of connection with you does not change that fact, https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2673969 It seems that you envision surgery with RT as a backstop. Think about this: why suffer the side effects of both RP and RT if you are going to rely on RT to kill the cancer? Just my opinion. Good luck with whatever you do.

Posts.Title: Update - TIme for a Biopsy ???

Posts.Content: Andy, You have a good story to tell. I have been on AS for eight years, and hope to die with PCa, and not of it. The acceptance of AS has been astonishing over the past five or six years. At large institutions, more than half of newly diagnosed low-risk men are choosing AS. Reports from Sweden, where newly diagnosed low-risk are advised of AS, show that 91 percent of those men chose that option last year. But, the key to success is in the "active" word. Following a formal schedule of tests is the most certain way to be aware of changes and confident in your decision. Continued good luck to you.

Posts.Title: My story, currently.

Posts.Content: Djin, Thanks for this article. It appears to show that MRIs still miss some PCa lesions that are found by protocol biopsies. Not what I wanted to read. But, the imaging is improving. Consult1, your questions have been discussed on several forums. I am traveling now, and don't have my PC with all its bookmarks. But, you can Google articles by Laurence Klotz and Johnathan Epstein which have the statistics and discussions of Gleason 3+3 and the possible upgrading risks. From what I recall, there is little or no chance of the low risk tumor morphing, BUT, upgrades happen by other, higher grade, tumors arising nearby. That is why AS must require constant testing.

Biopsies are not risk or pain free. Three out of 100 result in hospitalization for sepsis, and one in 1400 is fatal. Two of mine resulted in pain that lasted for six months, while tripling my psa. That said, I am not against biopsies if other tests are ominous for cancer. I would have another one if, lets say, I had a PIRADS 5 lesion on an MRI. Keep asking and questioning. IMHO, there is no immediate need to rush into a biopsy at this time, given what you have told us.

Posts.Title: RALP vs RT: a study of treatment decision-making in men with localised PCa

Posts.Content: The most effective treatment for high risk PCa is that proposed by RO#1. Even the most recent studies have that conclusion, and the outcomes are not close. His lack of connection with you does not change that fact, https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2673969 It seems that you envision surgery with RT as a backstop. Think about this: why suffer the side effects of both RP and RT if you are going to rely on RT to kill the cancer? Just my opinion. Good luck with whatever you do.

Consult1, your questions have been discussed on several forums. I am traveling now, and don't have my PC with all its bookmarks. But, you can Google articles by Laurence Klotz and Johnathan Epstein which have the statistics and discussions of Gleason 3+3 and the possible upgrading risks. From what I recall, there is little or no chance of the low risk tumor morphing, BUT, upgrades happen by other, higher grade, tumors arising nearby. That is why AS must require constant testing.

Posts.Title: 55 year old newbie wants to thank you all!

Posts.Content: Here is a highlight from a just-published twenty-year study of 63,000 prostate cancer patients in Denmark. "Among the > 35,000 men who had an initial biopsy result that was positive for prostate cancer 10,407/35,159 men (29.6 percent) actually died of prostate cancer. Among the > 27,000 men who had an initial biopsy result that was negative for prostate cancer 541/27,181 men (2.0 percent) actually died of prostate cancer." That is very strong data from a large study. Really something to think about for the newly diagnosed. I had two negative biopsies, one blind and one MRI fusion before hitting a small amount of PCa on the third try. But, this study will not cause me to cancel my future scheduled appointments, although it certainly is reassuring to read. Here is the article with a link to the full study: https://prostatecancerinfolink.net/2...fic-mortality/

Certainly, you should ask why he ordered it. It will be interesting to learn why your doctor wants that test at this time.

Posts.Title: My 9-month post-surgery visit

Posts.Content: Irish, First of all, active surveillance is NOT out of the equation. You are Grade Group 3 in the new WHO/Epstein protocol. But, the success rates with AS have been lower than than with low risk groups 1-2, so that caution needs to be emphasized, and you would have to be thinking about a next step. With two cores of G 3+4, I would think that you need treatment, but do not need to rush. You appear to be doing ALL the right consultations. Regarding radiation, there are now studies with good results using SBRT as a salvage therapy if primary radiation fails. Also, cryo, FLA, and HIFU are being used if there is a recurrence after primary radiation failure. The statements regarding rectal problems and secondary cancers are from very old studies. Radiation, like surgery, is not the same today, as it was in 1990. Also, the use of highly precise Cyberknife/SBRT focusing, and also the use of the SpaceOAR dissovelable rectal shields have addressed the old issues with secondary cancers and rectal damage. Don't let anyone tell you that the side effects are the same for RP and RT, those statements are not supported by recent research. Also, if a book is recommended, I would offer "Invasion of the Prostate Snatchers" by two prostate cancer experts. Don't worry, your case has great chances for total cure. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Since 2014

Posts.Content: Shred, There is SO much research and experimentation and clinical trials going on for Stage IV PCa cases, that I believe that any statistics and nomograms that are based on past data (which they all have to be), are possibly not going to be relevant for you. Advanced cancer and extending life is where all the intense research and out-of-the-envelope creativity are happening. Many different approaches. Things that were thought to make no sense, like ADDING testosterone, are now being tested to defeat advanced cancer. There are publications weekly, if not daily, of articles by specialists around the world announcing some new understanding of how PCa works. while some other group reports amazing results in mice with human stage IV genes. So, the present facts may be useful, but your hopes and expectations should exceed them.

Urologists are surgeons and make their money by doing surgery. Often, they are not fully aware of the advances in radiation. Prostate removal is no guarantee of stopping the cancer. Here is an article for your reading pleasure: https://www.sciencedaily.com/release...0418145458.htm

Not so in Turkmenistan, where the Soviet-style government blocks unacceptable websites, even using VPNs. Such banned sites include Facebook, Yahoo, Google, AND cancerforums.net. Why is that??? They do play favorites, blocking foxnews and drudge, while allowing cnn and msnbc. But, those are political, and, while cancer treatment discussions can sometimes have the tone of politics, the blocking of the site is puzzling. Other, similar PCa forums are allowed. Well, now we know why we never see postings from Turkmenistan ðŸ¤”
Posts.Title: HUMOR - This forum blocked in Turkmenistan

Posts.Content: Dan, We are seeing the thread through our different perspectives. I see the research as showing that younger men who are low risk do not gain any healing advantage by choosing immediate surgery over active surveillance. That plays to my bias against overtreatment. In your history, you were under-diagnosed before your RP, and so having that surgery and the resultant pathology, was none-too-soon for you. Your choosing immediate treatment was proven critical to your getting cured. Maybe the issue keeps coming back to more and better initial diagnostic tools, Who is really low risk, and who has a more serious instance of PCa? Those tools are coming, and being tested, but not in popular use, yet. In the meantime, all our opinions and advice are often best-intended assumptions.

Posts.Content: His PSA is very high, but I have read posts from two men who had PSA of over SIX THOUSAND, and were writing eight or ten years after their diagnosis. So, while high, it may still be curable, and certainly manageable for many years. I often read of a combination of radiation treatments plus hormones being used for advanced cases. Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind Intraductal carcinoma, Gleason 8 is not your garden variety Gleason 6 diagnosis...This is serious business..I have a feeling you will be doing radiation and ADT regardless so why take on the risks and side-effects associated with surgery? The combination of brachy and beam radiation using the techniques available today gives you an excellent chance for a cure.. I know it's a tough choice..You might consult with a Medical Oncologist and get his viewpoints on this matter. They have seen it all and may have some insights you have overlooked.... This diagnosis is "above my pay grade" in terms of what I would normally comment on. But, I happened to recently attend a support session and watch an RO discuss the various radiation options for high-risk cases. He spoke highly of the brachy boost and IMRT results. A surgeon and a chemo specialist were also in attendance, and were nodding their heads in agreement. That's all I know, but it was impressive.

Posts.Content: Frank, There are not many PBT threads here because, well...because not many PBT guys post here. They do post on some other forums and Facebook groups. The new AUA/ASTRO/SOU Guidelines for Clinicians state that PBT has not proven itself to be any better than other forms of radiation, while costing more. That seems to be a widely held consensus, except by PBT advocates, some of whom are almost evangelical in recommending the treatment. They believe that it has fewer side effects than surgery or photon radiation. Look around the internet and you will find plenty of information on PBT.

At any rate that was my first understanding of that number as well - aggressive prostate cancer - HOWEVER - the next scan we did was the CT scan - at that point the radiologist instead indicated we were working with Lymphoma - so the biopsy result is actually from the lymph node - All we have from the Dr. so far is that is stage 4 prostate cancer. I expect when we meet with the Dr. tomorrow I will get some information regarding the gleason score - (it is one of the questions on my list) and hopefully some treatment options. The real kicker here is that they thought that because the prostate looked pretty OK on the imaging scan. In terms of Cancer centers - I may look for a 2nd opinion from one, but our insurance does not cover any of the cancer centers. I have not ruled it out yet - but I want to see if I can get the same treatment options from within the system, but I have started to make some contacts along those lines. We are in Colorado - so if you know of a place I could go for a good 2nd opinion - I would appreciate the recommendation. I will post more tomorrow after I get the rest of the information we want from the Dr. but I appreciate the responses - I am doing my best to be optimistic and look at the best case scenarios - but I don't want to pretend the worst doesn't exist - The best comment that I can add here is that I have read posts by men with psa's of 6000, 7200, and 8000 (two of them), who were posting TEN YEARS after those diagnoses. And, their cases involved the meds and chemo that were available then, while more capable ones have been invented since. So, while his case is very serious, and those treatments are not a picnic, there are reasons to be hopeful.

Posts.Content: DG77, So sorry that you have to be here. For what it is worth, I have been trying to get an answer to the question "how high can a psa rise from non-cancerous causes?", for a couple of years, and have never seen an authoritative statement. Just recalling the posts by members of various prostate cancer forums, the highest I have read about was 58. That was a man whose psa then dropped back below 5, and subsequent tests found no prostate cancer. While my above remarks are anecdotal, and probably any urologist has a better reply, it indicates that your dad is likely dealing with cancer. As he receives more testing and feedback, there are members here who have experienced the full range of choices and treatments, who will be glad to try to advise and assist you and him/

Posts.Content: FredM, Your doctor's monitoring makes perfect sense to me. With the PIRADS 3 lesion, you need to keep some surveillance regimen, even though it may always be "nothing". An MRI does not have side effects. A biopsy can...I know only too well. So, you should follow his advice and have the follow-up MRI, which can allow you to relax, or justify a truly necessary biopsy. Good luck. You may wish to start asking for the PHI test, which includes psa, but also other factors, and is more accurate than psa alone.

Posts.Title: PSA over 100

Posts.Content: stephenb, Sorry to read of your situation. I attended a local prostate cancer support group last night, where there were presentations by a urologist, radiologist, and a chemo doctor. They have a lot of "tricks" to prolong life, even with very advanced prostate cancer. And, new clinical trials for a spectrum of treatments are available in most areas. A question was asked about "just letting go", and not dealing with the side effects of the advanced treatments. All three specialists became grim faced. Finally, after looking at each other, the urologist said that death from prostate cancer was slow and painful. It was something to be fought against as long as possible. That was a powerful moment, and something for you think about. Always try to be optimistic, breakthroughs are happening.

Posts.Title: PCA or prostatitis at age 40?

Posts.Content: Konna, You have received excellent advice above, and there will be agreement that some form of treatment is necessary. Now comes what is often the most challenging part, which is to choose a treatment. The issue with prostate cancer is that there are about a dozen different ways to cure a case like his. There are three types of surgery (open, laproscopic, and robotic): five types of radiation (intensity modulated "IMRT", stereotactic "SBRT", low dose brachytherapy "LDR-BT", high dose brachytherapy "HDR_BT", and proton beam "PBT"). All have been in use for more than a decade, and all have studies supporting their effectiveness. Further, there are more treatments, like Cryotherapy, High Intensity Ultrasound (HIFU), and various focal laser treatments. They have their advocates. The good part is that all of them have cured men of prostate cancer. The tough part is researching and deciding which is best for him, as all have some side effects. Make sure that he gets multiple opinions on his options. We are here to try to help as best we can.

If only one or two cores were positive, then you could add some of the focal therapies such as HIFU, Focal Laser Ablation, or focal cryotherapy to your list of options to research. Posts.Title: 46 YO - Stage IV with no symptoms?

Posts.Content: SG, I have had five biopsies, and never saw a device like your father mentioned. But, you need to stop guessing and getting worked up. The ultimate result of the biopsy will be the pathology report. Those are often completed with 3 days of the biopsy, but you may have to wait for the doctor to call you with the information. A finding of prostate cancer is determined by the pathologist looking for certain cell patterns under a microscope, after certain chemicals have been added to the slide. Whatever that device was indicating, it can only be an alert for closer inspection, it cannot, at this time, be a diagnosis.
Posts.Signature: DOB: May 1944 In Active Surveillance program at Johns Hopkins Strict protocol of tests, including PHI, DRE, MRI, and biopsy. Six biopsies from 2009 to 2019. Numbers 1, 2, and 5 were negative. Numbers 3,4, and 6 were positive with 5% Gleason(3+3) found. Last one was Precision Point transperineal. PSA 4.4, fPSA 24, PHI 32 Hopefully, I can remain untreated. So far, so good.

Posts.Title: Lab Corp PSA results not available until after urologist appointment next week

Posts.Content: stephenb, Sorry to read of your situation. I attended a local prostate cancer support group last night, where there were presentations by a urologist, radiologist, and a chemo doctor. They have a lot of "tricks" to prolong life, even with very advanced prostate cancer. And, new clinical trials for a spectrum of treatments are available in most areas. A question was asked about "just letting go", and not dealing with the side effects of the advanced treatments. All three specialists became grim faced. Finally, after looking at each other, the urologist said that death from prostate cancer was slow and painful. It was something to be fought against as long as possible. That was a powerful moment, and something for you think about. Always try to be optimistic, breakthroughs are happening.

Posts.Title: Thinking of passing on salvage radiation.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Terry's Cellar I apologize to any of the surgery guys I may have offended by my earlier post. I had no intention of doing so. I know I have a bias to my treatment choice and I know a lot of surgery guys do as well. Although I do recognize the benefits of surgery I have difficulty with so many Urologists not presenting RT as an option. I can't tell you how many guys I've talked to that thought surgery was their only option. Upon hearing they had Prostate Cancer they walked out of the office with surgery being scheduled. When I asked why they didn't consult with a Radiation Oncologist they said they didn't know that was an option or they had an entirely out dated understanding of the differences between treatments. I feel strongly that a lot of guys would benefit from at least being better informed. I don't whom to blame...the medical community or us the consumer? Terry, I attend local prostate cancer support groups, and many of the men had surgery years ago. They are angry that the diagnosing urologists did not give them any options except surgery. They heard "you have cancer" and "I can cure you" in the same moment. Based on hearing such personal stories, and reading threads on other PCa discussion forums, I have a very bad impression of how urologists have railroaded men, even those with minimal cancer, into surgery. Urologists are the only surgeons who diagnose and recommend treatments to their patients. Now, things are apparently improving, as over fifty percent of newly diagnosed low risk men who attend large medical institutions are choosing active surveillance, a huge increase. But, the percentage at small practices is far lower, as those urologists are not changing their attitudes or revenue opportunities. Telling the truth, while it may offend some victims, does not require any apologies.

Posts.Content: DG77, So sorry that you have to be here. For what it is worth, I have been trying to get an answer to the question "how high can a psa rise from non-cancerous causes?", for a couple of years, and have never seen an authoritative statement. Just recalling the posts by members of various prostate cancer forums, the highest I have read about was 58. That was a man whose psa then dropped back below 5, and subsequent tests found no prostate cancer. While my above remarks are anecdotal, and probably any urologist has a better reply, it indicates that your dad is likely dealing with cancer. As he receives more testing and feedback, there are members here who have experienced the full range of choices and treatments, who will be glad to try to advise and assist you and him/

Posts.Title: New here - need positive thoughts please

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic ddayglo, this "margin of error" between biopsied tissue and the whole prostate is a problem for those who could do AS. Perhaps your 3+4 is the hardest case. Trying to put myself in that position, I might well feel with AS I'm just waiting for a repeat biopsy to find a lesion with 4+3 that may have been there from the onset. Then I would worry that a biopsy with a 4 + 3 core has missed a 4 + 4. Of course you could be downgraded after RP too, but this is a risky enterprise. Djin, That is why a strict AS protocol like Johns Hopkins requires confirmatory biopsies when you enter the program. I had to have THREE biopsies within two years to make certain that I was properly placed. That really drives down the chances of missing more serious cancer.

Posts.Title: J. Epstein on Gleason scores and their implications

Posts.Content: Shred, There is SO much research and experimentation and clinical trials going on for Stage IV PCa cases, that I believe that any statistics and nomograms that are based on past data (which they all have to be), are possibly not going to be relevant for you. Advanced cancer and extending life is where all the intense research and out-of-the-envelope creativity are happening. Many different approaches. Things that were thought to make no sense, like ADDING testosterone, are now being tested to defeat advanced cancer. There are publications weekly, if not daily, of articles by specialists around the world announcing some new understanding of how PCa works. while some other group reports amazing results in mice with human stage IV genes. So, the present facts may be useful, but your hopes and expectations should exceed them.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Chris702 Thank you everyone for all your advice. I will definitely keep you updated after I do a repeat PSA and see my urologist. I’ve been off the TRT for about 2 1/2 weeks and definitely feel the loss of energy even on the super low dose I was on. I will go and pay for my own lab work next week to check my regular and free PSA. Can anyone explain the free PSA and what are considered good and bad numbers? Thanks for everything. You’ve been a big help... For free PSA, anything under 15 is suspicious for cancer, and anything above 25 makes it unlikely that a biopsy would find significant cancer. Why not order a PHI test, which will give you the PSA and fPSA numbers, but has an additional test, and it will provide a more accurate result? It costs about $115, from what I've heard.

Posts.Title: Prostate Biopsy Question

Posts.Content: The more I read of this report, the less relevant it becomes. A UK study with protocols determined almost twenty years ago? There are so many more tests available (and required) today to determine suitability for Active Surveillance. This study did not use fPSA, PHI, PCA3, OncotypeDX, Prolaris, mpMRI, 3Tesla MRI, PI-RADS, or other tools currently available to determine if a newly diagnosed man is actually "low risk". I can appreciate that large studies must cover many years to be credible, but the pace of advance of diagnostic technology has overtaken the current validity of this research. It certainly is not changing my mind.

Posts.Title: NEW -New England Journal of Medicine article... and associated NY Times article on it

Posts.Content: Chuck, Proton Beam Therapy is a whole gland treatment. It is another form of external beam radiation treatment (EBRT), but uses proton rather than photon beams. The theoretical advantage is that the beam has an endpoint, while photon does not. So, there would be less chance of overspray of radiation onto nearby healthy tissue. But, from what I have read, it still has issues similar to photon EBRT. Not quite realizing its potential yet.

Posts.Title: Proton Therapy Advice?

Posts.Content: zencat, Sorry that you have to join us here. As you know, you have low-intermediate grade PCa, and your odds of beating it with a form of treatment are very high. A couple of checklist items: (1) Have you had your biopsy slides sent to an expert institution such as Johns Hopkins or Bostwick? These second opinions are highly recommended by many PCa experts. Many times, the results will be different from the initial assessments. (2) Have you spoken with a radiation oncologist about their services? Very recent studies have indicated higher cure rates and lower side effects with certain newer forms of radiation. Its not fair to expect a surgeon to be fully up-to-date on radiation advances, and vice versa. As stated above, the odds are very, very good for cases like yours. Maybe do a little more researching, and then prepare for the treatment of your choosing. Good luck.

Posts.Title: First Post, Struggling to Stay Positive

Posts.Content: Frank, There are not many PBT threads here because, well...because not many PBT guys post here. They do post on some other forums and Facebook groups. The new AUA/ASTRO/SOU Guidelines for Clinicians state that PBT has not proven itself to be any better than other forms of radiation, while costing more. That seems to be a widely held consensus, except by PBT advocates, some of whom are almost evangelical in recommending the treatment. They believe that it has fewer side effects than surgery or photon radiation. Look around the internet and you will find plenty of information on PBT.

Posts.Content: Last, You might ask the office if they have a patient portal like MyChart. All of my physicians have this type of online patient access to medical tests and records. When I have an MRI, biopsy, or any blood tests, I receive an email about three days later stating that the results are now in MyChart. Unless the doctor is constantly scanning MyChart. I will see the results before he/she does. There is no excuse for waiting weeks for your results. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Confused

Posts.Content: Im on a tour of Central Asia, and am now in Uzbekistan, where internet access appears to be unrestricted. Not so in Turkmenistan, where the Soviet-style government blocks unacceptable websites, even using VPNs. Such banned sites include Facebook, Yahoo, Google, AND cancerforums.net. Why is that??? They do play favorites, blocking foxnews and drudge, while allowing cnn and msnbc. But, those are political, and, while cancer treatment discussions can sometimes have the tone of politics, the blocking of the site is puzzling. Other, similar PCa forums are allowed. Well, now we know why we never see postings from Turkmenistan ðŸ¤”
Posts.Title: HUMOR - This forum blocked in Turkmenistan

Posts.Content: For the past four years, my specialist at Johns Hopkins had been Ashley Ross, MD, PhD, Assistant Professor of Urology, Oncology, and Pathology, Johns Hopkins School Of Medicine. His phone number was the same as Dr. Ballentine Carter, which shows how highly his potential was regarded. I found Dr. Ross to be among the "best and brighest" of the younger generation of prostate cancer luminaries, and he seemed to be constantly publishing articles exploring new approaches to treating PCa. His wife is also a urologist, who recently took a position in Texas, and Dr. Ross left JH to join a private practice there. My point in this thread is a reference to comments by Dr. Ross that were reported by a poster on another forum: "Also spoke on phone with Ashley Ross who used to be PCa director at JH, urologist and one of the few people there involved with focal treatments. My sense is that JH is still pretty conservative and I think since RP pretty much started there they still cling to that as gold standard treatment. Going with the random sampling of a TRUS biopsy versus MRI targeted biopsy would be philosophically consistent with that. That said, Ross did say that he felt that radiation therapies were about to overtake RP in efficacy the next few years and that RP would likely be left for only the more "difficult" cases." Hmm, knowing Dr. Ross, he is the ultimate researcher. I would wager that that he is waiting for and anticipating the 10 year results from major SBRT practitioners like King, Katz, and Zelefsky. Their results through 8 or 9 years are impressive, but 10 years seems to be a benchmark. The SBRT and also HDR BT techniques are already in place, and it's just the 10 year results that are needed to tie the ribbon on the package. Something more for you to consider.

Posts.Content: Denis, That is an excellent set of questions. But, you may have to revise your expectations if you show up and there is a room full of men, and those being seen are cycling their way back out in less than 15 minutes. He/She may have their own set of questions and advice for you, that are designed to get you assessed and out within a brief time span. On the other hand, if the two men ahead of you just called in to cancel, you may have some time to discuss your items.

Posts.Title: My questions for new Urologist (Yale Smilow)

Posts.Content: Denis and Michael, DanATX only had one biopsy, and yes, based on that he would have been dangerously mis-placed in AS. BUT, in a strict AS program like Johns Hopkins, it takes more than one biopsy to confirm your enrollment. You must have a confirmatory MRI fusion biopsy a few months after the first positive biopsy. Then, if those are consistent, you are in the program and having more tests every six months. The problem with people saying "if I had taken AS, I would have lost valuable time in treating my serious cancer" is that they were thinking about AS after one biopsy, and without having all the testing necessary to actually be accepted into a program. At least, that's how it works at JH.

Posts.Title: My questions for new Urologist (Yale Smilow)

Posts.Content: Cubby1, How many cores was cancer found in? Only one? If only one or two cores were positive, then you could add some of the focal therapies such as HIFU, Focal Laser Ablation, or focal cryotherapy to your list of options to research. Those options claim to have far fewer serious side effects than surgery or radiation. Of course, they have less of a track record, but are worth looking at.

Posts.Title: Recently diagnosed and weighing my options

Posts.Content: RunLTW's signature does not mention if he had a 3 Tesla MRI before his initial biopsy. At least at JH, that protocol is part of determining if you are really eligible for their AS program. What I am reading as an ongoing attempt to be aware of my options is that MRI's are now capable of finding at least 97 percent of prostate cancers, and targeting them for biopsies. The amount of uncertainty is narrowing, year by year.

Posts.Title: A pain in the Prostate :(

Posts.Content: Hopeful65 , Brachytherapy, at least the low dose seed type, is not experimental. It was tried in the 1970's for prostate cancer, without good results due to lack of modern imaging for placement. Ultrasound changed that, and LDR has been in regular use since the late 1980's. There is a "sticky" thread near the top of this webpage that has a discussion on the "two types of brachytherapy". That should be valuable for you. However, there are not many regular members of this forum who have had brachytherapy, but they are elsewhere on internet forums, so you may have to search beyond any one forum to get the feedback that you want.

Posts.Title: Prostate Brachytherapy Vs. Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Emar, the biopsy results are for a fairly small amount of low risk cancer. That is not much of a threat, if no further upgrades are found. Federal CDC statistics indicate that his chances of dying from prostate cancer within the next ten years are less than one percent. That is an overview of ALL new cases, and his is low risk, driving the odds even lower. His case has set two new records for what I've read: (1) 8 biopsies before any cancer was found; and (2) a spike of 53 from a BHP infection. That must have been very worrisome for the both of you. At this point, all options of treatment, as well as surveillance, are on the table for you and he to research and select from. There is no need to rush in deciding what to do. However, the size of his prostate, and the existing urination problems, might be a factor to choose surgery, but that is something to very carefully think over. Good luck. Oops, looks like Chuck and I were writing at the same time. I was thinking of his case when suggesting surgery.

Posts.Title: Years Of Elevated PSA

Posts.Content: Ready, Sorry that you are dealing with the possibility of your husband having PCa. I said possibility, because about 65 percent or higher of initial biopsies are negative. I have several friends with psa histories higher than your husbands, and they have had multiple negative biopsies over many years. Please do not assume that he has cancer; the greater likelihood is that he has BPH. I am also surprised that his urologist is doing a biopsy without an fpsa or PHI or other preliminary test. I once had a biopsy cancelled because of a high (good) fpsa result. Biopsies are not risk-free. I know; painfully know. Please take your time, catch your breath, and read as much as you can comfortably absorb. There are several types of treatment, if that is even necessary. make sure that you and he fully comprehend the possible side effects of each. Good luck.

Posts.Title: First Ever PSA Test Very Elevated Second Even Higher

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by hopeful65 Chuck, First I'd like to say thank you for taking the time to reach out to me, I feel so overwhelmed with different emotions. I have two young kids, a beautiful family who depend on me, I saw my brother and my dad pass away from cancer, they had different, more serious types. It's very scary and very confusing, I don't know which path to take. I just turned 52, I'm in good shape, work out an average of two times a week, eat healthy, my work consists of manual labor so other than injury pains I feel pretty good. My PSA history, 11/14 - 4.8, 7/15 - 6.2, 11/15 - 3.6, 4/16 - 4.9, 10/16 - 5.9, 3/17 - 7.5, then again 3/17 - 8.2 Out of all of the samples taken, two were found to have a Gleason score of 7, (3 + 4), and the other three areas were a Gleason 6, (3 + 3). The two areas of Gleason seven were found on the right base lateral, 70% of the tissue sample, and right lateral mid, 15% of tissue sample. Thank you, Eddie Eddie, thanks for providing these details. While I try to suggest active surveillance for those men who might safely benefit from not having treatment at the present time, I would rather recommend that you need to research and select a form of treatment. Two G3+4 cores, one with 70 percent, and a total of 5 positive cores, at age 52 with a psa of 8, is not something that I would be comfortable with just monitoring. But, you should take some time now, and keep asking and learning. Several types of treatments should cure you. Just be comfortable with the one you choose.

Cryo fares badly against SBRT in this comparison. https://pcnrv.blogspot.com/2017/09/f...for-radio.html

Posts.Title: Any feedback on Cryotherapy as a primary treatment?

Posts.Content: Welcome, and sorry that you have to be here. This approach is new to me, but it makes sense if they want to reduce the size of your prostate before certain types of radiation treatment. That thermotherapy is FDA approved for treating BPH. And, since the prostate must be under 40-50cc in volume for certain treatments, they are reducing its volume as a preparatory step. Placement of fiducial markers is typical of several types of external beam radiation, as it helps position the beam despite your movements on the table. Have they discussed what type of radiation is being proposed? Have you consulted more than one specialist regarding your treatment options? You have time to explore all your options and feel comfortable with what you choose.
Posts.Title: Cooled Thermotherapy Treatment... Why??

Posts.Content: Urologists are surgeons, they will recommend surgery. Radiologists do their thing. Sometimes, they agree, or will recommend the other. But, it is always smart to consult with both, ans never let one describe the other.

Posts.Title: Cooled Thermotherapy Treatment... Why??

Posts.Content: For the past four years, my specialist at Johns Hopkins had been Ashley Ross, MD, PhD, Assistant Professor of Urology, Oncology, and Pathology, Johns Hopkins School Of Medicine. His phone number was the same as Dr. Ballentine Carter, which shows how highly his potential was regarded. I found Dr. Ross to be among the "best and brighest" of the younger generation of prostate cancer luminaries, and he seemed to be constantly publishing articles exploring new approaches to treating PCa. His wife is also a urologist, who recently took a position in Texas, and Dr. Ross left JH to join a private practice there. My point in this thread is a reference to comments by Dr. Ross that were reported by a poster on another forum: "Also spoke on phone with Ashley Ross who used to be PCa director at JH, urologist and one of the few people there involved with focal treatments. My sense is that JH is still pretty conservative and I think since RP pretty much started there they still cling to that as gold standard treatment. Going with the random sampling of a TRUS biopsy versus MRI targeted biopsy would be philosophically consistent with that. That said, Ross did say that he felt that radiation therapies were about to overtake RP in efficacy the next few years and that RP would likely be left for only the more "difficult" cases." Hmm, knowing Dr. Ross, he is the ultimate researcher. I would wager that that he is waiting for and anticipating the 10 year results from major SBRT practitioners like King, Katz, and Zelefsky. Their results through 8 or 9 years are impressive, but 10 years seems to be a benchmark. The SBRT and also HDR BT techniques are already in place, and it's just the 10 year results that are needed to tie the ribbon on the package. Something more for you to consider.

Posts.Title: For Denis and Others trying to Decide on which Treatment

Posts.Content: HIFU is not really new, as it was first used experimentally in the early 1940's in the United States. But, modern HIFU machines did not appear until the mid-1990's. It is approved throughout Europe, and also in Canada, Australia, and South Korea. The 2015 FDA approval basically classifies it as a scalpel for cutting prostate tissue, not a method to cure prostate cancer. From what I've read about it over the years, it still has to prove it has a reasonably low recurrence-free rate. Just having low side effects, and being able to repeat treatments, would not convince me to use it, at this time.

Posts.Title: Prostate Brachytherapy Vs. Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wbigs As someone who has recently joined the active surveillance club, I read all 3 articles and Im still not sure how I feel. While I think that its trying to convey that AS is a viable option for early cancer, I tend to pick out the negatives from the articles just as Michael has in the previous post. I think the hardest part is trying to be patient, which isn't one of my strong points. It doesn't help when you are telling people about your prostate cancer who aren't familiar with treatment options and you tell them that you are just going to keep and eye on things for a year or two and they look at you like your f-ing nuts. wbigs, The key statement in your post is "telling people about your prostate cancer who aren't familiar with treatment options" I had the same reaction in 2009. I am now entering my eighth year of Active Surveillance, with my assessment unchanged. Just had MRI and other tests last week. No changes at all. And, no negative changes to my quality of life due to radical treatments. Seek out informed medical advice, and dismiss the well-meaning, almost common-sense concerns of those who are not familiar with low risk prostate cancer. Join a local support group if you need people to talk with one-on-one. They are all aware of AS, and many wish that their doctors had recommended it to them.

Posts.Title: NEW -New England Journal of Medicine article... and associated NY Times article on it

Posts.Content: ISZ, It's a probability scheme, with a combination of PHI tests, DRE's, TRUS biopsies, 3T mp-MRIs, fusion biopsies, OncotypeDX and other genomics tests. When you do a regular schedule of all of those, you greatly reduce the odds of any significant cancer being missed. It takes much more than one biopsy to know what you are dealing with. A strict AS program gives you all the other testing. In Johns Hopkins' experience, there has been no additional mortality risk for men who began AS and later need treatment, versus those who chose immediate treatment.

Posts.Content: ejc61, Don't let the saynayers bother you. He has no basis for that 100% claim. You are doing exactly what you should be doing, and all the American medical groups that issue guidelines on treating prostate cancer agree with AS for your pathology. ALL of them consider AS to be a treatment. Check my signature. Ten years. I sleep well at night, knowing that I have lived normally, and not had to deal with the depressing side effects of treatment. Well, at least not yet. If you are on Facebook, there is a group there that is very supportive of AS. Let me know if you want their name.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jazzman Thanks for that information ASAdvocate. I appreciate it. Maybe I don't see it, but can you explain how they measure urinary toxicity and how the different grades are determined? Jazz, there are standards for grading urinary and gastro toxicities. I can't explain exactly how they do it, but this quote and the link to the article I extracted it from, should point you in the right direction for further research. "RTOG toxicity grades were assigned prospectively for genitourinary (GU) and GI toxicity at the date of each follow‐up visit by the attending physician. More detailed Common Toxicity Criteria (CTC) version 3.0 toxicity grades were then assigned retrospectively by chart review. " https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/....1002/cam4.261

Posts.Title: Any feedback on Cryotherapy as a primary treatment?

Posts.Content: Emar, the biopsy results are for a fairly small amount of low risk cancer. That is not much of a threat, if no further upgrades are found. Federal CDC statistics indicate that his chances of dying from prostate cancer within the next ten years are less than one percent. That is an overview of ALL new cases, and his is low risk, driving the odds even lower. His case has set two new records for what I've read: (1) 8 biopsies before any cancer was found; and (2) a spike of 53 from a BHP infection. That must have been very worrisome for the both of you. At this point, all options of treatment, as well as surveillance, are on the table for you and he to research and select from. There is no need to rush in deciding what to do. However, the size of his prostate, and the existing urination problems, might be a factor to choose surgery, but that is something to very carefully think over. Good luck. Oops, looks like Chuck and I were writing at the same time. I was thinking of his case when suggesting surgery.

Posts.Title: Years Of Elevated PSA

Posts.Content: South, As is sometimes the case where a biopsy with more than two cores, unilaterally, having a G6 finding, I will have to take some exception to the above posts (with all due respect) You and I are walking down a path which they have not, and our mentalities and attending urologists see things in another perspective. I also have been told I have three positive cores. No problem with AS, especially when the people telling you this are the ones who review the data and make those recommendations for national adaption. Now, the OncotypeDX genomics test can be done by sending your biopsy slides to that company. That checks about 20 genetic markers within the cancer to predict its aggressiveness. Also, the ERG and pten tests can be done on those slides. The PHI and PCA3 blood and urine tests are also widely used. I don't know your age or if you are in a formal program, but it sounds like we are receiving the same advice from our specialists. I have complete confidence in following it.

Posts.Title: Any feedback on Cryotherapy as a primary treatment?

Posts.Content: I have just returned from having biopsy number SIX. That was required by my AS protocol, as it had been almost five years since the last one. A major change was that this one was not a TRUS. Rather, it was transperineal, which is what Johns Hopkins has now switched to. The Precision Point system requires only local anesthetic, and no antibiotics. They have had zero cases of serious infections by going through the perineum. The pain and cancer detection results are about same as a TRUS, but the zero infection rate is a big deal. No more fears of antibiotics and sepsis.

Posts.Content: This confirms previous studies that failed to confirm the validity of age-related PSA classifications. But, perhaps PSAD(ensity) should be given more weight, especially in men over 70 where enlarged prostates with no or little cancer can produce suspicious high PSA. IMHO, PSAD should be a factor in deciding if a biopsy is warranted.

Posts.Title: My questions for new Urologist (Yale Smilow)

Posts.Content: Cubby1, How many cores was cancer found in? Only one? If only one or two cores were positive, then you could add some of the focal therapies such as HIFU, Focal Laser Ablation, or focal cryotherapy to your list of options to research. Those options claim to have far fewer serious side effects than surgery or radiation. Of course, they have less of a track record, but are worth looking at.

Posts.Title: Recently diagnosed and weighing my options

Posts.Content: Trex, Most of the advice that you have been given is about surgery. I would suggest two readings to help balance the choices. One suggestion would be Dr. Mark Scholz new book The Key to Prostate Cancer. He interviewed thirty PCa experts to combine a spectrum of knowledge and advice. Also, this Journal of the AMA article concludes that a combination of RT treatments produces better outcomes for high risk men than surgery does. https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jam...rticle/2673969 You are doing a great job of research and seeking advice. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: Looking for surgeon and/or RT doc in Seattle area ...

Posts.Content: Ready, Sorry that you are dealing with the possibility of your husband having PCa. I said possibility, because about 65 percent or higher of initial biopsies are negative. I have several friends with psa histories higher than your husbands, and they have had multiple negative biopsies over many years. Please do not assume that he has cancer; the greater likelihood is that he has BPH. I am also surprised that his urologist is doing a biopsy without an fpsa or PHI or other preliminary test. I once had a biopsy cancelled because of a high (good) fpsa result. Biopsies are not risk-free. I know; painfully know. Please take your time, catch your breath, and read as much as you can comfortably absorb. There are several types of treatment, if that is even necessary. make sure that you and he fully comprehend the possible side effects of each. Good luck.

Posts.Title: First Ever PSA Test Very Elevated Second Even Higher

Posts.Content: I have not heard of prostate cancer being reversible. There are instances where no cancer cells were found on subsequent biopsies. That has happened with me. But, I have no doubt that I still have PCa. When there is only a small amount, then it is reasonable to expect that a biopsy needle can miss it. There are websites that promote natural healing and various plants and chemicals, but those topics are usually not encouraged on sites like this one, which only deal with proven treatments. The radio personality Don Imus has been treating his G7 cancer with a hundred or more ingestions of pills and home-brewed potions every day since about 2009. He's apparently stabilized his PCa, but that's a LOT of stuff going into his body. I think that I will order that book. It has good reviews, and another perspective is always welcome. UPDATE: Yes, I have read of a recent clinical trial using an immunotherapy agent where previously diagnosed low risk PCa could not be found after treatment. But, that is really experimental and not generally available at this time.

Posts.Title: What Should PSA Be After Radiation as Primary Treatment?

Posts.Content: Welcome, and sorry that you have to be here. This approach is new to me, but it makes sense if they want to reduce the size of your prostate before certain types of radiation treatment. That thermotherapy is FDA approved for treating BPH. And, since the prostate must be under 40-50cc in volume for certain treatments, they are reducing its volume as a preparatory step. Placement of fiducial markers is typical of several types of external beam radiation, as it helps position the beam despite your movements on the table. Have they discussed what type of radiation is being proposed? Have you consulted more than one specialist regarding your treatment options? You have time to explore all your options and feel comfortable with what you choose.

Posts.Content: HIFU is not really new, as it was first used experimentally in the early 1940's in the United States. But, modern HIFU machines did not appear until the mid-1990's. It is approved throughout Europe, and also in Canada, Australia, and South Korea. The 2015 FDA approval basically classifies it as a scalpel for cutting prostate tissue, not a method to cure prostate cancer. From what I've read about it over the years, it still has to prove it has a reasonably low recurrence-free rate. Just having low side effects, and being able to repeat treatments, would not convince me to use it, at this time.

One suggestion would be Dr. Mark Scholz new book The Key to Prostate Cancer. He interviewed thirty PCa experts to combine a spectrum of knowledge and advice. Also, this Journal of the AMA article concludes that a combination of RT treatments produces better outcomes for high risk men than surgery does. https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jam...rticle/2673969 You are doing a great job of research and seeking advice. Good luck to you.

Posts.Content: PVD, Congratulations on the low psa. Regarding the "white coat hypertension syndrome", I've had to deal with that for SIXTY years. Started when I was about 13. It has caused me endless hassles during medical office visits. My readings at home or a supermarket are usually 110/60 or lower. At any medical appointment, the systolic can hit 190. Tried all kinds of meditation and distractions. Just can't help it. So, I always bring my meter with me, with all its recent history recorded. Of course, they want to use that device right then, and, when it matches their high readings , they make comments about " Wow! you really react. Well, thanks for showing us those numbers", then back off and move onto other issues. It's always a distraction that eats into the appointment time, but we just have to downplay it and move along as quickly as we can.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Brucec41 Your responses were very helpful and you asked for an update....please see below: On the trusted advice of two Urologists and your responses I did undergo a multiparametric MRI - summary findings below using their scale of 1-5 Two abnormalities found: 1) had a PI-RADS score of 3 2) had a PI-RADS score of 4 Seminal Vesicles - No Seminal Vesicle involvement Lymph Nodes - no evidence of pelvic lymphadenopathy Pelvis Bowl - Unremarkable Ascites - Trace pelvic ascites Pelvic Bones - No suspicious lesions in pelvis Based on the findings above I scheduled a fusion biopsy for this Friday 10/13/17 Assuming the biopsy is positive my leaning is towards Radical Prostatectomy since everything I read states this surgery yields the greatest probability for extending life span You may also want to research other treatments besides surgery. Urologists are surgeons, who tend to promote what they do, and are not always up to date on the advances in radiation in recent years. SBRT (Cyberknife) and HD Brachytherapy have been showing very impressive results in terms on non-recurrence and low side effects. https://www.sciencedaily.com/release...0418145458.htm

Posts.Title: Considering first Prostate biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider This is only for PSA screening, not for guys already under treatment for PC. I guess they made the determination that almost any man who hasn't been diagnosed by age 70, and has normal PSA/no symptoms, is "in the clear" and its extraordinarily unlikely that they will live long enough for PC to kill them. Assuming that is what they were thinking, it makes a lot of sense. Most American men who see a doctor every year have had many psa tests by age 70. When I was 51, with no symptoms or family history, and doctor said it was wise to start psa testing. BUT, there are some guys, and I know some, who have an abject fear of doctors. For that minority, who have not had multiple previous tests, there probably should not be an upper age limit. They need a baseline number. Whether they should be treated or not is not the question at hand.

Posts.Title: People over 70 not take PSA

Posts.Content: South, As is sometimes the case where a biopsy with more than two cores, unilaterally, having a G6 finding, I will have to take some exception to the above posts (with all due respect) You and I are walking down a path which they have not, and our mentalities and attending urologists see things in another perspective. I also have been told I have three positive cores. No problem with AS, especially when the people telling you this are the ones who review the data and make those recommendations for national adaption. Now, the OncotypeDX genomics test can be done by sending your biopsy slides to that company. That checks about 20 genetic markers within the cancer to predict its aggressiveness. Also, the ERG and pten tests can be done on those slides. The PHI and PCA3 blood and urine tests are also widely used. I don't know your age or if you are in a formal program, but it sounds like we are receiving the same advice from our specialists. I have complete confidence in following it.

Posts.Title: What a week --but still in zero club

Posts.Content: Ready, Sorry that you are dealing with the possibility of your husband having PCa. I said possibility, because about 65 percent or higher of initial biopsies are negative. I have several friends with psa histories higher than your husbands, and they have had multiple negative biopsies over many years. Please do not assume that he has cancer; the greater likelihood is that he has BPH. I am also surprised that his urologist is doing a biopsy without an fpsa or PHI or other preliminary test. I once had a biopsy cancelled because of a high (good) fpsa result. Biopsies are not risk-free. I know; painfully know. Please take your time, catch your breath, and read as much as you can comfortably absorb. There are several types of treatment, if that is even necessary. make sure that you and he fully comprehend the possible side effects of each. Good luck.

Posts.Content: ISZ, It's a probability scheme, with a combination of PHI tests, DRE's, TRUS biopsies, 3T mp-MRIs, fusion biopsies, OncotypeDX and other genomics tests. When you do a regular schedule of all of those, you greatly reduce the odds of any significant cancer being missed. It takes much more than one biopsy to know what you are dealing with. A strict AS program gives you all the other testing. In Johns Hopkins' experience, there has been no additional mortality risk for men who began AS and later need treatment, versus those who chose immediate treatment.

Posts.Title: HIFU? My husband is 71, has PSA 5.5, Gleason 4+3, T2b. Any advice?

Posts.Content: IMP, You have been on an AS alert for three years, so I must assume that you are informed and have thought the options through, over and over. Your criteria make sense, as does your reasoning, which is simply to buy some time now, hoping that the available treatments will improve by the time that they may be absolutely necessary. HIFU interests me, as does cryotherapy. But, there is about 25 years between us, so our thinking will likely not be the same. Since you expect the HIFU to be a holding action, and you know to keep your cancer under close surveillance, your plan sounds OK to me. Please keep us informed of your thoughts, experiences, and progress. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Biop result today GL3+4

Posts.Content: Kevin, Sorry that you received this news, and have to join us here. Among the best advice right now is for you to get a second reading on the biopsy slides. Many men take advantage of the services offered by Johns Hopkins, whose chief pathologist is considered the world authority on interpreting prostate biopsy slides. From the above report, you would be risk category 2 out of 5 on the new World Health Organization guidelines. No need to rush into a decision. Both surgery and radiation can effectively treat you. There are variations of both those therapies, and you need to learn about them. The side effects are especially important, and you need to thoroughly understand them before making a choice. I would suggest that you attend some local prostate cancer support groups, and talk with men who have had various treatments. Whatever you do, do not make a treatment decision after talking to only one specialist. Make sure that you consult with both surgeons and radiologists. The cure rates are about the same between both methods, but side effects may vary. Others will be along with more advice. Good luck to you.
