Posts.Title: Doc says time to do something.

Posts.Content: Denis, Reading your posts, both here and on at least two similar forums, has shown how thorough and deliberate you are in gathering the data and opinions for your decision. And, "Another" has once again replied with his insightful and concise reassurance. But, I must interject that one of the primary qualifications for active surveillance is peace of mind. Once you make your choice, you should not torture yourself by re-analyzing that process on a daily basis. My credo in making choices has three steps: Decision, Resolution, Closure. Make the choice, do what it takes to effect the choice, and don't keep re-thinking the choice. For AS, that would mean settling on a protocol of follow-up appointments and tests. But, you owe it to yourself not to constantly question your decision. If you won't be able to stop questioning, then, IMHO, AS is not a good choice for you. I hang around forums and meetings because I have an advocacy for AS and against overtreatment. I do not re-examine if my choice was correct. This factor needs to be included in your calculus. As always, good luck in whatever your decision is.

Posts.Title: Surveillance to delay treatment, decision time?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Dogdollar Thanks, Frenchy. I find it a little difficult to believe that these stats are not easier to find. Seems pretty obvious to me....this talk about Pca being overtreated has GOT to have something to do with the number of G6 cases that have RALRPs.......and yet " no man dies of a Gleason 6"? Just one example.... Regards, DD dog, You may have trouble finding up-to-date numbers. I attended a local PCa support group recently, and heard presentations from a surgeon, a radiologist, and a chemo doctor. The surgeon showed statistics that the rate of choice of AS for newly diagnosed patients had risen from 10 to over 50 percent in three years. That's an amazing change! He was also adamant that G6 cases should not have intervention. That surely would not have been common advice five or ten years ago. So, the available statistics for "overtreatment" may not be accurate in light of this rapidly changing environment.

It would seem to me that there should not be such a great difference in what he, as your surgeon, told you, and what this calculator gave you. You might want to ask him about the calculator. Meanwhile, it doesn't appear that credible.
Posts.Signature: DOB: May 1944 In Active Surveillance program at Johns Hopkins Strict protocol of tests, including PHI, DRE, MRI, and biopsy. Six biopsies from 2009 to 2019. Numbers 1, 2, and 5 were negative. Numbers 3,4, and 6 were positive with 5% Gleason(3+3) found. Last one was Precision Point transperineal. PSA 4.4, fPSA 24, PHI 32 Hopefully, I can remain untreated. So far, so good.
Posts.Title: Is this calculator accurate????

Posts.Content: If you have Gleason (4+4), it may be smart to also consult with radiation oncologists. Combinations of radiation treatments, and sometimes hormones, are yielding very good results with high risk Gleason 8-10 cases. Keep in mind that radiation can reach beyond the prostate, killing the cancer cells it targets. But, good luck with whichever path you choose.

Posts.Title: Prostate MRI Results

Posts.Content: Kevin, Sorry that you received this news, and have to join us here. Among the best advice right now is for you to get a second reading on the biopsy slides. Many men take advantage of the services offered by Johns Hopkins, whose chief pathologist is considered the world authority on interpreting prostate biopsy slides. From the above report, you would be risk category 2 out of 5 on the new World Health Organization guidelines. No need to rush into a decision. Both surgery and radiation can effectively treat you. There are variations of both those therapies, and you need to learn about them. The side effects are especially important, and you need to thoroughly understand them before making a choice. I would suggest that you attend some local prostate cancer support groups, and talk with men who have had various treatments. Whatever you do, do not make a treatment decision after talking to only one specialist. Make sure that you consult with both surgeons and radiologists. The cure rates are about the same between both methods, but side effects may vary. Others will be along with more advice. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: Got the news yesterday, what now?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee If it perhaps may have begun to spread, which is unlikely for grade 3 but possible for grade 4, then you will still have the option of radiation treatment "down the road". If radiation is chosen as the first line treatment, that is generally no longer an option. Hi RobLee, Things are changing rapidly in the world of advanced radiation applications, and the old wisdom of salvage radiation not being used if it was the primary treatment may be outdated. https://pcnrv.blogspot.com/2016/08/s...nce-after.html

Posts.Title: Got the news yesterday, what now?

Posts.Content: TomoTherapy is a variant of IMRT, so it is photon-based, and quite different from Proton Beam Therapy. I did just notice a recent study concluding that Tomo could have some rectal protection advantage over SBRT (Cyberknife), but that study only involved 12 patients, and SpaceOAR or other rectal shields were not used, so it is of limited value. I peruse four prostate cancer forums, and I think that this is only the second time anyone has mentioned TomoTherapy. Very, very few CCA patients post on internet forums. I have no clue why that is.

Posts.Title: Is TomoTherapy the same as Proton Therapy, Just Different Name?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mikesimm This raises an interesting element... Is it the prostate that is "producing" the threes and fours - and is not producing 5's? Or do the threes and fours replicate themselves and perhaps morph/multiply into a higher number? In other words, where is the factory? All of this is just academic, but it's how I think. I'm of the view that nobody knows anything, including me. Remember when the earth used to be flat? My biopsy results just got changed (for the worse) after being reviewed at MD Anderson. I'm still leaning heavily toward Proton treatment, assuming I'm a candidate. Mike in Kerrville Mike, The question of "can Gleason 3 cells morph into higher grade?" is a regularly discussed topic on PCa forums. The general conclusion is usually "yes, it's possible, but the odds of it happening are insignificant, like 1 out of 2000". The research was based on the Johns Hopkins and Sunnybrook As groups which have over 3,000 patients and over 20 years history on some of them. I recall there were 2 cases where the DNA analysis seemed to prove morphing was possible, but not frequent enough for patients to worry about.

Posts.Title: PSA jump

Posts.Content: You are in the zone where whatever you choose, your chances of not dying from prostate cancer are very good. While that is good, it can also be very confusing. There are many opinions. Surgery (two types), radiation (a half dozen types), and an alphabet soup of other treatments like HIFU and FLA, who have very adamant supporters. The topic of what a newly-diagnosed low intermediate grade man should choose is by far the most discussed and debated one on the internet forums, and also at local support groups. I would agree with Fairwind, that the major advances in the past decade have been with radiation, especially with SBRT (Cyberknife) and HD brachytherapy. Their recent results with "cure" rates and low side effects are impressive. If primary radiation should fail, follow up with SBRT or cryotherapy is now possible. As to active surveillance, some 50 percent of the low risk men in my area are now choosing it. But, there is serious caution with G3+4, and I would guess that depends on whether there is more than a trace of the 4 in each core. I have been on AS for eight years, but would come off of it if more than 10 percent Gleason 4 was were found in more than one core. But, that's just my opinion, and I have a high threshold for dealing with it. The "surgery for younger men" theme is being questioned both by radiation and AS proponents with new research. But, if you take the time to search around, you will encounter all of those viewpoints. You might want to follow the past posts of "subdenis", a new member who has been doing an amazing amount of research in a similar quest for answers to his best choice.

Posts.Title: Options for early stage prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Denis, Reading your posts, both here and on at least two similar forums, has shown how thorough and deliberate you are in gathering the data and opinions for your decision. And, "Another" has once again replied with his insightful and concise reassurance. But, I must interject that one of the primary qualifications for active surveillance is peace of mind. Once you make your choice, you should not torture yourself by re-analyzing that process on a daily basis. My credo in making choices has three steps: Decision, Resolution, Closure. Make the choice, do what it takes to effect the choice, and don't keep re-thinking the choice. For AS, that would mean settling on a protocol of follow-up appointments and tests. But, you owe it to yourself not to constantly question your decision. If you won't be able to stop questioning, then, IMHO, AS is not a good choice for you. I hang around forums and meetings because I have an advocacy for AS and against overtreatment. I do not re-examine if my choice was correct. This factor needs to be included in your calculus. As always, good luck in whatever your decision is.

Posts.Title: Surveillance to delay treatment, decision time?

Posts.Content: Cathy, I'm not sure why he is being sent for those scans with only G6 cancer being found. As the others have said, that is the lowest grade of PCa, and often, as in my case, does not require treatment, but rather close monitoring. What is most helpful for us in providing advice is for you to obtain the biopsy pathology report (he paid for it, and owns it), and write up some of the findings in a signature, as you will see on the posts here. Yes, getting guys to open up is sometimes difficult, but prostate cancer boards are a big exception. People do not hold back their private details when they want and need to exchange advice. The most important thing now, is that he gets multiple opinions, and is NOT pressured into surgery or another (possibly unnecessary and damaging) treatment without a full understanding and discussion of all his options.

Posts.Title: 3+ 4 and 4+3 - Is there REALLY a Difference?

Posts.Content: Dev, He is a risk level 2 out of 5 on the new Epstein/World Health Organization grading system for prostate cancer. That would assign him an almost 100 percent likelihood of NOT dying from PCa within the next 10 years. That should encourage you to breathe easier and change your username. There is a lot of things to learn and think over. Prostate cancer is not like other cancers. Many cases are indolent or very slow growing. He can also learn by finding and attending a local PCa support group. They are in most communities, and hold monthly meetings. Jim's advice on surgery, with possible salvage radiation has worked for him, but you will find that there are radiation partisans on other websites, who have different opinions. Conflicting advice, and the sheer number of possible types of treatments is simply part of learning about the choices ahead. Whatever the future decisions are, the odds are overwhelming that his cancer will be successfully treated and that he will be around for a long time.

Posts.Content: He had a negative biopsy AFTER having positive ones. Same as me. I have read that Johns Hopkins considers a negative biopsy after a positive one to be a strong indicator of indolent cancer. Let's not be so quick to condemn the doctor. BTW, I have also had PSA over 10, and it was just a spike that went back down over time.

There is a lot of things to learn and think over. Prostate cancer is not like other cancers. Many cases are indolent or very slow growing. He can also learn by finding and attending a local PCa support group. They are in most communities, and hold monthly meetings. Jim's advice on surgery, with possible salvage radiation has worked for him, but you will find that there are radiation partisans on other websites, who have different opinions. Conflicting advice, and the sheer number of possible types of treatments is simply part of learning about the choices ahead. Whatever the future decisions are, the odds are overwhelming that his cancer will be successfully treated and that he will be around for a long time.
Posts.Signature: DOB: May 1944 In Active Surveillance program at Johns Hopkins Strict protocol of tests, including PHI, DRE, MRI, and biopsy. Six biopsies from 2009 to 2019. Numbers 1, 2, and 5 were negative. Numbers 3,4, and 6 were positive with 5% Gleason(3+3) found. Last one was Precision Point transperineal. PSA 4.4, fPSA 24, PHI 32 Hopefully, I can remain untreated. So far, so good.
Posts.Title: Concerned - PC diagnosed :(

Posts.Content: While I am not a CK patient, I have read hundreds of posts about psa bounces following radiation treatments. It is expected, and can continue for up to three years. There are opinions on typical patterns, timings, and post-nadir rises, if any. But, the bounces are part of the treatment process.
Posts.Title: PSA Bounce Post CK

Posts.Content: Based on your patholgy, either surgery or radiation will likely cure you. The difference is the side effects, and, being only 55, you could have many years to regret making the wrong choice. See the RO, and hear what they have to say. But, equally as important, ask what types of radiation therapy they offer. There are IMRT, SBRT, LDRBT, HDRBT, and Proton Beam. I'm not aware of any one RO who performs all of them. And, some of the least practiced may have the best results. So, if the RO you see only does IMRT, you have only been told a fraction of the offerings, and need to consult further. Certainly a major center such as Anderson or MSKCC would afford you a range of options. Hopkins is renown for their surgery, but I rarely hear of their other offerings.

Again, my knowledge and experiences are just opinions, among the many that we can all share to help this member.

Posts.Title: Great Article about Gleason 6, New Gleason Groups

Posts.Content: Not at all surprising. BHP and prostatitis can have your psa ricocheting all over the place. The fact that your high psa went DOWN is a huge indicator that you may have other issues than cancer, as that tends to steadily increase. Prostate infections are mostly not indicated in urine cultures or affected by antibiotics. They often come and go on their own. Keep seeing your doctors, and taking their advice. At this time, it is likely that your problems are not cancer.

Posts.Content: Hi warrior, Sorry to hear of these complications. May I ask why surgery was chosen? What I commonly read on prostate cancer websites is that surgery is not usually performed on men over 70. Radiation or another type of intervention is recommended instead. Was this your husband's decision? Did he consult with several radiologists and surgeons? I do not want to further distress you about an irreversible decision, but it may be helpful for us to understand why this choice of treatment.

Posts.Title: Pain and Discharges

Posts.Content: Cathy, I'm not sure why he is being sent for those scans with only G6 cancer being found. As the others have said, that is the lowest grade of PCa, and often, as in my case, does not require treatment, but rather close monitoring. What is most helpful for us in providing advice is for you to obtain the biopsy pathology report (he paid for it, and owns it), and write up some of the findings in a signature, as you will see on the posts here. Yes, getting guys to open up is sometimes difficult, but prostate cancer boards are a big exception. People do not hold back their private details when they want and need to exchange advice. The most important thing now, is that he gets multiple opinions, and is NOT pressured into surgery or another (possibly unnecessary and damaging) treatment without a full understanding and discussion of all his options.

Posts.Title: Newbie with a question

Posts.Content: You are receiving excellent advice from the members who have shared their knowledege and experience. But, be careful with what you read on the internet. A month or two ago, I saw a similar post from a man with 8 or 9 cores of G(3+3). This was on a different prostate cancer forum. I commented that he needed to choose a treatment that he was comfortable with and then proceed with it. I was then criticized by several men adamantly insisting that "Gleason 6 is not cancer". Whew! That surprised me. All the other comments agreed with them. That is a viewpoint, a theory, that some specialists and patient advocates have. I think that it is dangerous until proven. Please do not fall for opinions that sound good, but are out of the mainstream of research and practice. You will not hear such opinions going unchallenged here.

Posts.Title: Biopsy results back - Feel like squirrel crossing busy street

Posts.Content: I belong to several PCa forums and have seen posts over the years from men who had RP, and then had rising PSA as late as 23 years later. It is even more common if the threshold is lowered to 10 years. Of course, that is not what anyone wants to hear. But, it is fact, and I have read the postings. Some folks will say that "cure" is not an appropriate term with PCa. I'd rather that people who have had treatment "consider themselves cured", but get yearly (or more frequent) testing, just to be damn sure.

Posts.Title: PSA Bounce Post CK

Posts.Content: Two points - IMHO, a man is never really qualified for AS after one biopsy. At Johns Hopkins' very successful program, you must have an mp-MRI and a confirmatory biopsy within six months. Plus, whichever genomics or blood/urine tests they are currently using with newly-diagnosed men. The additional testing is what has contributed to JH's AS men having no greater risk of mortality if they later need treatment than men who had immediate treatment. Point 2 - Basal cell carcinoma - Just diagnosed with a spot on my leg. With reddish hair and easily sunburned, this was no surprise. Mohs surgery set for the end of August. No concerns about the cancer, or having it "cut out". That's truly a low risk cancer and the surgery has no significant side effects. I have no worries about that issue at all.

Posts.Title: Recent articles on Gleason Grading

Posts.Content: Geo, From what I have learned from others, prostate cancer is not a fast and painless death. So, if you were, for example, to find some statistic that said you might live 12 years without treatment, that does not mean that you would have eleven plus normal years, and then die in your sleep. Far from it. I have read the journals, on other forums, of those who lost long fights with PCa. The last months' accounts were written by their relatives. Their fate is something that you want to avoid, even with serious side effects from treatments.

Posts.Title: Surgery wait time

Posts.Content: OTS, IMHO, it is good to hear that you will be moving forward with a treatment plan. But, I noticed your remarks about RT side effects and 20 year survival statistics. Some points for you to consider. None of the RT techniques used today existed 25 years ago, which is when such studies would have started. That includes IMRT, IGRT, SBRT, and Photon Beam. Brachytherapy (both types) did exist then. But, the precision focusing of Varian Truebeam and Cyberknife devices, with all their sophisticated targeting of possibly moving organs, did not exist. Years ago, the overreach from the CDRT radiation at that time caused the bowel and bladder issues. Those problems are far less frequent today than in 1993. Also, you may want to explore proton beam therapy. I am hearing from patients (elsewhere on the internet) who say it has cured them with zero side effects. Yeah, I know that sounds like hype, and requires skepticism, but their comments sound consistent, and perhaps you should talk with a center that offers that service. Anyway, you are proceeding to a cure, whichever path you now choose. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Surgery wait time

Posts.Content: Welcome to the forum, JackF. It sounds like the cancer is the least of your prostate issues. You have been through the usual AS first-year protocol of biopsy diagnosis, MRI, and fusion biopsy, with only insignificant cancer being found. The fact that no cancer was found on the second biopsy is a good indicator of indolent PCa. You have already had the confirmatory biopsy, so I don't see a reason why another MRI would be needed anytime soon. A possible regimen for you would be six month psa/fpsa or PHI tests, annual DRE's, and MRI's or biopsies every 2-3 years, or as required by the other test results. You are the first poster that I seen comment on the Urolift. Others will probably find your experience of interest. There is also a new bph treatment called Prostate Artery Embolization (PAE) that you may want to research.

Posts.Title: AS - One Year In, Two Biopsies, One MRI, PSA Stable since 1/17

Posts.Content: Sudds, Sorry that you have be here, but you will receive great advice from many caring and sincere members. I have to ask if, in making your decision for surgery, that you spoke with anyone other than a surgeon? Did you seek an opinion from a radiologist? I have seen several instances (on other forums) of men cancelling their surgery appointments and going with other treatments after being asked if they had looked into "this" treatment or "that" research. This is important, because you need to be 100 percent certain that you have fully evaluated all the several options for prostate cancer treatment. And, if you now feel that you have done that, then the best of luck to you.

Posts.Content: Lowlight. With a 16 core biopsy and a prostate MRI both being negative, you have some cause to relax, but not to stop being vigilant. I will assume that you have also had DRE's, and free PSA tests, right? Was your MRI with the trans-rectal coil, or a newer machine that can equal its results? If those tests all show negative at this time, you are probably like many of my friends dealing with BPH, and possible infections. High PSA's, up to 8 seem to be common with BPH. I had a PSA of 11 due to an infection following a biopsy. As others can tell you, drugs and surgery can help with BPH. Just keeping regular consultations about cancer is prudent, although your tests now, are, well, negative, and that's something to be relieved about.

Posts.Title: Heading for a second biopsy maybe?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another I'm concerned that it seems you have not been doing the watchful part for the last 3 years. I just had an iguinal hernia. Had it repaired. Not uncommon in older men. Surgeon said it was from a life time of wear and tear. So, the bump can be many things. See a doctor. Just with what you have shared, you were not a candidate for watch waiting or active surveillance 3 years ago with multible cores of cancer. What's going on? Get yourself to a major cancer center and into professional care. Or, update your signature if you have been watching it because I'm worried for you. Another, Multiple positive cores of G6 do not disqualify a man from AS. Some guidelines want 2 or less, some want a percent threshold, like 35 of the total number of cores, and some, like Sunnybrook, have no limit. What is confusing to me is guessing how many cores were taken during that biopsy, 12, 6, or less? We need more info on the total number of samples involved. But, that doesnt change our mutual advice for him to take serious action now.

Posts.Title: Inguinal lump after 2-3 years of watchful waiting

Posts.Content: You are receiving excellent advice from the members who have shared their knowledege and experience. But, be careful with what you read on the internet. A month or two ago, I saw a similar post from a man with 8 or 9 cores of G(3+3). This was on a different prostate cancer forum. I commented that he needed to choose a treatment that he was comfortable with and then proceed with it. I was then criticized by several men adamantly insisting that "Gleason 6 is not cancer". Whew! That surprised me. All the other comments agreed with them. That is a viewpoint, a theory, that some specialists and patient advocates have. I think that it is dangerous until proven. Please do not fall for opinions that sound good, but are out of the mainstream of research and practice. You will not hear such opinions going unchallenged here.

Posts.Content: Sudds, Sorry that you have be here, but you will receive great advice from many caring and sincere members. I have to ask if, in making your decision for surgery, that you spoke with anyone other than a surgeon? Did you seek an opinion from a radiologist? I have seen several instances (on other forums) of men cancelling their surgery appointments and going with other treatments after being asked if they had looked into "this" treatment or "that" research. This is important, because you need to be 100 percent certain that you have fully evaluated all the several options for prostate cancer treatment. And, if you now feel that you have done that, then the best of luck to you.

Posts.Title: New to site and PC

Posts.Content: " Originally Posted by ASAdvocate You have already had the confirmatory biopsy, so I don't see a reason why another MRI would be needed anytime soon. A possible regimen for you would be six month psa/fpsa or PHI tests, annual DRE's, and MRI's or biopsies every 2-3 years, or as required by the other test results." "I'm unfamiliar with the terms "fpsa" and "PHI." Could you expand?" Yes, fpsa is an acronym for "free PSA", which is a percentage of types of antigens found in your blood. It is based on PSA, and is considered more accurate than PSA alone, for a PSA range between 4 and 10. PHI (prostate health index) is a blood test that has been in use for about five years now. It is based on PSA, and includes results for PSA, Free PSA, and a cancer biomarker. So, PHI gives you three scores, and is that considered more accurate than just having PSA and/or Free PSA results. It costs about $110, the last that I heard. That's good input on the Urolift device. So many men are suffering with BPH, so your success with that product should be helpful to others.

Posts.Title: Surprise

Posts.Content: Active surveillance is usually not assumed as a safe course after only one biopsy. The typical protocol, after the first biopsy, is to have an MRI, and then have a confirmatory fusion biopsy within a year. The second biopsy greatly reduces the chances of a significant cancer being missed by the first one. The risk is not from Gleason (3+3) lesions, as these have never been shown to metastasize. The issue is that nearby high grade lesions were missed. As Pratoman stated, its time to have the MRI and fusion biopsy now.

Posts.Title: Sustained relatively high PSA confirming next steps

Posts.Content: I'm going to offer my opinion here, which is simply observational, with no specific studies or data to cite. If only 5 to 10 percent of the men who had RP suffer from incontinence after 12 months, then all of them must be on internet PCa forums. Seriously! I have somehow managed/mismanaged to belong to EIGHT different prostate cancer forums (I do have a life, and travel constantly, but the internet is always available). There are so many, many posts from men complaining and seeking advice about post-RP incontinence, that I would believe a percentage above 60, if you told me that. One forum is subsidized by Dr. Samadi to support men having/had RP, and it seems that many of those men are back on the forum months, or a year, later complaining about incontinence. Yes, I know that unsatisfied customers of any product or service are the ones most likely to complain on Yelp or other feedback forums....But, there is a real disconnect between those low RP/incontinence numbers quoted by medical practices, and the posts I see on PCa forums from (some of) the men who were operated on.

Posts.Title: Surprise

Posts.Content: Welcome perp, although nobody wants to be here, you will receive great advice and support on this forum. With only a small amount of low intermediate grade cancer found, he doesn't have to rush into having treatment. He may want to get an appointment with Dr Laurence Klotz at Sunnybrook to see if he would qualify for their world-famous Active Surveillance program. I noticed your statement about radiation after surgery. There are now three recent studies of successful secondary radiation after primary radiation. All those studies used SBRT to target the area(s) of recurrence. So, the old wisdom of primary surgery offering a salvage advantage may no longer apply. There are many surgery patients and advocates here, and they will surely tell you that "experience is everything" when choosing a surgeon. You are smart to be cautious and evaluating possible doctors. Good luck to your dad.

My psa spikes were due (1) to an apparent infection, and (2-3) to post biopsy trauma, months after the biopsies. I am in the Active Surveillance study group at Johns Hopkins, so I am closely monitored. But, I no longer let myself be alarmed by any one psa test.

Posts.Title: How do you know when to advocate for another biopsy ...

Posts.Content: PSA results are notoriously unreliable. Mine have gone from 2.5 to over 10 within a few months, and then gone back again THREE TIMES in the past seven years. As the others have suggested, the 3 Tesla MRI is a reliable diagnostic tool to map suspicious areas, and can be superimposed as a biopsy template if a further look is deemed necessary. I have had the 3T MRI's both with and without the rectal coil...its a lot more comfortable without it.

Posts.Title: How do you know when to advocate for another biopsy ...

Posts.Content: Zen, Reading the recent posts on this thread, I now agree with Michael F that treatment is needed, and that your thought process should be on what form of treatment will both stop the cancer and provide the least lifelong side effects. There are prostate cancer forums that tend to favor surgery as the gold standard for fighting PCa; there are others that don't like surgery and favor radiation, especially SBRT/Cyberknife. There are others that promote newer, less invasive therapies, like FLA and TOOKAD, and offer a chaos of sincere and conflicting opinions. At this point, maybe your time is best spent sorting out all the varied experiences and opinions of the men that have "gone before" you. Not an easy task...but one you may be glad you attempted. You may want to attend a local prostate cancer support group. They are in all areas, and are wonderful places to frankly exchange experiences and knowledge. I didn't know if I would fit in, but everyone, from the G 3+3 to the G 5+5, is accepted with great interest and support. The US TOO groups organize many of these.

Posts.Title: Second Opinion Costs/Benefits

Posts.Content: As the others have said, you psa is well within normal limits. However, your last free psa reading was borderline, and that will merit future monitoring. I would suggest that your next check-up include a PHI test, rather than just psa. PHI includes psa, fpsa, another blood marker for PCa, and an algorithm that calculates your risk of having prostate cancer. It is more stable and reliable than psa alone. Until that next time, relax and heed the good advice given above.

Posts.Title: Interesting AS video

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic ASA, do we know if the RP vs RT percentages of AS men who go on to need/opt for treatment is also about 1:1? Also, do you think the 2018 Guidelines for AS we discussed in another thread will change the percentage of AS-eligible men compared to the previous criteria? Djin, I do not know the breakdown in treatment preferences for men who move from AS to treatment. I would suspect that it is possibly more towards non-surgical treatments since men on AS often search for other options and opinions, and not automatically follow the advice of their diagnosing urologist. The new 2018 Guidelines for Clinicians have widened the criteria for very-low-risk and low-risk men and made AS the default recommendation. I was very pleased to see that they jettisoned the "no more than two positive cores" rule, which was created when six core biopsies were standard. Also, no mention of bilateral involvement. The addition of PSA Density is fine with me, as that allows for normal aging and BPH to be factored into your risk. So, I do see the new criteria as making more men safely eligible for AS, and the percentage should continue to increase. Last year, the chief urologist at a large area hospital told my support group that he did not want to perform any more RP's on G(3+3) men, and that 50 percent of newly diagnosed men were choosing AS.
Posts.Signature: DOB: May 1944 In Active Surveillance program at Johns Hopkins Strict protocol of tests, including PHI, DRE, MRI, and biopsy. Six biopsies from 2009 to 2019. Numbers 1, 2, and 5 were negative. Numbers 3,4, and 6 were positive with 5% Gleason(3+3) found. Last one was Precision Point transperineal. PSA 4.4, fPSA 24, PHI 32 Hopefully, I can remain untreated. So far, so good.

Posts.Title: Recommendation for first class SBRT RO in San Antonio or close by...

Posts.Content: I will add the list of tests by suggesting the Prostate Health Index. It is a simple blood draw. It includes psa as one of its factors, so the usual warnings about no sex, bicycle riding, etc. beforehand will apply. Johns Hopkins has found PHI to provide better results the PCA3 urine test. As far as psa and bph, I have several friends who have had psa of 8 to 10 for many years, with multiple negative imaging and biopsy results. So, a psa of 8 can be benign, at least for some men.
Posts.Title: Need advice regarding husband's situation

Posts.Content: There are several blood tests that can be used after a suspicious PSA to help determine if a biopsy is likely to find anything significant. These tests are 4K Score, Prostate Health Index (PHI), and SelectMDX. There may be others, as this is a fast-growing area of product development. My advice is to try one or more of these tests to get more accurate data about the need for a biopsy.

Posts.Title: New member, new worries.

Posts.Content: Lowlight. With a 16 core biopsy and a prostate MRI both being negative, you have some cause to relax, but not to stop being vigilant. I will assume that you have also had DRE's, and free PSA tests, right? Was your MRI with the trans-rectal coil, or a newer machine that can equal its results? If those tests all show negative at this time, you are probably like many of my friends dealing with BPH, and possible infections. High PSA's, up to 8 seem to be common with BPH. I had a PSA of 11 due to an infection following a biopsy. As others can tell you, drugs and surgery can help with BPH. Just keeping regular consultations about cancer is prudent, although your tests now, are, well, negative, and that's something to be relieved about.

Posts.Title: Need advice regarding husband's situation

Posts.Content: Welcome, DBosdad, Yes, your psa is elevated, but most such readings are more likely to be from benign causes than prostate cancer. PSA is an indicator of prostate activity, and is not diagnostic for cancer. You could have an inflammation, and those are difficult to treat as most do not respond to antibiotics. They just come and go with time. Instead of just another PSA test, I would suggest a PHI instead. That includes PSA, free PSA, and a prostate cancer biomarker. It is more accurate and less affected by inflammation than PSA alone.

Posts.Title: met with radiologist today

Posts.Content: Cane, The endo-rectal coil and the contrast dye apply to MRI imaging. They are not used in biopsies. The endo-rectal coil is usually not used in 3T MRI's as the additional power makes them less necessary. The contrast dye will allow for sharper imaging on either strength MRI. The MRI images can be used with special technology during a follow up biopsy to "fuse" the suspect areas of the MRI with the real-time image of the ultrasound, to precisely "target" where the needles should go. But, this is getting way ahead of where you are, which is probably not a cancer at all.

Posts.Content: As to your point about the percentages of men choosing which treatment, the SEER database of 400,000 men shows that the numbers of newly diagnosed now choose AS, RP, and RT in about equal numbers. There has been a major decrease in low risk men having surgery, and that has dropped the surgery percentage to where RT has been for a long time. AS continues to rise, despite not having perfect screening tools.

Posts.Title: Just to stir the pot: RP vs. EBRT +/- Brachy for men <60 yr with G 8-10

Posts.Content: Kentucky, You appear to be a "very low risk" patient. The trend recently is not to treat such cases, but rather enroll them in an Active Surveillance program. There is a lot of controversy about "overtreatment" of G3+3 cancer, where the treatment has serious side effects, yet the cancer may never become life-threatening. In certain areas, the rate of new low risk patients choosing AS has skyrocketed from almost none to over fifty percent in less than five years. In Sweden, over 90 percent of new low risk cases are on AS. Please do research on "active surveillance", and learn about your options. Here is a link to the program at Johns Hopkins and their experience since 1994: http://www.urology.jhu.edu/prostate/...rveillance.php

Posts.Title: Searching for the right treatment

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another Good for him. My G6 was a G7, and therein lies the rub. Another, I understand what your experience was, and that the current diagnostic tools for AS are not perfect. That is why it is incumbent on both the doctor and the patient to see that a G6 diagnosis is followed up by an MRI and targeted fusion biopsy, to minimize the chances of under-diagnosis. To fill out the lecture by that Chief Urologist, he did kept using the phrase "puny Gleason 6", so most likely he would not have thought that your findings of eight positive cores to be "puny". He probably would have been willing to discuss surgery with you.

Posts.Title: Large prostate means lower risk?

Posts.Content: I am not a supporter of alternative medicine unless it has an advantage. That is especially true in a disease like cancer. But, here is more fuel for the fire in the debate about alternative medicine and prostate cancer. A Yale study published by the NCI states that that was no increased mortality for prostate cancer when comparing usual treatments and alternative methods over a 5-1/2 year followup. Other cancers showed dramatically high adverse statistics, but not PCa. http://www.cnn.com/2017/08/17/health...udy/index.html IMHO, this may be due to the long period it takes for PCa to kill. Other studies have shown no difference between treatment and no treatment for the first 10 years. But, we may expect this study to heat up the discussion on allowing posts for those medicines.

Posts.Content: I have various cysts in my kidneys, which have turned out, after many years of observation, to be anomalies, rather than anything threatening. I recall years ago, when they were first noticed on an ultrasound, that the head radiologist was called in, glanced at the screen, and declared them cysts. I asked how she could tell, and she said that they were dark, whereas a cancer tumor would show up as light colored. For what that's worth....

Take things a step at a time.

Posts.Title: Impact of sexual activity on PSA

Posts.Content: As the others have said, your husband needs further diagnostic testing to determine the extent of the cancer, and then some intervention, either surgery or radiation. Diet, supplements, and other regimens may, or may not, have some value to an older patient like myself trying to keep a lower grade cancer from progressing, but your husband's tests so far would indicate that such efforts are not going to make a difference. The odds are on his side, he will have the support of many experienced, and now healthy, fellow patients during his journey. Please check in frequently as he goes through the next months of tests and consultations.

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed.....

Posts.Content: Moss, I will second Pratoman's advice to get more data, especially the pathology report, and also hear a second (or third) opinion. From what you have written, it sounds like a low-intermediate risk case, and nothing has to be decided this month...or next. Catch your breath. All of us are different about telling spouses/family. I would not tell anyone who did not already know until you have the information noted above. If your spouse knows, then you have to fully educate her to understand what the facts are, which are for a complete, if sometimes rocky, recovery after treatment.
Posts.Signature: DOB: May 1944 In Active Surveillance program at Johns Hopkins Strict protocol of tests, including PHI, DRE, MRI, and biopsy. Six biopsies from 2009 to 2019. Numbers 1, 2, and 5 were negative. Numbers 3,4, and 6 were positive with 5% Gleason(3+3) found. Last one was Precision Point transperineal. PSA 4.4, fPSA 24, PHI 32 Hopefully, I can remain untreated. So far, so good.
Posts.Title: Newbie with first results looking for comments

Posts.Content: As the others have said, your husband needs further diagnostic testing to determine the extent of the cancer, and then some intervention, either surgery or radiation. Diet, supplements, and other regimens may, or may not, have some value to an older patient like myself trying to keep a lower grade cancer from progressing, but your husband's tests so far would indicate that such efforts are not going to make a difference. The odds are on his side, he will have the support of many experienced, and now healthy, fellow patients during his journey. Please check in frequently as he goes through the next months of tests and consultations.

Posts.Content: You have received good advice already, and I just want to ask some questions. What is your psa history? What predictive tests have you had? This includes pre-biopsy like PHI, 4K, PCA3, ExoDx, and SelectMDX. Also biopsy assays like Prolaris, OncotypeDX, or Decipher? You mentioned already having several biopsies. I can appreciate your wanting to avoid more. But, a psa rising into double digits must be explained. If you are in an AS program, then I have repeat what Another asked what does your doctor say?

Posts.Title: Question about active surveillance protocol

Posts.Content: The 1.5 will certainly show any abnormal areas, and, since you have a general issue, that should be fine. If they use an endo-rectal coil, and also use a contrast dye, that will further sharpen the images. The 3T is being used more as a finely detailed diagnostic tool, to guide biopsies, focal ablation, radiation, and also estimate the cancer aggressiveness and extent. I think that your doctor wants an overall picture of what is going on, and the 1.5T should provide that answer, or, hopefully, find nothing.

Posts.Title: 3T vs 1.5T MRI

Posts.Content: Size is important, as psa density is now a significant factor in how Johns Hopkins monitors its active surveillance patients. I don't recall it being mentioned in past visits, but it was printed out and mentioned to me three times on my recent check-up. My psa density is 0.09, which my specialist is happy with.

Posts.Title: Man cured of prostate cancer after being given testosterone to shock tumors

Posts.Content: Stage 1 prostate cancer should usually not require radical treatment. But, your testing should tell you if there is additional cancer not found previously. Are you eligible for radiation? The cure rates are at least equal to surgery. There are many chemicals, plants, and potions being touted as cancer cures. Some people claim they have helped them, but, if that were universally true, oncology would cease to be needed, and I doubt that is going to happen.

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed.....

Posts.Content: Copies of the biopsy pathology reports belong to you. If your doctor's office uses an online patient portal like MyChart, you can easy see/print all your test results by logging in. Ask for copies, by email, fax, or paper; or access to a portal. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Negative, but

Posts.Content: Two facts to keep in mind: (1) about 2/3 pf initial biopsies are negative. (2) The American Cancer Society states that 98 percent of the men diagnosed with prostate cancer today, will not die from prostate cancer during the next ten years. Relax. Get some sleep.

Take things a step at a time.

Posts.Title: Question about active surveillance protocol

Posts.Content: Welcome JohnSu, Wow! that is quite a puzzling summary. By all your psa-based tests, it would appear that you have prostate cancer. The 39 psa, 4.3 fpsa, and 97 PHI (mine is 29, and I have cancer) would almost certainly indicate a serious level of PCa. But, as you know, blood tests don't diagnose PCa, and you have had two 3T MRIs and two saturation biopsies, which are essentially negative. With those drastically conflicting results, I wouldn't know if I should cry or sing. Hopefully, the next responders may offer some better insight. Also, keep trying as many forums as you can find, as this puzzle may need a lot of exposure to find the guidance that you need. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: nmguy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider Do you know if this patient was very elderly, and/or had major co-morbidities which would make treatment an even less desirable choice? Is this for "any" G6 patient, or just this individual and others like him. G6 is the majority of prostate cancer out there, this would be big economic news if G6 patients could no longer get surgery and radiation. He's 53, and no mention of other issues. His RO at MSKCC said that this notice appears to be generic, rather then specific to him. Where this is really wrong is that they are denying him coverage for an MRI and a genomics test which are part of MSKCC's AS protocol to be more certain that he is properly placed. He wants to be in AS, but this interferes with their testing. I could imagine that this would play havoc with the thinking of those men who can't deal with AS and want the cancer gone. Their choices are being restricted.

Posts.Content: Nero, I agree with the others. If you have a prostate anomaly, then you need to biopsy it and know what, if anything of consequence, that you are dealing with. An MRI beforehand would help in "seeing" suspicious areas, but they are often not done for initial biopsy. Good luck, and don't worry unless and until an expert advises you that there is something to worry about.

Posts.Title: nmguy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ocman Thanks for replying! Second Bio in two weeks ! Do you know about proton therapy as apposed to radiation ?? What I know is that the available studies seem to show that proton beam therapy does not have significantly better outcomes when compared to other radiation treatments like IMRT, SBRT, LDR-BT and HDR-BT. Also, it is much more costly, and there are frequent comments (elsewhere on the internet) from patients saying that their insurance will not pay for it. PBT sounds great in theory, but, well, it's time has not come yet.

Posts.Content: A friend of mine had proton beam therapy for his prostate cancer about four years ago. I think that he was sixty at the time with a Gleason 3+4. He went to Florida and had about 45 sessions. When I asked him recently about his feelings about his choice of treatment, he responded that proton therapy was superior to surgery. I have no further detail, except that he was satisfied, and his PSA was undetectable.

Posts.Title: Questions regarding Proton Therapy for Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: This is from a thread elsewhere on the Internet: "was just informed by my AS coordinator at MSKCC that my insurance carrier will NOT approve ANY treatment for a G6 PCa patient!" This man was diagnosed with Gleason (3+3) in 1 of 12 cores, with 35 percent involvement. His insurance carrier is the largest in NY state. His RO requested a pelvic MRI, which was rejected, and also rejected on appeal. Now, this notification has arrived. This case could have major implications for future choices for very-low-risk men. They could (as far as I know) choose to treat (or not). This is bound to be controversial.

Posts.Title: Insurer Refuses to Pay for G(3+3) Treatments

Posts.Content: While this is likely "above my pay grade", it sounds like they are treating you as Stage 4. That's fine if that is what the experts have determined is best for you. The really significant research, innovation, and progress is in this stage. This where all the "out of the box" ideas and new advancements are coming. By skipping over surgery and radiation, you have avoided the significant side effects of both. The game plan now, IMHO, is to gain time and try new cures. Learn about and try to enroll in a clinical trial. There are many of them for your status. Learn and live!

Posts.Title: Fifty, Asymmetric prostate and a 1.1 PSA

Posts.Content: If he has prostate cancer, he may not need any treatment. The default recommended treatment by the major medical associations for low grade prostate cancer is active surveillance. Actually, depending on age or co-morbidities, a more relaxed form of observation known as watchful waiting may be appropriate. So, try not to get ahead of yourself on treatment decisions until more tests confirm cancer, and at what grade and stage. As Southsider mentioned, fluctuations are more indicative of prostatitis than prostate cancer.

Posts.Title: Fluctuating PSA

Posts.Content: An MRI followed by a fusion biopsy that targets any suspicious lesions are the usual next steps. But, don't get too far ahead of yourself, as PSA is not indicative of prostate cancer, just the need to do more testing. Yesterday, I read a post on another forum where a man had a first PSA of 32. A follow up test was 3. Yes, that can happen. So, have the recommended tests, and take one step at a time.

Posts.Content: ljames, TOOKAD is not quite the same as this nanoparticle therapy. I think that TOOKAD will treat all the cancers within the prostate, while this trial only wants men with two or less lesions. They do both release poisonous agents which bind to prostate cancer cells, and then are activated by laser or other specialized light sources. Regarding Dr. Sperling and the other FLA practitioners, there is another forum that has hundreds (probably thousands) of posts over the five years. I find them highly biased in favor of a handful of doctors, but that sounds like the information that you are looking for. I am not allowed to cite their website in a post (as it is a competitive PCa forum), so check your private messages, and I will provide that link there.

Posts.Title: Elevated PSA, Biopsy with HGPIN

Posts.Content: This is yet another technology being tested to see if it works. Intended for focal destruction of one or two lesions in low and intermediate risk men. It sounds similar to TOOKAD, but instead of a fluid chemical, it uses gold nanoparticles to bind to the cancer cells. Like TOOKAD, an external light source then activates those agents to destroy the cancer. More outside-the-box thinking. Let's hope that it has success. https://medicalxpress.com/news/2018-...Obdr_k5d7bjzcE

Posts.Title: New prostrate cancer

Posts.Content: With only one positive core out of 12, and that being a Gleason (3+3) at 5 percent, every medical association's guidelines would prescribe active surveillance for you. The psa/fpsa results would prompt me to ask "what is your PSAD(ensity)"? A large prostate due to bph could possibly explain those results. Also, recent statistics show that equal percentages of men are choosing radiation as are choosing surgery. You would do well to learn about the various types of radiation, such as SBRT and High Dose Brachytherapy, as part of your awareness of possible future options. Three biopsies in three years? Not good, as that happened to me and caused long-lasting damage. If they want yet another biopsy, then insist on an MRI first, and then a fusion biopsy, but, only if the MRI shows PIRADS 4 or 5 lesions.

Posts.Title: nmguy

Posts.Content: Littleman, He appears to have low intermediate grade prostate cancer, and would be a candidate for active surveillance in all but the strictest programs. His age would also factor into a decision on treatment (AS is considered a treatment). He can request a genomics test, such as OncotypeDX, Decipher, or SelectMDX on his biopsy slides, and that would provide additional predictive data as to whether there is more serious cancer that was missed by the biopsy. Certainly, an MRI followed by a confirmatory fusion biopsy within the next year would be a necessary step for an AS program. In any event, it appears that he is not under any time pressure to make decisions, so ask and consult all you can.

Posts.Title: High PI-RADS, negative biopsy, what next?

Posts.Content: Good discussion, gentlemen. The term "Active Surveillance", as coined by Klotz and popularized in the USA by Carter, is not intended to apply to post-treatment cases. But, your idea and intent is very valid, and "AWW", or whatever you decide to call it, can define a very pro-active monitoring for recurrence. The suggestion of augmenting uPSA testing with PET scans and MRI's, certainly would constitute a more intensive level of "watching". Many men want as much early warning of recurrence as possible, and all want the peace of mind of stable, negative tests. Call this scheduling what you want, that is secondary to its value.

Posts.Title: Hi, I'm a new member

Posts.Content: An MRI followed by a fusion biopsy that targets any suspicious lesions are the usual next steps. But, don't get too far ahead of yourself, as PSA is not indicative of prostate cancer, just the need to do more testing. Yesterday, I read a post on another forum where a man had a first PSA of 32. A follow up test was 3. Yes, that can happen. So, have the recommended tests, and take one step at a time.

Posts.Title: High PI-RADS, negative biopsy, what next?

Posts.Content: Good discussion, gentlemen. The term "Active Surveillance", as coined by Klotz and popularized in the USA by Carter, is not intended to apply to post-treatment cases. But, your idea and intent is very valid, and "AWW", or whatever you decide to call it, can define a very pro-active monitoring for recurrence. The suggestion of augmenting uPSA testing with PET scans and MRI's, certainly would constitute a more intensive level of "watching". Many men want as much early warning of recurrence as possible, and all want the peace of mind of stable, negative tests. Call this scheduling what you want, that is secondary to its value.

Posts.Title: Recurrent Prostate Cancer and Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: This question is often asked, but there is no central database of that data. Some doctors and hospitals will release data for studies, but that is voluntary on their parts. Some doctors who promote themselves, like Dr. Samadi in NYC, have such numbers available, but they are themselves the source. Researching forums and other prostate cancer websites will turn up many posts from men who were satisfied with their treatments and recommend those providers.

Posts.Title: Scorecards for ND & Hospitals-?

Posts.Content: Matt, you certainly have been doing your homework, and I suspect that several members will be needed to try to address all the (very relevant) questions that you have posted. I would agree with you that AS is not likely to a good a course of action for you. At age 50, with a positive DRE, treatment would seem advisable. I'm not sure how serious a GPS of 37 is, but I can tell you that mine is 2. You may also seek out some additional forums. I participate in three, and find that one leans towards surgery, another towards radiation, and a third towards focal therapies like FLA and HIFU. When I was on another forum, I mentioned comments identical to yours regarding the side effects of surgery and radiation. I was strongly reprimanded by the moderator, who insisted that such data on radiation side effects was very old, and that radiation had far fewer and less serious SE's than surgery. So, you need to also hear those experiences and viewpoints as you make your decisions. There are also new clinical trials using Prostvac and other non-invasive vaccine treatments. The future may belong to vaccine and genomic therapies, which offer the hope of no side effects. You can do some research on those. Much to learn, but you are certainly asking good questions.

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance vs Beams vs Seeds vs Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Terri, I would caution about making any decision as soon as you get the biopsy pathology report. If he has PCa, and it is of a stage that requires treatment...well, there are several types of treatments available, and the urologist is probably only really knowledgable about surgery. Consulting with a radiation oncologist would provide a second opinion. There is a new sticky at the top of the main page for "Books on Prostate Cancer". Reading some of them will provide some perspective beyond Dr. Walsh's book, which has been criticized as out-of-date and biased towards surgery. In any event, you will soon have facts in front of you, and then you can begin to determine what to do next. Good luck.

Posts.Title: PSA Testing Probelms

Posts.Content: If I'm reading your number notations correctly, you have a psa of 1.16 ; a free psa of 0.16 ; and a percent free ratio of 13.7. While the 13.7 might be suspicious, the free psa test is not valid for a psa below 4, so you can't dwell on that. In summary, you have a good psa (even for your age), and imaging negative for lesions. If you have not discussed the test with your doctor, do so and consider his/her advice. Otherwise, don't rush ahead and worry yourself needlessly.

Posts.Title: First Post Bummed newbie

Posts.Content: Maverick, That sounds pretty typical of how relatives get the news. Some people are very private, but I would expect that close family are told as yours was. While I post many threads on Facebook, I and almost all of my friends try to avoid telling our personal medical challenges on there. Seems everybody my age has some issues, and airing them would change the generally upbeat nature of our shared exchanges. BTW, if you were older, I would ask why you are not doing Active Surveillance because of the low amount of G6 cancer found. You could, if you chose to, although I believe that the great majority of men your age decide to get intervention now. Still, there is no hurry to make your choice,

Posts.Title: Who do you tell? and why tell them?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider You are looking for a goose egg here, anything greater is presumed to be cancer as you longer have a prostate. While this question is outside of my personal experience, what I have read many times is that you can expect a non-zero result, and still be cancer-free. This is especially true for the ultra sensitive psa tests. You will have a number, but if it is < .02, then you are fine. Some remaining benign prostate tissue can produce psa, and women even produce small amounts of psa from several glands. So, "near zero" is a more realistic expectation.

Posts.Content: Denis, I'm sorry to hear that your Decipher test indicates the need for treatment. From what I've read of the testing that JH did with that product, it's predictive percentage is impressive. Your wonderful natural gifts of intellectual curiosity and probing may not have been a good fit for AS in any event, IMHO. Dr. Leapman's slide presentation was most impressive. You are very fortunate in having him as your specialist. Now, I have to ask, will you go with his recommendation, or will you seek out prominent practitioners of other therapies, such as Alan Katz with SBRT, or Josh Yamada at MSKCC with HD Monotherapy, or Zelefsky at MSKCC, who has been reporting great results with radiation protocols BEYOND SBRT? In any event, my best wishes to you. You deserve the best outcome because you have done an amazing amount of research, which has benefited...everybody!

Posts.Title: Probable Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Bernard, As the others have noted, you have time to research, ask, consult, and finally be content with whatever course you choose. I recently had an online exchange with a man who was 51, and had, as I recall, three positive cores each with a higher percentage of G3+3 cancer. He went to see the top doctor at a leading prostate cancer center. This doctor had founded what is probably the strictest and best known active surveillance program in the nation. After a discussion with the patient and his wife, this well known specialist signed him up for the AS program. That certainly surprised me! But, the reasoning is now clear to me. (1) his risk of mortality will not be increased if he is monitored closely. Studies have proved that. (2) This doctor is very aware of the ongoing research...maybe there will be a noninvasive cure in a few years. (3) the patient was simply not mentally ready to have surgery. So, the rules can be flexed, probably without risk. The lesson here is not to feel rushed, and the time that you can safely delay radical treatment both increases your "normal" years, and allows for new treatments to be developed. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: New Diagnosis

Posts.Content: FishSpear, based on your comments, you need to learn more about active surveillance. Firstly, multiple studies have shown that there is NO increased mortality for those men who chose AS and later needed treatment, versus those men who chose immediate treatment. Another issue is that while surgery is indeed difficult after primary radiation, there several other effective salvage treatments available, I have been on AS for ten years, and am glad for those years of living normally. If you choose treatment, SBRT/Cyberknife has a non-recurrence rate of about 97 percent for your pathology. That is far above surgery or other treatments, An excellent new book which presents the views of thirty prostate cancer experts, is The Key to Prostate Csncer, by Mark Scholz. Posts.Content: FishSpear, based on your comments, you need to learn more about active surveillance. Firstly, multiple studies have shown that there is NO increased mortality for those men who chose AS and later needed treatment, versus those men who chose immediate treatment. Another issue is that while surgery is indeed difficult after primary radiation, there several other effective salvage treatments available, I have been on AS for ten years, and am glad for those years of living normally. If you choose treatment, SBRT/Cyberknife has a non-recurrence rate of about 97 percent for your pathology. Posts.Title: Hi, I'm a new member

Posts.Content: Great result, OTS, way to go! Regarding the timing of lab results, I always sign up for each provider's online portal, which is usually MyChart, or a close competitor. Often, I am woken at 6:00am the next morning notifying me that my results are online. That is typical of standard blood chemistries and also PSA. Free PSA and PHI may take an additional day. MRI and biopsy results may take 3 days, depending on the work week. Normally, I know the results before hearing comments by text from the provider. Things have vastly improved since the old days. There is no excuse for waiting a week or more for feedback, unless the test is being sent out to a certain specialist for their opinion, and you know that at the time of the test. Let's hope for your continued path to being cancer-free

Posts.Title: ASTRO, ASCO, and AUA Guideline for Hypofractionated RT for Localized PCa

Posts.Content: This is a topic of concern for me, as I appear to be one of the exceptions to the rule for G4 imaging. My dominant lesion is G4, but it has been biopsied 5 times, the last three using fusion 3T targeting, with little or no cancer found. Those biopsies, plus my stable almost normal psa/fpsa, favorable OncotypeDX test, negative DRE, and age, have led my uro-oncologists at Johns Hopkins to recommend that I remain in AS, if I wanted to. I have read that I am in a group of about 10 percent of the G4 patients who do not appear to have a threatening case. Not a reassuring percentage, but I trust my physicians. So far, so good.

Posts.Title: Seeking New York City general practitioner with experience with digital rectal exams

Posts.Content: Had a nice Christmas present today. The results of a 3T mp-MRI that was done at Johns Hopkins last week. I was in the tube for an hour as they did a 3D reconstruction study. The previous three MRI's had shown three lesions. The index one was first scored as a PIRADS 4 and the others as PIRADS 3. Then, later MRI's downgraded the 4 to a 3. This new result downgraded the original 4 to a 2 , and did not see the other two lesions. So, over the past ten years, my prostate cancer appears to have shrunk and regressed. This is not what I expected when I started out on this journey, but I'll gladly take it. Have to discuss having future biopsies with Dr. Carter. He insists on his protocol scheduled biopsies, and believes I need (a sixth) one for that reason. But I'm not sure that I see any benefit in having anymore, at least until other testing demonstrates a concern.

Posts.Title: New MRI Results - MY PCa is Regressing

Posts.Content: Steve, I agree with Another that you are not safe. BUT, How I will respond to you depends on what prostate cancer forum we are on. The dominant voices here tend to favor a strict "old school" definition of AS guidelines, which, among other things specify two or less positive cores of G3+3. This is based on the original Johns Hopkins AS criteria, and also the current NCCN risk classification of "very low risk". So, If I use those guidelines, and tell you that you need to have treatment, most members here would approve. But, if I wrote that on another popular PCa forum, I would be chewed up by the dominant posters there and chastised that my thinking was way out of date, and that MSKCC, Cleveland Clinic and other major institutions now had less stringent AS criteria, and that the NCCN now was recommending AS for "low risk" patients, which would include your present findings. Also, some AS programs are now allowing men with intermediate risks to enroll, on the patients request. I even know of a case where the founder of JH's program allowed such a patient to sign up. That was compassionate, but it shows that the strict AS guidelines are no longer enforced. So, what you will hear for advice depends on what forum you are in. That's just reality. If I were you, I would have an OncotypeDX or Prolaris test done on your recent biopsy cores. See what happens with those findings. Anything is possible with Gleason 6. In my case, I had three positive cores on one fusion biopsy and none on the next one. No, I did not do anything different. It's often the nature of those small lesions. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance Cancer Upgrade Question

Posts.Content: Ron, Your plan is a good one. I have seen some imaging centers boasting 98 percent accuracy in finding significant lesions, so having a prostate scan with 3T mp-MRi using PIRADS 2 software is about as definite as current technology can be. Also, from what I've read, most cases of prostatitis are not caused by bacteria, so antibiotics such as Levaquin and Cipro will not have any effect. The inflammations tend to come and go on their own. Still, trying Cipro is probably worthwhile. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Second Biopsy After ASAP on First

Posts.Content: Matt, you certainly have been doing your homework, and I suspect that several members will be needed to try to address all the (very relevant) questions that you have posted. I would agree with you that AS is not likely to a good a course of action for you. At age 50, with a positive DRE, treatment would seem advisable. I'm not sure how serious a GPS of 37 is, but I can tell you that mine is 2. You may also seek out some additional forums. I participate in three, and find that one leans towards surgery, another towards radiation, and a third towards focal therapies like FLA and HIFU. When I was on another forum, I mentioned comments identical to yours regarding the side effects of surgery and radiation. I was strongly reprimanded by the moderator, who insisted that such data on radiation side effects was very old, and that radiation had far fewer and less serious SE's than surgery. So, you need to also hear those experiences and viewpoints as you make your decisions. There are also new clinical trials using Prostvac and other non-invasive vaccine treatments. The future may belong to vaccine and genomic therapies, which offer the hope of no side effects. You can do some research on those. Much to learn, but you are certainly asking good questions.

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance vs Beams vs Seeds vs Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: I just read this change on the JH Brady website. My urologist works with Dr. Johnathan Epstein, who formulated the 1994 criteria, and had told me that they were being revised. The changes have eliminated the use of percentage of a core's involvement, and increased the value of unilateral/bilateral involvement. I was verbally told that the number of cores involved was also being de-emphasized, but that was not changed in this notice. "In a study published in 2014 the original criteria have been modified with the presence of a unilateral cancer (cancer on only one side of the prostate either right or left) replacing the percentage of the tissue core involved with cancer. The current criteria that are referred to as very low risk include a PSA density below 0.15, Gleason score 6 on prostate biopsy, no more than 2 cores of tissue with cancer that is located on one side of the prostate on biopsy. Men who meet these criteria are considered at very low risk of harboring aggressive prostate cancer and could be considered the most ideal candidates -but not the only candidates -for active surveillance."

Posts.Title: Second Biopsy After ASAP on First

Posts.Content: Welcome Chuck, and sorry that you have to join us here. This is a great forum for balanced advice from guys who had been down every path. The recommendations from your doctors reflect the recent guidelines published by the American Urological Association and the three other organizations that represent the American medical establishment regarding prostate cancer. They endorse active surveillance as the default treatment for your pathology. The MRI, and confirmatory fusion biopsy are essential requirements for determining that you are correctly placed in AS. There are several optional genomics tests that could be run on your biopsy slides. Among those are OncotypeDX, Prolaris, SelectMDX, and Decipher. They can cost up to several thousand dollars, but my knowledge is out of date, and you may need to contact the various companies and practices to shop prices. There are also studies comparing them that may be found online. Stay calm and focused. You need to be informed, and follow your testing protocol, even with low risk prostate cancer. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Systemic Therapies & Combinations with Local Treatment for High-Risk Localized PCa

Posts.Content: I read a commentary on the FDA approval. That writer stated that the two manufacturers had been trying to get approval for eleven years, but could not satisfy the volume of patient data that the FDA wanted to see. So, a few months ago, one of the companies submitted a different application asking that their machine be certified for removing prostate tissue. It was. So, that means that the machine was approved as a type of surgical knife, but did not address its effectiveness for cancer. Now, of course, because the process is "approved" for removing all prostatic tissue, that includes cancer. So, yes, there is more legitimacy in using the device and process, but the patient has no more assurance of long term outcome than before.

Posts.Content: Mitchden, I often read the meme that 30 percent of prostate cancers get upgraded post RP, but, IMHO, I think that argument is over-used to persuade newly diagnosed men to have RP. The reality, according to Dr. Epstein, is that 20 percent get upgraded, AND 16 percent get downgraded. Funny, but I almost never hear about the biopsy-graded cancers that are downgraded or not found after RP. http://pcri.org/insights-blog/2016/3...ng-pathologist

Posts.Title: Pathology Second Opinions

Posts.Content: It needs to be understood that the men assigned to surveillance in the ProtecT study were not selected by the rigorous criteria that a man entering a modern AS program would have to pass. That was a random "next in line, step to your left" assignment, using little selection besides psa. No imaging was used. Also, robotic surgery, IMRT, brachytherapy, and SBRT were not used. Those are the cornerstones of today's treatment. The study has some value, but the above caveats, and some others, must be taken into consideration.

Posts.Title: my takeaways from prostate conference

Posts.Content: Brave, Some studies have shown a 30 percent highly likelihood for men with prostatitus to get PCa. However, the latest advice from the American Cancer Society suggests that the evidence is not strong. I have read that antibiotics only work on a small percentage of prostatitus cases. Most cases of prostate inflammation are non-bacterial, and come and go away on their own. If his basic issue is a greatly swollen prostate, there are two non-radical interventions to shrink/alleviate that condition. These are implantation of the Uro-lift device, and also Prostate Artery Embolization (PAE). Just some suggestions.

Posts.Title: RP done, post op PSA concern - urgent advise needed

Posts.Content: gjw, You need to educate yourself and be fully informed of all the options available to you. Surgery is one, radiation is another, various focal interventions are gaining in use, and Active Surveillance (in a formal program) is certainly reasonable with your known pathology at this time. There are studies showing that about 66 percent of those enrolled in Johns Hopkins AS program since 1994 have never had treatment. So, the G3+3 cancers may never become more dangerous. However, at age 55, you are younger than most of those men, and need to be aware that their outcomes may or may not apply to you. Certainly, if you are going to not seek treatment at this time, then you need to be under a structured AS program with all the testing and protocols that it requires. BTW, I am one of those hoping to die with PCa, and not from it, but not everyone has the same mindset, and that is understandable.

Posts.Title: Have PC

Posts.Content: He may do want to attend some local prostate cancer support groups. These usually meet once every month under the patronage of a hospital or a national support group. Men are there to share their experiences, and many of them would not do their method of treatment again, if they could turn back time. Much to learn if you find a good group. About a year ago, I attended such a meeting where three MD's did a presentation. A urologist, who did surgery several times every week, a radiation oncologist, and a medical oncologist, who specialized in chemotherapy. The urologist was interesting, in that he said that he did not want to operate on any more Gleason 3+3 cases, as that was overtreatment. The chemo guy was a lab type who knew his stuff, but wasn't good at translating his points in patient terms. The radiation guy had the greatest impact, as he presented comparative results for surgery, EBRT, IMRT, and seeds at their hospitals. The results were strongly favorable to seeds + IMRT. They had stats for several hundreds of patients and the "cure" rates and side effects for that combination of radiation methods had VERY impressive results. The two other specialists agreed, and were happy to share the good results as a team. You will hear that there WERE issues with radiation causing secondary cancers, but that data was from 30 years ago, and should not be applicable to today's technology. Also, there are several treatments like SBRT, HIFU, and FLA available if there is a recurrence after primary radiation treatment. If he is going to prefer radiation, then I would suggest that he research SBRT/Cyberknife, which is a type of radiation treatment that is having great recent results. So much to learn, so much at stake ... he is doing the right thing by taking some time to carefully and thoughtfully examine what choices he has. Keep asking, and the members here will try to answer and assist as best we can.

Posts.Title: surgery vs. radiation for younger patients

Posts.Content: OTS, Part of the problem is that your urologist defined the RT process for you. There are five main types of RT, and he described one with the most sessions, creating the commuting challenge. SBRT is done in five sessions. HDR-BT is done in two. And, LDR-BT is over in one day. IMRT and also proton require about 40 sessions, but they are not your only RT options. As always, good luck with your search for your cure.

Posts.Title: my takeaways from prostate conference

Posts.Content: Bernard, As the others have noted, you have time to research, ask, consult, and finally be content with whatever course you choose. I recently had an online exchange with a man who was 51, and had, as I recall, three positive cores each with a higher percentage of G3+3 cancer. He went to see the top doctor at a leading prostate cancer center. This doctor had founded what is probably the strictest and best known active surveillance program in the nation. After a discussion with the patient and his wife, this well known specialist signed him up for the AS program. That certainly surprised me! But, the reasoning is now clear to me. (1) his risk of mortality will not be increased if he is monitored closely. Studies have proved that. (2) This doctor is very aware of the ongoing research...maybe there will be a noninvasive cure in a few years. (3) the patient was simply not mentally ready to have surgery. So, the rules can be flexed, probably without risk. The lesson here is not to feel rushed, and the time that you can safely delay radical treatment both increases your "normal" years, and allows for new treatments to be developed. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: RP done, post op PSA concern - urgent advise needed

Posts.Content: The no more than two positive cores of Gleason 6 to be considered for a very low-risk AS program dates from the 1990s when a six-core biopsy was standard. Now, with 12 cores for a standard biopsy and some extra for a targeted one, the rules have changed at many institutions. That new criteria is no more than 34% of cores taken can be positive. Basically, the same standard, just being updated for todays biopsy practices. So, you may indeed be considered eligible for AS. As others have said, get another opinion, both on reading your biopsy slides, and with a different urologist. Good luck.
