Posts.Content: Karen, In regards to the side effects of RT, make sure that the results you are looking at are recent. There have been great advances in RT precision within the past ten years, resulting in higher efficacy and less unintended toxicity. Posts.Title: HIFU Treatment Receives FDA Approval

Posts.Content: Jim, The whole promise of HIFU, as I understand it, is the avoidance of any side effects when treating localized PCa. Also, its use does not preclude any subsequent therapy, and it can be used repeatedly, if necessary. As far as multiple cancer sites, some of the comments that I have read from HIFU enthusiasts is that secondary lesions are usually G6, and don't pose a danger if left alone or treated later. I am not knowledgeable enough to recommend or not recommend HIFU...just repeating what I have read about it.

Posts.Content: KJ, There is a new study out regarding the association of heredity and the aggressiveness of prostate cancer. While your risk of getting PCa is twice that of someone else, any cancer that you get would not necessarily be aggressive. "Researchers found no relationship between family history and several prostate cancer biomarkers associated with tumor aggressiveness, for example. This suggested that family history does not increase the risk of prostate cancer aggressiveness." https://prostatecancernewstoday.com/...ggressiveness/

Posts.Title: Thoughts on high and bouncing PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic ASA, it's hard to imagine a better MRI and I understand your reluctance to biopsy again. Having had no complications from my biopsies, I never balked when a uro wanted yet another because of a jump in my PSA (the question always being was the rise due solely to my BPH?). But you are justifiably wary with your different biopsy track record. If a 6th biopsy found one 3+4 core with a small percentage of 4, would you treat? 4+3 ? Your genomics test was pretty good, but does leave the door open. I know you'll weigh everything carefully, including your doc's opinion, and make an informed decision. As was discussed, if you go ahead, I would ask about needle washing between cores, as well as colon prep and antibiotic choice (I wonder if the choice is also influenced by geographic location as well as an institute's experience and patient's history). I know little about transperineal biopsy other than I read it has a near zero sepsis rate. My uro mentioned it when we chatted about post-biopsy infection and it seems to be becoming more popular. Best Wishes to you and all Forum Brothers for a Happy and Healthy New Year! Djin Hi Djin, A few years ago, I set a threshold for treatment at "two cores with more than ten percent of Gleason 4". That is certain. One core with ten percent or less? Probably not, especially as I'm looking at age 75 around the corner. While I am very active and agile, the mortality tables and seeing what's happening with people not much older than I would persuade me to take the risk of continuing monitoring. Before the MRI report was posted on MyChart, I went through the normal "what if?" anxieties and watched some videos on SBRT, which would be my favored choice of a treatment. Two take-aways were (1) that it was not totally side effect free, and (2) that the specialists setting up the machine better be in top form all the time, as they are wielding a lot of radiation with very close margins. So, I would not jump to treatment without a significant risk of not treating. Another patient of Dr. Carter told me that he recently had a biopsy using a Precision Point transperineal device operated by another doctor at Hopkins. I will ask about that, as well as your research on the needle cleaning. But, enough of that thought process. Today is a day for family, and all of mine will be together at my son's house. My best wishes to you, and the others who have commented. Have a loving Christmas, and a healthy and happy new year.

Posts.Title: New MRI Results - MY PCa is Regressing

Posts.Content: Fairwind has summed it up well. The 30 percent upgrade number is likely from the selection of AS after just one TRUS biopsy. After that initial positive biopsy, additional MRI's, biopsies, genomics tests, specific blood and urine tests, etc., will further filter those men to see who are correctly placed on AS. The probability is that any upgrade is not due to your G6 itself morphing, but the discovery of previously undetected G7 or higher cells. Each new test drives down those odds. At my age and testing history, I MAY (pray) be able to avoid more biopsies IF all other tests stay relative stable.

Posts.Title: Terrified That I Have Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Kevin, you have met with two urologists, and are really considering surgery. That is like saying that you went to two Chevrolet dealers, and are really considering buying a Chevy. The cure rates are the same for both surgery and radiation, but the side effects are not the same. You owe it to yourself to also consult with a radiation oncologist. Do not rely on urologists having either recent or accurate information regarding radiation. The impressive recent results have come from SBRT and HDR brachytherapy. Please do the research and consultations.

Posts.Title: New to forum, need help

Posts.Content: Welcome, Mainer, You have asked the most-debated question about prostate cancer - which treatment is better - especially between surgery and radiation? I see this question fought over, again and again, everyday, between advocates of surgery and those of radiation. The primary reason for this conflict is that there about a dozen types of treatments that can cure your husband's low-intermediate risk PCa. These treatments include 3 types of surgery (ORP, LRP, RALP), at least 5 types of radiation (IMRT. SBRT, LDR-BT, HDR-BT, and PBT), plus several other methods (Cyro, HIFU, FLA, VDT, etc.) ALL have records for curing prostate cancer. The differences are in recurrence-free and side effects severity statistics. Regrettably, one study of results may be different than another. This leads to confusion and "taking sides" This is a well-moderated forum with mature commentators. Some others I know are openly partisan, one side or the other. You need to try to sample the various opinions and the facts that different sources offer. Your doctor recommended 40+ days of radiation. That is IMRT, which is the most profitable treatment for the providers. I would suggest that you also consider SBRT (Cyberknife) which only requires 5 treatment days, and also High Dose Brachytherapy, which requires two days. Do not make the mistake of asking a surgeon about RT, and as they are often not informed (and, vice versa). Also, a radiologist usually only is well educated on the type of treatment they offer. You need to consult with each specialist, if that treatment interests you. The huge SEER database shows that newly-diagnosed men are choosing AS, surgery, and radiation in equal numbers. While I am an advocate for AS, the G7 would make me agree with the others that treatment may be needed. To directly address your question about why someone would choose radiation, here are two articles for for review: https://www.sciencedaily.com/release...0418145458.htm https://pcnrv.blogspot.com/2016/08/p...f-florida.html

The differences are in recurrence-free and side effects severity statistics. Regrettably, one study of results may be different than another. This leads to confusion and "taking sides" This is a well-moderated forum with mature commentators. Some others I know are openly partisan, one side or the other. You need to try to sample the various opinions and the facts that different sources offer. Your doctor recommended 40+ days of radiation. That is IMRT, which is the most profitable treatment for the providers. I would suggest that you also consider SBRT (Cyberknife) which only requires 5 treatment days, and also High Dose Brachytherapy, which requires two days. Do not make the mistake of asking a surgeon about RT, and as they are often not informed (and, vice versa). Also, a radiologist usually only is well educated on the type of treatment they offer. You need to consult with each specialist, if that treatment interests you. The huge SEER database shows that newly-diagnosed men are choosing AS, surgery, and radiation in equal numbers. While I am an advocate for AS, the G7 would make me agree with the others that treatment may be needed. To directly address your question about why someone would choose radiation, here are two articles for for review: https://www.sciencedaily.com/release...0418145458.htm https://pcnrv.blogspot.com/2016/08/p...f-florida.html

Posts.Title: Newbie Question

Posts.Content: ConfirmMDX assays prostate tissue from a negative biopsy to try to detect the presence of cancer elsewhere in the gland. It senses the amount of menthylation in the tissue sample. It has a 90 percent negative predictive value, and is used to help avoid more biopsies.
Posts.Title: What experience do you folks have with ConfirmMDx

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Not to put any words in ASA's mouth, but I think he may have meant that the side effects between surgery & radiation are not the same in terms of WHEN they happen. Otherwise, they are EXACTLY the same. The difference is the timing -- the SEs happen immediately after surgery whereas they happen a year or two after radiation treatments. Chuck Chuck, All due respect, I truly believe that neither the same side effects, nor the same rate of incidence, is found with surgery and radiation. Radiation patients, for example, do not complain about penis shortening or retrograde ejaculations. I am out the country and only have my iPhone and spotty connectivity this week. But, here is a study supporting my assertions. https://www.pcf.org/c/side-effects

Posts.Title: Surgeons at Johns Hopkins

Posts.Content: Welcome Chuck, and sorry that you have to join us here. This is a great forum for balanced advice from guys who had been down every path. The recommendations from your doctors reflect the recent guidelines published by the American Urological Association and the three other organizations that represent the American medical establishment regarding prostate cancer. They endorse active surveillance as the default treatment for your pathology. The MRI, and confirmatory fusion biopsy are essential requirements for determining that you are correctly placed in AS. There are several optional genomics tests that could be run on your biopsy slides. Among those are OncotypeDX, Prolaris, SelectMDX, and Decipher. They can cost up to several thousand dollars, but my knowledge is out of date, and you may need to contact the various companies and practices to shop prices. There are also studies comparing them that may be found online. Stay calm and focused. You need to be informed, and follow your testing protocol, even with low risk prostate cancer. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Can Focal Therapy Replace Radical Therapy for Prostate Cancer? Against Focal Therapy

Posts.Content: A PIRADS 4 lesion can one of many things. Hemorrhage, internal stricture, benign lesion, scar tissue, infection damage, as well as prostate cancer. I had a PIRADS 4 lesion on PIRADS version 1, and it was downgraded to 3 with PIRADS 2.0. I have read several posts from men whose PIRADS 4 lesions were followed up with fusion MRI's, and no cancer was found. Some even had more biopsies, all still negative. You can drive yourself sick by trying to "guess your odds". The usual step now is a fusion biopsy targeting that lesion area. Good Luck.

Posts.Content: The good news for you is that prostate cancer is generally asymptomatic unless it is very advanced. There is no proven link between prostatitis and prostate cancer. You could request a PHI blood test, or a SelectMDx urine test if you are really doubting your urologist and need more confirmation. Those may be necessary if you are badly in need of more data to reassure yourself. p.s. If they don't know about these two tests, then you need to change doctors!

Posts.Title: Psa result

Posts.Content: Mags, Welcome to the forum. Your husband s prostate cancer will require treatment, and either surgery or radiation can cure him if the cancer is still confined to the prostate. I would like to address the bladder mass, as I have large kidney cysts, which have been stable for many years, but look scary on imaging. I think they were caused by a rust dissolver chemical I was using to restore a car. Anyway, when they were first noticed on a ultrasound, the technician was alarmed, and brought the chief radiologist in to see the images. The radiologist quickly diagnosed them as cysts, I think she said that was because the fluid filled cysts appeared as black, where solid tumors would appear as white. At least that I what I can recall from 15 years ago. So, in my experience, a skilled doctor should be able to distinguish a cyst from a tumor,
Posts.Title: Lots of research but still have questions

Posts.Content: SW, With an FPSA that low, you need to proceed with another level of testing. The tests mentioned by your doctor are valuable, but not very determinate, with their wide margins of uncertainty. I would recommend the 3T mpMRI, then followed with the fusion biopsy if suspicious areas are seen. Even if you don't have an MRI, a template biopsy would provide a baseline assessment of your prostate. At age 42, you need to know what is going on, and have the peace of mind that you are on top of your situation.

Posts.Title: Diagnosed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mags1310 I am a little bit more confused now that we have left the doc. He did the "cancer talk " with us and answered many questions. He does about 25-35 of the Da Vinci Robotic surgeries per year so he seems quite experienced at it. A question for ASA - my husband also has a left upper pole cortical simple cyst measuring 3.6 x 3.6 x 2.8 in his kidney. Dr. did not mention to this but I had requested a copy of the cat scan and it is the number one diagnosis on it. Is that what you have also? Is that big? And to clarify the cyst/tumor in bladder what he has is prostatic utricle projecting into the urinary bladder 1.7 x 1.4cm. The Dr says that IF we decide on surgery this would be removed and sent to pathology along with the prostate. Can anyone give me any insight into a cortical cyst in kidney and a prostatic utricle projecting into urinary bladder? Anything we need to worry about? Thanks!! mags, what the nephrologists and urologists at Johns Hopkins told me is that they saw no need to surgically remove cysts, as they were unlikely to become cancerous. Now, kidney cysts CAN be very dangerous, even fatal, if they become so large that they crowd out the nephrons that provide the filtering function, and cause the kidney to fail. In my case, I had the interventional radiologists at a local hospital drain the largest cysts (17cm and 15 cm) in both kidneys to relieve that pressure. That was just before I consulted at JH. But, you have to understand that I had a one-time chemical exposure, not a hereditary cyst disease, so the one-time draining worked for me.

Posts.Title: Any stage of people will produce cancer

Posts.Content: I was reading a commentary on another site regarding "the 40 year debate about surgery versus radiation". It presented two links. One was to a "Point" article by two radiologists claiming that RT was superior to surgery. The second was a "Counterpoint" article by a very experienced Urologist defending his specialty, which he believed achieved a better result. OK - I will post those two links for those debating this decision. But, what struck me was the statement by the urologist that: "Our group recently reported that over 60% of contemporary men who had a Gleason score of 8 on prostate biopsy were downgraded at the time of radical prostatectomy." That runs counter to what I usually read about upgrades often being an unwelcome result of post-RP pathology. There just don't seem to be absolute truths to rely upon when making decisions with this disease. http://www.cancernetwork.com/prostat...e-radiotherapy http://www.cancernetwork.com/oncolog...=1&ts=25112017

Posts.Title: Highly Experienced Surgeon Claims Significant DOWNGRADES After RP

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 So often you hear that there is no need to act on the discovery of prostate cancer because "...it's likely something else will kill you first". But prostate cancer is the second leading cause of cancer deaths among men in the U.S. (estimated 29,480 deaths in 2014). That's a pretty impressive number. If you have the opportunity to catch it early and get rid of it, it just seems logical that you would want to do that. Because, as you get older, if nothing else DOES kill you first, then the prostate cancer absolutely will be your demise. If I had it to do over again, I would LEAP onto the operating table. With all respect for your blunt and honest opinions, Jim, yours is not the only opinion in this matter. I have been under advisement for over five years, and certain for 30 months that I have some PCa. Yet, with the advice of my uro-oncologists at Johns Hopkins, and my own readings, I am quite comfortable to NOT jump onto an operating table unless there is a change in the pathology of my case. Now, you see things your way, and I see things mine. I understand your ardor and wanting to make sure that a new poster is aware of the potential danger of this disease. Still, he may be "wired" more like me, and want to wait before seeking an intervention that may unnecessarily harm his quality of life without prolonging it.

Posts.Title: Decision Made - RALP scheduled

Posts.Content: Yes, Garyi is correct. I will need to find a new urologist. I think that Dr. Michael Gorin will be his primary replacement. He is the one who trained the others on the Precision Point biopsy device. Dr. Carter is 65 or 66. Apparently, he has planned his retirement for some time. Think of the challenges that Bal faced in 1994 when proposing to defer treatment some men with proven cancer. For a young surgeon, that must have been heresy to his colleagues. Malpractice, credibility, not using your skills, and loss of income. He, and Laurence Klotz in Toronto were the pioneers of active surveillance for prostate cancer. They have had a respectful rivalry for years. Many thousands of men, including myself, are grateful for Dr. Carter's vision and advocacy. AS as a treatment choice may or may not last a lifetime, but these are years well lived.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic One thought I'll throw out is that there are two sets of stats for surgical outcomes: one is for the statistically average surgeon and the other for the best high-volume surgeons. Hopefully one will choose a surgeon in the latter group. I don't know if this is also true for radiation. By "significant downgrades" downgrading, I assume ASAdvocate means a significant percentage of men and not significant Gleason downgrades for each man in the downgrade group. In my case I was downgraded from 5+5 to 5+4. Yes, that is how I interpreted his quote. Still, while it's exclusive to his practice, it's not in line with other sources.

Posts.Title: Highly Experienced Surgeon Claims Significant DOWNGRADES After RP

Posts.Content: He may do want to attend some local prostate cancer support groups. These usually meet once every month under the patronage of a hospital or a national support group. Men are there to share their experiences, and many of them would not do their method of treatment again, if they could turn back time. Much to learn if you find a good group. About a year ago, I attended such a meeting where three MD's did a presentation. A urologist, who did surgery several times every week, a radiation oncologist, and a medical oncologist, who specialized in chemotherapy. The urologist was interesting, in that he said that he did not want to operate on any more Gleason 3+3 cases, as that was overtreatment. The chemo guy was a lab type who knew his stuff, but wasn't good at translating his points in patient terms. The radiation guy had the greatest impact, as he presented comparative results for surgery, EBRT, IMRT, and seeds at their hospitals. The results were strongly favorable to seeds + IMRT. They had stats for several hundreds of patients and the "cure" rates and side effects for that combination of radiation methods had VERY impressive results. The two other specialists agreed, and were happy to share the good results as a team. You will hear that there WERE issues with radiation causing secondary cancers, but that data was from 30 years ago, and should not be applicable to today's technology. Also, there are several treatments like SBRT, HIFU, and FLA available if there is a recurrence after primary radiation treatment. If he is going to prefer radiation, then I would suggest that he research SBRT/Cyberknife, which is a type of radiation treatment that is having great recent results. So much to learn, so much at stake ... he is doing the right thing by taking some time to carefully and thoughtfully examine what choices he has. Keep asking, and the members here will try to answer and assist as best we can.

Posts.Title: surgery vs. radiation for younger patients

Posts.Content: Denis, Thank you for joining these forums and including many of us in your thought process. It has been very beneficial. Two months ago, you were reciting the usual talking points in favor of surgery, so I guessed that your mind was made up, but that your inquisitive impulse couldn't resist the mental flagellation of pondering more choices that you would not take seriously. I would have bet money on your doing surgery. Obviously, I would be a failure as a gambler. But, while I have been firmly in favor of SBRT, should I ever need treatment, you have caused me to also consider HDRBT, and I can see its advantages. Thanks. As a far as RALP being so popular, I would think that men just like the idea of high tech automatically being infallible, and promising a great result. What will be interesting is the narrowing of the risk classes for RP. It would seem that only G7 and 8 may be the best applications for RP, as AS is now the standard (by the NCCN, AUA, and ASCO) for very low and low risk men, and the triple play of HT, Brachy Boost, and IMRT or SBRT appear to be producing the best results for G9+. And, RP would be in competition with various forms of radiation even within the G7 and G8 risk classes. Anyway, your journey has been fascinating to follow. Best wishes for total success.

Others will argue that that advantage is offset by the adverse additional side effects. Either way, he will require a regimen of treatments. The good news is that Gleason 4+3 is not the worst diagnosis, and has a chance for being cured, not just managed.

Posts.Content: " If it were as easy as taking a pill it would be a solved problem but its not. With that said at eight hundred to a thousand dollars a month for pills who can afford that." Wow! That is really, really high. Pfizer's US patent on Viagra partially expires this month, so the US retail prices should be lower soon. But, anyway, you can buy generic Viagra (sildenafil) for about $75 for thirty 100mg tablets, which are designed to break into two. Many Canadian and other mail order pharmacies offer these deals, and, yes, it is legal to import small amounts of such drugs for personal use. So, the drugs (perfectly equal) are available for far less than you were quoted.

Posts.Title: surgery vs. radiation for younger patients

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F We all look forward to the advancements in liquid biopsies and imaging technologies that will detect PC (and a whole spectrum of other CA) before clinical significance is reached. MF Yes, that's the only way to bring the "overtreatment" debate to a close. I fully understand that the 2012 panel was trying to prevent unnecessary worry, biopsies, and men with indolent cases being rushed into surgery. There are now several alternatives/augmentations to psa tests, and more are coming down the pipeline. Some look to have VERY high confidence levels, but they aren't on the market today. When they are, and are accepted, hopefully within the next 5 to 10 years, we can put these concerns to rest. For now, psa testing, with all its flaws, is absolutely better than no testing at all.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic As the authors point out: If the main benefit of ADT were its action on micrometastases outside the prostate, it would have the same effect when combined with RP as with local RT. Don't forget, radiation has to kill all the malignant cells in the prostate over time, whereas RP simply removes them. Djin, I re-read sections 3 and 4 of the article, and, while I would like to agree with you, it appears that what they have analyzed so far does not indicate that RP has the same improvements with systemic treatments included, that EBRT has demonstrated.

Posts.Title: RP done, post op PSA concern - urgent advise needed

Posts.Content: Chris, Calm down. You've gotten way ahead of the known facts in your situation. As Chuck has pointed out, your data is far below what would be expected for advanced prostate cancer. At this point, all that needs to be done is to determine if you possibly have any actual prostate cancer. The MRI is an excellent idea, as it will allow the doctor doing the biopsy to precisely target any suspicious areas of your prostate. And, if you DO have some PCa, only a minority of cases are high-risk. Prostate cancer has a spectrum of risk classifications, and perhaps half or more of the cases will never be life threatening. The number of men newly diagnosed with PCa every year is eight times the number of men who die from that disease. Those statistics should help relax you. Follow your doctor's advice and try to enjoy life without letting your fear get ahead of what is known. Good Luck.

Posts.Title: Gleason Patterns

Posts.Content: Djin, Thanks for posting this. The lesson that I see here is that one biopsy is a very thin basis for making a treatment decision (or not). One factor that is missing is the amount of cancer found in those who chose or were recommended for immediate treatment. I'm always reading about men trying to make decisions based on just one 12 core TRUS biopsy. It seems to me that they need more tests, an MRI and a confirmatory fusion biopsy, and genomics testing, before they can have a decent guess as to whether AS is a good option for them.

Posts.Title: Management and outcomes of Gleason 6 found on biopsy -- One doc's outcomes

Posts.Content: One important data item is missing. Was the Gleason score of 7 a (3+4) or a (4+3)? That changes your Grade Group from 2 to 3 if it is the latter score. Still, I would be starting to look at treatment options if I had that report. As there are three types of surgery, six types of radiation, and another six or seven assorted prostate cancer treatments available, that research can take some time. Luckily, time is not an urgency for you.
Posts.Title: Biopsy Results - 2x Gleason 7 +. Need some help.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SubDenis My thought about AS was a delaying tactic, not a lifelong decision. The studies from the longest-running AS groups at Sunnybrook and Johns Hopkins show 20 and 15 year retention rates at 55 percent. Maybe I'm just fooling myself, but I want to believe that AS can be a lifelong choice for many men with low risk PCa. And, even if I can't make it that far without treatment, hopefully, some less-damaging treatment options will then be available.

Posts.Title: Management and outcomes of Gleason 6 found on biopsy -- One doc's outcomes

Posts.Content: Hi Ha, Welcome the forum. Hopefully, the biopsy will be clear (about 65 percent of new biopsies are), and you won't have to be here long. Your uro is doing standard practice protocol. Initial biopsies are usually done with US, although there is much discussion that a prior MRI would lead to more specific targeting of suspect areas. Please try not to think too far ahead. We all have been guilty of that. You only need to be concerned if cancer is found on the biopsy slides. But, keep in mind, that prostate cancers run the spectrum from indolent to aggressive. I was diagnosed eight years ago, and so far it appears to be indolent, and not needing treatment. A different diagnosis could lead to having to research and choose from a menu of treatments. But, again, that's getting ahead of what you know. When you receive the post-biopsy lab report (if any cancer is found), then try to paste as much of the report's findings as possible. That would allow us to provide you with informed opinions for your consideration. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Surgery at Hopkins - Post Surgical Interactions?

Posts.Content: Mark, Two of my five biopsies caused internal hemorrhages which are permanent damage. Their symptoms were pain which lasted for about six months. Now, they are not an issue other than showing up on MRI's, but, yes, there can be problems with biopsies. The sepsis rate is maybe 2 in 100, and the death rate is about 1 in 1400. Now, after the scary stuff, I agree with Michael F and your doctor that you should soon be out of the worry zone for an infection to develop.

A key quote: "radiation therapy was the most common treatment at 58 percent, followed by radical prostatectomy (a surgical procedure to remove the prostate) at 19 percent. Other treatments trailed at 10 percent, including watchful waiting (where doctors wait and see if cancer progresses before treating it) and active surveillance (when patients undergo routine biopsies, blood tests and MRI to determine if cancer is progressing and undergo active treatment)." http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases...0219160434.htm

Posts.Title: Interesting Statistics on Prostate Cancer Treatment Options

Posts.Content: A prophylactic prostatectomy is a very radical step. I've only heard of one other case, where the man was motivated by the same fears. But, from what I have read, while the propensity of near relatives to get PCa is known, the Gleason grade and staging are not correlated among the family. So, you COULD get PCa, but it might not be life-threatening. What testing have you had done, besides this genomic assay? What has been your psa history, and MRI results? Prostate size, any biopsies? I get where you are coming from, but suggest that you know a lot more about your present prostate analytics before taking such a drastic course.

Posts.Title: How often does THIS happen ??

Posts.Content: Caddy, As your doctor advised, you don't need to be in any rush to make a decision. Every treatment technique that I can think of has undergone almost day-and-night changes over the past 20 years. So, advice on outcomes and side effects has to be as current as possible, as the old stories and statistics aren't applicable to those treated today. On the surgery side, robotics are now close to 90 percent of the operations. The small incisions, faster recovery times, and precision accuracy would seem to be tremendous improvements over open RP. But, all the scholarly studies I've seen keep saying that the patient outcomes have not changed, and that the skill of the surgeon is more important than the method. On the radiation side, there have recently been reported improvements in both the outcomes and side effects. This is happening as the technologies evolve to fewer sessions and more precise focusing and tracking. SBRT/Cyberknife and HDR monotherapy are the methods receiving the most notice for fewer cancer recurrences and also fewer and lower toxicity side effects. There are advocates for Proton beam, HIFU, FLA, and Cryotherapy. Their supporters can be adamant, but don't have the statistics (yet), in my opinion. You will likely receive some great advice on this thread. Please read them all carefully.

Posts.Title: CT scan and DRE shows issue with my prostate, confused

Posts.Content: If I had a core with 40% of pattern 4, I would plan on a treatment. That said, you have time to make a decision that you can be comfortable with. Some men prefer what they assume is the finality of surgery. Regrettably, quite a few of them seem to be back online the next year asking about salvage RT. Some men advocate for focal therapies that target and destroy imaged lesions. But, minimal side effects matter little if the cancer keeps coming back. My readings bias me towards SBRT or HDRT-BT, two types of specifically targeted high-dosage radiation. They are actually designed to provide about the same toxicity to the cancer cells, but one therapy is external, and the other internal, to the body. One treatment I would advise that you look at would be proton beam therapy. I know, up to now its been expensive, required 44 sessions, and not shown superior results. But, some recent exchanges I have had with PBT advocates state that they are reducing the number of sessions to five, just like SBRT, and these advocates (I've now counted about a dozen of them online) are all claiming ZERO side effects, with no recurrences. That's worth checking out. As above, you have the time to get this right.

Posts.Signature: DOB: May 1944 In Active Surveillance program at Johns Hopkins Strict protocol of tests, including PHI, DRE, MRI, and biopsy. Six biopsies from 2009 to 2019. Numbers 1, 2, and 5 were negative. Numbers 3,4, and 6 were positive with 5% Gleason(3+3) found. Last one was Precision Point transperineal. PSA 4.4, fPSA 24, PHI 32 Hopefully, I can remain untreated. So far, so good.
Posts.Title: Big spike in PSA level - worried

Posts.Content: I attended a local support group last year where the chief urologist of a large hospital made a slide presentation of the data that supported the 2012 USPTF guidelines. I think that only perhaps 2 out of 1,000 men who were randomly psa tested were saved from an early death from PCa. There was a lot of data graphics in this presentation. Now, here we have a guy who does RP's for a living making a defense for no psa testing. Well, he did it to show us that there was a strong case to be made against over treatment, which was a driving force 10 years ago. Now, as he discussed with us, things have changed. He counsels his G6 patients to go into AS, for example. While there is still a concern that urologists in small practices will still push patients into unnecessary treatment, that trend is sharply decreasing. It was an interesting and lively discussion. I'm glad that I was diagnosed, and am aware of my status. I see the overtreatment issue as one of doctors' advice (motivated by greed or firm belief), not of diagnostics. This is improving year by year.

Posts.Title: PSA testing change 2017

Posts.Content: Excellent points, Terry. Yes, the changes in radiation technology and possibilities are moving faster than the insurers can adjust. Medicare and insurance companies want lengthy periods of proven performance, and the radiations guys are seeing such positive results with small samples that they want to keep leapfrogging ahead. I recently have heard and read that IMRT can be done in as few as 10 or 12 sessions, and SBRT in 1. ONE! The major obstacle is the payment puzzle. Is this a reality to make happen now, or optimistic arrogance and gambling by the radiologists pushing it? That answer is surely above my pay grade, but you can bet that more studies will be posted soon, and the debate will be in full swing.

Posts.Title: Sticky: What I Need to Know About SBRT & IMRT

Posts.Content: He is having the standard, and most effective, treatment for his stage. Often, In the USA, they will attack this with a triple play of hormone therapy, external beam radiation, and High Dose Bracytherapy, with a potential for a curative result. If they have ruled out distant metastasis, by using PET or similar imaging, then there is hope that the cancer can be cured. If not, there has been great progress in managing the disease for many years, while more research may lead to a cure for all stages.

Posts.Title: Distraught daughter looking for help & clarification

Posts.Content: jag, I would suggest that your doctor order a PHI test rather than just the psa. PHI includes psa, free psa, and another marker for cancer activity. It is more accurate than psa alone, and less affected by BPH. I won't frighten you with tales of my two "bad" biopsies, just be aware that they are not risk-free, and should be avoided unless really necessary.

Posts.Title: prostate biopsy due to sudden elevated PSA

Posts.Content: Bernard, As the others have noted, you have time to research, ask, consult, and finally be content with whatever course you choose. I recently had an online exchange with a man who was 51, and had, as I recall, three positive cores each with a higher percentage of G3+3 cancer. He went to see the top doctor at a leading prostate cancer center. This doctor had founded what is probably the strictest and best known active surveillance program in the nation. After a discussion with the patient and his wife, this well known specialist signed him up for the AS program. That certainly surprised me! But, the reasoning is now clear to me. (1) his risk of mortality will not be increased if he is monitored closely. Studies have proved that. (2) This doctor is very aware of the ongoing research...maybe there will be a noninvasive cure in a few years. (3) the patient was simply not mentally ready to have surgery. So, the rules can be flexed, probably without risk. The lesson here is not to feel rushed, and the time that you can safely delay radical treatment both increases your "normal" years, and allows for new treatments to be developed. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: New Diagnosis

Posts.Content: Welcome, Bassoneman, If you have multiple cores of G 3+4 with 50% involvement, then I agree that AS is not the best choice for you. Sounds like you are having IMRT, is that correct? That has a very good cure rate, and is still the most-chosen radiation protocol. Dr. Walsh's book is very good at explaining what the prostate is, how it functions, and how his surgical techniques are beneficial, but it does not have the latest data on radiation protocols. Still, a very worthwhile buy. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: New here... TAD Nervous Start Radiation this week -

Posts.Content: The no more than two positive cores of Gleason 6 to be considered for a very low-risk AS program dates from the 1990s when a six-core biopsy was standard. Now, with 12 cores for a standard biopsy and some extra for a targeted one, the rules have changed at many institutions. That new criteria is no more than 34% of cores taken can be positive. Basically, the same standard, just being updated for todays biopsy practices. So, you may indeed be considered eligible for AS. As others have said, get another opinion, both on reading your biopsy slides, and with a different urologist. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Distraught daughter looking for help & clarification

Posts.Content: What is your prostate size? That should be on your biopsy pathology report. A large prostate will produce a higher PSA. The prostate density (PSAD) calculation is gaining acceptance as a more reliable measure than PSA alone, or even PHI. I think your doctor is correct to want more analysis of your case before rushing into a treatment that could either under-or-over treat you.

Posts.Title: I Am A Bit of A Unicorn

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic ASA, it's hard to imagine a better MRI and I understand your reluctance to biopsy again. Having had no complications from my biopsies, I never balked when a uro wanted yet another because of a jump in my PSA (the question always being was the rise due solely to my BPH?). But you are justifiably wary with your different biopsy track record. If a 6th biopsy found one 3+4 core with a small percentage of 4, would you treat? 4+3 ? Your genomics test was pretty good, but does leave the door open. I know you'll weigh everything carefully, including your doc's opinion, and make an informed decision. As was discussed, if you go ahead, I would ask about needle washing between cores, as well as colon prep and antibiotic choice (I wonder if the choice is also influenced by geographic location as well as an institute's experience and patient's history). I know little about transperineal biopsy other than I read it has a near zero sepsis rate. My uro mentioned it when we chatted about post-biopsy infection and it seems to be becoming more popular. Best Wishes to you and all Forum Brothers for a Happy and Healthy New Year! Djin Hi Djin, A few years ago, I set a threshold for treatment at "two cores with more than ten percent of Gleason 4". That is certain. One core with ten percent or less? Probably not, especially as I'm looking at age 75 around the corner. While I am very active and agile, the mortality tables and seeing what's happening with people not much older than I would persuade me to take the risk of continuing monitoring. Before the MRI report was posted on MyChart, I went through the normal "what if?" anxieties and watched some videos on SBRT, which would be my favored choice of a treatment. Two take-aways were (1) that it was not totally side effect free, and (2) that the specialists setting up the machine better be in top form all the time, as they are wielding a lot of radiation with very close margins. So, I would not jump to treatment without a significant risk of not treating. Another patient of Dr. Carter told me that he recently had a biopsy using a Precision Point transperineal device operated by another doctor at Hopkins. I will ask about that, as well as your research on the needle cleaning. But, enough of that thought process. Today is a day for family, and all of mine will be together at my son's house. My best wishes to you, and the others who have commented. Have a loving Christmas, and a healthy and happy new year.

Posts.Title: New MRI Results - MY PCa is Regressing

Posts.Content: Fairwind has summed it up well. The 30 percent upgrade number is likely from the selection of AS after just one TRUS biopsy. After that initial positive biopsy, additional MRI's, biopsies, genomics tests, specific blood and urine tests, etc., will further filter those men to see who are correctly placed on AS. The probability is that any upgrade is not due to your G6 itself morphing, but the discovery of previously undetected G7 or higher cells. Each new test drives down those odds. At my age and testing history, I MAY (pray) be able to avoid more biopsies IF all other tests stay relative stable.

Posts.Content: Semiramide, Are you saying that those of us who are low risk are not deserving of being heard? If so, then you are blind to the stresses of fearing that ones ticket could be punched by their next test. If you are attempting to validate each mans opinion by their Gleason score, then you are also dividing a community that we all should be supporting and strengthening. I participate in nine on-line and one in-person PCa support group. While there are many, many differences of opinions, this is the first time that I have ever heard one patient dismiss another based on their current risk profile. Not good....

Posts.Title: Trial: identifying clinically significant lesions in Low Risk Ca pts.

Posts.Content: In addition to Chuck's always good advice, it should be noted that he should be in no rush to decide on a form of treatment. Prostate cancer is slowing growing, and, only one person out of 100 who is diagnosed with it today, will die from it within 10 years, according to the American Cancer Society statistics. So, if he takes a few months to research, consult, and ask, it is unlikely to affect his longevity. There are several forms of treatments, available, with surgery and different forms of radiation being the most chosen. There are also focal therapies like HIFU and FLA which are growing in use. Clinical trials of different immunotherapy drugs are available, at least in the US, and may also be found in India. Please make sure that he is fully aware of the side effects of the different types of treatments, and seeks a second opinion. Attending a local prostate cancer support group and seeking advice from other men who have had treatment, can also be very helpful. In any event, it does appear that his cancer is certainly curable. Good luck to him.

Posts.Title: Trial: identifying clinically significant lesions in Low Risk Ca pts.

Posts.Content: "The increase could be because the disease is becoming more aggressive, or it could be because there is less screening being done, but we don't know why," said lead researcher Dr. Edward Schaeffer. He is chair of urology at Northwestern University's Feinberg School of Medicine in Chicago." While I am totally in favor of psa testing, this quote is potentially worrisome, because he mentions that the disease itself may be coming more aggressive. That would be far more challenging to deal with than revising the task force recommendation to test everyone again. Time will tell, but I sure hope that we are not facing new variants of PCa.

Posts.Title: Father recently got diagnosed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Terry's Cellar GMJJ, I can understand your husband's concern after the lose of his brother. I'm not an expert but my experience with my biopsy was that it was much easier than I expected and it would not have kept me from driving 9 hours three days post. That said why not reschedule to reduce any concern. The only way to diagnose PCa is a biopsy. I think either the Dr. misspoke or was misinterpreted. There are other causes for an increase in PSA besides PCa so don't get ahead of yourselves. And even if the biopsy is positive for most men the challenge is deciding how best to weigh through all of the options. All the statistics are still in your favor. Terry is right on about the doctor either being misspoken or misinterpreted. That's a pretty bold statement for him to make, and outside of his guidelines. I have had a couple of very painful biopsies with long lasting effects, and I could not imagine driving for that time. Terry's other suggestion about rescheduling sounds prudent.

Posts.Title: Another new member here

Posts.Content: I read a commentary on the FDA approval. That writer stated that the two manufacturers had been trying to get approval for eleven years, but could not satisfy the volume of patient data that the FDA wanted to see. So, a few months ago, one of the companies submitted a different application asking that their machine be certified for removing prostate tissue. It was. So, that means that the machine was approved as a type of surgical knife, but did not address its effectiveness for cancer. Now, of course, because the process is "approved" for removing all prostatic tissue, that includes cancer. So, yes, there is more legitimacy in using the device and process, but the patient has no more assurance of long term outcome than before.

Posts.Title: HIFU Treatment Receives FDA Approval

Posts.Content: Jim, The whole promise of HIFU, as I understand it, is the avoidance of any side effects when treating localized PCa. Also, its use does not preclude any subsequent therapy, and it can be used repeatedly, if necessary. As far as multiple cancer sites, some of the comments that I have read from HIFU enthusiasts is that secondary lesions are usually G6, and don't pose a danger if left alone or treated later. I am not knowledgeable enough to recommend or not recommend HIFU...just repeating what I have read about it.

Posts.Content: Recently speaking with a radiation oncologist at a support group, I was surprised to learn that his university facility uses the same equipment for IMRT and SBRT. I had thought that SBRT required equipment supplied by Cyberknife or Varian. Not the case. The same LINAC's used for conventional radiation can also be used for SBRT. Just a matter of setup. Always something to learn.

Posts.Content: Just to add a note that these studies did not analyze the newest modalities of FT, which are in-bore MRI targeting during Focal Laser Ablation, or the radically improved HIFU machines now being sold. The in-bore MRI settings for FLA have been performed in the USA for several years now. I do not have a dog in this fight, but know that FT enthusiasts elsewhere on the Internet would quickly state this opinion.

Posts.Title: Can Focal Therapy Replace Radical Therapy for Prostate Cancer? Against Focal Therapy

Posts.Content: There can be different protocols for active surveillance depending on whether you have had a positive biopsy. I was on "unofficial" active surveillance for 20 months, and have been part of an "official" program for the past 29 months. The unofficial monitoring was a psa every six months, and a DRE and free psa every year. A prostate MRI would be called for if there were significant changes. The official AS is a study group that I joined at Johns Hopkins Medical School, which has very specific protocols. These include psa/fpsa every six months, and an annual DRE and biopsy. Also, MRI's as necessary. Yes, an annual biopsy regardless of any other test. As I am now over 70, and had a negative last biopsy, they may just do the MRI next year and skip the biopsy, unless there are changes. To guess at your situation, I would think the "unofficial" lever of surveillance, which you have been doing, would be reasonable, given your family history.

Posts.Title: Monitoring Changes after negative Biopsy.

Posts.Title: From Hopkins - Margins - Don't Panic if not Negative

Posts.Content: Kevin, you have met with two urologists, and are really considering surgery. That is like saying that you went to two Chevrolet dealers, and are really considering buying a Chevy. The cure rates are the same for both surgery and radiation, but the side effects are not the same. You owe it to yourself to also consult with a radiation oncologist. Do not rely on urologists having either recent or accurate information regarding radiation. The impressive recent results have come from SBRT and HDR brachytherapy. Please do the research and consultations.

Posts.Title: New to forum, need help

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Not to put any words in ASA's mouth, but I think he may have meant that the side effects between surgery & radiation are not the same in terms of WHEN they happen. Otherwise, they are EXACTLY the same. The difference is the timing -- the SEs happen immediately after surgery whereas they happen a year or two after radiation treatments. Chuck Chuck, All due respect, I truly believe that neither the same side effects, nor the same rate of incidence, is found with surgery and radiation. Radiation patients, for example, do not complain about penis shortening or retrograde ejaculations. I am out the country and only have my iPhone and spotty connectivity this week. But, here is a study supporting my assertions. https://www.pcf.org/c/side-effects

Posts.Title: New to forum, need help

Posts.Content: He may do want to attend some local prostate cancer support groups. These usually meet once every month under the patronage of a hospital or a national support group. Men are there to share their experiences, and many of them would not do their method of treatment again, if they could turn back time. Much to learn if you find a good group. About a year ago, I attended such a meeting where three MD's did a presentation. A urologist, who did surgery several times every week, a radiation oncologist, and a medical oncologist, who specialized in chemotherapy. The urologist was interesting, in that he said that he did not want to operate on any more Gleason 3+3 cases, as that was overtreatment. The chemo guy was a lab type who knew his stuff, but wasn't good at translating his points in patient terms. The radiation guy had the greatest impact, as he presented comparative results for surgery, EBRT, IMRT, and seeds at their hospitals. The results were strongly favorable to seeds + IMRT. They had stats for several hundreds of patients and the "cure" rates and side effects for that combination of radiation methods had VERY impressive results. The two other specialists agreed, and were happy to share the good results as a team. You will hear that there WERE issues with radiation causing secondary cancers, but that data was from 30 years ago, and should not be applicable to today's technology. Also, there are several treatments like SBRT, HIFU, and FLA available if there is a recurrence after primary radiation treatment. If he is going to prefer radiation, then I would suggest that he research SBRT/Cyberknife, which is a type of radiation treatment that is having great recent results. So much to learn, so much at stake ... he is doing the right thing by taking some time to carefully and thoughtfully examine what choices he has. Keep asking, and the members here will try to answer and assist as best we can.

Posts.Title: surgery vs. radiation for younger patients

Posts.Content: For its Active Surveillance study group, Johns Hopkins switched to the PHI test several years ago. PHI includes PSA, free PSA, a prostate cancer biomarker, and an algorithm that produces a score on the likelihood of finding aggressive cancer on biopsy. I have heard that it costs about $100, about double that of psa alone, and worth it for its superior accuracy.

Posts.Title: BPH symptoms?

Posts.Content: Denis, Thank you for joining these forums and including many of us in your thought process. It has been very beneficial. Two months ago, you were reciting the usual talking points in favor of surgery, so I guessed that your mind was made up, but that your inquisitive impulse couldn't resist the mental flagellation of pondering more choices that you would not take seriously. I would have bet money on your doing surgery. Obviously, I would be a failure as a gambler. But, while I have been firmly in favor of SBRT, should I ever need treatment, you have caused me to also consider HDRBT, and I can see its advantages. Thanks. As a far as RALP being so popular, I would think that men just like the idea of high tech automatically being infallible, and promising a great result. What will be interesting is the narrowing of the risk classes for RP. It would seem that only G7 and 8 may be the best applications for RP, as AS is now the standard (by the NCCN, AUA, and ASCO) for very low and low risk men, and the triple play of HT, Brachy Boost, and IMRT or SBRT appear to be producing the best results for G9+. And, RP would be in competition with various forms of radiation even within the G7 and G8 risk classes. Anyway, your journey has been fascinating to follow. Best wishes for total success.

Posts.Title: Acronyms

Posts.Content: With 7 of 12 cores being positive, it would appear that your cancer is on both sides of the prostate. Under Johns Hopkins' criteria, that would pretty much rule out AS. They have relaxed the criteria on percentage of core involvement, and are considering reducing the importance of number of cores. But, bilateral involvement is now considered a higher risk than those two factors. In my unscientific awareness of what therapy appears to be producing the best overall results, SBRT (Cyberknife) appears to be winning out. Just a suggestion, but worth your checking out.

Posts.Title: Need advice

Posts.Content: gjw, You need to educate yourself and be fully informed of all the options available to you. Surgery is one, radiation is another, various focal interventions are gaining in use, and Active Surveillance (in a formal program) is certainly reasonable with your known pathology at this time. There are studies showing that about 66 percent of those enrolled in Johns Hopkins AS program since 1994 have never had treatment. So, the G3+3 cancers may never become more dangerous. However, at age 55, you are younger than most of those men, and need to be aware that their outcomes may or may not apply to you. Certainly, if you are going to not seek treatment at this time, then you need to be under a structured AS program with all the testing and protocols that it requires. BTW, I am one of those hoping to die with PCa, and not from it, but not everyone has the same mindset, and that is understandable.

While your risk of getting PCa is twice that of someone else, any cancer that you get would not necessarily be aggressive. Posts.Title: 44 Yr old Male. Ive had 4 prostate infecttions.

Posts.Content: PSA does not not determine cancer. High psa can be caused by several non-cancerous issues. Yours, to my knowledge, is hardly high, even for your age. You should not rush into a biopsy unless there is an evident need for it. For some men, biopsies can be painful with long lasting damage. Three of every hundred require hospitalization for sepsis. Why not have a PHI test, which includes psa, free psa, and a biomarker for prostate cancer? I think that it costs about $110. and is more accurate than psa alone, as it is less affected by benign issues. I have been taking aspirin and statins for 25 years. They certainly haven't hurt me, and my doctors are happy that I take them.

Posts.Title: Not sure what to do

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 So often you hear that there is no need to act on the discovery of prostate cancer because "...it's likely something else will kill you first". But prostate cancer is the second leading cause of cancer deaths among men in the U.S. (estimated 29,480 deaths in 2014). That's a pretty impressive number. If you have the opportunity to catch it early and get rid of it, it just seems logical that you would want to do that. Because, as you get older, if nothing else DOES kill you first, then the prostate cancer absolutely will be your demise. If I had it to do over again, I would LEAP onto the operating table. With all respect for your blunt and honest opinions, Jim, yours is not the only opinion in this matter. I have been under advisement for over five years, and certain for 30 months that I have some PCa. Yet, with the advice of my uro-oncologists at Johns Hopkins, and my own readings, I am quite comfortable to NOT jump onto an operating table unless there is a change in the pathology of my case. Now, you see things your way, and I see things mine. I understand your ardor and wanting to make sure that a new poster is aware of the potential danger of this disease. Still, he may be "wired" more like me, and want to wait before seeking an intervention that may unnecessarily harm his quality of life without prolonging it.

Posts.Content: Yes, Garyi is correct. I will need to find a new urologist. I think that Dr. Michael Gorin will be his primary replacement. He is the one who trained the others on the Precision Point biopsy device. Dr. Carter is 65 or 66. Apparently, he has planned his retirement for some time. Think of the challenges that Bal faced in 1994 when proposing to defer treatment some men with proven cancer. For a young surgeon, that must have been heresy to his colleagues. Malpractice, credibility, not using your skills, and loss of income. He, and Laurence Klotz in Toronto were the pioneers of active surveillance for prostate cancer. They have had a respectful rivalry for years. Many thousands of men, including myself, are grateful for Dr. Carter's vision and advocacy. AS as a treatment choice may or may not last a lifetime, but these are years well lived.

Posts.Title: How do you process all the information?

Posts.Content: Bernard, As the others have noted, you have time to research, ask, consult, and finally be content with whatever course you choose. I recently had an online exchange with a man who was 51, and had, as I recall, three positive cores each with a higher percentage of G3+3 cancer. He went to see the top doctor at a leading prostate cancer center. This doctor had founded what is probably the strictest and best known active surveillance program in the nation. After a discussion with the patient and his wife, this well known specialist signed him up for the AS program. That certainly surprised me! But, the reasoning is now clear to me. (1) his risk of mortality will not be increased if he is monitored closely. Studies have proved that. (2) This doctor is very aware of the ongoing research...maybe there will be a noninvasive cure in a few years. (3) the patient was simply not mentally ready to have surgery. So, the rules can be flexed, probably without risk. The lesson here is not to feel rushed, and the time that you can safely delay radical treatment both increases your "normal" years, and allows for new treatments to be developed. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: New Diagnosis

Posts.Content: Have your doctor do a blood draw for a PHI test. It provides psa, free psa, and another cancer biomarker, and it is more accurate than psa alone. Biopsies have infection risks, and are to be avoided unless there is strong evidence you need one. Get the PHI test. If it is suspicious, then get an mpMRI. If those prove the need, then have a fusion biopsy.
Posts.Signature: DOB: May 1944 In Active Surveillance program at Johns Hopkins Strict protocol of tests, including PHI, DRE, MRI, and biopsy. Six biopsies from 2009 to 2019. Numbers 1, 2, and 5 were negative. Numbers 3,4, and 6 were positive with 5% Gleason(3+3) found. Last one was Precision Point transperineal. PSA 4.4, fPSA 24, PHI 32 Hopefully, I can remain untreated. So far, so good.
Posts.Title: 2nd PSA still high after no cancer found in biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 So often you hear that there is no need to act on the discovery of prostate cancer because "...it's likely something else will kill you first". But prostate cancer is the second leading cause of cancer deaths among men in the U.S. (estimated 29,480 deaths in 2014). That's a pretty impressive number. If you have the opportunity to catch it early and get rid of it, it just seems logical that you would want to do that. Because, as you get older, if nothing else DOES kill you first, then the prostate cancer absolutely will be your demise. If I had it to do over again, I would LEAP onto the operating table. With all respect for your blunt and honest opinions, Jim, yours is not the only opinion in this matter. I have been under advisement for over five years, and certain for 30 months that I have some PCa. Yet, with the advice of my uro-oncologists at Johns Hopkins, and my own readings, I am quite comfortable to NOT jump onto an operating table unless there is a change in the pathology of my case. Now, you see things your way, and I see things mine. I understand your ardor and wanting to make sure that a new poster is aware of the potential danger of this disease. Still, he may be "wired" more like me, and want to wait before seeking an intervention that may unnecessarily harm his quality of life without prolonging it.

Posts.Title: Prostate Biopsy 46 yrs old 4.8 PSA

Posts.Content: Kevin, you have met with two urologists, and are really considering surgery. That is like saying that you went to two Chevrolet dealers, and are really considering buying a Chevy. The cure rates are the same for both surgery and radiation, but the side effects are not the same. You owe it to yourself to also consult with a radiation oncologist. Do not rely on urologists having either recent or accurate information regarding radiation. The impressive recent results have come from SBRT and HDR brachytherapy. Please do the research and consultations.

Posts.Title: Recurrence after Surgery - Now what?

Posts.Content: Jim and ddayglo, Your points are well made. This study only addressed the follow-up issues for men in their late sixties with low-risk PCa. However, the take-away lesson here, in my opinion, is that men who are well qualified for Active Surveillance, but inclined towards immediate treatment, may want to think about re-programming their "wiring". Its one thing to want the cancer out and/or hit it as hard as possible. Its another thing to consider the long term quality of life issues. And, if, as studies have shown, your mortality is not significantly affected should you choose a formal AS program, there should be less over-treatment chosen.

Posts.Title: Survey results from low risk patients who chose RP, RT, and AS

Posts.Content: A PIRADS 4 lesion can one of many things. Hemorrhage, internal stricture, benign lesion, scar tissue, infection damage, as well as prostate cancer. I had a PIRADS 4 lesion on PIRADS version 1, and it was downgraded to 3 with PIRADS 2.0. I have read several posts from men whose PIRADS 4 lesions were followed up with fusion MRI's, and no cancer was found. Some even had more biopsies, all still negative. You can drive yourself sick by trying to "guess your odds". The usual step now is a fusion biopsy targeting that lesion area. Good Luck.

Posts.Title: Pi-rads 4 / mri scan

Posts.Content: Had a nice Christmas present today. The results of a 3T mp-MRI that was done at Johns Hopkins last week. I was in the tube for an hour as they did a 3D reconstruction study. The previous three MRI's had shown three lesions. The index one was first scored as a PIRADS 4 and the others as PIRADS 3. Then, later MRI's downgraded the 4 to a 3. This new result downgraded the original 4 to a 2 , and did not see the other two lesions. So, over the past ten years, my prostate cancer appears to have shrunk and regressed. This is not what I expected when I started out on this journey, but I'll gladly take it. Have to discuss having future biopsies with Dr. Carter. He insists on his protocol scheduled biopsies, and believes I need (a sixth) one for that reason. But I'm not sure that I see any benefit in having anymore, at least until other testing demonstrates a concern.

Posts.Title: EBRT and HT not for several months

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mags1310 I am a little bit more confused now that we have left the doc. He did the "cancer talk " with us and answered many questions. He does about 25-35 of the Da Vinci Robotic surgeries per year so he seems quite experienced at it. A question for ASA - my husband also has a left upper pole cortical simple cyst measuring 3.6 x 3.6 x 2.8 in his kidney. Dr. did not mention to this but I had requested a copy of the cat scan and it is the number one diagnosis on it. Is that what you have also? Is that big? And to clarify the cyst/tumor in bladder what he has is prostatic utricle projecting into the urinary bladder 1.7 x 1.4cm. The Dr says that IF we decide on surgery this would be removed and sent to pathology along with the prostate. Can anyone give me any insight into a cortical cyst in kidney and a prostatic utricle projecting into urinary bladder? Anything we need to worry about? Thanks!! mags, what the nephrologists and urologists at Johns Hopkins told me is that they saw no need to surgically remove cysts, as they were unlikely to become cancerous. Now, kidney cysts CAN be very dangerous, even fatal, if they become so large that they crowd out the nephrons that provide the filtering function, and cause the kidney to fail. In my case, I had the interventional radiologists at a local hospital drain the largest cysts (17cm and 15 cm) in both kidneys to relieve that pressure. That was just before I consulted at JH. But, you have to understand that I had a one-time chemical exposure, not a hereditary cyst disease, so the one-time draining worked for me.

Posts.Title: Lots of research but still have questions

Posts.Content: Mags, Welcome to the forum. Your husband s prostate cancer will require treatment, and either surgery or radiation can cure him if the cancer is still confined to the prostate. I would like to address the bladder mass, as I have large kidney cysts, which have been stable for many years, but look scary on imaging. I think they were caused by a rust dissolver chemical I was using to restore a car. Anyway, when they were first noticed on a ultrasound, the technician was alarmed, and brought the chief radiologist in to see the images. The radiologist quickly diagnosed them as cysts, I think she said that was because the fluid filled cysts appeared as black, where solid tumors would appear as white. At least that I what I can recall from 15 years ago. So, in my experience, a skilled doctor should be able to distinguish a cyst from a tumor,
Posts.Title: Lots of research but still have questions

Posts.Content: Sandy, a free psa of 33 is excellent, and a good indicator that you do not have PCa. Either a 4K or a PHI test should be next. Some people will tell you that biopsies are no big deal, that was the case with three of mine. But, two caused pain that lasted for months, and temporarily tripled my psa. Do not take biopsies lightly. If you have a small amount of low-risk cancer, I would caution you not to give in to a "get it out" reaction. You need to carefully read about the side effects of treatments, which often have seriously negative impacts on one's quality of life. Your doctor sounds like he is giving you great advice. Try not to think too far ahead until you know more.

Posts.Title: Psa result

Posts.Content: What is different about this approach is that it does not rely on temperature. Both FLA and cryotherapy use heat or cold to kill the cancer cells. But, I have recently read an article stating that the cancer can defend itself against temperature changes, and that throws the effectiveness of such therapies into question. In contrast, this treatment uses light-triggered toxins, which is a totally different method of attack. Great news. Progress. Thanks for posting this.

Posts.Title: Interesting Article

Posts.Content: I found the write-up to be confusing, and misleading. 592 men had negative MRI's, and 100 of them had RP. Of the 100 who had RP, 14 had cancer. That meant that the MRI had an 86 percent negative predictability. Of the 14, 11 had Gleason 7 or higher. That 11/14 is where the 79 percent figure was calculated. Unless I'm really reading the article wrong, there is nothing shocking here.

Posts.Title: Lots of research but still have questions

Posts.Content: These are the results from a survey of 427 low risk patients more than four years after they chose surgery, radiation, or active surveillance for their prostate cancer. The quality-of-life differences between those who had treatments and those who did not are very dramatic. http://prostatecancerinfolink.net/20...-surveillance/ Now, while this looks to be a strong testament for AS, it has to be noted that all of the men involved were classified as low risk at the time they made their decisions. So, it is perhaps more useful as a caution against choosing possible over-treatment, when AS is being suggested as an option by your physician(s).

Posts.Title: Here is the news, tell me what you think

Posts.Content: Sw, I can perfectly understand your anxiety in resolving your status and making decisions ASAP. We all do that. But, maybe you need to wait and not jump ahead with plans until you have a talk with your uro with all the test results available. I say this because I saw my specialist last week for an annual visit (I have blood work every six months near my home) , and had saved up seven pages of 4X6 cards jammed with notes on things I wanted to discuss with him. Most of these had to do with excerpts I had seen in scholarly articles that possibly raise concern about my similar pathologies. He knocked them down in a few minutes, and reassured me. I thought that I had carefully researched all the criteria and ranges for these issues...but, then again, I had to realize that he is one of Johns Hopkins top researchers, and probably peer-reviewed those articles I had read. I am mentioning this because, at some point, you and I and other well-intentioned forum members simply have to stop relying only on our knowledge, and defer to those in the business. Have a good meal and some wine. Good luck at your appointment.

Posts.Title: Struggling with course of treatment decision?

Posts.Content: These various tests are run at different times in the diagnostic cycle. PSA, Free PSA. PHI (which includes PSA and Free PSA plus a PCa biomarker), 4K Score, PCA3, and SelectMDX are all done BEFORE a biopsy to help determine if one may be necessary. OncotypeDX, Prolaris, ConfirmMDX, and Decipher are all run AFTER a biopsy to determine the genomic aggressiveness of the cancer samples found. That is done to help determine what, if any, treatment may be recommended. Hope this helps.

Posts.Title: Other PSA testing options - list needed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ejc61 Thanks. Your comment PIRADS v.2. Is that version 2? Is that a separate thing from version 1 or do you just mean PIRADS 4 and 5? I guess my head is not clear at the moment. My thought is that while in the past, I've been told that one can be on AS without being on a "technical" Program. I would think that there has to be some common ground so that I can be actively monitored yet maybe figure a way around the timing of future biopsies. My AS Study Program has me for a repeat in 2019 and then in 2021. I believe my regular Uro thought if nothing changes, possibly doing my next biopsy in 2020. Is this significant at this point? I'm not sure. I'll expect my call later on today. PIRADS v.2 is version 2, which is a different, improved, library of software than version 1. PIRADS scores of 1-5 are the grading system applied to areas that appear suspicious, and how likely they are to have significant cancer if the the prostate were to be remove and analyzed. Those areas (lesions) can be targeted in subsequent biopsies. AS programs are becoming more flexible about the scheduling of biopsies. You need to keep talking with your specialists, and maybe they will do alternative testing.

Posts.Content: Big Sky, There are also genomics tests (more all the time, it seems) that can be run using the slides from the post-op pathology. These will note certain genetic markers in the cancer that can predict the level of aggressiveness and likelihood to spread. You are perfectly right to question the treatment and guidance that you have received. As the others have suggested, please obtain and post here as much of the pathology report as you can. Information is power, and there is a lot of experience and knowledge here to try to assist you.

Posts.Title: Greetings

Posts.Content: With a strong family history and 6/14 cores positive, moving to treatment is the right step. Since this has been a concern for several years, I trust that he and you have familiariizied yourselves with all the available treatment options. There are three types of surgery, and five type of radiation therapies available. All can cure your husband. The differences are in the number and severity of sessions, and also in the long term side effects. Take your time, and consult with the various specialists to be as comfortable as possible with the treatment decision you make, A word of advice is not to let a urologist speak for radiology, and vice versa. Consult directly with those who provide a certain service. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Father recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Sandy, a free psa of 33 is excellent, and a good indicator that you do not have PCa. Either a 4K or a PHI test should be next. Some people will tell you that biopsies are no big deal, that was the case with three of mine. But, two caused pain that lasted for months, and temporarily tripled my psa. Do not take biopsies lightly. If you have a small amount of low-risk cancer, I would caution you not to give in to a "get it out" reaction. You need to carefully read about the side effects of treatments, which often have seriously negative impacts on one's quality of life. Your doctor sounds like he is giving you great advice. Try not to think too far ahead until you know more.

Posts.Title: To biopsy or not

Posts.Content: I don't buy that advice. My recent advice from Johns Hopkins was "Yes, you are stable at this time. Please make an appointment for six months from now. Remember, Active Surveillance only works if it is 'active'" I'll be 74 by then, and they aren't letting up on monitoring me, although there has been no mention of a biopsy for several years. I firmly believe that testing should go on past 70. I run, hike, jet ski, dance a lot, and enjoy life with my gf. Please don't call guys over 70 "old". I still fully celebrate life, while some men I know were "old" at 30

Posts.Title: Looks like old guys over 70 do not have to worry about death from PC

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ejc61 Thanks. Your comment PIRADS v.2. Is that version 2? Is that a separate thing from version 1 or do you just mean PIRADS 4 and 5? I guess my head is not clear at the moment. My thought is that while in the past, I've been told that one can be on AS without being on a "technical" Program. I would think that there has to be some common ground so that I can be actively monitored yet maybe figure a way around the timing of future biopsies. My AS Study Program has me for a repeat in 2019 and then in 2021. I believe my regular Uro thought if nothing changes, possibly doing my next biopsy in 2020. Is this significant at this point? I'm not sure. I'll expect my call later on today. PIRADS v.2 is version 2, which is a different, improved, library of software than version 1. PIRADS scores of 1-5 are the grading system applied to areas that appear suspicious, and how likely they are to have significant cancer if the the prostate were to be remove and analyzed. Those areas (lesions) can be targeted in subsequent biopsies. AS programs are becoming more flexible about the scheduling of biopsies. You need to keep talking with your specialists, and maybe they will do alternative testing.

Posts.Title: re: confirmatory biopsy 4/19/18 snag

Posts.Content: Duck2, You are going through a lot of decisions and emotion right now, and I hesitate to ask this....but, if you are having surgery, but are also pretty certain that you will require radiation to finally kill the cancer, why are you subjecting yourself to the side effects of two treatments? You don't have a signature, so I don't know your staging. But. if you are high risk, the recent studies show that a triple play combo of IMRT + BBT + ADT have the highest non-recurrence rates. Yes, more things to check out, but better to do that now than question your choices after the fact. https://pcnrv.blogspot.com/2018/03/b...ry-extend.html Best wishes to you.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F We all look forward to the advancements in liquid biopsies and imaging technologies that will detect PC (and a whole spectrum of other CA) before clinical significance is reached. MF Yes, that's the only way to bring the "overtreatment" debate to a close. I fully understand that the 2012 panel was trying to prevent unnecessary worry, biopsies, and men with indolent cases being rushed into surgery. There are now several alternatives/augmentations to psa tests, and more are coming down the pipeline. Some look to have VERY high confidence levels, but they aren't on the market today. When they are, and are accepted, hopefully within the next 5 to 10 years, we can put these concerns to rest. For now, psa testing, with all its flaws, is absolutely better than no testing at all.
