Posts.Content: KJ, There is a new study out regarding the association of heredity and the aggressiveness of prostate cancer. While your risk of getting PCa is twice that of someone else, any cancer that you get would not necessarily be aggressive. "Researchers found no relationship between family history and several prostate cancer biomarkers associated with tumor aggressiveness, for example. This suggested that family history does not increase the risk of prostate cancer aggressiveness." https://prostatecancernewstoday.com/...ggressiveness/

Posts.Content: The overwhelming prevalence of radiation therapy was a surprise to me. A key quote: "radiation therapy was the most common treatment at 58 percent, followed by radical prostatectomy (a surgical procedure to remove the prostate) at 19 percent. Other treatments trailed at 10 percent, including watchful waiting (where doctors wait and see if cancer progresses before treating it) and active surveillance (when patients undergo routine biopsies, blood tests and MRI to determine if cancer is progressing and undergo active treatment)." http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases...0219160434.htm

Posts.Title: Interesting Statistics on Prostate Cancer Treatment Options

Posts.Content: Chris, Calm down. You've gotten way ahead of the known facts in your situation. As Chuck has pointed out, your data is far below what would be expected for advanced prostate cancer. At this point, all that needs to be done is to determine if you possibly have any actual prostate cancer. The MRI is an excellent idea, as it will allow the doctor doing the biopsy to precisely target any suspicious areas of your prostate. And, if you DO have some PCa, only a minority of cases are high-risk. Prostate cancer has a spectrum of risk classifications, and perhaps half or more of the cases will never be life threatening. The number of men newly diagnosed with PCa every year is eight times the number of men who die from that disease. Those statistics should help relax you. Follow your doctor's advice and try to enjoy life without letting your fear get ahead of what is known. Good Luck.

I had a X-ray on my back was giving me more pain than usual and was told I had it in my spine and pelvis, went for my blood check up a few days ago told them and they said it was in most of my bones from the early scan when diagnosed 20 months ago, at the time I was only told it was in my shoulder which I had RT on and my upper rib. To say I was taken back was an understatement, I go for an MRI tonight on my back see if there's any damage. My PSA is still very low at 0.07 a slight rise from 0.04 with all my organs still in good shape although liver very slightly higher but still within normal range. Thanks for looking if you have any info would be grateful Joe Possibly Nanoknife (irreversible electroporation) would qualify, as it uses electric pulses to destroy tumors. It is now approved for treating pancreatic cancer.

Posts.Content: One important data item is missing. Was the Gleason score of 7 a (3+4) or a (4+3)? That changes your Grade Group from 2 to 3 if it is the latter score. Still, I would be starting to look at treatment options if I had that report. As there are three types of surgery, six types of radiation, and another six or seven assorted prostate cancer treatments available, that research can take some time. Luckily, time is not an urgency for you.
Posts.Title: Biopsy Results - 2x Gleason 7 +. Need some help.

Posts.Content: A prophylactic prostatectomy is a very radical step. I've only heard of one other case, where the man was motivated by the same fears. But, from what I have read, while the propensity of near relatives to get PCa is known, the Gleason grade and staging are not correlated among the family. So, you COULD get PCa, but it might not be life-threatening. What testing have you had done, besides this genomic assay? What has been your psa history, and MRI results? Prostate size, any biopsies? I get where you are coming from, but suggest that you know a lot more about your present prostate analytics before taking such a drastic course.

Posts.Title: genome tested, lots of badness

Posts.Content: With a strong family history and 6/14 cores positive, moving to treatment is the right step. Since this has been a concern for several years, I trust that he and you have familiariizied yourselves with all the available treatment options. There are three types of surgery, and five type of radiation therapies available. All can cure your husband. The differences are in the number and severity of sessions, and also in the long term side effects. Take your time, and consult with the various specialists to be as comfortable as possible with the treatment decision you make, A word of advice is not to let a urologist speak for radiology, and vice versa. Consult directly with those who provide a certain service. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Interesting how my GPs approach Prostate and other cancers

Posts.Content: Three of my five biopsies were no problem, and two resulted in pain, tripling of my PSA, and inflammation lasting for six months. The only thing that stopped the inflammation were sitz baths. So much for high-tech meds! If I were you, I would avoid any more biopsies unless you have an MRI with one or more PIRADS v.2 grade 4 or 5 lesions. But, that's only my opinion, and your doctors have suggested a plan that sounds as safe as they can try to make it. Hopefully this biopsy will show no change, or even less cancer. Good luck.

Posts.Title: 9-year survival differences: aggressive vs. conservative treatment for advanced PC

Posts.Content: If I had a core with 40% of pattern 4, I would plan on a treatment. That said, you have time to make a decision that you can be comfortable with. Some men prefer what they assume is the finality of surgery. Regrettably, quite a few of them seem to be back online the next year asking about salvage RT. Some men advocate for focal therapies that target and destroy imaged lesions. But, minimal side effects matter little if the cancer keeps coming back. My readings bias me towards SBRT or HDRT-BT, two types of specifically targeted high-dosage radiation. They are actually designed to provide about the same toxicity to the cancer cells, but one therapy is external, and the other internal, to the body. One treatment I would advise that you look at would be proton beam therapy. I know, up to now its been expensive, required 44 sessions, and not shown superior results. But, some recent exchanges I have had with PBT advocates state that they are reducing the number of sessions to five, just like SBRT, and these advocates (I've now counted about a dozen of them online) are all claiming ZERO side effects, with no recurrences. That's worth checking out. As above, you have the time to get this right.

Posts.Title: Meeting with the URO next Friday for TX options

Posts.Content: Caddy, As your doctor advised, you don't need to be in any rush to make a decision. Every treatment technique that I can think of has undergone almost day-and-night changes over the past 20 years. So, advice on outcomes and side effects has to be as current as possible, as the old stories and statistics aren't applicable to those treated today. On the surgery side, robotics are now close to 90 percent of the operations. The small incisions, faster recovery times, and precision accuracy would seem to be tremendous improvements over open RP. But, all the scholarly studies I've seen keep saying that the patient outcomes have not changed, and that the skill of the surgeon is more important than the method. On the radiation side, there have recently been reported improvements in both the outcomes and side effects. This is happening as the technologies evolve to fewer sessions and more precise focusing and tracking. SBRT/Cyberknife and HDR monotherapy are the methods receiving the most notice for fewer cancer recurrences and also fewer and lower toxicity side effects. There are advocates for Proton beam, HIFU, FLA, and Cryotherapy. Their supporters can be adamant, but don't have the statistics (yet), in my opinion. You will likely receive some great advice on this thread. Please read them all carefully.

Often, In the USA, they will attack this with a triple play of hormone therapy, external beam radiation, and High Dose Bracytherapy, with a potential for a curative result. If they have ruled out distant metastasis, by using PET or similar imaging, then there is hope that the cancer can be cured. If not, there has been great progress in managing the disease for many years, while more research may lead to a cure for all stages.

Posts.Title: Distraught daughter looking for help & clarification

Posts.Content: My suggestion is that you have a genomics test, either OncotypeDX, Prolaris, SelectMDX, or Decipher performed on your positive biopsy slides that were taken in February. That would give you some measure of how aggressive the cancer is. Why do men choose radiation or surgery? That topic is like the old Ford vs Chevy debate. Each has its supporters, and each has arguments and counter-arguments. I would suggest that you attend some local support groups, where men who have had those treatments will share their experiences and opinions. Also, some PCa forums tend to attract people with strong opinions on one side or the other. So Google "prostate cancer forums" to check out the spectrum of discussions.

Posts.Title: Rising PSA and decisions to make

Posts.Content: If I had a core with 40% of pattern 4, I would plan on a treatment. That said, you have time to make a decision that you can be comfortable with. Some men prefer what they assume is the finality of surgery. Regrettably, quite a few of them seem to be back online the next year asking about salvage RT. Some men advocate for focal therapies that target and destroy imaged lesions. But, minimal side effects matter little if the cancer keeps coming back. My readings bias me towards SBRT or HDRT-BT, two types of specifically targeted high-dosage radiation. They are actually designed to provide about the same toxicity to the cancer cells, but one therapy is external, and the other internal, to the body. One treatment I would advise that you look at would be proton beam therapy. I know, up to now its been expensive, required 44 sessions, and not shown superior results. But, some recent exchanges I have had with PBT advocates state that they are reducing the number of sessions to five, just like SBRT, and these advocates (I've now counted about a dozen of them online) are all claiming ZERO side effects, with no recurrences. That's worth checking out. As above, you have the time to get this right.

Posts.Content: Thanks, Dijin. There are some sites where Focal Therapy has an almost cult-like following, so this is a sober read. One of the conclusions states that active surveillance is the preferred treatment for low-risk men, who were most of those involved in these studies. That removes most of the arguments in favor of FT. as these men probably never should have had FT. There is a new type of HIFU, which its advocates say is far superior. But, as always, claims and studies run years apart, so there is no way to judging if it will be really valuable, or not.

Posts.Title: Distraught daughter looking for help & clarification

Posts.Content: Hi Ha, Welcome the forum. Hopefully, the biopsy will be clear (about 65 percent of new biopsies are), and you won't have to be here long. Your uro is doing standard practice protocol. Initial biopsies are usually done with US, although there is much discussion that a prior MRI would lead to more specific targeting of suspect areas. Please try not to think too far ahead. We all have been guilty of that. You only need to be concerned if cancer is found on the biopsy slides. But, keep in mind, that prostate cancers run the spectrum from indolent to aggressive. I was diagnosed eight years ago, and so far it appears to be indolent, and not needing treatment. A different diagnosis could lead to having to research and choose from a menu of treatments. But, again, that's getting ahead of what you know. When you receive the post-biopsy lab report (if any cancer is found), then try to paste as much of the report's findings as possible. That would allow us to provide you with informed opinions for your consideration. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Father recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: I attended a local support group last year where the chief urologist of a large hospital made a slide presentation of the data that supported the 2012 USPTF guidelines. I think that only perhaps 2 out of 1,000 men who were randomly psa tested were saved from an early death from PCa. There was a lot of data graphics in this presentation. Now, here we have a guy who does RP's for a living making a defense for no psa testing. Well, he did it to show us that there was a strong case to be made against over treatment, which was a driving force 10 years ago. Now, as he discussed with us, things have changed. He counsels his G6 patients to go into AS, for example. While there is still a concern that urologists in small practices will still push patients into unnecessary treatment, that trend is sharply decreasing. It was an interesting and lively discussion. I'm glad that I was diagnosed, and am aware of my status. I see the overtreatment issue as one of doctors' advice (motivated by greed or firm belief), not of diagnostics. This is improving year by year.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 With all due respect, as usual, I probably fall into the category of Devil's Advocate. The discussion seems centered on testing, testing, testing. My take is this: why the hell is ANYONE talking about testing when -- as Chuck pointed out -- the patient has ALREADY been CONFIRMED to have prostate cancer. Instead of worrying whether something bad is going on with a constantly rising PSA -- "What should I do? What should I do?", to me, the answer is rudimentary: get it the hell out of there and let post-surgery pathology figure out what's actually in there. If I was the patient, with two brothers with PC, I would be shopping this morning at Wal-Mart for a robe and slippers for my overnight hospital stay following surgery. But I guess I'm just a crazy old man. Sorry, Jim, I somehow managed to miss his stating that he had a previous positive biopsy. Not sure that surgery is the best solution, but you are correct that his case is beyond testing for the existence of cancer.

Posts.Title: Negative Biopsies but rapidly rising PSA

Posts.Content: A "concerning area" on a ultrasound could be hemorrhage, inflammation, atypical cells, HGPIN, or something benign. It could be cancer, but the odds are that is something else until proven to be cancer. I had two bad experiences with biopsies, so they are not risk-free. Another test that can provide useful data is PHI, which is less influenced by inflammation than psa alone. It is a simple blood test. At this point, I think that you should not have a biopsy unless an mp-MRI indicates a significant possibility of cancer. Good luck.

I won't frighten you with tales of my two "bad" biopsies, just be aware that they are not risk-free, and should be avoided unless really necessary.

Posts.Title: 65 Years Old Male PSA 12, DRE feels hardness on the right side, waiting for biopsy

Posts.Content: A prophylactic prostatectomy is a very radical step. I've only heard of one other case, where the man was motivated by the same fears. But, from what I have read, while the propensity of near relatives to get PCa is known, the Gleason grade and staging are not correlated among the family. So, you COULD get PCa, but it might not be life-threatening. What testing have you had done, besides this genomic assay? What has been your psa history, and MRI results? Prostate size, any biopsies? I get where you are coming from, but suggest that you know a lot more about your present prostate analytics before taking such a drastic course.

Posts.Title: genome tested, lots of badness

Posts.Content: I did see some references to Mulhall's book a few years ago, but not since then. Any book dealing with sexual effects from prostate cancer treatment that was written ten years ago would, IMHO, not have much value today. That's because of all the emphasis on penile rehab that exists now, but not then. And, from what I have read, his expertise is in dealing with the after effects of RP. But, now there are impressive studies showing the efficacy and low side effects of certain RT therapies such as SBRT and Proton beam. So, even with better rehab practices, RP is not your only option. So, my two cents worth of advice would be to skip this outdated book.

Posts.Title: Decision made to go with MD Anderson instead of Urologist who diagnosed.....

Posts.Content: Excellent points, Terry. Yes, the changes in radiation technology and possibilities are moving faster than the insurers can adjust. Medicare and insurance companies want lengthy periods of proven performance, and the radiations guys are seeing such positive results with small samples that they want to keep leapfrogging ahead. I recently have heard and read that IMRT can be done in as few as 10 or 12 sessions, and SBRT in 1. ONE! The major obstacle is the payment puzzle. Is this a reality to make happen now, or optimistic arrogance and gambling by the radiologists pushing it? That answer is surely above my pay grade, but you can bet that more studies will be posted soon, and the debate will be in full swing.

Posts.Title: Are we moving in the right direction (aggressive PC diagnosis)

Posts.Content: Gleason 3+3 does not metastasize, there is almost no evidence of it turning more aggressive, and several top experts are arguing that it should not even be classified as cancer. Now, the issue is: Can there also be other, more aggressive cells, that the biopsy missed? We don't know that after one biopsy. To have a degree of confidence, you would need a 3T mp-MRI and a fusion biopsy to confirm, as best as possible, that all you have is the low risk Gleason 6. Please do not be rushed into treatment that you may not need. Ever. You are at the beginning of learning about your situation. Prostate cancer is not the same as "CANCER"! Far more men with PCa will die of something else. Like 85-90 percent of them. Remember that. Keep asking and learning and becoming your own advocate. Good luck.

Posts.Title: 48 y/o Newbie

Posts.Content: I have been trying for years to get an authoritative answer to the question "how high can psa rise for benign reasons". So far, no answer. But, from friends, and my own experiences with spikes, I would guess up to 12. Maybe a bit beyond, but not above 20. So. you are at the edge of your psa still being caused by non-cancer issues. Don't panic. You are doing the right thing, with one of the best doctors. Maybe you should just chill. If you are really strung out about it, and that's just a factor of personalties, there is a new enhanced MRI feature called RSI (restricted spectrum imaging) that is being touted at UC-san Diego as being significantly more precise and predictive than 3T mpMRI. You could contact them and go there. If I were you, I'd chill...for now.

Posts.Title: Wish me luck... Please!

Posts.Content: Yes, it is possible for an MRI to not show any cancer lesions although cancer was found on biopsy. It is also common for a biopsy to find no cancer in areas seen as probable cancer on an MRI. The 3Tesla multi-parametric MRI's are the best ones, and, if he had one of those, and no suspicious areas were seen, then it is probably a good indication that he has only a tiny amount of low/intermediate risk cancer, and does not need to rush into treatment. He may want to research active surveillance as a possible course of action.

Posts.Content: Another form of treatment for bloated prostates is prostatic artery embolization (PAE). Two hospitals in my area are now advertising it. A radiologist I met socially told me that it reduces prostate size by 85 percent, and his practice is very pleased with their results. But, you have PCa, and I'm not sure what the advice is for using TURP, PAE, Urolift, etc. in cases where the patient has diagnosed cancer.

Posts.Title: Urolift

Posts.Content: What was the PIRADS score of that 12mm lesion on the MRI? Have there been blood tests, such as PHI, 4K Score, SelectMDx, or genomics tests on the biopsy slides like Prolaris, OncotypeDX, or ConfirmMDX? For a urologist to be talking about a prostatecomy when no evidence of cancer has been found, cannot be justified. ASAP is not cancer, does not merit any intervention. One of my suggestions would be for you to consult with other specialists.

Posts.Title: biopsy psa and ASAP

Posts.Content: Glad, Many men would love to have that biopsy path report. PIRADS 4 is simply a higher liklihood of cancer, it does not mean that the lesion is cancer. There are at least six other benign causes that I could cite that can cause a PIRADS 4 score. I had an MRI that reported a PIRADS 4 lesion, but then when they upgraded the equipment to PIRADS 2.0, the next report concluded that same lesion was a 3. So, nothing is written in stone. Two questions: (1) what is the size of your prostate? The MRI should have that measurement; And, (2) has your psa been steadily rising, or, has it "peaked and valleyed" over the years.

Posts.Title: biopsy psa and ASAP

Posts.Content: If I had a core with 40% of pattern 4, I would plan on a treatment. That said, you have time to make a decision that you can be comfortable with. Some men prefer what they assume is the finality of surgery. Regrettably, quite a few of them seem to be back online the next year asking about salvage RT. Some men advocate for focal therapies that target and destroy imaged lesions. But, minimal side effects matter little if the cancer keeps coming back. My readings bias me towards SBRT or HDRT-BT, two types of specifically targeted high-dosage radiation. They are actually designed to provide about the same toxicity to the cancer cells, but one therapy is external, and the other internal, to the body. One treatment I would advise that you look at would be proton beam therapy. I know, up to now its been expensive, required 44 sessions, and not shown superior results. But, some recent exchanges I have had with PBT advocates state that they are reducing the number of sessions to five, just like SBRT, and these advocates (I've now counted about a dozen of them online) are all claiming ZERO side effects, with no recurrences. That's worth checking out. As above, you have the time to get this right.

Posts.Title: Meeting with the URO next Friday for TX options

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by TxMommy As you can see from my signature his Gleason score is at a 8. So as another user in the forum said we really have no time for second opinions. BUT we just received notification today that insurance approved the bone scan so we already are having to wait on that. Our appointment now with the urologist at MD Anderson is Tuesday. Certainly you need to choose an intervention, and doing it soonest is the best course. But, if you have an opportunity for another opinion within a few weeks, and you feel that you want it, then I would suggest that you do it. Acting promptly is required, acting immediately (like this week)...probably not.

Posts.Title: Decision made to go with MD Anderson instead of Urologist who diagnosed.....

Posts.Content: He will need treatment, although taking a few months to evaluate the options will probably not change the odds. Either surgery or radiation can likely eradicate his cancer. The best thing that he can do is NOT to follow any attempt by the first doctor to rush him into a particular type of treatment. All treatments have some types of side effects, and you need to spend weeks or months learning about them. Most of all, consult with both urologists (surgeons) and radiation oncologists. Do NOT let one describe the other, as they are often biased and out-of-date on treatments they do not provide. There is a big learning curve ahead, but his odds are good.

This has been available in Canada for several years, and costs about a quarter of what Pfizer's Viagra brand does, while being the exact same thing. BTW, if you are in Canada, you can get a sildenafil rx from a walk-in clinic and take it to a Costco for a huge savings versus buying Viagra in the USA now.

Posts.Title: biopsy psa and ASAP

Posts.Content: Ron_G, The JH criterion of unilateral PCa for their AS program is a recent finding. Probably within the the past 18 months. Dr. Epstein analyzed recent data to see if his 1994 criteria were still valid, and the result was that bilateral involvement was more important than the number of cores or the percentage of a core. However, I think that only the percentage factor was downplayed in the updated guidelines.

Posts.Title: Updated new articles regarding the use of AS as a option

Posts.Content: The background articles state that this has been demonstrated in vitro, which is test-tube level work. Not yet even in human gene-modified mice. So, while I share the sentiment that this has all been heard before, and that scientists have created indestructible test tubes and immortal mice...I also have to appreciate that yet another basic layer of cancer complexity has been uncovered and perhaps understood. That is progress, and progress in defeating cancer is welcome, even if its benefits are years, or even decades, down the road.

Posts.Title: Have they FINALLY found it??

Posts.Content: To address your original question about supplements, I did have a conversation with my specialist, who is a Professor of Urology, Oncology, and Pathology at Johns Hopkins School of Medicine. He did not recommend taking supplements to manipulate the psa, but we went over what I have been ingesting for many years. His comments: Green tea extract - fine Pomegranate extract - fine Aspirin (since 1985) - highly recommended Atorvastatin (since 1998 - good, protective Atenolol (since 1980) - good, protective Losartan (since 1995) - good protective wild blueberries (cup) - can't hurt The conversation just included my regular regimen, and I did not ask about Metformin or other drugs that might be helpful in retarding PCa. I will the next time.

Posts.Title: Finding the right doctor for 3T MRI + question on lycopene

Posts.Content: "The increase could be because the disease is becoming more aggressive, or it could be because there is less screening being done, but we don't know why," said lead researcher Dr. Edward Schaeffer. He is chair of urology at Northwestern University's Feinberg School of Medicine in Chicago." While I am totally in favor of psa testing, this quote is potentially worrisome, because he mentions that the disease itself may be coming more aggressive. That would be far more challenging to deal with than revising the task force recommendation to test everyone again. Time will tell, but I sure hope that we are not facing new variants of PCa.

Posts.Title: 3 month post HDRBT blood work results

Posts.Content: Bradb, As in Chuck's case, many men do not have any incontinence issues after RP. Some do, and it's very hard to get solid statistics on how many. I've seen numbers from single digits to over 35 percent. Surgeons report glowing results, and some men appear not to want to be honest about their situations, at least in personal interviews. Men have two urinary sphincters, an external one (like females), and an internal one that is removed during prostatectomy. The internal one is also responsible for preventing urine flow during ejaculation. I attended a lecture by a prominent RALP surgeon who made a point of stating that the loss of the internal sphincter will weaken urine control. In contrast, men still have both sphincters following radiation. Still, studies show about 10 percent have some incontinence issues three years later. Now, incontinence after RT is not the same as after RP. With RP, men can have stress incontinence, where they leak when coughing, laughing, lifting, etc. This is not typical of RT, where men could have urgency incontinence. In those cases, irritation of the urinary tract causes frequent urination, which can be annoying. Radiation advocates will claim that "incontinence is almost non-existent" following RT. They are only partially correct, as that may mostly be true for avoiding full loss of control following primary RT, but there are still urinary issues for some men. As others have noted, you have a highly curable case. The SEER database of 400,000 PCa patients shows that newly diagnosed men are choosing surgery, radiation, and active surveillance is equal numbers. There are three types of surgery (ORP, LRP, RALP), at least five types of radiation (IMRT, SBRT, LDR-BT, HDR-BT, PBT), and many other types of treatments (HIFU, FLA, Cryo, VTP), ALL of which can cure your G7 prostate cancer. That last group of focal treatments will claim NO urinary side effects, but they don't have a long history of results in curing the cancer. So, take your time and investigate your options. One piece of advice would be not to take the opinions of a specialist in one area about other treatments, as they often don't know much about the other, and tend to promote their own. Stayed tuned, and let us know what questions you are having. Good luck.

That last group of focal treatments will claim NO urinary side effects, but they don't have a long history of results in curing the cancer. So, take your time and investigate your options. One piece of advice would be not to take the opinions of a specialist in one area about other treatments, as they often don't know much about the other, and tend to promote their own. Stayed tuned, and let us know what questions you are having. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Medicinal Oils

Posts.Content: You can drive yourself to drink pondering all the many forms of intervention for the small amount of prostate cancer that you have. But, at age 51, getting it out and over with probably makes the most sense. Being twenty years older than you, I am comfortable with AS, or doing Focal Laser Ablation or cryotherapy if things got worse. But, for you, a lot can happen in twenty years, and you probably want the assurance that the cancer has been dealt with in as final a manner as possible. Cyberknife, like Proton Therapy, has its supporters, but the verdicts aren't really in, or not clearly superior, at this time. To my knowledge, you are seeing the top PCa specialist in the world. My guy works for/with him. Follow his advice. You can't do better than that.

Posts.Title: Treatment question, before this makes me crazy!!! Cyberknife vs. surgery?

Posts.Content: Recently speaking with a radiation oncologist at a support group, I was surprised to learn that his university facility uses the same equipment for IMRT and SBRT. I had thought that SBRT required equipment supplied by Cyberknife or Varian. Not the case. The same LINAC's used for conventional radiation can also be used for SBRT. Just a matter of setup. Always something to learn.

Keep in mind that Pfizer's patent on Viagra expires on December 11, 2017, and that prices will likely fall by 70 percent or more at that time. Posts.Title: New Technique has Potential to Improve Surgery Outcomes

Posts.Content: Djin, Thanks for this. It helps to further flesh out the facts regarding radiation as a primary treatment, and what is possible if it fails? From what I thought I read, The various non-surgical salvage treatments have a composite 5 year non-BCR rate of 64 percent. That ranges from cryo at 54 percent to BT at 69. The study also notes that salvage RP after RT has a 5 year non-BCR range from 47 to 82 percent, which would give a composite score of about 64 percent, equal to the non-surgical treatments. So, if you have RT, and need salvage treatment of any type, your chances of being BCR-free 5 years later is roughly 64 percent. So, while this is, of course, spaceship to earth level analysis, what is the comparable 5 year non-BCR percentage following RP and then SRT? That question seems to come up frequently in various "have to make a decision" threads. I know that every case has many, many different variables (ADT, etc.), but some overall framework of comparison is useful.

Posts.Title: Dad has been diagnosed with prostate cancer - can use some help

Posts.Content: Bradb, As in Chuck's case, many men do not have any incontinence issues after RP. Some do, and it's very hard to get solid statistics on how many. I've seen numbers from single digits to over 35 percent. Surgeons report glowing results, and some men appear not to want to be honest about their situations, at least in personal interviews. Men have two urinary sphincters, an external one (like females), and an internal one that is removed during prostatectomy. The internal one is also responsible for preventing urine flow during ejaculation. I attended a lecture by a prominent RALP surgeon who made a point of stating that the loss of the internal sphincter will weaken urine control. In contrast, men still have both sphincters following radiation. Still, studies show about 10 percent have some incontinence issues three years later. Now, incontinence after RT is not the same as after RP. With RP, men can have stress incontinence, where they leak when coughing, laughing, lifting, etc. This is not typical of RT, where men could have urgency incontinence. In those cases, irritation of the urinary tract causes frequent urination, which can be annoying. Radiation advocates will claim that "incontinence is almost non-existent" following RT. They are only partially correct, as that may mostly be true for avoiding full loss of control following primary RT, but there are still urinary issues for some men. As others have noted, you have a highly curable case. The SEER database of 400,000 PCa patients shows that newly diagnosed men are choosing surgery, radiation, and active surveillance is equal numbers. There are three types of surgery (ORP, LRP, RALP), at least five types of radiation (IMRT, SBRT, LDR-BT, HDR-BT, PBT), and many other types of treatments (HIFU, FLA, Cryo, VTP), ALL of which can cure your G7 prostate cancer. That last group of focal treatments will claim NO urinary side effects, but they don't have a long history of results in curing the cancer. So, take your time and investigate your options. One piece of advice would be not to take the opinions of a specialist in one area about other treatments, as they often don't know much about the other, and tend to promote their own. Stayed tuned, and let us know what questions you are having. Good luck.

Posts.Content: I think that there have only been rare cases of a cell mutating. Johns Hopkins had a bulletin a couple of years ago stating that they had found one or two cases out of several thousand where it appeared that a cell actually genetically changed to a higher grade. The usual findings are that OTHER cells can emerge that have the higher grade. That doesn't mean that they will emerge, just that they developed separately.

Posts.Title: With apologies....

Posts.Content: Djin, Thank you very much for posting these new guidelines. There are two points that stood out for me, and may settle long-running debates about qualifications for low-risk men, and also the primacy of AS as the choice of treatment for those men: 1) "Very Low Risk PSA <10 ng/ml AND Grade Group 1 AND clinical stage T1-T2a AND <34% of biopsy cores positive AND no core with >50% involved, AND PSA density <0.15 ng/ml/cc. " This is a serious change, as it supercedes the old Epstein criteria of "no more than two positive cores". That finding goes back to the 1990's and was based on six core biopsies. Now, with this new criteria, a man can have FOUR positive cores out of 12, and still be "very low risk". 2) "7. Clinicians should recommend active surveillance as the best available care option for very low risk localized prostate cancer patients. (Strong Recommendation; Evidence Level: Grade A)" This places AS as the default treatment option for those men described in point 1). This guideline should (hope/pray) discourage what overtreatment pressure may still be applied by some doctors. All good. Great work, Djin.

Maybe sometime in the near future some less invasive test can replace biopsies, but, for now, your doctor is correct.

Posts.Title: Advice for Newbie concerning prostrate MRI

Posts.Content: Jeromelo, From what little I know, it appears that you have bilateral low risk prostate cancer. My case is something similar, but I was much older when diagnosed, so my options and choice may be not be the same as yours. You are not in a position where you need to act quickly, but you might start researching all the treatment options available, and their side effects. Newer options like Focal Laser Ablation, and the trials of immune therapy treatments, which promise fewer side effects, may be attractive to you. Also, try to have some additional tests run, like the PHI and/or 4K Score blood tests, the PCA3 urine test, and, especially, the OncotypeDX and/or Prolaris tests on your biopsy sldes. The purpose of those tests in to try to predict if your cancer is likely to be aggressive, or not. That type of information is what you need right now.

Posts.Title: Treatment question, before this makes me crazy!!! Cyberknife vs. surgery?

Posts.Content: Jigger, You are doing the best possible course of action by seeking all the opinions and advice you need for your choice of treatment. I have read in many articles that the long term survival rates are the same for surgery and radiation, but that the side effects happen in different time phases. The side effects of surgery are immediate, and things usually improve with time. With radiation, the issues of incontinence and impotence may not be significant when you finish the therapy, but then the radiation seeps further, and those side effects may appear after a year or two. So, the two therapies sort of equal out. Many of the posters on this forum are glad that they did surgery, as the removed prostate can be fully assessed and that gives them peace of mind. I also do some hiking, and relieving yourself behind a tree in the woods is not an issue with other hikers, especially if they are about your age. Good Luck with your consultations.
Posts.Signature: DOB: May 1944 In Active Surveillance program at Johns Hopkins Strict protocol of tests, including PHI, DRE, MRI, and biopsy. Six biopsies from 2009 to 2019. Posts.Title: Treatment decision time.

Posts.Content: Tim, There was a big study released about a year ago by Dr. Laurence Klotz of Sunnybrook Medical in Toronto. He has been running a large active surveillance program since the 1990's. Unlike Johns Hopkins, the Sunnybrook program had looser criteria, and admitted men with Gleason 3+4. Their long term results on AS were not encouraging, as shown in this summary: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27569437

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Here is one news report, which also says: "... For patients who don't fall into these risk categories, fluoroquinolones may still be a good option. They have been helping patients with bacterial infections for more than 30 years. ... In July, the agency sent a notice that these drugs may significantly decrease blood sugar and negatively impact mental health. In 2016, the FDA said that the drugs may have a disabling side effect on muscles, nerves, joints and the central nervous system and should be restricted for use in some simpler infections." I would point out that some studies have shown that the post-biopsy sepsis rate can be drastically reduced by washing the biopsy needle in a disinfectant between cores -- isopropyl alcohol being perhaps the safest and most efficacious. My uro uses this (plus antibiotics) and says he hasn't had a case of sepsis since he started. He also fears some of the other compounds some uros are using are perhaps too strong: the effect of their contact with tissue isn't know. One study I came across with a large number of men had a sepsis rate of 0 in the antibiotics + alcohol washing cohort. Thank you very much, Djin, I am facing a sixth biopsy simply because Dr. Carter runs the strictest AS program on the planet, and I am really concerned about sepsis since two of my past biopsies caused long term pain. Knowing this information about the alcohol cleansing, I may decide to challenge the plan for the next biopsy, or not have it, and risk moving to another program. We will see. This point will be raised and discussed.

Posts.Title: Treatment decision time.

Posts.Content: A study of the long term side effects of both prostate surgery and radiation can be found here. http://www.cancernetwork.com/prostat...gery-radiation Now, the conclusion that the functional decline for both therapy groups is similar after 15 years is probably not what is most important to many men, as the 2 year and 5 year rates of incontinence were significantly higher in the prostatectomy group. Also, the cases go back to the early 1990's, and both therapies have seen improvement since then. Thanks to Otaga and lancepeace for their comments and the need for further clarification.

Posts.Content: Chuck, The cells can morph to a higher grade. I have read comments from Klotz, Carter, and Epstein to that effect. But, it is extremely rare. I think that between JH and Sunnybrook's AS programs, they had maybe 3 or 4 cases, which was about one in a thousand. So, technically, yes, it has been proven by DNA, but, practically, it is very, very unlikely.

Posts.Content: Pratoman, In the long run, we're all dead. No sense worrying about how or when unless you are on your back and gasping. You are very conscious of your mortality, and you admit that, and want to talk about it. That's all good. So your trivial pursuits like Seinfeld, are worthwhile in that they help distract you and allow you some relaxation. At least, you understand your situation, which gives you an edge in controlling it. One warning about Zoloft. A female friend of mine took it for a couple of years about 20 years ago. All her hair fell out, and never came back. That is a known, but rarely occurring side effect of Zoloft. Damn! Now I've just given you something else to worry about.

Posts.Content: Also, for those considering surgery, "Man to Man" by Michael Korda. The author is a respected writer and publisher who had RP with Dr. Patrick Walsh in 1993, at the apex of Walsh's career. There were unanticipated problems, which Korda discusses in candid, intimate detail. Also, how he and his wife eventually dealt with those challenges. While written in 1996, this book is still very relevant to surgery patients. It is available on Amazon and eBay.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Here is an interesting article about prostate cancer that I got today from Web MD. https://www.webmd.com/prostate-cance...bO9j0WnT5B8%3d Chuck, I read that article and have serious questions about two of their statements: "About 50% of men diagnosed with local prostate cancer will get metastatic cancer during their lifetime." and "On average, 8 years pass from the time a man is first diagnosed with prostate cancer to the discovery that it has become metastatic." Clearly, this cannot include Gleason 6 patients, who are about 65 percent of newly-diagnosed men. According to them, I should be writing my will now. IMHO, this article is misleading by failing to specify the patients' staging that is applicable to their advice.

Posts.Content: You can drive yourself to drink pondering all the many forms of intervention for the small amount of prostate cancer that you have. But, at age 51, getting it out and over with probably makes the most sense. Being twenty years older than you, I am comfortable with AS, or doing Focal Laser Ablation or cryotherapy if things got worse. But, for you, a lot can happen in twenty years, and you probably want the assurance that the cancer has been dealt with in as final a manner as possible. Cyberknife, like Proton Therapy, has its supporters, but the verdicts aren't really in, or not clearly superior, at this time. To my knowledge, you are seeing the top PCa specialist in the world. My guy works for/with him. Follow his advice. You can't do better than that.

Posts.Title: Treatment question, before this makes me crazy!!! Cyberknife vs. surgery?

Posts.Content: As mentioned by the forum brothers, your biopsy results make you a perfect fit for AS. My only caution would be the PIRADS 4 lesion. That has a high likelihood for containing Gleason 7 or higher disease. I would suggest that you have a genomics test done on your biopsy slides. There are assays like OncotypeDX, Decipher, Prolaris, and others. That would provide more certainty that your lesion is not more serious. In my case, an MRI interpreted to have a PIRADS 4 lesion caused a lot of concern for my medical team, and more intensive tests for me. But, when the PIRADS version 2 guidelines were published, that lesion was re-classified as a 3. So, having frequent and appropriate testing going forward is always in your best interest. Good luck.

Posts.Title: From Slow Growth to Rapid Growth - Anyone experience this?

Posts.Content: Sherry, Any psa that high needs to be explored further to determine its cause. I tend to remember extreme numbers, and the highest psa that I have read about where no cancer could be found after extensive testing was 52. Now, my reading doesn't prove anything, and he still could be cancer-free, but the need for the MRI is obvious. How large is his prostate? That should be noted on the biopsy pathology report. As far as blood or urine tests for infections, the majority of prostate inflammation cases do not involve bacteria, and so are difficult to diagnose or cure. They often just come and go without treatments.

Posts.Title: Enlarged prostate with negative biopsy

Posts.Content: As mentioned by the forum brothers, your biopsy results make you a perfect fit for AS. My only caution would be the PIRADS 4 lesion. That has a high likelihood for containing Gleason 7 or higher disease. I would suggest that you have a genomics test done on your biopsy slides. There are assays like OncotypeDX, Decipher, Prolaris, and others. That would provide more certainty that your lesion is not more serious. In my case, an MRI interpreted to have a PIRADS 4 lesion caused a lot of concern for my medical team, and more intensive tests for me. But, when the PIRADS version 2 guidelines were published, that lesion was re-classified as a 3. So, having frequent and appropriate testing going forward is always in your best interest. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Newbie from Ottawa

Posts.Content: Yay, Yay, Yay! ðŸ˜ This is great to read. The VA's 72 percent of low risk men choosing AS is way ahead of any other organization in the USA, although still below the amazing 91 percent rate in Sweden. The problem remains the private practices, where the uro's still tend to herd men into unnecessary surgery. I say "surgery" simply because that is what the diagnosing physicians practice. I have known men who were rushed into surgery with Gleason 5... yes, that's right G (2+3) before the guidelines changed in 2005, and one of them wrote several books to try to keep incontinent and impotent men from giving up on life. We still have a way to go with developing better diagnostics. That is indisputable. But, IMHO, the problem with the diagnosing doctor saying "you have cancer", and then "I can cure you" within 5 seconds, has to be broken. There needs to be a separation of practitoners between those statements.

Posts.Title: Interesting Article in Washington Post about PCA TReatment

Posts.Content: I don't know how much FLA has been discussed here previously, but there are new results being reported this week. An NIH study of 15 selected patients, where they had FLA and then biopsies after one year. The results were impressive. No cancer in 13, with 2 having residual G6 in one core. Another, larger, Phase II trial is now being planned. The first sentence of the article is badly written, as the 30% refers to the low risk patients, not those who died. But, this is good news for a possible low SE treatment for low risk patients. My doctors have mentioned it as a possibility if my own cancer should progress. http://www.urotoday.com/aua-2015/aua...ighlights.html

Posts.Content: Is this your first biopsy? If so, there is no question that you need it to determine if those observed lesions are cancerous or not. Biopsies are not that painful, but you must take antibiotics and be quick to seek help if a blockage or infection happens afterwards. There is a sticky thread in the top area of the forum about biopsies. The fusion biopsy is the best tool for taking core samples from those two lesion areas, and having a pathologist examine them.

The author is a respected writer and publisher who had RP with Dr. Patrick Walsh in 1993, at the apex of Walsh's career. While written in 1996, this book is still very relevant to surgery patients. It is available on Amazon and eBay.

Regarding active surveillance, the strict requirements at Johns Hopkins would suggest against it because of the bilateral involvement. But, other prestigious institutions would allow it. What I am saying is that you do not have a case requiring immediate intervention. So, take a couple of months to fully inform yourself of as many opinions and options as you can hold. Never be hesitant to ask anyone anything. It's his life, and he(or you) must be his foremost researcher and advocate.

Certainly, you have time to carefully choose the treatment that best suits you. Research, ask, consult, and follow the good advice you receive, like in the above posts. Good luck.

So, technically, yes, it has been proven by DNA, but, practically, it is very, very unlikely.

Posts.Content: You are in a zone where most AS programs would not necessarily recommend treatment. Those would include MSKCC, Sunnybrook, Mayo Clinic, UCLA, and some others. On the other hand, Johns Hopkins is strict about the four cores and bilateral presence signaling an intervention. So, while AS may continue to be a reasonable course for you, the emphasis has to be on "active". The next MRI is a very good idea. Also, using the PHI test will be an improvement over just PSA.

Posts.Title: Results of confirmatory biopsy 4/19/18

Posts.Content: Hilander, Please stop searching and clear your head. About 2/3 of the men having first-time biopsies have negative results. Even if yours proves positive, there are are a wide range of degrees of severity, and many do not demand immediate treatment. This is not a "one size fits all" disease. If some cancer is detected, then come here and post some of the details to hear advice on what to consider for treatment. My children like to remind me "Dad, the only thing that you need to know about prostate cancer is the date of your next appointment."

Posts.Title: Probability?

Posts.Content: Yes, I have a small lesion that was scored as PIRADS 4 ten years ago. It was later downgraded to PIRADS 3 when version 2 came out. Recently, it was scored as PIRADS 2. Three biopsies found a small amount of Gleason (3+3), and three found nothing. So, what this tells us is that the PIRADS assessments of low grade cancer is not that accurate. By definition, a lesion is anything seen somewhere in the body where it is not expected. A pimple is a lesion. Prostate lesions are often benign, and can caused by inflammation scarring, hemorrhage, cysts, etc. Wait until you know more before getting ahead of yourself. In addition to the Walsh book, I would recommend Mark Scholz' The Key to Prostate Cancer. He interviewed 30 prostate cancer experts, and presents their views on the appropriate treatment choices for each patient's pathology. A very balanced book and easy to get through.

Posts.Title: Pirads 4/ Heard of good biopsies

Posts.Content: There is also the OncotypeDX test for prostate cancer, which looks at the genetics of cancer cells found at biopsy. But, like the deciphertest, that is meant to be predictive. In my case, the OncotypeDX was used to confirm that active surveillance was my best course. There are also similar genetic tests by other companies that are coming onto the market. I guess that you should discuss with your doctor what they would do with the results, and how an unfavorable test result would be dealt with.

Posts.Title: Genome test for Prostate CA after RP in 2009

Posts.Content: Welcome Denver, RobLee has given you sound advice for scheduling to wait another two months for Medicare to kick in. I've been on Medicare for eight years, and between that and my supplemental plan, I haven't paid one cent out of my pocket for any medical service. The choice between surgery and radiation is one that you owe it to yourself to intensively research. Online prostate cancer forms have outspoken advocates of surgery, radiation, and an alphabet soup of focal treatments that would not apply to your case. When being told generalities about "surgery has more side effects", or "radiation causes secondary cancers", do not assume that those views are valid today. They may be based on 30 year old studies, and the advances in technologies are totally different today. My readings and interactions with both patients and practitioners have led me to favor radiation, especially the SBRT technique, if i were to select a form of treatment. But, that's just my opinion. As RobLee predicted, others will be heard from. Good luck to you,

Posts.Title: What Do You Do When Your 2nd Opinion Is Different From Your First

Posts.Content: I have read a rebuttal to this study by a well known pro-radiation blogger. He had several criticisms of the study mechanisms, which I am not informed enough to understand, but others on that forum, including the man who cited the study, agreed with him. One point that I did understand is that the study had an age cutoff of 65. He made the point that men who have RT are typically ten years older than men who have RP. Therefore, they must have had other health issues which precluded surgery. That fact alone could account for the overall mortality finding.

Posts.Content: Rylee, I can tell you from experience that biopsies can cause scar tissue and hemorrhaging that shows up in subsequent MRI's. Also, they can double or triple your psa for several months, and also cause aching that will only go away with the passage of time. I have been lobbying my doctor to never have one again. Due to new tests, and my age, I "might" get my wish. We'll see. But, I have no experience with surgery, so I can't help you with that question. I have read that concern, but Chuck's comment makes sense that internal scarring would not seem to impact the gland's removal. Maybe someone else has a specific answer.

Regarding active surveillance, the strict requirements at Johns Hopkins would suggest against it because of the bilateral involvement. But, other prestigious institutions would allow it. What I am saying is that you do not have a case requiring immediate intervention. So, take a couple of months to fully inform yourself of as many opinions and options as you can hold. Never be hesitant to ask anyone anything. It's his life, and he(or you) must be his foremost researcher and advocate.
Posts.Signature: DOB: May 1944 In Active Surveillance program at Johns Hopkins Strict protocol of tests, including PHI, DRE, MRI, and biopsy. Six biopsies from 2009 to 2019. Numbers 1, 2, and 5 were negative. Numbers 3,4, and 6 were positive with 5% Gleason(3+3) found. Last one was Precision Point transperineal. PSA 4.4, fPSA 24, PHI 32 Hopefully, I can remain untreated. So far, so good.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed 56 year old husband with PSA of 21 and 3/14 cores postitive-help!

Posts.Content: Yay, Yay, Yay! ðŸ˜ This is great to read. The VA's 72 percent of low risk men choosing AS is way ahead of any other organization in the USA, although still below the amazing 91 percent rate in Sweden. The problem remains the private practices, where the uro's still tend to herd men into unnecessary surgery. I say "surgery" simply because that is what the diagnosing physicians practice. I have known men who were rushed into surgery with Gleason 5... yes, that's right G (2+3) before the guidelines changed in 2005, and one of them wrote several books to try to keep incontinent and impotent men from giving up on life. We still have a way to go with developing better diagnostics. That is indisputable. But, IMHO, the problem with the diagnosing doctor saying "you have cancer", and then "I can cure you" within 5 seconds, has to be broken. There needs to be a separation of practitoners between those statements.

Posts.Title: Interesting Article in Washington Post about PCA TReatment

Posts.Content: Gulfcoaster, The negative biopsy after a positive one could be normal. Same with the psa of 10. I've had both. But, a steady psa rise, as opposed to my spikes, is a concern that you need to address. Have you had a 3T mpiMRI followed by a fusion biopsy? That is about as definitive as is currently available. How about a PHI blood test test? That's quick and simple. The PCA3 urine test, mentioned above, is also worthwhile. You need to keep on top of this with as much testing as is reasonable. If the psa goes down...great. But, if it keeps rising, you must keeping digging deeper until you determine the cause.

Posts.Title: Any good studies on how long it takes for PSA to return to baseline post prostate bx?

Posts.Content: Dave, How old are you? Age is always a factor in these decisions. Assuming that you are under 75, the three cores and 60% involvement might put you at the outer edge for AS, but the bilateral involvement would disqualify you, based on the criteria used by Johns Hopkins. Certainly, you have time to carefully choose the treatment that best suits you. Research, ask, consult, and follow the good advice you receive, like in the above posts. Good luck.

Posts.Title: About Vidatox Cancer Medication

Posts.Content: Also, for those considering surgery, "Man to Man" by Michael Korda. The author is a respected writer and publisher who had RP with Dr. Patrick Walsh in 1993, at the apex of Walsh's career. There were unanticipated problems, which Korda discusses in candid, intimate detail. Also, how he and his wife eventually dealt with those challenges. While written in 1996, this book is still very relevant to surgery patients. It is available on Amazon and eBay.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Here is an interesting article about prostate cancer that I got today from Web MD. https://www.webmd.com/prostate-cance...bO9j0WnT5B8%3d Chuck, I read that article and have serious questions about two of their statements: "About 50% of men diagnosed with local prostate cancer will get metastatic cancer during their lifetime." and "On average, 8 years pass from the time a man is first diagnosed with prostate cancer to the discovery that it has become metastatic." Clearly, this cannot include Gleason 6 patients, who are about 65 percent of newly-diagnosed men. According to them, I should be writing my will now. IMHO, this article is misleading by failing to specify the patients' staging that is applicable to their advice.

Posts.Title: Books on Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: mikesimm, Sorry that you have to join us, but this is a great forum with many caring members sharing lots of experiences and knowledge. Yes, Proton is being promoted as more centers are being built. It has theoretical advantages, but so far, I don't think that it has enough solid data to support producing superior outcomes. Like Pratoman mentioned, SBRT and also HDR monotherapy seem to be reporting the best new results. You need to also be mindful to research the recent studies about certain treatments, as there are some widespread comments about various treatments that were true decades ago, but now, due to tech advances, those comments are myths. Also, you may be interested in looking up and attending a local prostate cancer support group. Lots of experience and advice available at some of them.

Posts.Title: New Prostate Cancer Drug?

Posts.Content: When you say "show signs of cancer", do you mean that the pathology report identified some percentage of adenocarcinoma in those five core samples? Sometimes, doctors will refer to ASAP or HGPIN as pre-cancers, and I want to be sure what you mean. Also, were the Gleason scores (3+4) or (4+3), and what percentage of each core was found to be cancerous? From what you have said, I agree with Southsider that treatment may be necessary. But, as he said, radiation can cure you as effectively as surgery. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Cranberry pills

Posts.Content: Hilander, Please stop searching and clear your head. About 2/3 of the men having first-time biopsies have negative results. Even if yours proves positive, there are are a wide range of degrees of severity, and many do not demand immediate treatment. This is not a "one size fits all" disease. If some cancer is detected, then come here and post some of the details to hear advice on what to consider for treatment. My children like to remind me "Dad, the only thing that you need to know about prostate cancer is the date of your next appointment."

Posts.Title: Starting off the new year with my father's new diagnosis :-(

Posts.Content: From the November AARP Bulletin: "The facts: While PSA testing has been shown to reduce deaths from prostate cancer, no study has shown a decrease in overall mortality with PSA screening for men of any age, says Kenneth Lin, M.D., professor of family medicine at Georgetown University Medical Center in Washington, D.C. Any prostate cancer benefit was offset by deaths and complications from biopsies, surgery, radiation and chemotherapy. And screened groups had much higher rates of complications, including impotence and incontinence. Indeed, diaper manufacturers are frequent sponsors of PSA screening drives, says Otis Brawley, M.D., chief medical and scientific officer at the American Cancer Society, who, at age 59, declines PSA screening for himself. The truth is, about half of men will have some cancer cells in their prostate by age 60, and 70 percent of them will develop prostate cancer by age 80. Yet only 3 percent of men actually die from it, Lin says." This article, reaching 35 million people, doesn't help the PSA screening debate, which has been ongoing for years. But, the statements from the ACS's top doctor surprised me. Diaper makers sponsor PSA screening drives?

Posts.Title: Diaper Manufacturers Sponsor PSA Screening Drives?

Posts.Content: Two facts for you to consider: 1. 70 percent of prostate biopsies are negative 2. Of all men diagnosed with prostate cancer today, less than two percent of them will die of prostate cancer within ten years (American Cancer Society stats) Now, calm down. The odds are that your psa is being raised by benign causes like prostate inflammation, infection, sex, bike riding, etc. And, even if you have some PCa, many cases are indolent, and may never need any type of treatment. Get another blood test, preferably a PHI test, which also will include your free psa number. Your reaction is typical of almost all of us. Relax, do some reading, and don't panic yourself into getting ahead of what you know.

Posts.Content: Whew! that's a big jump in dosage. But, there is a trial going on right now using HDR-BT as a salvage monotherapy. THIRTY Gy's in a a single session!!! That's about 15 times what each session of standard EBRT delivers. I have visions of the scene in the 1930's Frankenstein movie where they raise the creature up into a thunderstorm to attract the lightening bolt that gives him life. https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT03312972 I'll bet that they will get volunteers. Posts.Title: Rapid Rise in PSA

Posts.Content: It will likely never be zero, as he still has a prostate. That's OK, perfectly normal to have some detectable psa after RT. What you will be looking for is the psa nadir, which is the lowest point it reaches. That can take two to three years to be reached, and "bounces", where it goes up and then down, are also common. You learn more by googling "prostate psa nadir" for a list of links. Here is one such article: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5590195/

Posts.Title: Results of confirmatory biopsy 4/19/18

Posts.Content: According to the NCCN. the AUA, and ASCO, the three major medical organizations that issue guidelines for the treatment of prostate cancer, the default course of action for your pathology is Active Surveillance. Meaning that you begin a monitoring program and defer any treatment. Now, you can insist on surgery, radiation of some sort, or another form of treatment. But you should slow down and use the next several months to ask, consult, research, and soul search as to what you want to do. All treatments have side effects, some of which can seriously impact your quality of life. So, you should know all the facts. Active surveillance could last until you die of something else, or it could lead to a future upgrade, and the need to treat then. As far as you know right now, you have a minimal threat of prostate cancer. Use that to your advantage to learn as much as you can about the disease.

Posts.Title: New prostate cancer diagnosis for lymphoma survivor

Posts.Content: mikesimm, Sorry that you have to join us, but this is a great forum with many caring members sharing lots of experiences and knowledge. Yes, Proton is being promoted as more centers are being built. It has theoretical advantages, but so far, I don't think that it has enough solid data to support producing superior outcomes. Like Pratoman mentioned, SBRT and also HDR monotherapy seem to be reporting the best new results. You need to also be mindful to research the recent studies about certain treatments, as there are some widespread comments about various treatments that were true decades ago, but now, due to tech advances, those comments are myths. Also, you may be interested in looking up and attending a local prostate cancer support group. Lots of experience and advice available at some of them.

Posts.Title: Diagnosed Today

Posts.Content: A free PSA of 47% is by far the highest I have ever seen mentioned on a prostate cancer forum. That's because you don't have PCa. ASAP and HGPIN can/maybe not be precursors of PCa, There are different studies. They are anomalies, but not cancer. The chance that any man might get PCa in his lifetime is about 14-16 percent. The chance of a man of 73 having some amount of prostate cancer is much, much higher. I would take that 12 percent guess and sleep well on it. Yes, you are OK. The only concern you need to have about prostate cancer is keeping your next routine appointment.

Posts.Title: Results of confirmatory biopsy 4/19/18

Posts.Content: As an AS study participant, I will try to see if I can find a justification for your question. IF he receives a second opinion that rates all his slides at 3+3, that might open a possibility for AS, as JH has just de-emphasized the percentage of core criterion, and maybe be moving to increase or disregard the number of positive cores. BUT, that is offset if any cancer is found bilaterally, which raises the risk classification. Also, a PSA over 10, or age under 65 would largely rule out AS. He has a very slim hope of avoiding intervention. But, why discourage him from getting more advice? If he has unsettled questions in his mind, that may bother him the rest of his life. At least, after he gets the extra input, he will be certain that he did the right thing by having intervention.

Posts.Title: Question about the value of a 2nd opinion on the biopsy slides...

Posts.Content: I would wait and request a PHI test next time. That offers the same type of "do I need a biopsy?" assessment, but using different markers than 4K. Biopsies are not to be taken lightly. The chances of hospitalization for sepsis are 2 out of 100, and mortality is 1 of 1400. I have had 5 biopsies. Three were non-eventful, and two created long lasting pain and permanent prostate damage. My psa was doubled, and tripled for six months. Did I mention that all were done by professors of Urology at Johns Hopkins? A positive DRE does NOT mean that you have cancer, it means that you could possibly have it, and that more tests are required. With your current psa and fpsa, I would suggest a bit more monitoring before risking a biopsy.

Posts.Content: Just google "prostatectomy recurrence" and read the research (after a few ads). Skimming them, it seems that 35 percent or more experience BCR at 5 years after RALP. That includes ALL risk groups. So, yes, it is common. Here is one study: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3535788/ OTS, I am a few years older than you, and every nomogram tells me that I have less than 1 percent chance of dying from PCa in the next 10 years. The next sentence tells me that I have a 36 percent chance of being ALIVE in 10 years. That's it! Tomorrow is jet skiing and then dancing at night. No time to spare

Posts.Title: Still in Zero club, plus question about someone else

Posts.Content: He has prostate cancer, technically, adenocarcinoma of the prostate gland, as does just about everyone on this forum. He has a 3 on the new Gleason Grading prognostic scale of 1-5. Both surgery or radiation can cure him. The scans will usually be negative given his psa. The most important advice is that he has time to carefully research and chose his treatment. There are many discussions about which treatment is better, and which has the lower rate of side effects. None are 100 percent perfect, as he will hear. He needs to have another reading of his biopsy slides, and also consultations with surgeons and radiation oncologists. There are a lot of opinions on the internet, and at local prostate cancer support groups. There is also a "sticky" thread with recommended books. The more you ask, the more you and he will learn.

Posts.Title: What Do You Do When Your 2nd Opinion Is Different From Your First

Posts.Content: Hi Nick, as you said, we hope that you are just passing by. If the psa appears high, a follow up test should be PHI, which includes psa, free psa, a marker for prostate cancer, and an algorithm that predicts if prostate cancer would be found by biopsy. That blood test is more accurate than psa alone, and less influenced by infections. I assume that you were aware to have avoided any sexual activity, bike riding, heavy lifting, etc., for 72 hours before the psa blood draw. If any of those things happened, it would artificially raise your result. Hopefully, this will be your only thread here. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Hi guys, hopefully just a temporary visit here to say hello.

Posts.Content: Two facts for you to consider: 1. 70 percent of prostate biopsies are negative 2. Of all men diagnosed with prostate cancer today, less than two percent of them will die of prostate cancer within ten years (American Cancer Society stats) Now, calm down. The odds are that your psa is being raised by benign causes like prostate inflammation, infection, sex, bike riding, etc. And, even if you have some PCa, many cases are indolent, and may never need any type of treatment. Get another blood test, preferably a PHI test, which also will include your free psa number. Your reaction is typical of almost all of us. Relax, do some reading, and don't panic yourself into getting ahead of what you know.

Posts.Title: Had preop call with nurse for HDR BT, guess this is real!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by garrjim I am 64 this month. My PSA was always normal until 2015 when it registered 8 from a 4. I get an annual physical every year. I took antibiotic and it jumped to 12. Did the biopsy and found Gleason 6 and was put on active servalience. PSA then went back down to 8. Physical in 11/2017 showed PSA at 17. Did MRI and biopsy and then rated Gleason 7 3+4. Doctor is recommending treatment of surgery or radiation High Dose Rate Prostate Brachytherapy Treatment (which requires no hormones). I have also researched a new procedure by Dr. Sperling which treatment is done by laser. (which looks very promising). My local friends that I have talked with were Gleason 8 or higher and with PSA of 43 or better. Plus some had treatments over 10 years ago which are not very relevant to my situation. I am interested in hearing from others who have had more recent treatments. HDTBT is not a new technology, as it has been used for prostate cancer for over twenty years. What is more recent is it's use as a monotherapy, and not to boost other treatments. Forum member subdenis recently had HDRBT after six months of intense research. I would advise you to read his posting history.

Posts.Title: Significant rise in PSA

Posts.Content: I understand your anxiety, but you shouldn't get ahead of the pathology stats. About nine years ago, my PSA went from 1.8 to 3.2 within a year, and to 5.1 two weeks later. Referred to a urologist who scheduled a biopsy, but also gave me a course of Levaquin and also scheduled another PSA and fPSA just before the surgery. Sure enough, after a week of taking the antibiotic, and then having those two blood tests, I got a call cancelling the biopsy, and telling me not to worry. PSA of 1.8 again and fPSA of 25. No worries. So, yes, you could very likely have an infection, and not be dealing with cancer (at least at this time). Relax.

Posts.Title: DX Last Week.....

Posts.Content: Two facts for you to consider: 1. 70 percent of prostate biopsies are negative 2. Of all men diagnosed with prostate cancer today, less than two percent of them will die of prostate cancer within ten years (American Cancer Society stats) Now, calm down. The odds are that your psa is being raised by benign causes like prostate inflammation, infection, sex, bike riding, etc. And, even if you have some PCa, many cases are indolent, and may never need any type of treatment. Get another blood test, preferably a PHI test, which also will include your free psa number. Your reaction is typical of almost all of us. Relax, do some reading, and don't panic yourself into getting ahead of what you know.

Posts.Title: "Inflamed" prostate - should I be worried?

Posts.Content: I don't see any fault in your wanting an mp-MRI and more testing (like PHI, 4K, Exo dx, etc.) to better determine your risk before having a biopsy. The MRI should give you the prostate size, and you can use that to calculate your prostate density. Prostate density is being increasing used as an indicator for further action, especially at Johns Hopkins, where I am in an observational study. The above forum brothers are all correct that ONLY a biopsy can diagnose prostate cancer. But, that doesn't mean that one should be scheduled without a good basis of suspicion for PCa. Two of my five biopsies caused pain for six months, and a tripling of my psa due to swelling and damage. Three out of 100 biopsies result in hospitalization for sepsis, and one of 1400 is fatal. So, it is not always a walk in the park. That said, if you have the MRI and other tests (that were developed to reduce the number of biopsies), and they are suspicious, you need to have one. At least, you will then know with more certainty that is your correct choice.

Posts.Title: How to choose a urologist who could do multiparametric MRI fusion biopsy if needed?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic ASA, does your problemed biopsy history affect your thinking about continuing on AS, or are you just resigned to accepting the risk of complications? I believe the some cases of sepsis that lead to death from prostate biopsies result from the symptoms being ignored for days before treatment is sought. The key is to identify the bacteria and start appropriate antibiotics as soon as possible, so each day counts. All docs should give out written post-biopsy instructions which include monitoring for fever, chills, etc. Well, at this point, with my age, years in the AS program, and stable PSA kinectics and PSADensity, I haven't been pushed into having more biopsies. So, that could change, but right now, I'm hoping to avoid future ones. My next scheduled appointment will be with Dr. Carter, and that may prove interesting, as I would resist a "protocol" biopsy. Don't want to think ahead...we'll see. All my biopsies were done at JH by professors of urology. They did culture swabs a month ahead to see what my gut biotics were like, and I had a very strict pre-and-post biopsy regimen of stuff to avoid and antibiotics to take. Just shows that things can go wrong even with expert precautions. You, with 10 fault-free biopsies, did extremely well, and lived to tell about it

Posts.Title: How to choose a urologist who could do multiparametric MRI fusion biopsy if needed?

Posts.Content: Mark, You do not have a death sentence. Either surgery or radiation can cure a Gleason(4+4) patient. Some recent studies are showing dramatic improvements in survival rates when both regular radiation and a brachytherapy boost are used. But, that is getting into treatment choices, and you need to have a couple more tests before you start consulting with the doctors who can treat you. A caution: there are three types of surgery and five types of radiation available to treat you. You may need to speak with practitioners of several to get comfortable with your future direction. It's confusing, but its better to have choices than not.

Posts.Title: Recent articles: US Task Force on PSA Screening / Biochemical Persistence (BCP)

Posts.Content: I would wait and request a PHI test next time. That offers the same type of "do I need a biopsy?" assessment, but using different markers than 4K. Biopsies are not to be taken lightly. The chances of hospitalization for sepsis are 2 out of 100, and mortality is 1 of 1400. I have had 5 biopsies. Three were non-eventful, and two created long lasting pain and permanent prostate damage. My psa was doubled, and tripled for six months. Did I mention that all were done by professors of Urology at Johns Hopkins? A positive DRE does NOT mean that you have cancer, it means that you could possibly have it, and that more tests are required. With your current psa and fpsa, I would suggest a bit more monitoring before risking a biopsy.
