Posts.Title: DX Last Week.....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wtdedula Hi Consult1; I actually had surgery at the Cleveland Clinic about 1-1/2 weeks ago (August 1, 2017) by Dr. Andrew Stephenson and am recovering at home now. I found that surgery was a breeze with very little to no pain but the catheter (which I thankfully only had for 8 days) was a major pain (literally) - it hurt so bad. Some men don't experience pain like I did, guess I was just unlucky. You will have to put up with sleeping on your back for only a week. Interestingly, I always sleep on my back so wasn't a problem for me but many men who need a catheter don't and they still manage to get through the week OK. Obviously, sleeping on your stomach isn't an option with a catheter. You can read about my complete day-to-day experiences before and after surgery here ... https://www.cancerforums.net/threads...Some-questions As I have learned, most of the people on this forum are pro-surgery. In my case, I wanted to just get rid of the cancer rather than just burn it out with radiation. Plus, Radiation has the potential to lead to secondary cancers. In addition, if you have surgery and your PSA comes back, then you can be treated with radiation to knock out the rest of the cancer. But if you're treated with radiation, and you have a reoccurrence, you generally can't go back and have surgery. So in other words, if your cancer comes back following treatment, you get a second shot at a cure with surgery but not so with radiation. So just my opinion, I think you shouldn't fear surgery and give it a consideration. I am not really familiar with the lab test results you got but I'm sure others will chime in here too with additional insight. A few studies and information seem to indicate that Gleason 6 is not capable of spreading, but some men with Gleason 6 are found to actually have a higher grade of cancer once the full prostate is examined by a pathologist (If you opt for surgery - which is another benefit to having surgery that isn't available with radiation). Fortunately for me, that didn't happen and I remained the same gleason grade that I was on biopsy but others on this forum have been upgraded following surgery when they received the results of their final pathology. It is said to happen in about 20% of cases. Tim There are a number of outdated statements in this post. The possibility of secondary cancers from radiation was true in the 1980's and maybe 1990's, but is insignificant today due to improved technology. Also, if there is a recurrence after primary radiation, that can now be successfully treated by SBRT radiation. So, many of the talking points about surgery having advantages over radiation are no longer true. As Tim admitted, this is a pro-surgery prostate cancer forum. There are others that favor radiation, and still others that favor an alphabet soup of lesser known treatments. You owe it to yourself to get as many opinions as you can. Good luck.

Posts.Title: First post and very stressed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wtdedula Hi Consult1; I actually had surgery at the Cleveland Clinic about 1-1/2 weeks ago (August 1, 2017) by Dr. Andrew Stephenson and am recovering at home now. I found that surgery was a breeze with very little to no pain but the catheter (which I thankfully only had for 8 days) was a major pain (literally) - it hurt so bad. Some men don't experience pain like I did, guess I was just unlucky. You will have to put up with sleeping on your back for only a week. Interestingly, I always sleep on my back so wasn't a problem for me but many men who need a catheter don't and they still manage to get through the week OK. Obviously, sleeping on your stomach isn't an option with a catheter. You can read about my complete day-to-day experiences before and after surgery here ... https://www.cancerforums.net/threads...Some-questions As I have learned, most of the people on this forum are pro-surgery. In my case, I wanted to just get rid of the cancer rather than just burn it out with radiation. Plus, Radiation has the potential to lead to secondary cancers. In addition, if you have surgery and your PSA comes back, then you can be treated with radiation to knock out the rest of the cancer. But if you're treated with radiation, and you have a reoccurrence, you generally can't go back and have surgery. So in other words, if your cancer comes back following treatment, you get a second shot at a cure with surgery but not so with radiation. So just my opinion, I think you shouldn't fear surgery and give it a consideration. I am not really familiar with the lab test results you got but I'm sure others will chime in here too with additional insight. A few studies and information seem to indicate that Gleason 6 is not capable of spreading, but some men with Gleason 6 are found to actually have a higher grade of cancer once the full prostate is examined by a pathologist (If you opt for surgery - which is another benefit to having surgery that isn't available with radiation). Fortunately for me, that didn't happen and I remained the same gleason grade that I was on biopsy but others on this forum have been upgraded following surgery when they received the results of their final pathology. It is said to happen in about 20% of cases. Tim There are a number of outdated statements in this post. The possibility of secondary cancers from radiation was true in the 1980's and maybe 1990's, but is insignificant today due to improved technology. Also, if there is a recurrence after primary radiation, that can now be successfully treated by SBRT radiation. So, many of the talking points about surgery having advantages over radiation are no longer true. As Tim admitted, this is a pro-surgery prostate cancer forum. There are others that favor radiation, and still others that favor an alphabet soup of lesser known treatments. You owe it to yourself to get as many opinions as you can. Good luck.

Posts.Content: One of my specialists at Johns Hopkins was Ashley Ross, who is often published in prostate cancer research articles. Going over my meds, he was delighted that I had been taking aspirin, atorvastatin, and atenolol for over twenty years. He believed they all helped inhibit PCa.
Posts.Title: Cholesterol lowering seems to be a protective mechanism against advanced PC

Posts.Content: I understand your anxiety, but you shouldn't get ahead of the pathology stats. About nine years ago, my PSA went from 1.8 to 3.2 within a year, and to 5.1 two weeks later. Referred to a urologist who scheduled a biopsy, but also gave me a course of Levaquin and also scheduled another PSA and fPSA just before the surgery. Sure enough, after a week of taking the antibiotic, and then having those two blood tests, I got a call cancelling the biopsy, and telling me not to worry. PSA of 1.8 again and fPSA of 25. No worries. So, yes, you could very likely have an infection, and not be dealing with cancer (at least at this time). Relax.

Posts.Title: Is HT possible in early stage?

Posts.Content: According to the NCCN. the AUA, and ASCO, the three major medical organizations that issue guidelines for the treatment of prostate cancer, the default course of action for your pathology is Active Surveillance. Meaning that you begin a monitoring program and defer any treatment. Now, you can insist on surgery, radiation of some sort, or another form of treatment. But you should slow down and use the next several months to ask, consult, research, and soul search as to what you want to do. All treatments have side effects, some of which can seriously impact your quality of life. So, you should know all the facts. Active surveillance could last until you die of something else, or it could lead to a future upgrade, and the need to treat then. As far as you know right now, you have a minimal threat of prostate cancer. Use that to your advantage to learn as much as you can about the disease.

So, this reply should bump this thread back to the top, and I trust that some of those with similar histories will comment.

Posts.Title: Family History?

Posts.Content: I don't see any fault in your wanting an mp-MRI and more testing (like PHI, 4K, Exo dx, etc.) to better determine your risk before having a biopsy. The MRI should give you the prostate size, and you can use that to calculate your prostate density. Prostate density is being increasing used as an indicator for further action, especially at Johns Hopkins, where I am in an observational study. The above forum brothers are all correct that ONLY a biopsy can diagnose prostate cancer. But, that doesn't mean that one should be scheduled without a good basis of suspicion for PCa. Two of my five biopsies caused pain for six months, and a tripling of my psa due to swelling and damage. Three out of 100 biopsies result in hospitalization for sepsis, and one of 1400 is fatal. So, it is not always a walk in the park. That said, if you have the MRI and other tests (that were developed to reduce the number of biopsies), and they are suspicious, you need to have one. At least, you will then know with more certainty that is your correct choice.

Posts.Title: How to choose a urologist who could do multiparametric MRI fusion biopsy if needed?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic ASA, does your problemed biopsy history affect your thinking about continuing on AS, or are you just resigned to accepting the risk of complications? I believe the some cases of sepsis that lead to death from prostate biopsies result from the symptoms being ignored for days before treatment is sought. The key is to identify the bacteria and start appropriate antibiotics as soon as possible, so each day counts. All docs should give out written post-biopsy instructions which include monitoring for fever, chills, etc. Well, at this point, with my age, years in the AS program, and stable PSA kinectics and PSADensity, I haven't been pushed into having more biopsies. So, that could change, but right now, I'm hoping to avoid future ones. My next scheduled appointment will be with Dr. Carter, and that may prove interesting, as I would resist a "protocol" biopsy. Don't want to think ahead...we'll see. All my biopsies were done at JH by professors of urology. They did culture swabs a month ahead to see what my gut biotics were like, and I had a very strict pre-and-post biopsy regimen of stuff to avoid and antibiotics to take. Just shows that things can go wrong even with expert precautions. You, with 10 fault-free biopsies, did extremely well, and lived to tell about it

Posts.Content: IMHO, the problems with overtreatment, which did drive the 2012 USPSTF guidelines, was never with the diagnosis, but with the subsequent advice by urologists to have radical treatment in almost all cases. The USPSTF overreacted by discouraging the diagnostics, and some men have suffered due to lack of testing. That has changed now, with active surveillance being the primary recommended "treatment" in both very low risk and low risk classifications. There is more balanced counseling, and less cases of rushing into treatment. I have not heard anyone recently promoting that psa tests not be given, and think that there is now broad agreement that psa screening is desirable.

Posts.Content: JulesM, Everything I've ever read about PCa matches what you have read, and what his doctor has told him. That is, that only advanced cases cause symptoms. Did you say that he was diagnosed last week, has surgery scheduled for October 23rd? Has he consulted with other specialists, or only this one? I'm mentioning this because the biggest controversy about prostate cancer treatment is the need to fully explore the various types of treatments, and have consultations with multiple surgeons and radiation oncologists. If you take the time to peruse the several discussion forums for prostate cancer, you will find many comments from men regretting that they rushed into a treatment plan without taking the time to research other types of treatment. PCa is a slow growing cancer, and there is always time to stop and think and be certain that you have chosen the best course. Good luck to you both.

Posts.Title: New PSA Results & A Little Confusion About Stuff

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wtdedula Hi Consult1; I actually had surgery at the Cleveland Clinic about 1-1/2 weeks ago (August 1, 2017) by Dr. Andrew Stephenson and am recovering at home now. I found that surgery was a breeze with very little to no pain but the catheter (which I thankfully only had for 8 days) was a major pain (literally) - it hurt so bad. Some men don't experience pain like I did, guess I was just unlucky. You will have to put up with sleeping on your back for only a week. Interestingly, I always sleep on my back so wasn't a problem for me but many men who need a catheter don't and they still manage to get through the week OK. Obviously, sleeping on your stomach isn't an option with a catheter. You can read about my complete day-to-day experiences before and after surgery here ... https://www.cancerforums.net/threads...Some-questions As I have learned, most of the people on this forum are pro-surgery. In my case, I wanted to just get rid of the cancer rather than just burn it out with radiation. Plus, Radiation has the potential to lead to secondary cancers. In addition, if you have surgery and your PSA comes back, then you can be treated with radiation to knock out the rest of the cancer. But if you're treated with radiation, and you have a reoccurrence, you generally can't go back and have surgery. So in other words, if your cancer comes back following treatment, you get a second shot at a cure with surgery but not so with radiation. So just my opinion, I think you shouldn't fear surgery and give it a consideration. I am not really familiar with the lab test results you got but I'm sure others will chime in here too with additional insight. A few studies and information seem to indicate that Gleason 6 is not capable of spreading, but some men with Gleason 6 are found to actually have a higher grade of cancer once the full prostate is examined by a pathologist (If you opt for surgery - which is another benefit to having surgery that isn't available with radiation). Fortunately for me, that didn't happen and I remained the same gleason grade that I was on biopsy but others on this forum have been upgraded following surgery when they received the results of their final pathology. It is said to happen in about 20% of cases. Tim There are a number of outdated statements in this post. The possibility of secondary cancers from radiation was true in the 1980's and maybe 1990's, but is insignificant today due to improved technology. Also, if there is a recurrence after primary radiation, that can now be successfully treated by SBRT radiation. So, many of the talking points about surgery having advantages over radiation are no longer true. As Tim admitted, this is a pro-surgery prostate cancer forum. There are others that favor radiation, and still others that favor an alphabet soup of lesser known treatments. You owe it to yourself to get as many opinions as you can. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Nearing the end of active surveillance

Posts.Content: I would suggest that you take a month or two to further research ALL your options. Yes, you need to have intervention, but you should be fully aware of the results and risks of each method of intervention. There is a literal alphabet soup of possible treatment options for you. I just read an article where a study group of men had surgery, and subsequently sought treatment for impotence and incontinence, and didn't remember being told that these were possible outcomes. Maybe the urologists failed to inform them, or they failed to comprehend, but the resultant unhappiness was evident. Saving your life is the foremost priority, but make sure that you evaluate the outcomes of all the many forms of treatment.

Posts.Title: Alternative to PSA?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lexpar As a recent member of the forum, I wonder how many of us are, or were, in the same boat as I am. I want to make it absolutely clear I am not looking to pace blame anywhere. I had been asking my family Dr for two years about doing a PSA. He told me that conventional thinking about PSA's had changed; that they raised so many "false positives" that the thinking was now to wait until there were symptoms. (This was confirmed by a family friend, a urological surgeon with 50 yrs experience.)He did do a DRE and said everything felt as it should. My first PSA was run completely by accident. When doing pre-op lab work for shoulder surgery the lab ran a PSA without being directed to. That came back elevated; a second PSA blood test was taken which also came back elevated which led to the biopsy and diagnosis. My point is that had I waited till I was symptomatic, it may well have been too late to hope for a positive outcome. Should the collective"we" be pressing for some sort of diagnostic test that is more dependable that the PSA or DRE? God Bless all of the other various cancer groups pushing for $$$$, but I have been astounded by many men I know have come forward to me saying they have gone through various forms of prostate cancer. Two men I know lost their battle with the disease. And that's just in our little town. This is certainly a common condition, and one which will kill if treatment is left too late. If a PSA is not considered reliable enough, why isn't an alternative test or screening procedure being developed? If one is, how can we support it? There has been a great deal of research over the past 15 years to find a better diagnostic tool than the PSA test. There is a huge financial incentive for biomedical research companies, both large and small, to patent "THE" successor test to PSA. There are many contenders, from imaging to biomarker assays. Blood, urine, and mouth swabs are part of the wide array of tests that have been proposed and examined. Some have good clinical results, but then, other studies are not so sure. Better tests than psa already exist, like PHI and 4K Score. But, they are derivatives of psa. Believe me, a small army of researchers are working on finding "the" test that has high accuracy. It's coming...sometime.

Posts.Title: Alternative to PSA?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Kopterkojak It started with minimal nocturnal urine flow leading to Nightly Tamosulin(Urimax)BPH.4.Along the road a DRE,PSA's etc.In 2016 Biopsy was clear with PSA 19. 2018 PSA 64 Biopsy Gleason 3+4, post op 4+4. Jr does not salute and Diapers fashionable. MRI Pelvis & Bone scan were clear but post op cells on membrane hence Hormone injections for 2 yrs 3 monthly and 37 days radiation. Presently analysing why Jr could not stand up to the occasion and why did the immune system break down. In the scientific approach of starving the cancer a range of foods is mentioned.This is in tune with Jindal Naturopathy pointing at improper digestion leading to toxins.Howevever Aging is a factor.Lifestyle,BMI, pollution etc?? So Elp me Gawd! Regards KOJAK (YouTube.com/kopterkojak/soldier-LA Taxi Live) How is the cancer control going? That has to be your primary focus. The ADT certainly will cause ED. That's what it does. If the ADT has stopped, then there is a whole array of tools - pills, injections, implants, to try to restore sexual function. The incontinence needs the attention of a specialist (there are some in that field of post-treatment Pca) you just have to find one. As far as diet, I am part of a PCa program at Johns Hopkins, long famous for their surgery and radiation skills. On my last visit, my specialist emphasized that the role of what we ingest is of primary importance. "you are what you eat". So, yes, research those alternative foods.

Posts.Title: Need da Vinci surgeon from Dallas Fort Worth Area

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi Big_Bob! Your biopsy (Bx)result was Gleason (3+3). As it turned out, you elected surgery and were upgraded to Gleason (3+4). Was Prolaris able to "predict" the upgrade to G (3+4)? Others' Opinions invited please!: - Do Prolaris results always mirror pGleason Stages? - Does Prolaris have any ability to ultimately improve outcomes? How much was your insurance billed and how much did they reimburse? In the end, we are all very happy that you are not in a high risk category! MF Both Prolaris and OncotypeDX were validated against historical tissue samples. Their predictive power is based on the gene assay analyzed and the death rates of those subject patients, and the history of progression and metatasis, not upon the post-op Gleason score. http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/825578 https://urology.ucsf.edu/prostate-ca...esting-at-ucsf http://www.prnewswire.com/news-relea...300408549.html

So far, so good.

Posts.Title: Questioning the Motives of the Forum

Posts.Content: Welcome, mamadeesix, I hope that you will find answers to your questions from our helpful members. Normal psa for him should be less than 4. Recent studies have shown that scaling psa by age in older men was not as accurate as hoped, and is not generally recommended. I am not aware of studies that attempted to correlate free psa and age. Yes, bph can raise psa and also lower free psa. I've experienced it myself. Also, I've seen posts from men with psa results up to 50 from bph, although that is extremely rare. A PHI test is more accurate that either psa or fpsa, but still can be influenced by bph. Having the MRI, (make sure that it is a 3-Tesla multi-parametric machine) is the logical next step. The MRI cannot diagnose cancer, but it can pinpoint suspicious areas for a subsequent fusion biopsy.

Posts.Title: BHP and age in improve odds?

Posts.Content: Football, with a PIRADS 4 lesion found on your MRI, a biopsy is not optional, it is required to determine if you have any prostate cancer. It is certainly possible that no cancer, or very minimal cancer, will be found, but it is best to get the biopsy done and better understand what your situation is. Good luck.
Posts.Title: New to Board

Posts.Content: JulesM, Everything I've ever read about PCa matches what you have read, and what his doctor has told him. That is, that only advanced cases cause symptoms. Did you say that he was diagnosed last week, has surgery scheduled for October 23rd? Has he consulted with other specialists, or only this one? I'm mentioning this because the biggest controversy about prostate cancer treatment is the need to fully explore the various types of treatments, and have consultations with multiple surgeons and radiation oncologists. If you take the time to peruse the several discussion forums for prostate cancer, you will find many comments from men regretting that they rushed into a treatment plan without taking the time to research other types of treatment. PCa is a slow growing cancer, and there is always time to stop and think and be certain that you have chosen the best course. Good luck to you both.

Posts.Title: Feeling confused

Posts.Content: HDR-BT has been offered at UCLA since 1996, so it is not an experimental treatment. What is relatively recent is its offering as a monotherapy, rather than as part of an ADT, EBRT, and HDR-BT combination. The published results for HDR-BT are very favorable in terms of cancer control and side effects. However, there are not many practicioners trained in that treatment, allegedly because radiologists are paid a lot more for the 44-session EBRT sessions. Michael F has provided you with good info re: subdenis and that SpaceOAR is usually used for other types of RT.

Posts.Title: MRI-guided Nerve-sparing HDR Brachytherapy

Posts.Content: JLH, Chuck has given you the bottom line order of priorities. LIfe is always worth living, even with some disabilities. And, while I have read complaints from men who were unhappy with prostate cancer treatments, others attest that they have regained satisfactory sexual function, so the results are individual. Also, keep in mind that having a psa test and confirmatory biopsy that you have prostate cancer, does not necessarily mean that you need treatment. I have an apparently indolent case, and have been watching it for eight years, with no change in quality of life. Perhaps 50 percent of newly diagnosed men are in this category. Research is fine, but IMHO, you also need to find doctor(s) that you can trust and confide in. They may instantly see a unique set of characteristics about you that browsing the internet would not have deduced.

Posts.Title: MRI-guided Nerve-sparing HDR Brachytherapy

Posts.Content: How old are you? Have you had a DRE? Any history of BPH or prostatitis? Family history of PCa? I would suggest a PHI test, as it is more accurate than psa and/or Fpsa alone. It think that it costs less than $90 at most labs. A biopsy is a serious step, as a small percent of men have infections and damage. You may have to have one, but you should have some more tests, including an MRI, before moving to a biopsy.

Posts.Title: worrisome results

Posts.Content: A lady with my travel group here in Bukhara, Uzbekistan fell while exiting her shower and broke her wrist. After the front desk was notified, a doctor and nurse promptly came to her room and evaluated her. They did some injections to the injury, and called for an ambulance. A few minutes later, she was at a hospital, had X-rays and saw a surgeon, who reset her bones. A plaster cast was made, and she was released at her insistence, to join todays tour. She was given pain medication. Total time was about 90 minutes from accident to release. Cost? There is no cost for medical care in Uzbekistan. Our group of Americans and Canadians were amazed. Free AND fast??? This is a third world Soviet-style nation, and there is much to criticize about the governments heavy control of everything. But, there are bright spots in every gray scene, and today, health care was Uzbekistans shining example.

Posts.Title: Around another corner

Posts.Content: IMHO, the problems with overtreatment, which did drive the 2012 USPSTF guidelines, was never with the diagnosis, but with the subsequent advice by urologists to have radical treatment in almost all cases. The USPSTF overreacted by discouraging the diagnostics, and some men have suffered due to lack of testing. That has changed now, with active surveillance being the primary recommended "treatment" in both very low risk and low risk classifications. There is more balanced counseling, and less cases of rushing into treatment. I have not heard anyone recently promoting that psa tests not be given, and think that there is now broad agreement that psa screening is desirable.

Posts.Title: Feeling confused

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Lumore51 I was confident enough that this therapy would rid me of the problem, and if it didn't there were still options for further radiation and/or hormone therapy (which is Plan B for the surgery guys anyway). Gio, I am glad to see that you mentioned that there are salvage options should primary radiation fail. There seems to be a widespread misconception that you are out of luck if radiation fails, while surgery will afford you a "second bite of the apple". These opinions do not admit the fact that there are several post-radiation salvage treatments that are available. Cryotherapy, HIFU, FLA, SBRT, and HDRBT all have proven success in dealing with follow-up treatment. More men pondering their options need to be aware of this. Thanks.

Posts.Title: Question for the members re: Repeat biopsy

Posts.Content: There has been a loosening of the requirements in my AS group at Johns Hopkins. When I joined the program, the protocol was to be a biopsy every year. Now, I have been told that it will be EITHER a biopsy OR an MRI every two years. Maybe the fact that I have been in the program for several years, and am over 70 has also changed my rules. The concern that I have with your stats is the low fpsa and the bilateral core involvement. Maybe having an mp-MRI and PHI or 4K test would be a good next move for you.

Posts.Title: SRT? Or No SRT. More Data From My Surgery 3 + years Ago

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lexpar As a recent member of the forum, I wonder how many of us are, or were, in the same boat as I am. I want to make it absolutely clear I am not looking to pace blame anywhere. I had been asking my family Dr for two years about doing a PSA. He told me that conventional thinking about PSA's had changed; that they raised so many "false positives" that the thinking was now to wait until there were symptoms. (This was confirmed by a family friend, a urological surgeon with 50 yrs experience.)He did do a DRE and said everything felt as it should. My first PSA was run completely by accident. When doing pre-op lab work for shoulder surgery the lab ran a PSA without being directed to. That came back elevated; a second PSA blood test was taken which also came back elevated which led to the biopsy and diagnosis. My point is that had I waited till I was symptomatic, it may well have been too late to hope for a positive outcome. Should the collective"we" be pressing for some sort of diagnostic test that is more dependable that the PSA or DRE? God Bless all of the other various cancer groups pushing for $$$$, but I have been astounded by many men I know have come forward to me saying they have gone through various forms of prostate cancer. Two men I know lost their battle with the disease. And that's just in our little town. This is certainly a common condition, and one which will kill if treatment is left too late. If a PSA is not considered reliable enough, why isn't an alternative test or screening procedure being developed? If one is, how can we support it? There has been a great deal of research over the past 15 years to find a better diagnostic tool than the PSA test. There is a huge financial incentive for biomedical research companies, both large and small, to patent "THE" successor test to PSA. There are many contenders, from imaging to biomarker assays. Blood, urine, and mouth swabs are part of the wide array of tests that have been proposed and examined. Some have good clinical results, but then, other studies are not so sure. Better tests than psa already exist, like PHI and 4K Score. But, they are derivatives of psa. Believe me, a small army of researchers are working on finding "the" test that has high accuracy. It's coming...sometime.

It is certainly possible that no cancer, or very minimal cancer, will be found, but it is best to get the biopsy done and better understand what your situation is. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Scared of Meeting da Vinci

Posts.Content: JLH, Chuck has given you the bottom line order of priorities. LIfe is always worth living, even with some disabilities. And, while I have read complaints from men who were unhappy with prostate cancer treatments, others attest that they have regained satisfactory sexual function, so the results are individual. Also, keep in mind that having a psa test and confirmatory biopsy that you have prostate cancer, does not necessarily mean that you need treatment. I have an apparently indolent case, and have been watching it for eight years, with no change in quality of life. Perhaps 50 percent of newly diagnosed men are in this category. Research is fine, but IMHO, you also need to find doctor(s) that you can trust and confide in. They may instantly see a unique set of characteristics about you that browsing the internet would not have deduced.

Posts.Title: Early Detection/Ben Stiller

Posts.Content: JulesM, Everything I've ever read about PCa matches what you have read, and what his doctor has told him. That is, that only advanced cases cause symptoms. Did you say that he was diagnosed last week, has surgery scheduled for October 23rd? Has he consulted with other specialists, or only this one? I'm mentioning this because the biggest controversy about prostate cancer treatment is the need to fully explore the various types of treatments, and have consultations with multiple surgeons and radiation oncologists. If you take the time to peruse the several discussion forums for prostate cancer, you will find many comments from men regretting that they rushed into a treatment plan without taking the time to research other types of treatment. PCa is a slow growing cancer, and there is always time to stop and think and be certain that you have chosen the best course. Good luck to you both.

What makes you a "favorable intermediate risk" is the Grade Group 2 - Gleason (3+4). That alone overrides your PSA, negative DRE, and unilateral positive biopsy. See Table 1 in this link: https://www.sciencedirect.com/scienc...22534717780032

Posts.Title: The more I research the more confused I am

Posts.Content: Welcome PaulG, although this is not a place anyone wants to be. Could you tell us more about the biopsy? What number of cores were positive? What percentage involved? Where all the involved cores on the same side or bilateral? I think that everyone's first reaction to a cancer diagnosis is "get it out!". But prostate cancer is very different. You have a full range of possibilities, from active surveillance to focal therapies, to types of radiation and surgery. Make sure that you are fully aware of the common side effects of surgery and radiation. Those side effects sometimes greatly impact one's quality of life, and may cause you to carefully re-think whether immediate treatment is the best course for you. There will be others along with great knowledge, experience, and opinions to share. Don't rush, or be rushed, into making a decision. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: What are the outcomes after treatment for BCR after primary RT?

Posts.Content: There has been a loosening of the requirements in my AS group at Johns Hopkins. When I joined the program, the protocol was to be a biopsy every year. Now, I have been told that it will be EITHER a biopsy OR an MRI every two years. Maybe the fact that I have been in the program for several years, and am over 70 has also changed my rules. The concern that I have with your stats is the low fpsa and the bilateral core involvement. Maybe having an mp-MRI and PHI or 4K test would be a good next move for you.

Posts.Title: Question for the members re: Repeat biopsy

Posts.Content: mitchden, Again, sorry to have you join us here. As the others have said, you have a minimal amount of less-risky cancer, so there is no rush to make any decision. My experience has been somewhat different, and I would offer a few additional suggestions for you. Genomics tests, like OncotyeDX and Prolaris, can assay specific genetic components from your biopsy slides, and calculate the probability of aggressive progression. You could consider active surveillance if those tests and confirming MRI studies support it. As to the psa rise, mine has doubled, and even tripled at times, and gone back to normal without any action on my part. It is certainly an area of concern, but psa is never determinate. With only only positive core, the focal therapies mentioned above, like HIFU, FLA, and cryotherapy, are worthwhile alternatives for you to research. Also, there are now clinical trials on vaccines, which are the holy grail of future PCa treatment. Check out what is available to you. The existing "gold standards" for PCa intervention are surgery and radiation, but they have side effects that impact men's quality of life in many instances. If they were perfect, there would not be all this intensive investment and research to replace them with less invasive protocols. Take your time, research, question, consult; you have to be your own advocate in getting all the correct data to make your decision for your path forward. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Kim, While the others have provided great advice, and the odds are he has prostate cancer, his psa is far from the highest I have read about from patients. PSA results of 3,000, 5,200, and even 7,200 have posted by people who were diagnosed years ago, and are still writing in to tell about their cases. So, while the necessary tests and consultations, and treatment decisions are in the near future, there is good reason to be hopeful that current and future intervention techniques will allow him to manage this disease. Good luck.

Posts.Title: In-Bore MRI Guided Prostate Biopsy

Posts.Content: Proton Beam treatment is increasing in use, with new centers being built, but it has not demonstrated superiority over photon treatments. Most posters here have done surgery. There are also sites where types of radiation are favored. A mix of opinions and experiences is always good. As mentioned above, the number one concern is to defeat the cancer, and both major forms of treatment have good success rates. Regarding radiation, I am providing a link to an NIH study showing the superiority of combining brachytherapy (seeds) with IMRT, versus IMRT alone. You will have many questions going forward, and I hope that we can be helpful to you. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24447404

Posts.Title: Pathology Report seems OK or maybe not so OK

Posts.Content: I had one for my first (of five) MRIs at Johns Hopkins. It was a 1.5 Tesla machine. I found it excrusiatingly painful. Since 2013, when they installed the 3T machines, they no longer use the ERC, but rather an apron coil. JH believes that is produces equal images without "patient discomfort". But, that is my experience. I replied to a man on another forum a few months ago about awful my pain had been. He then had an MRI with ERC and posted a thread attacking me for terrifying him unnecessarily. He said it was merely uncomfortable for him. So, every man's experience is different. But, nobody has EVER complained about the apron coil.

Posts.Title: Around another corner

Posts.Content: mitchden, The NCCN criteria for Active Surveillance states that Gleason 7 is acceptable if your life expectancy is less than ten years. But, I have known people to get into formal AS programs (even at Hopkins) with G7 and being much younger than you. The logic now seems to be that you will be so closely monitored, that your risk of mortality will not be increased, while you avoid the downsides of intervention as long as possible. Well, you have options, and you should take all the time that you feel necessary to be comfortable with your next steps. Please do not let one doctor try to pressure you into a decision before you are ready.

Posts.Title: Scared of Meeting da Vinci

Posts.Content: JLH, Chuck has given you the bottom line order of priorities. LIfe is always worth living, even with some disabilities. And, while I have read complaints from men who were unhappy with prostate cancer treatments, others attest that they have regained satisfactory sexual function, so the results are individual. Also, keep in mind that having a psa test and confirmatory biopsy that you have prostate cancer, does not necessarily mean that you need treatment. I have an apparently indolent case, and have been watching it for eight years, with no change in quality of life. Perhaps 50 percent of newly diagnosed men are in this category. Research is fine, but IMHO, you also need to find doctor(s) that you can trust and confide in. They may instantly see a unique set of characteristics about you that browsing the internet would not have deduced.

Posts.Title: Early Detection/Ben Stiller

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Lumore51 I was confident enough that this therapy would rid me of the problem, and if it didn't there were still options for further radiation and/or hormone therapy (which is Plan B for the surgery guys anyway). Gio, I am glad to see that you mentioned that there are salvage options should primary radiation fail. There seems to be a widespread misconception that you are out of luck if radiation fails, while surgery will afford you a "second bite of the apple". These opinions do not admit the fact that there are several post-radiation salvage treatments that are available. Cryotherapy, HIFU, FLA, SBRT, and HDRBT all have proven success in dealing with follow-up treatment. More men pondering their options need to be aware of this. Thanks.

Posts.Title: Which and why you selected your PC tx

Posts.Content: The purpose of post-biopsy assays like Prolaris, OncotypeDX, and ConfirmMDX is to help men with low and low-intermediate grade prostate cancer decide if they are proper candidates for active surveillance. In my case, OncotypeDX was THE determining factor that I stay on AS, instead of undergoing surgery or some other treatment. I am stunned that you had a low probability of aggressive PCa, and that your doctor did not inform you, and proceeded with the surgery. IF, however, your mind was absolutely set on having surgery regardless of the low risk, (and that is your choice), then there was no purpose or value in having the assay done.

Posts.Title: SRT? Or No SRT. More Data From My Surgery 3 + years Ago

Posts.Content: mitchden, Again, sorry to have you join us here. As the others have said, you have a minimal amount of less-risky cancer, so there is no rush to make any decision. My experience has been somewhat different, and I would offer a few additional suggestions for you. Genomics tests, like OncotyeDX and Prolaris, can assay specific genetic components from your biopsy slides, and calculate the probability of aggressive progression. You could consider active surveillance if those tests and confirming MRI studies support it. As to the psa rise, mine has doubled, and even tripled at times, and gone back to normal without any action on my part. It is certainly an area of concern, but psa is never determinate. With only only positive core, the focal therapies mentioned above, like HIFU, FLA, and cryotherapy, are worthwhile alternatives for you to research. Also, there are now clinical trials on vaccines, which are the holy grail of future PCa treatment. Check out what is available to you. The existing "gold standards" for PCa intervention are surgery and radiation, but they have side effects that impact men's quality of life in many instances. If they were perfect, there would not be all this intensive investment and research to replace them with less invasive protocols. Take your time, research, question, consult; you have to be your own advocate in getting all the correct data to make your decision for your path forward. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Pathology report is in

Posts.Content: Welcome PaulG, although this is not a place anyone wants to be. Could you tell us more about the biopsy? What number of cores were positive? What percentage involved? Where all the involved cores on the same side or bilateral? I think that everyone's first reaction to a cancer diagnosis is "get it out!". But prostate cancer is very different. You have a full range of possibilities, from active surveillance to focal therapies, to types of radiation and surgery. Make sure that you are fully aware of the common side effects of surgery and radiation. Those side effects sometimes greatly impact one's quality of life, and may cause you to carefully re-think whether immediate treatment is the best course for you. There will be others along with great knowledge, experience, and opinions to share. Don't rush, or be rushed, into making a decision. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: Three consecutive 0.0 PSA's ... No More Lupron, WooHoo!

Posts.Content: mjpina, Welcome to the forum. Hopefully, your situation will prove non-cancerous, and your stay here will be short. I can follow all your reasoning, and I am no fan of biopsies. BUT, a positive DRE flips the switch on the debate. A positive DRE ups the potential risk, and demands further investigation. Unfortunately, only a biopsy can make a diagnosis of prostate cancer. Also, I am not sure if the negative biopsy rate is so low when a positive DRE is involved. One thing you could request is a 3T mpMRI to map any suspicious areas in the prostate. If none are found, that could possibly justify skipping the biopsy. If areas are found, the biopsy could use that mapping as a template to target the needles. And, if the biopsy is negative, you will gain peace of mind. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Hello everyone, Dad was diagnosed with PC.

Posts.Content: I am an American, but my girlfriend livse in Toronto, so I go up there a lot. What I do is have my American doctor write a prescription for Viagra. Then in Canada, I go into any storefront clinic and ask the doctor there to give me the same rx. They do, and charge me about $38. Then, I go to the nearest Costco, and get the generic Viagra for 1/3 of the cost in the US, saving me about $400. Easy. The generic viagra is made by a very large Israeli company, and there is no quality compromise. The FDA has extended Pfizers' Viagra patent until 2020, so the Canadian route is the sensible way to go. Pfizer lied on their Canadian patent application, and their Supreme Court unanimously voided their patent.

Posts.Title: In-Bore MRI Guided Prostate Biopsy

Posts.Content: Welcome PaulG, although this is not a place anyone wants to be. Could you tell us more about the biopsy? What number of cores were positive? What percentage involved? Where all the involved cores on the same side or bilateral? I think that everyone's first reaction to a cancer diagnosis is "get it out!". But prostate cancer is very different. You have a full range of possibilities, from active surveillance to focal therapies, to types of radiation and surgery. Make sure that you are fully aware of the common side effects of surgery and radiation. Those side effects sometimes greatly impact one's quality of life, and may cause you to carefully re-think whether immediate treatment is the best course for you. There will be others along with great knowledge, experience, and opinions to share. Don't rush, or be rushed, into making a decision. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: New guy

Posts.Content: mitchden, The NCCN criteria for Active Surveillance states that Gleason 7 is acceptable if your life expectancy is less than ten years. But, I have known people to get into formal AS programs (even at Hopkins) with G7 and being much younger than you. The logic now seems to be that you will be so closely monitored, that your risk of mortality will not be increased, while you avoid the downsides of intervention as long as possible. Well, you have options, and you should take all the time that you feel necessary to be comfortable with your next steps. Please do not let one doctor try to pressure you into a decision before you are ready.

Posts.Title: Hello everyone, Dad was diagnosed with PC.

Posts.Content: mitchden, Again, sorry to have you join us here. As the others have said, you have a minimal amount of less-risky cancer, so there is no rush to make any decision. My experience has been somewhat different, and I would offer a few additional suggestions for you. Genomics tests, like OncotyeDX and Prolaris, can assay specific genetic components from your biopsy slides, and calculate the probability of aggressive progression. You could consider active surveillance if those tests and confirming MRI studies support it. As to the psa rise, mine has doubled, and even tripled at times, and gone back to normal without any action on my part. It is certainly an area of concern, but psa is never determinate. With only only positive core, the focal therapies mentioned above, like HIFU, FLA, and cryotherapy, are worthwhile alternatives for you to research. Also, there are now clinical trials on vaccines, which are the holy grail of future PCa treatment. Check out what is available to you. The existing "gold standards" for PCa intervention are surgery and radiation, but they have side effects that impact men's quality of life in many instances. If they were perfect, there would not be all this intensive investment and research to replace them with less invasive protocols. Take your time, research, question, consult; you have to be your own advocate in getting all the correct data to make your decision for your path forward. Good luck.
